narrative:
On 05/20/2022 at 8:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced Annual Licensing Inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator, Shakisha Howard. The facility currently has a Group Home (GH) license. The facility is licensed to serve four (4) regional center clients with mild to severe developmental disabilities ages 7-17 years old. There are currently four (4) clients in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. The facility is a single-story home with four (4) bedrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, backyard and three (3) restrooms. There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. There are no bodies of water in the facility premises. At 8:50 AM, LPA conducted a walkthrough of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept inaccessible and locked in a cabinet located in the garage. Sharps/knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the hallway. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguisher was fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 110 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets are in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens were observed. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean,

safe, sanitary and in good repair. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conduct meetings to review and discuss the facility's operation. The facility administrator is the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least monthly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan LPA reviewed the facility's emergency intervention plan. Facility does not use manual restraints. Facility has an emergency intervention training curriculum. All staff members are trained on the facility's emergency intervention procedures. Client Records LPA reviewed four (4) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. During records review, LPA observed that all four (4) clients' account of personal property/valuable were missing and/or not updated. It was also observed that psychotropic medications are not logged separately for each psychotropic medication.

One (1) Type B deficiency citation and one (1) Advisory Note Technical Violation were issued during today's inspection, see LIC809D and LIC9102TV. An Annual Continuation is required at a different time. The administrator was provided information on where to locate the Provider Information Notices (PINs), guidance to the new CARE Tools inspection process and Guardian. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC9102TV, LIC811 and appeal rights were provided to the facility administrator.

On 05/24/2022 at 8:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced Annual Continuation inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator, Shakisha Howard. This inspection is a continuation of the annual inspection conducted on 05/20/2022. At 9:00 AM, LPA Silva reviewed two (2) staff records. Staff Records All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. LPA verified 20 hours of annual training for direct care staff. Clients with Special Health Care Needs There are currently no clients in care with special health care needs. LPA interviewed two (2) staff members. There are no citations assessed during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to the facility administrator.

Continue from page 1 . . . . The facility (GH) staff stated that a staff was present with C1 when he ran from the GH and went after him but sight was lost. The GH staff indicated that the child asked the staff to fix his electronic and then took off running. The GH staff stated that the client's Regional Center Worker, County Social Worker were notified and law enforcement was called to start a missing person's report. The GH staff stated that attempts were made to get in contact with the client's first family member but were not able to get a respond by phone but the GH was able to get in contact with the client's second family member to report the incident. The GH staff stated that the clients are given three meals and snacks when in the GH and are able to get seconds if the clients want to. Staff stated that the client has not been denied or deprived of food and is given snacks and fruits through the day. The confidential interviews conducted did not collaborate the allegations. The clients interviewed are non-verbal and were not able to give a statements. The Regional Center Social Worker and County Social Worker indicated the facility has reported when the client has AWOL. The Social Workers indicated having no concerns with the food in the GH or the care and supervision in the GH. Other statements revealed inconsistent information, there was information indicating that the GH never contacted the first family member and was not sure if the GH did but the second family contact indicated that the GH contacted her when the client left the GH. Information indicated that the client asks for food during family visit and the family takes food to the client but were not sure if the GH is feeding the client properly. Based on the interview and records reviewed the allegations are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On July 26, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Shakisha Henry, Administrator. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA interviewed one client and one staff on March 11, 2022, LPA interviewed one staff and Regional Center case worker via telephone on June 20, 2022, LPA interviewed one staff, County Social Worker and two others via telephone on July 21, 2022, and LPA interviewed one client on July 22, 2022 (see Confidential Names LIC 811 dated July 26, 2022). LPA analyzed pertinent documents such as Special Incidents Reports, Behavior Event Reports and others. It was alleged Resident eloped from facility and Facility does not meet resident's nutritional needs. It was also alleged Licensee did not notify responsible party of incident.

narrative: The facility staff indicated client sustained the injuries while be transported to school on the school bus. The facility staff stated the school did not inform the facility about the incident until 2/22/22 due to the transportation staff not informing the school that the incident happened on 2/18/22. The facility staff reported the incident as soon as the facility was made aware of the incident. The facility staff stated a bong was found in the back yard and it did not belong to any of the staff. Staff filed a police report and threw away the bong. Staff stated clients are offered daily activities that clients can participate in. The confidential interviews conducted did not collaborate the allegations. Two client’s interview could not answer any questions when LPA interviewed clients. Both clients are non-verbal. The RC indicated the facility did report the incident after the facility was informed about what happened. The RC stated the school did not report the incident until 2/22/22 to the facility. The RC stated all of the facility staff denied owning the bong that was found. There was no corroborating information obtained through interviews nor review of records to confirm the allegations. Based on the interview and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On July 21, 2022 at 11:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Cabral met with the Facility Administrator Shakisha Howard. During the course of the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed two facility staff on 3/4/22 and three facility staff on 7/14/22. LPA interviewed two clients and attempted to interview two clients on 7/14/22 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated July 21, 2022). LPA Cabral interviewed one regional center coordinator (RC) on 3/8/22 and attempted to interview another regional center coordinator on 3/4/22. LPA reviewed incident reports, police report and emails. On 2/28/22 the department received a complaint alleging client sustained injuries while in care, facility staff did not write up an incident report for client’s injuries and clients had access to hazardous objects.

narrative: The Department received a complaint regarding an alleged physical abuse violation on C1. The complaint stated bruises were observed on the left side of C1’s forehead near his eyebrow which were sustained, allegedly, due to being hit by S1. LPA Larios obtained records from the placing agency pertaining to the date the injury was first observed, 03/09/22. The records revealed a placing agency staff observed superficial scratches on C1’s forehead, not bruising as reported to the Department. On 03/11/22, C1 was taken for medical evaluation. The physician observed cystic acne on C1’s forehead, no bruising was documented. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with the RSC, CSW and Therapist revealed C1 had frequent contact with mandated reporters during the time of the alleged incident. None of these individuals observed injuries to C1’s forehead indicating physical abuse occurred. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with facility staff and school personnel revealed C1 is prone to self-injure. While it was consistently reported C1 has a tendency to bite his hand, information obtained by LPA Larios indicated C1 was observed hitting his head against, and with objects. There were no identified witnesses to the alleged incident. Based on information gathered through interviews conducted and record review, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 09/23/22 were given to the above-mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited.
investigation_findings: 13An unannounced follow up inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 09/23/22 at 12:00 PM. During the course of the investigation LPA Larios conducted interviews with one Residential Service Coordinator (RSC) and Staff #2 (S2) on 09/19/22, Staff #3 (S3) on 09/20/22, Staff #4 and #5 (S4, S5) on 09/21/22, one Therapist and one County Social Worker (CSW) on 09/22/22. LPA Larios attempted to interview Staff #1 (S1), however, S1 did not respond to contacts attempts. LPA Larios attempted to interview Client #1 and #3 (C1, C3) on 09/20/22 and Client #2 (C2) on 09/21/22, however, LPA Larios was unable to obtain a meaningful statement regarding the allegations. A record review was conducted on 04/07/22. LPA Larios obtained copies of staff and client rosters, C1 Individual Program Plan, medical records, body check forms, client notes, Needs and Services Plan and Child Family Team Meeting notes. (Continued)

narrative:
The investigation revealed that the facility client went to school with multiple injuries as observed by school personnel. The facility administrator stated that the staff who supervised the client prior to the school observing the client’s injuries did not document any injuries in the body check form which led to the staff’s termination. In addition, the facility client’s mother stated that she was notified by the former staff member of her son’s behavior, but the former staff did not inform her of the injuries that was observed by the school. Other facility staff interviewed indicated that they were unaware as to how the client sustained the injuries. The facility client was non-verbal and had a history of exhibiting self-injurious behaviors. Based on the information gathered, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was met, therefore the allegation is substantiated per California Code of Regulations Title 22 – refer to LIC9099-D for deficiencies. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, LIC 9099-D for deficiency and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

The investigation revealed that the facility client went to school with multiple injuries as observed by school personnel. Multiple facility staff interviewed denied witnessing or subjecting clients to physical abuse. Investigator Douglas was unable to make contact with a former facility staff after multiple attempts. The facility client was non-verbal and had a history of exhibiting self-injurious behaviors. Based on the information gathered, the allegation is unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met although the allegation may have happened or is valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for providing care and supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on the information obtained, it was determined that a facility client sustained multiple injuries due to neglect and lack of supervision by staff, and staff failed to notify the client's responsible party, a finding which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: On 02/10/2022, the Department received a complaint alleging allegations of lack of supervision and personal rights toward one client. It was alleged that client 1 has unexplained bruises, including that his cellular phone was taken away from him while speaking to a family member. The Facility Administrator (FA) including facility staff workers that provided a statement provided consistent statements and denied the allegations. FA reported that clients are not allowed to bring electronics to the table to avoid being distracted when eating. The FA and statements by facility staff stated that they would never take away a phone from a client while having or listening to a person on the phone. In confidential interviews, three clients were unable to provide clear and understandable verbal statements, and therefore no information was brought forth with respect to the allegations reported. The individual identified as other who disclosed some concerns for the focused client could not be contacted, therefore no statement was obtained. However, LA Co. Emergency Response Worker was able to obtain a statement and other corroborated the allegations reported. All professional collateral contacts, such as the county social worker (CSW), Regional Center Services Representative, including representatives from the client's school who are mandated reporters denied any concerns with the care and supervision by the facility staff workers. The school provided reports about the bruising, and it was not caused at the facility. Information obtained in the county reports reads that the City of Montebello Police responded to the facility and denied observing any abuse towards the clients and left the facility without further incident. The interviews obtained in the explanations about the lack of supervision and personal rights violations could not be corroborated. Therefore, the above allegations are determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the above aforementioned for review and signature. No deficiencies were cited at this time.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carrie Palmer conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility on 5/15/2023 at 9:00 AM for the purpose of conducting a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Shakesha Howard (Henry). LPA reviewed a copy of an updated Personnel Report (LIC 500), The Register of Facility Clients/Residents listing 1 child and the Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities. LPA along with the facility staff conducted a tour of the facility inside and outside of the home. There is 1 client currently residing in the home with special needs. The following was observed during the inspection: Physical Plant/Personal Accommodations (Buildings and Grounds) - The facility is a one story home. LPA observed the following on the first floor: Four (4) bedrooms, 1 kitchen which includes an area with a table, 1 office, 1 storage area for medications, 3 bathrooms, 1 living room the backyard, and a garage. The Facility License is posted in plain view in the living room. LPA reviewed the Emergency Disaster Plan, Client Grievance Procedures and Rights of Individuals with Developmental Disabilities, which was posted in plain view. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom # 1 sleeps 1 client and has 1 beds, 1 dresser and closet Bedroom # 2 sleeps 1 client and has 1bed, 1 dresser and closet Bedroom # 3 sleeps 1 client and has1 bed, 1 dresser and closet. Bedroom # 4 sleeps 1 client and has 1 bed, 1 dresser and a closet. The room has its own bathroom (Master) . All beds are clean. Three of the four beds are in good repair.

Food Service - The facility maintains adequate perishable and non-perishable food supplies; the menu plans for the week and weekly program schedule of activities are posted. The kitchen utensils, glasses and dishes were found to be in good condition. There is a back up refrigerator in the garage used for overflow of food items. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be in the mandated range. All exits were free of hazards and all doors opened freely. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activity. Exit signs were posted throughout the facility. Sharp knives, medications, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. Interviews (Staff): LPA interviewed 2 staff (Administrator), and 1 Direct Care Staff (DCS) Interviews (Clients): LPA didn't interview clients as the client is non-verbal. File Review: No file reviews were conducted during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the LIC 809, 809C, 809Ds, Appeals Rights, 9102, and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative. At the time of this inspection there is 1 Type A, 2 Type B, and 1 Technical Assistance.

The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom # 1 sleeps 1 client and has 1 beds, 1 dresser and closet Bedroom # 2 sleeps 1 client and has 1bed, 1 dresser and closet Bedroom # 3 sleeps 1 client and has1 bed, 1 dresser and closet. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carrie Palmer conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility on 05/21/2024 at 11:30 AM for the purpose of conducting a Required Annual Inspection Continuation. LPA met with the Administrator and discussed the purpose of the visit. During the inspection, LPA Palmer completed the following domains: Operational Requirements, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staffing, Staff Records, and Client Records and interviews with staff and clients. The Special Needs Domain was also completed. LPA Palmer conducted 1 of 1 client file review and 3 of 8 staff file reviews. There is 1 client in care at this time. LPA Palmer requested to see the following: staffing schedule, administrator's resume, administrator certificate, current physicians’ orders, staff job descriptions, training certificates, staff applications for employment, proof of staff training, cash resources and medication. Operations: The facility has an indoor and outdoor activity plan, which is hung in the dinning area in plain view. LPA Palmer was able to see board meeting minutes, written compliant procedures posted to include a drop box for staff and clients to communicate their concerns. LPA Palmer also discussed the importance of the awareness of the Child Abuse Hotline. Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Intervention: The facility was able to provide their emergency drill binder to include drills for fire, earthquake, violent and threatening situations, utility failure and bomb threat. The staff training binder was also provided to LPA Palmer which includes: SIRs and Abuse, Oral Hygiene, Medication Training, Data HCBS New Rule and Body Checks. During an interview with staff it was determined that staff needs more training on the understanding of the needs and services plan as well as the emergencies intervention plan.

Client Records: The facility was able to present the P and I Binder (Personal and Incidentals), which includes the cash resources form (LIC 405), cash and receipts – all in good standing. LPA Palmer was also able to review the MAR (Medication Administration Record), which includes: the name of the medications, the side effects, the initials for staff after , the dosage, birthdate and area for allergies to be listed. The staff was able to provide medical/dental exams and immunizations. Psychotropic medications are supported by consent forms. Staff Records: During the review of 3 staff records, it was determined that staff received background checks prior to working at the facility. It was also observed that staff receives ongoing training that consists of, but not limited to the following: CPI Training, Title 22, Management and Aggression, Non Punishment Procedures, Replacement Behaviors, Communication, Chocking, Break Schedules. Certificates of completion were provided for the following: Nutrition for Healthy Living, Emergency Disaster Preparedness, and Regional Center Training. Job Descriptions were also observed within the staffs files and the administrators certificate is not up to date, but the administrator was able to show that she is on the ACS list for her certificate to be issued. One of the three staff files did not include the staffs job description. The facility corrected the non compliance during the visit. Clients with Special Health Care Needs: During observation and interview, it was determined that the special needs individualized health care plan/needs and services plan was not being updated every 6 months, but was being updated annually. Clients have assessment plans and placement document from DFCS; as the documentation shows custody and disability info. Clients have assessment plans and placement document from DFCS; as the documentation shows custody and disability info. The following will be issued during todays visit: 1 TV and 1 Citation. And exit interview was conducted and an 809, 811, 1 TV, 1 Type B, and Appeals Rights has been provided to the facility representative. D

narrative: Client was able to participate in a community walk the evening after the incident. Due to this, staff did not inform the Administrator of the incident but noted what occurred on the daily log. The Administrator provided a refresher training on incident reporting requirements to facility staff on 4/17/24. Client was unable to explain how the bruises were sustained when interviewed by the LPA. Records show that client was not cooperative during an interview by another investigating agency but appeared happy and comfortable at placement. Although there were faint bruises observed, client did not appear to be in pain. There were no witnesses and no records found to corroborate the allegation. Based on information obtained, the allegation is closed as unsubstantiated because the preponderance of standard of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and the Confidential Names Form dated 6/18/24 were provided to the facility representative. Appeal rights forms were also provided and explained.
investigation_findings: 13On June 18, 2024 at 11:50am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at the facility to deliver the finding of the allegation. LPA met with the facility representative named above. The allegation was investigated by the LPA. Interviews were conducted with the client on 4/12/24, facility staff on 4/17/24 and 5/1/24 and other related parties between 4/12/24 and 5/1/24. Client records and other complaint-related documents were reviewed on 4/12/24 and 5/24/24. During the course of the investigation, it was discovered that client was observed with what appeared to be discolored bruises on the buttocks, but client was unable to explain how the bruises were sustained. Interviews revealed that the client stumbled and fell, hitting the steps of a slide, during an outing at a local playground. Client did not complain of any pain or discomfort and there were no injuries observed on the client by staff when the incident occurred.

narrative: On 03/12/2025 at 10:00 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico arrived at the facility for the case management to review the staffing requirement to meet Title 22 . LPA met with Shakisha Henry, Administrator. LPA presented the Administrator with the Program Statement Regional Office has on file and the Administrator presented the Program Statement for the facility that differs from the one Regional Office has on file. LPA inquired when the Program Statement has been updated and if it was sent to Regional Office for review. Administrator was not aware when exactly the change occurred and if the Program Statement has been approved. LPA requested that the Administrator and the Licensee send the new Program Statement for the approval to the Regional Office, since the Group Home cannot operate with the Program Statement that has not been approved by the Regional Office. LPA also noted that if the Licensee did send the statement for approval, LPA would need the letter of approva sent to the licensee by the Regional Office. Administrator stated she will meet with the licensee to discuss the issue and they will send the amended Program Statement for approval. During the brief review, LPA noticed the new Program Statement was missing Facility Manager and Psychiatric Technician Jobs descriptions. LPA noted those have to be added to the Program Statement. Administrator also will send the new LIC 500 with the Facility Manager schedules to comply with Title 22. LPA is requesting the amended Program statement and LIC 500 to be sent by March 26,2025. LPA also advised the Administrator to ensure the personnel requirements are met for the staff for the facility manager. LPA notified the Administrator LPA will be back with another case management to review the LIC 500 and staff qualifications once the Program Statement is reviewed and approved or will reach out if any changes are needed. LPA also advised that the in office meeting might be scheduled to review the Program Statement or if any further assistance is needed and Administrator and Licensee have any questions. No deficiencies cited at this time. The copy of this report was e-mailed and explained to the Administrator.

On 12/09/2024, the Department received a complaint alleging that Staff spoke inappropriately to youth. The focused staff (S1), who was identified in the report, denied the allegation, and stated that the youth was not called an inappropriate name and there was not an inappropriate comment made to the youth. S1 stated that the youth had a behavior episode when the youth was told he has passed the number of calls that the youth was allowed to make. The youth began arguing with S1 and S1 stated that during the argument the youth called another youth in the home a retard. S1 explained to the youth that this word is not to be used and he should use the term intellectual challenged. S1 stated that the youth was told that all the youth in the facility are all the same and fall within the same spectrum and that the youth was diagnosed as a retard. Other staff in the facility stated that they never heard S1 call the youth a retard and S1 only redirects the youth. The focus youth (C1) stated that S1 called him a retard on several occasions and that nobody was around. C1 stated that S1 calls him names to get back at him and S1 called him a retard when he called the other youth in the facility a retard. C1 stated that he did not know if S1 was explaining to him not to call the other youth a retard or if S1 was calling him a retard to bother him. Based on the information from staff, youth, collateral contacts and documents reviewed the allegation is found to be substantiated. A substantiated finding means that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation is found to be true. Exit interview completed. The following deficiencies cited and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with facility representative mention above.
investigation_findings: 13On March 11, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Heriberto Perez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the above facility and met with Shakisha Henry, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the revised finding for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one staff and one youth in person in the facility and conducted telephone interview with County Social Worker (CSW2) on 12/12/24, LPA conducted telephone interivew with County Social Worker (CSW) on 12/19/24, LPA conducted telephone interviews with three staff and interviewed one minor in person on 02/25/25 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated March 11, 2025). LPA also reviewed documents including but not limited to Client's Need and Service Plans, Special Incident Reports (SIR), client's notes, law enforcement report and other documents. It was alleged Staff spoke inappropriately to youth.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (c) (16) PERSONAL RIGHTS: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature......... This requirement has not been met by evidence of: Based on the information obtained, staff called a youth a retard, this violation poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.

narrative:
On 06/06/2025 at 9 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Shakisha Henry. LPA requested via e-mail prior to the inspection and reviewed a copy of an updated Personnel Report (LIC 500), The Register of Facility Clients LIC 9020, LIC 308, LIC 309, LIC 610C. During the visit LPA requested and reviewed Board Meeting Minutes, Emergency Disaster Drill log, restraint log. LPA along with the facility staff conducted a tour of the facility. There is 1 client with special needs currently residing in the home. The following was observed during the inspection: Physical Plant The facility is a one story home. LPA observed the following on the first floor: Four (4) bedrooms, kitchen which includes an area with a table and 3 chairs, 1 office, 1 storage area for medications, 3 bathrooms, 1 living room with the TV and couch for clients to use, the backyard with tables and chairs, and a garage. The Facility License is posted in plain view in the living room. The kitchen has counter with four stools, working fridge, stove, microwave, sink. LPA observed plenty of fruits on the counter as well as the shelves with the various activities for the clients (games, play-doh, sensory activities games etc). LPA observed CARF certification, Emergency Disaster Plan, Persons with Disabilities Rights poster, weekly and daily activities list posted in the kitchen. Temperature inside the facility was at 72 degrees F. LPA observed plenty of perishable and non-perishable foods. LPA also observed the menu posted on the wall in the kitchen.

The following bedroom arrangements were noted: all bedroom have one full bed, storage dresser, closet and plenty of room for the clients to use. LPA observed 3 bathrooms at the facility with the working sink, shower and toilet. The facility is clean and sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed screens in good condition on all the windows. LPA observed trash cans without lids in the bathrooms and issued technical violation to the facility. Administrator will get the trash cans with lids for each bathroom. Kitchen trash can had cover on it. Operations The facility has an indoor and outdoor activity plan, which is hung in the dinning area in plain view. LPA Maico was able to review board meeting minutes, grievance procedures. Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Intervention The facility has the Emergency Disaster Plan posted at the facility with the phone numbers and e-mails. The facility was able to provide their emergency drill binder to include drills for fire, earthquake, violent and threatening situations, utility failure and bomb threat. LPA reviewed manual restraints log and the EIP certificates for the staff. Clients files LPA reviewed one (1) client file. LPA observed admission agreement, information for the medical and dental providers, medical and dental records, medication administration logs, copies of the IPPs, vaccination and TB test records. Staff files LPA reviewed 5 (five) staff files. LPA reviewed the criminal record clearances, training for the staff, child abuse reporting, emergency intervention training. Training includes but not limited to child abuse reporting, cultural competency, autism spectrum disorder, Personal Rights, Health and Safety Practices. LPA attempted to interview one client and LPA interviewed one staff. LPA issued one Technical Assistance and two Technical Violations to the facility. No deficiencies issued at the time of inspection. The copy of this report and LIC 811 was given to the facility Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Maria Luna at Bella Vista Maple because no one was available at the Evergreen location. The purpose was to finalize this complaint investigation. LPA arrived at the Maple St. location at 12:30 PM after having been to the Evergreen location at 12:00 PM. On July 19, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward received an emailed copy of a clearance letter from a company named Mold Inspection & Testing. The letter indicated that professional mold remediation was not required. LPA Jones-Steward contacted the technician who issued the letter for clarification. The technician informed LPA Jones-Steward that mold was found at the home. However the level of mold was not enough to presentt an immediate health hazard. The technician stated that he had verbally advised the administrator to enlist a prfessional HVAC cleaner to remove the mold that did exist. Based on consultation with the technician who inspected the home, the allegation that mold was found in the home was substantiated. A finding that the complaint is substantiated means that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Buildings and Grounds The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. The licensee failed to meet this standard because there was mold found in the home.

narrative: On February 15, 2022 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Olivia Rosas arrived at the above facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. This is a facility located in a residential area and equipped with four (4) bedrooms, one (1) staff office, two (2) bathrooms, living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry room, and medication room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Common areas area clean and in good repair. Rooms are fully furnished with one bed, and closet space. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward interviewed the above allegations. 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA found that there was only one staff person on duty during the time of the AWOL. Her AWOL frequency and violent behavior were indicative of a need for increased supervision. Based on the available information, the above allegations are resolved as substantiated.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with administrator Shakisha Henry to resolve the allegations, The allegations were previously discuseed with former administrator Teandra Pitts. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA reviewed client records and interviewed staff, behavioral consultants, regional center coordinators and parents, LPA also made personal observations of the suprvision being provided to clients on two separate visits. narrative:
On May 30, 2025 at 9:30 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Justine Armstrong made an unannounced visit to the Facility Bella Vista Wyoming House for the purpose of conducting a Annual/Required visit. LPA J. Armstrong met with Direct Service Provider, James Buckley who granted access into the facility and a tour of the facility was conducted. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to three (3), developmentally disabled children, ages 6-17 years old, ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. On this day the census is two (2) children. This is a one-story home equipped with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, kitchen/laundry area, dining area and outdoor space. There is a detached garage that is split in half by a wall one side is used for storage and the other side is used as the staff office. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1, Bedroom #2 , Bedroom #3: The rooms is equipped with one full size bed. There is adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. (See Continued on 809C

Bathrooms: There is a total of two bathrooms in the facility. All bathrooms were checked and were in clean operating conditions. Kitchen: There is a stove with five (5) burners, a microwave, air fryer, dishwasher and refrigerator/freezer all working in good condition. The home has plenty of perishable/nonperishable food. The cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the clients and stored/ locked under the kitchen sink. Next to the kitchen there is also a washer and dryer that stores extra laundry detergent and cleaning solutions that are locked up. There is also a locked medication cabinet in this area with a fire extinguisher. All trash cans have tight lids on. Dining Area: There is a table with two (2) chairs. There are posting of Facility License, facility map, Personal Rights and emergency disatser plan. Living Room: There are two chairs no sofas and a mounted TV. Back Space Area: This area is used as a staff break area with a desk, chair, and fire extinguisher. Garage: The garage space is used for the Facility vehicle and on the other side of the wall is the staff office which has its own door to enter into the office space. LPA Armstrong viewed the vehicle registration which was current. The vehicle is a white clean and safe for transporting clients. Outdoors: The outdoor area is clean there was a bbq grill a trampoline, basketball court, chairs. Overall, the home appears to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. The home has a first aid kit stored inside one of the locked cabinets where the medication is stored. All knives and sharp objects are kept locked in a box and stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. The hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. The yard is free of debris and hazardous material. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at the time of the visit and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility
During the investigation of complaint 34-CR-20210607151029, LPA Jones-Steward uncovered some record keeping issues that were addressed with Ms. Oliver.

Information obtained during the investigation including confidential interviews of C1, staff members and assigned investigators from outside agencies did not provide enough evidence to support the reported allegation. Interviews revealed no witnesses to the alleged incident and during the time of the alleged incident, Staff member #2 (S2) also present with S1 corroborates C1’s bedroom door was open while S1 was present inside C1’s room. S2 reported no issues or concerns observed. The allegation was also investigated by South Central Los Angeles Regional Center. The case was closed with a finding of 'not supported' as C1 recanted the allegations. The Department of Children and Family Services reported a history of unsupported allegations and determined the allegation to be inconclusive. Records reviewed revealed no past reprimands or incidents of sexual misconduct for S1. Due to a lack of evidence, it has been determined that the allegation is Unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred. Exit Interview conducted with Facility Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights are emailed to Administrator and also mailed to Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On July 16, 2021 at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a subsequent complaint inspection at Bella Vista Zook House for the purpose of concluding and delivering investigation findings on the above allegation. LPA with Facility Administrator, Lavatha Oliver and together discussed the investigation details. The allegation was investigated by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Bureau, Investigator Peter Zertuche. On April 6, 2021, CCLD received a complaint alleging sexual abuse by Staff member #1 (S1) on minor Client #1 (C1) (see LIC811, dated 7/16/2021). It was reported in part that C1 told a staff member that on either 4/2/21 or 4/3/21, S1 walked into C1’s room and touched a bracelet on C1’s arm. S1 then allegedly touched C1 (specifics unknown), exposed self to C1, and then raped C1. Upon C1’s disclosure, S1 was placed on administrative leave. C1 was immediately taken to the hospital and law enforcement was notified. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA spoke with Client #1 and staff. Client #1 was inconsistent in her details about whether or not staff is abusive towards her or if her personal rights are being violated. Based on the inability to obtain supporting evidence, these allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Facility Manager Doreece Claxton to resolve the above allegations. LPA asked for a copy of the client intake for C1 and was informed that no intake was done. That situation will be discussed with the supervising administrator Kim Commadore who is currently out of town. Based on the above investigation and lack of documentary information, the above allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated. If reasonable people would disagree as to whether the allegation happened, or if the LPA thinks it happened but sufficient evidence cannot be obtained, then the complaint is unsubstantiated, not unfounded.

Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection August 10, 2023, at 10:54 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 6 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 10, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Lavatha Oliver.

The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1, Bedroom #2 , Bedroom #3: all are equipped with one full size bed, adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in the room. (F). Living Room: There is a table, with two sofa chairs, and a TV mounted on the wall. Furniture seems to be in good conditions. The following was discussed with the facility Administrator: Based on LPA interviews and record reviews and evidence obtained, the Facility is issued a citation in accordance with the Group Home Licensing Standards, Chapter 5 Division 6 the Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, as stated in Title 22 ILS 84065 (d) Personnel Requirements: The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present… this poses an potential health, health and safety, or personal rights. At approximately 12:20 PM, LPA Medina and LPM Segura conducted a walk-through of the facility, including both the interior and exterior areas. The facility has added an Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU) in the backyard. The facility and grounds were observed to be clean, tidy, and free of obstructions. There are two client bedrooms and two staff bedrooms. All bedrooms are single occupancy, and beds were equipped with clean linens and mattress pads. Centrally stored medications were observed in a locked cabinet located in the kitchen. Toxic chemicals were secured in a locked cabinet in the garage. Sharps were located in ADU. The facility maintains at least a one-week supply of nonperishable food and a two-day supply of perishable food. The indoor temperature was maintained at 70 degrees Fahrenheit, and the hot water temperature measured 112 degrees Fahrenheit—both within the required range. During the walk-through, LPA observed an eye drop medication stored in the staff refrigerator located in the garage. Staff promptly relocated and secured the medication in the refrigerator located in the ADU. Please refer to LIC 9102 for further details. At approximately 1:30 PM, LPA Medina and LPM Segura began reviewing the operational requirements, disaster preparedness, and emergency intervention sections of the CARE Inspection Tool. During the review of the disaster preparedness plan, it was noted that documentation indicating when the plan was last reviewed was not available. LPA advised the facility to create a document including any revisions (if applicable), the date of review, and the reviewer’s signature. While reviewing the emergency intervention section, it was noted that no manual restraints had been conducted in the past three years, which is in compliance with the licensing document retention requirement. LPA Medina also conducted one staff interview. The inspection is now complete. Based on observations and findings documented in the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were cited. However, LPA observed two areas where technical support may be beneficial. See LIC 9102 pages dated 4/09/2025 for further information. An exit interview was conducted, and the report, along with appeal rights, was reviewed and provided to Facility Lead, Nicole Clupny.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco conducted an unannounced visit to the Bethany Christian STRTP in order to deliver the findings of the above allegations and met with Steven Toal. The above allegation was referred to Community Care Licensing for investigation. The investigation included an inspection of the Facility, interviews, and a review of facility and children's records. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Steven Toal along with appeal rights.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lidia Tinoco and Cynthia Galindo traveled to Bethany's House Group Home for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management and met with Joyce Gee. LPA's addressed the Emergency Intervention Plan (EIP) that must be submitted every 6 months. The department has not received any Bianual Review Plan. LPAs referred the agency to 84322(h)(2)(A-C) which provides detailed information about the requirements of the EIP Review. LPA's also addressed that the requested documentation for a change of Administrator has not been received since the initial request on August 2022. LPAs provided the agency with a list of the required documents for the Administrator Change. The agency is being cited on 84064.3(j)(1) Administrator Recertification Requirements and 84322(h)(2)(A-C) Emergency Intervention Plan. A copy of this report was provided at the conclusion of the inspection along with appeal rights.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco traveled to Bethany's House in Modesto for the purpose of conducting a Case Management regarding an incident reported on 3/30/2023. LPA Tinoco met with Administrator, Miriam Castellon. LPA Tinoco discussed the incident as well as the outcomes. The Administrator reported that the staff member in question was placed on leave pending test results. After failing to provide appropriate results it was decided to terminate the staff member. Administrator also states that none of the clients reported being aware of the incident and were not affected or involved. LPA Tinoco discussed reporting expectations with Administrator. No Deficiencies were cited on this Case Management. A copy of this report provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

On April 12, 2023 An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Lidia Tinoco at Bethany's House Group Home. LPA met with Administrator Miriam Castellon and inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers are properly charged. The facility has pull fire alarms. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. LPA reviewed 5 Staff Files and 5 Client Files. Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 1 Unit Supervisor, 1 Assistant Supervisor, 1 Lead Youth Counselor, 1 full time direct care staff, 2 part time direct care staff, 1 full time child care provider as well as additional ancillary positions including a teacher and medical coordinator. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA. The Accreditation is valid through 03/31/2025. One Type B Deficiency was observed and cited. A Technical Assistance was provided. A copy of this report was provided at the end of the visit.

On April 8, 2024 An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by LPAs (Licensing Program Analysts) Lidia Tinoco and Miriam Flores at Bethany's House Group Home. LPAs met with Assistant Director Shelli Prosser and inspected the facility, inside and out. On March 22, 2024, Program Director informed Community Care Licensing that since March 31, 2024 the contract with ORR has not been renewed and the decision to become non-operational has been made. At this time there are no staff or clients at the facility. The facility has the ability to maintain medications centrally stored in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers are properly charged. The facility has pull fire alarms. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There are no perishable foods available and a week supply of nonperishable foods. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA. The Accreditation is valid through 03/31/2025. No Deficiencies were cited on today's visit. A copy of this report was provided at the end of the visit.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carolyn Flynn conducted a Zoom Tele-Visit for the above listed facility at 2:30 PM on 3/17/2021. LPA Flynn was joined by Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) AmyLe Tran, Standards Compliance Coordinator - San Andres Regional Center, Hazel Jordan, MS, Service Coordinator - San Andreas Regional Center, Richard Gonzalez, and Administrator (Adm), Sharon Basa and Licensee, Eleanore Basa from the facility on this meeting. The purpose of this informal meeting is to discuss the future of Better Living Group Home. Currently there are four clients over the age of 18 years old residing at the facility. The fifth client will turn 18 in June of this year. LPA Flynn has been requesting a written plan from the facility to determine if they will be converting to an adult facility since November 2020. Both Sharon and Eleanore Basa has verbally informed LPA Flynn that they will be converting to an adult facility, but there has not been an application submitted nor has a written plan with dates submitted to LPA Flynn to confirm this conversion. Eleanore did come to the CCL office on Friday 3/12/2021 to request a copy of the Glacier II B documents and Program Statement. LPM Romeo Manzano from the Adult and Senior Care Program has had this emailed to Eleanore. This facility is currently operating beyond the scope of the original license issued for Better Living Group Home to serve children. The plan discussed today is that Better Living Group Home will be applying to convert to an Adult Home. Eleanore agreed to submit as much of the application to Sacramento by April 15, 2021 along with the fee to convert to and Adult Facility. The families have been notified that the facility will be converting to an adult facility and all families would like for their families would like to remain. Eleanore has agreed to submit the paperwork required to convert to San Andres Regional Center by the end of April 2021. If there are any changes or delays, Eleanore or Sharon will notify LPA Flynn and Richard Gonzalez from. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted

via Zoom and a copy of this report was emailed to Sharon Basa, Administrator with a read request added. LPA Flynn requested that a copy of this report be signed and sent back to LPA for the file.

On August 27, 2025, at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray met for Component III of the application process for BLUME BEHAVIORAL HEALTH Group Home located at 18161 Patronella Ave. Torrance CA, 90504 was held at the Children’s Residential Regional Office in El Segundo. Attending Component III were the following individuals: Administrator Aida Shadfan and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray. The objectives of Component III meeting were to familiarize applicants with general Group Home Rules and Regulations to prepare the Licensee to maintain and operate their facilities, provide information to avoid potential problem areas, to provide a clear description of Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA) role in operation of facility, and to provide clear description of Civil Penalties. LPA-Gray discuss the client’s Personnel Records, to be documented, retained, maintained, available and posted at the facility for inspections, discussed the gender population and specific problems and issues of operating a Group Home, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, allergies, hygiene, gender hygiene products, visitation, personal property, searches, community sensitivity, Electronic Files to store records, ensure the client ratio is based on staff to behavior that may include increasing staff to provide proper supervision, staff training that also include administer of medication and who will be responsible for administering medication. LPA discussed who will ensure the Technicians are aware of the clients triggers and the reason for their placement and need to provide a Grievance Box for the clients to report anonymous issues and concerns. LPA discussed the procedure of notification when an unusual incident occurs and documented LIC 624 that includes details of who what when, where and how the incident occured. LPA discussed prudent parenting and if the client is resistant to care and or are forced, how will the facility get the clients to buy in. LPA concluded Component III meeting, signed the Orientation/Application Process Certificate of Completion and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator Aida Shadfan

met_with: Basel Shadfan Chief Executive Officer/ Administrator
narrative: On February 15, 2024, 10AM, Component II of the application process for BLUME BEHAVIORAL HEALTH Group Home located 2403 PERKINS LANE, REDONDO BEACH CA, 90278 was held at the El Segundo Children’s Residential Regional Office in El Segundo. Attending Component II were the following individuals: Christina Kiesselbach, Compliance Specialist, Devon Wayt,Compliance Specialist, Basel Shadfan Chief Executive Officer/ Administrator and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray. The purposes of this Component II meeting were to review the incomplete application and Program Statement, to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: Personnel Report (LIC 500), Group Home 40 Hour Administrator certificate and by-laws. The Gender Population to identify the gender for this facility. The CEO determined that the above facility will provide care and supervision for male; Transportation; Needs and Services; Personal Rights that include, Visitation, Phone calls, Allowances, Discipline policy, Removal and/or Discharge Procedures; Neighborhood Complaint Procedures. The applicants were informed of the Health and Safety Code stated policy and requirements regarding the overconcentration of residential care facilities which are separated by a distance of 300 feet or less from another residential facility unless approval is obtained from the city or county in which the facility will be located. The applicant CEO/Administrator agreed to provide a Business License and a letter of approval from the city on a city letter. The applicants were advised of the following revision and/or corrections needed to the application and/or Program Statement: Sections 1-29 of the Program Statement was reviewed and discussed. Revisions are due February 29, 2024. The Pre-Licensing inspection has been scheduled for Thursday March 7, 2024 at 9:30 AM. A copy of this report was provided to Basel Shadfan Chief Executive Officer(CEO)/Administrator.

The purposes of this Component III meeting were to discuss the Child’s and Personnel Records, to be documented, retained, maintained, available and posted at the facility for inspections. LPA-Gray discussed the gender population and specific problems and issues of operating a Group Home, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, allergies, hygiene, gender hygiene products, visitation, personal property, searches, community sensitivity, Electronic Files to store records, ensure the client ratio is based on staff to behavior that may include increasing staff to provide proper supervision, staff training that also include administer of medication and who will be responsible for administering medication. LPA discussed who will ensure the Technicians are aware of the clients triggers and the reason for their placement, and need to provide a Grievance Box for the clients to report anonymous issues and concerns. LPA discussed the procedure of notification when an unusual incident occurs, and documenting on the LIC 624 that include details of who what when where and how. LPA discussed prudent parenting and if the client is resistant to care and or are forced, how will the facility get the clients to buy in. The applicant was informed the fingerprint clearances are Pending status that include the Administrator. A copy of this report was provided to Basel Shadfan Chief Executive Officer (CEO)/Administrator.

narrative: On April 4, 2024 at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray met for Component III of the application process for BLUME BEHAVIORAL HEALTH Group Home located BLUME BEHAVIORAL HEALTH Group Home located 2623 Voorhees Ave. Redondo Beach CA 90278 was held at the Children’s Residential Regional Office in El Segundo. Attending Component III were the following individuals: Christina Kiesselbach, Compliance Specialist, Basel Shadfan Chief Executive Officer/ Administrator and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray. The purposes of this Component III meeting were to discuss the Child’s and Personnel Records, to be documented, retained, maintained, available and posted at the facility for inspections. LPA-Gray discussed the gender population and specific problems and issues of operating a Group Home, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, allergies, hygiene, gender hygiene products, visitation, personal property, searches, community sensitivity, Electronic Files to store records, ensure the client ratio is based on staff to behavior that may include increasing staff to provide proper supervision, staff training that also include administer of medication and who will be responsible for administering medication. LPA discussed who will ensure the Technicians are aware of the clients triggers and the reason for their placement, and need to provide a Grievance Box for the clients to report anonymous issues and concerns. LPA discussed the procedure of notification when an unusual incident occurs, and documenting on the LIC 624 that include details of who what when where and how. LPA discussed prudent parenting and if the client is resistant to care and or are forced, how will the facility get the clients to buy in. The applicant was informed the fingerprint clearances are Pending status that include the Administrator. A copy of this report was provided to Basel Shadfan Chief Executive Officer (CEO)/Administrator.
