investigation_findings: 13On April 26, 2021 at 2:00 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks conducted a follow-up complaint inspection via telephone to BNI Treatment Center-Agoura and spoke with Maria Sarkisian, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During investigation of the allegation, LPA conducted interviews and reviewed documents. Based on interviews, there were no statements to determine that staff failed to adequately supervise group home children. Interviews with staff revealed staff denied allegation. Records were also reviewed and revealed staff performed room checks every 15 minutes. During room checks, Child #2 was observed in the hallway. Staff advised Child #2 to return to his room. Child #2 had entered Child #1's room as clients were transitioning to bed and was observed in hallway after departing Child #1's room. Both clients and staff confirmed that staff routinely perform room checks. Facility was in ratio on the evening of the incident and had an adequate number of staff on duty. There was no documentary evidence or witnesses to corroborate allegation. Continued on LIC 9099C

narrative:
On 03/11/2022 at 9am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA Karnsrithong had conducted health and safety assessment upon arriving at the facility. LPA Karnsrithong met Maria Sarkisian, Administrator for the facility who granted access and tour of the facility. The current census is (4) and there are four (4) staff present in the facility. The facility’s CARF accreditation is currently being renewed and they will come on Monday, March 14, 2022 to finalize the accreditation. During the inspection LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following: The facility is in a residential neighborhood. It is licensed to care and supervise up to six (6) male and female youth ages 12 to 17 ambulatory only. The facility is a two-story home with three (3) detached units being used as a gym, accounting/payroll, and therapy room. The therapy room is two-story detached unit. There are two (2) therapists who facilitates these rooms for the clients during sessions. The downstairs therapy room has couch, an office desk, chair, and rug. The upstairs therapy room has a large table, office chairs, couch, office desk and chair for the therapist. All therapy rooms have smoke/carbon monoxide alarms and first aid kits. The gym/office room is two (2) story unit. The downstairs is used as a gym that houses sporting equipment for clients and upstairs is used as an office for accounting/payroll. A first aid kit and smoke/carbon monoxide alarm are located in the this unit. The education room is located next to the pool. It has desks, chairs, and computers for clients to use. There are fire extinguishers on all the detached units. All outdoor and indoor passageways are free of debris and obstruction. Front Area: The front part of the property has a private driveway that leads to the parking area and the main driveway. There are stairs that leads to the main foyer. There are trees in the front part of the of the house. Utility shut off valves are located in front of the main property. (Page 1 of 2)

The main entrance has a seating unit. COVID-19 checks are done in the front door area. There is a countertop bar located in the the front reception area as well. Dining Area: The dining room is located in the front portion of the main property. It has a large table with eight (8) chairs. It has a cabinet and has a large window overlooking the front part of the property. Outside Area: The facility has a rolling backyard. There are patio furniture’s throughout the outside area. There is a pool has a clear fence surrounding it that is self-closing and is at least five feet in height. The pool is clean and well maintained. The pool valves are located in the back side of the property. The pool area has chairs and a volleyball net available for clients to use. Kitchen Area: The facility has a large kitchen which is located in the back side of the main house. It has six (6) stove gas burner, a refrigerator, air fryer, microwave, toaster, coffee maker, and dishwasher. Temperature logs for the refrigerator and sink water are checked regularly and documented. There is ample supplies of perishable and non-perishable foods for clients. There is a breakfast nook next to the kitchen that has a mini-fridge that has the clients snacks. It has a table and dining chairs. All sharp objects are locked up and inaccessible for clients. There are two (2) fire extinguishers in the kitchen area. The food preparation area is kept clean and well maintained. All kitchen cabinets are labeled and organized. There are sufficient pots, pans, utensils, plates and cups for clients to use. There is a chef that prepares all the meals for the children and is aware of all dietary restrictions. Clients are being served nutritious meals daily. Menus are posted in the kitchen. Common Room: There are two (2) common room located downstairs for clients to use. One is used for group activities and one is used for recreational use. There are couches and tables for clients and staff to use. All living room furniture are in good condition. Nurse Office: The nurse office is located upstairs. It has a mini refrigerator to store medications, cabinets, first aid kits, defibrillator, blood borne pathogens kit, computer, office desk, and chairs. Medication is maintained by the pharmacologist. The nurse is on call 24/7. All psychotropic and over the counter medications are stored in this office. This office is kept locked when staff is not present. (Page 2 of 2)

Laundry Room: The laundry room has a washer and dryer unit. It has a shelf for laundry supplies for clients and staff to use. It is kept locked when not in use. Bathroom: There are three (3) full size bathrooms in main property. There is one (1) bathroom located downstairs with a shower, toilet, sink, mirror and cabinets. There are two (2) bathrooms located upstairs. One bathroom upstairs is only used by staff and is also used to store COVID and cleaning supplies. All personal and contraband items of clients are also stored in this room. There is a tub in this bathroom but is not being used. The other upstairs bathroom is used by clients. All bathrooms are clean and water temperature are all in safe range. Bedrooms: There are four (4) bedrooms in the facility. One is located downstairs and three (3) upstairs. Each bedroom has a sturdy and clean mattress, adequate lighting and storage. Downstairs bedroom has a sliding door that leads to the back yard. The upstairs bedrooms have window screens that are in good condition. Shed: There is a utility shed located in the side of the house. This is used to store garden and cleaning equipment for the facility. It is also next to the air condition units. Clients are being accorded of their personal rights. Psychiatrists provides services to clients once a week. Clients have regular activities such as beach outing, surfing, and equine. There is a Physician Assistant in the facility as well. Licensed Vocational Nurse and counselors administers medication to clients. Therapeutic services are provided at a minimum of three times a week. LPA Karnsrithong interviewed two (2) staff and one (1) client. All counselors and nursing staff have access to the keys to the facility. There is one (1) facility vehicle being used to transport clients that is in good working condition. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Maria Sarkisian, Administrator. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility. (Page 3 of 3)

investigation_findings: 13On August 2, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at BNI Treatment Center – Agoura for the purpose of delivering findings for the allegation listed above. LPA met with Administrator, Maria Sarkisian. During investigation of the allegation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documents. Based on interviews, statements provided did not determine that staff administered medication to minor without responsible party’s consent. Staff denied the allegation and stated parental consent is obtained during client intake. Client statement could not be obtained. Based on information obtained, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

narrative:
On 12/05/24 at 10:01 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at BNI Treatment Center Agoura for an annual/random inspection and met with Administrator Maria Sarkisian. LPA and LPM requested and were given a copy of the staff roster (LIC 500) and the client Roster (LIC 9020). LPA and LPM then conducted a facility inspection. The Group Home is licensed to provide care/supervision up to six (6) clients and has a current census of three (3). There is a swimming pool on premises. This is a two-story home with 4 bedrooms, 3 full bathrooms, nursing station, 2 living rooms, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, front yard, back yard with a swimming pool and school house, a unattached garage that has extra food storage and two therapists rooms, and another unattached backyard garage with a downstairs gym and upstairs records room. The facility only accepts private placement clients. LPA and LPM observed the facility license posted in public view in the front enterance, posted activity schedule for clients in the living room, and a posted menu for the month in the kitchen. There is one non-operable fireplace. There are no security bars on windows. There are working smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in the home. All 7 out of 7 fire extinguishers were fully charged. Facility has adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable food for at least one week and extra of both in the garage. Facility has operable land line that has been removed from its locked cabinet and is now open to all clients. All knives were kept on chefs person making them inaccessible to clients. Bathrooms were clean and sanitary and cleaning solutions were made inaccessible. LPA and observed a laundry room with adequate amount of extra towels, linens, and blankets. Report continued on LIC 809-C.

Living room and dinning area have adequate seating capacity. The facility has adequate indoor and outdoor space. The front and backyard were found to be clean of debris and observable hazards. The facility has a working washer and dryer. The facility uses video surveillance. LPA and LPM informed Administrator to submit revisions to the program statement that reflects the facilities usage of video cameras. Backyard pool is kept locked with a key, not with a self latching lock. Administrator confirmed that all staff have keys that unlock the swimming pool area. LPA and LPM observed pool door being stuck and not closing or locking when exiting the pool area. Administrator informed LPA and LPM that maintenance would come and adjust the alignment to allow the door to close and lock. Medications are stored in the nurses office which is on the seconded floor of the main house. The office is kept locked, but inside the office LPA and LPM observed an unlocked fridge storing medication that needs to be kept temperature controlled, and one container of dry medication not locked with the clients other medication. LPA and LPM also observed a locked container of medication intended for destruction that has not been disposed of yet. LPA and LPM also observed clients hygiene products stored in the nursing station. The nursing station also houses the surveillance camera monitors. Bedroom #1 is located downstairs, it has 2 beds with storage attached under the bed frame. LPA observed that the second bed in the room is blocking the sliding door exit to the backyard. LPA and LPM advised Administrator to remove the second bed that is blocking the sliding door. Bedroom #1 had no other storage units, including no extra closets or drawers. LPA observed and tested working smoke/carbon monoxide detector. Bedroom #2 is upstairs and has two beds both with storage drawers under the bed frames. LPA and LPM observed and tested working smoke/carbon monoxide detector in the room. LPA and LPM also observed a sliding door that leads to the balcony. LPA tested the sliding door and found it to be stuck. Bedroom also has a master bathroom that is attached to it that is used as storage space and kept locked. LPA and LPM informed Administrator to not use clients bedroom as passageway to facility storage room. Administrator shared that they would create another entrance to the storage room to avoid using the bedroom as a passageway. LPA and LPM observed that smoke/carbon monoxide detector are working. Report continued on LIC 809-C.

Bedroom #3 is upstairs it has 2 beds with storage attached under the bed frame. LPA observed a window with a missing screen in the bedroom. Bedroom also has a closet for extra storage space. LPA and LPM observed an odor coming from the bedroom. Administrator stated that client in the room wets the bed and while the mattress is water proof the staff consistently change the sheets and blankets, yet the room still caries the odor. LPA and LPM observed that smoke/carbon monoxide detector are working. Bedroom #4 is upstairs it has 2 beds with storage attached under the bed frame. Bedroom also has a closet for extra storage space. LPA and LPM observed that two out of the three lights in the room were not working. LPA and LPM observed that the facility has 8 beds but only has a capacity of 6. LPM and LPA informed Administrator that the facility can only have a maximum of 6 beds which matches their maximum capacity of 6. Bathroom #1 is downstairs. LPA tested the sink water temperature to be at 60 degrees F. Bathroom #2 is upstairs and has two sinks both with water temperature at 120 degrees F. LPA also observed some ants in the shower. The following deficiencies were cited see 809-D. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was given to Maria Sarkisian.

On October 29, 2024, at 2:00 PM, a Component II Office Meeting was held to discuss the application received for BNI Treatment Centers Attending Component II were the following individuals: Proposed administrator Maria Sarkisian, Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward and Licensing Program Manager Lakescia Smith. The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns and issues The following issues were discussed. 1. Job description for administrator will be included in program statement. 2. The proposed administrator change for BNI, Agoura will need to be approved before Maria Sarkisian can be approved as administrator for this facility. 3. LIC 401: The Monthly Operating Statement is incomplete. A realistic estimated cost is needed for each item. An LIC 401 is needed for all existing facilities. 4. LIC 404: An updated Release of Financial Information is needed along with verification of financial resources 3 times greater that the combined expenses for all facilities. 5. LIC 610: Items III and V will be completed. 6, Facility Sketch: Bedroom dimensions, notation of bedroom windows, location of utility shutoffs, number of clients per bedroom will be included.

7. The Fire Clearance has not been received. 8.The Emergency Intervention Plan is incorrect, It should not contain information on emergency evacuation procedures. 9. The Runaway Plan will be updated to t include a continuum of interventions to prevent runaways. 10. House rules surrounding rights of clients to private visitation were discussed and clarified. 11.. House Rule Regulations were discussed and clarified. Clients will perform chores on a voluntary basis. 12. Operating Agreement is needed that designates Maria Sarkisian to act for the LLC 13 Parental authority is needed for psyche meds. Applicant will include their procedures for obtaining parental authorization for administration of psychotropic medications. 14 Applicant will provide a sample menu and sample calendar of activities. Prelicensing visit is scheduled for November 19th, 2024 at 10:00 AM

On November 19, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Maria Sarkisian to conduct a pre-licensing evaluation of the facility. The following was observed. This is a four bedroom, four and a half bathroom home located in an unincorporated area of Calabasas, CA. There are no security bars on windows. There are plans to install a pool or a ball court in the backyard. The applicants will inform the Department if either choice is made. Bedrooms All bedrooms are on the 2nd floor and there is a nursing station that will be manned by a licensed nurse while clients are in their bedrooms. All bedrooms have beds and linens in good condition. There is the required drawer and closet space for each bedroom. There is a nursing station situated near the bedrooms. There are automatic blinds on the bedroom windows. Bathrooms/Kitchen/Dining Area All bathrooms are clean and well maintained. The bathroom on the first floor is a half bath. There is a stove and a refrigerator. The propane supply was disconnected due to high winds, therefore the hot water temperature and the stove burners could not be checked. No sharp knives will be stored on the premises; the chefs will bring their knives on a daily basis and take them at the end of their shift. However knives will be locked up while the chefs are on duty. There is a breakfast nook. There is a dining table that seats eight. Fire/Yard Safety All fireplaces are safely screened. There are currently no bodies of water on the premises. There are working smoke detectors in the hallways and bedrooms along with a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway. There are fully charged fire extinguishers throughout the house. The yard perimeter is fenced to provide safety from the steep hills. The patio and yard areas present no visible hazards. LPA informed Ms. Sarkisian that the fire marshal will have to approve the use of the garage as a rec room.

Misc: There are several complete first aid kits on the premises. There is also a supply of first aid items in the nursing station. Medications will be locked in the nursing station. Household cleaners will be locked in the laundry room. The following items will be reviewed during the return inspection: Applicant will have the propane supply activated so that safe water temperature and working stove condition can be verified. LPA will verify that the automatic blinds that cover the bedroom windows are working. LPA will verify that the doorway behind the 2nd bed in bedroom number 4 is covered. Applicant will either tint or cover windows in the dining and kitchen areas to ensure privacy of clients. LPA will also review the facility vehicle for safety.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward held a Face Time meeting with Maria Sarkisian to verify completion of the corrections pre-licensure. LPA was able to verify the following: The automatic window blinds in all four bedrooms are working. The hot water temperature is 119 degrees. The doorway behind 2nd bed in bedroom number 4 is covered. There are curtains in the dining room area. LPA Jones-Steward will forward the application to LPM Lakescia Smith for approval.

On May 25, 2021 at 10:00 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cameo Banks made a virtual telephone visit to the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA virtually met with Administrator, Maria Sarkisian, who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is designed to accept private placements to provide care/supervision for six (6) ambulatory only clients, ages 12-17 years. There are six clients in placement at this time. The home is set up as follows: This home is located in a remote residential neighborhood. The two-story home has four (4) bedrooms, eight and a half (8.5) bathrooms, group therapy room, school room, two (2) therapy rooms, laundry room, Administration office, nursing station room, dining area, kitchen, backyard with pool, and attached garage, which will be used a fitness room. 1st Floor: The first level of the home includes the following: Kitchen- The kitchen and surrounding area were equipped with fully operable kitchen appliances and dining table with seating with eight chairs. The kitchen was fully stocked with ample eating utensils, pots/pans, plates, bowls and cups. Fire extinguisher located in the kitchen was noted to be up to date. The was at least a two day supply of perishable food supplies and 7 day supply of non-perishable food in pantry located to the right of the kitchen. There is also a miniature refrigerator with snacks for the youth. The knives are stored in locked Administrator office. Dining room-There is a wooden table with eight chairs. School room-This room has a total of six individual desks and six computers. Laundry room-This room has a front loading washer and dryer. Laundry detergent is in locked cabinet. Living room-There is one large sofa chairs which appears to be in new condition and four bean bags for sitting. Fireplace in living room has screen. There are numerous fully charged fire extinguishers available. Both therapy rooms and Group therapy room are furnished with chairs and sofas. Bathrooms: There are a total of 8.5 bathrooms; 3.5 bathrooms located on the 1st floor. Toilet, sink and tub/showers are in safe, clean, and operating condition in all bathrooms. Report continued on 809-C

2nd Floor: The second level of the home includes the following: Bedroom #1: This room is equipped with two queen size beds. There are adequate drawer space and lighting in this room. This room has a patio backdoor entrance/exit that has a manual lock. All windows in this room can not be opened. There are no security bars on the windows. There An alarm system has been installed on all windows and doors. This room also has a private bathroom. Bedroom #2 This room is equipped with one queen size bed. There are adequate drawer and closet space and lighting in this room. All windows in this room can be opened. This room also has a private bathroom which is locked. Bedroom #3 This room is equipped with one queen size bed. There are adequate drawer and closet space and lighting in this room. All windows in this room can be opened. This room also has a private bathroom. Bedroom #4 This room is equipped with two queen size beds. There are adequate closet and drawer space and lighting in this room. This room has a sliding backdoor entrance/exit that has a manual lock. There are two windows in this room, and one window can be opened. This room also has a private bathroom. Nursing station-This room has one desk, one mini fridge, cabinet with hygiene supplies and locked cabinet where medication is stored. Employee and client files also stored in nurses office station. Storage closet: surplus of non perishable foods, feminine hygiene products, toiletries, office supplies, hand sanitizing wipes 2nd storage closet: Specifically COVID-19 supplies that include paper towels, face shields , masks, disinfectant, bleach, hand sanitizer hall closets:(3) remains locked. contains individual caddies with grooming baskets, towels, art supplies, and clients empty luggage Admin office: adequately furnished and remains locked. Sharp objects are locked in Administrator's file cabinet. Sitting area, one sofa 2 bean bags Report continued on 809C

Backyard: Backyard is clean and free of debris. Swimming pool has a gate that is at least 5 feet with outside self latching lock. There is a ping pong table, BBQ grills with attached dishwasher, sink and mini fridge. Garage: Garage is used as a fitness gym, punching bag and gloves, yoga mats, resistance bands, two stationary bikes, jumps ropes, foam rollers and a screen television. The garage also contains a second refrigerator which hold extra food supplies. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Facility provides nutritious snacks between meals. Facility posts child’s rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more children. Children are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and will be treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children in care will be supervised & protected at all times. Due to restrictions due to COVID-19, LPA unable to physically visit facility to review client and staff files. Files will be reviewed at a later date. Adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances. Adults working/residing in the facility have Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility personnel meet staff qualification requirements. Facility personnel meet staff training requirements. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Current and available for review. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Administrator.

On 04/21/2022 at 10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting an annual site inspection. LPA Karnsrithong met with Maria Sarkisian, Administrator who granted access and tour of the facility. Health and safety risk assessment were conducted during the visit. COVID-19 check in were conducted in the front entrance. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to six (6) male and female youth ages twelve to seventeen (12 to 17) years of age. The current census at the time of the visit is 6. During the visit LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following: This group home is located in a residential neighborhood. The facility is a two-story home. The entrance has parking for staff and visitors. There is a stairway that leads to the front door/main entrance of the facility. Upon entering the facility, staff checks in visitors temperature and abides to COVID-19 Protocols. The facility has four (4) bedrooms, eight (8) bathrooms. Safety drills are conducted once a month and is recorded in their safety binder. A physician assistant comes in once a day and a psychologist meets with clients three (3) times a week. During the inspection, the clients were at equine outing. LPA Karnsrithong has reviewed two (2) staff files and three (3) client files. LPA Karnsrithong has interviewed one (1) staff during the inspection. There is one (1) facility vehicle that transports clients. First Floor: The first floor has three (3) fire extinguishers that are located in the common room, kitchen hallway, and gym. There are four (4) bathrooms located in the first floor. Three (3) bathrooms are used by clients and one (1) bathroom is dedicated for employees only. The employee bathroom is kept locked. All bathrooms have a toilet, sink, and cabinets. It has ample lighting and all water temperatures are in the safe range. There are two (2) closets located downstairs. (Page 1 of 4)

Common Room/Living Room: This is located in front of the main entrance. It has couches, coffee table, television, and a fireplace that is non-operational. The Emergency Disaster Plan and Facility Sketch Plan is posted in this area. A closet is also located next to the common room that stores board games. The common room has a sliding door that leads to the outdoor patio. Outdoor Patio Area: This area has outdoor patio furniture that is clean and in good repair. It also has a ping-pong table that is securely attached. There is an outdoor kitchen set but the facility only uses grill for cooking; the refrigerator and dishwasher is not being used. There is sink as well in the outdoor kitchen area. Therapy Rooms: There are two (2) individual therapy rooms that is equipped with couches, desk, table and chairs. It has picture windows. There is ample lighting in the therapy rooms. There is a full-size bathroom in the individual therapy rooms that is equipped with toilet, sink, and shower. The bathroom has cabinets. The therapy bathrooms are in good repair and well maintained. The temperature inside the therapy room are within the safe range. Group Therapy Room: The group therapy room is located next to the stairway. It has chairs and a dry erase board used during group sessions. School Room: The school room is equipped with desks, computers and cabinets. Clients conduct school/educational activities in this room. There is a teacher that supervises the clients when the school room is being used. There is ample lighting in the school room and the temperature is within the safe range. Hallway: The hallway has a small library that is enclosed with a glass sliding door. It has books for clients to use. Pantry Room: The pantry room is next to the kitchen/dining area. There is ample supply of perishable and non-perishable food items. (Page 2 of 4)

Kitchen/Dining Area: The kitchen/dining area has a two (2) dining tables and ten (10) chairs. Licensing postings, menus, kitchen rules, and facility sketch plans are posted in the dining area. There is a kitchen island that has a separate sink and cabinets for utensils. There is a six (6) range gas burner stove that has a griddle and oven. There is hood range as well with the stove. There is a toaster, microwave, and a small snack refrigerator. Another sink is located next to the kitchen windows. There is ample cabinet space that stores in cups, plates, and other food preparation equipment. Sharp items are brought in by the chef and is only taken out when being used. Chef is responsible for storing the sharp items away from the facility. The chef prepares all meals for the children and accommodates to dietary restrictions as needed. Food preparation is clean and is free of any litter. There is a trash can with a fitted lid in the kitchen/dining area. Laundry Room: The facility has a separate and enclosed laundry room equipped with a working washer and dryer. Laundry supplies are kept in this room. Cleaning and disinfectant supplies are stored in a cabinet in and is kept locked at all times. Staff does laundry for the clients in the group home. Gym Room/Fitness Room: The attached garage is currently being used as a gym/fitness room. It has sports equipment, treadmill, exercise bikes, and other exercise supplies. The attached garage leads to the driveway and to a basketball court. There is a fridge on the side of the gym used to store other perishable food supplies. The water heater is also located in the gym room and has a wooden housing. Second Floor: The second floor has plexi glass partitions located in the stairway. All four (4) bedrooms are located upstairs. The Administration Office and Nursing Station is also located upstairs. There are four (4) bathrooms in the second floor. All bathrooms are clean and have water temperature in the safe range. Administrative Office: This room is not connected to the client’s living area. It has big desk, closet for storage, fire extinguisher, first aid kit, and dry erase board. It also has a couch. This office room also has its own full-size bathroom that has a working toilet, sink and shower. The shower is not being used. There is a closet space inside the Admin office bathroom that is used to store facility supplies. (Page 3 of 4)

Bedrooms: All bedrooms are equipped with queen size beds, sturdy mattress, ample storage space and adequate lighting. Room 1 has two (2) beds and shared by two (2) clients. Room 1 has a full size bathroom with a non-operational tub, a shower and double sink vanity. Room 1 also has a non-operational fireplace that is blocked off by a plexi glass. There are cabinets in the vanity sink. Room 2 and 3 have one bed and only have one (1) client each room. Both Room 2 and 3 have its own full-sized bathrooms equipped with toilet, sink, and shower. Room 4 has two (2) full sized beds and has its own full size bathroom as well. It is also equipped with toilet, sink, and shower. There are patio doors in the bedrooms and is kept locked at all times. When the patio doors are open, an alarm signal goes off to inform staff. There are window screens in all bedrooms and are in good repair and free of insects or debris. Hallway Closet: There are two (2) closet space located in the 2nd floor. It is used to store hygiene and emergency supplies. Nursing Station-This room has one desk, one mini fridge, cabinets with hygiene, first aid and other medical supplies. Medication logs are also kept in this room. A nurse compliance checklist binder is also kept in this room to monitor compliance with medication administration. There is a nursing staff onsite all day. Outdoor Area: The backyard is fenced in. A pool that is gated with a self-close latch is located in the backyard. Currently, the facility is making an organic garden for the clients to use. All utility shut off valves are located outside the group home. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Maria Sarkisian, Administrator and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility. (Page 4 of 4)

On March 30, 2023, at 1:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to BNI Treatment Centers – Calabasas for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Special Incident Report #03-2023-34-CM-08. The incident occurred 03/14/2023 and the incident report was received by the Department on 03/20/2023. LPA met with Administrator/Director of Operations, Maria Sarkisian and discussed the incident. During this visit, confidential interviews were conducted. Additional interviews will be conducted on a later date. LPA requested a copy of hospital discharge for Client #1 (C1), copy of the police report regarding the incident or law enforcement contact information for the date of the incident including police report number, current LIC 500, Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting notes for Client #1 (C1), and a copy of the safety plan implemented for C1. Additionally, LPA requested to view video footage of the incident. The Director of Operations stated a copy of the video footage would be requested from the internal IT Department and all other requested information would be emailed to LPA. LPA will follow-up with the Director of Operations to review video footage within the next two (2) weeks. Based on the information gathered, this incident needs further investigation. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator/Director of Operations.

On November 16, 2023, at 9:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at the facility to deliver findings for the Case Management referral dated March 20, 2023. Based on the incident report, confidential interviews, and documentary evidence; statements were consistent that adequate supervision was provided, and that appropriate emergency intervention procedures and protocols were implemented to support the safety of the client. There was no corroborating evidence that supports that a violation occurred. This case management has been found to be unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Maria Sarkisian, Administrator/Director of Operations. A copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator/Director of Operations.

On 5/21/2025 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and LPA Andrea Aceves arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting an Requierd 2-Year Inspection. LPA's met Maria Sarkisian, Administrator for the facility who granted access and tour of the facility. The current census is 5. LPA's conducted a facility walk through. During the inspection LPA's observed the following: The facility is in a residential neighborhood. It is licensed to care and supervise up to six (6) male and female youth ages 12 to 17 ambulatory only. The facility is a two-story home with a garage being used as a gym, and a backyard with a pool. The facility does use cameras. The facility has synched dual smoke and carbon monoxide detectors in every room. The facility license and disaster plan are posted in the dinning room. Down Stairs Living Room: There is a couch and 4 beanbag chairs providing adequate seating. There is a TV, a fire place with a cover, a fully charged fire extinguisher, a thermostat, and adequate lighting. There is an locked activity closet with games, puzzles, and arts supplies. Living room leads to the therapists office, bathroom, the upstairs area, and group therapy room. Bathroom #1: This is a half bath with a toilet and a sink. There are working lights. No cleaning solutions stored. The water temp was measured at 105 degrees F.

Therapy Room #1: This room is used by therapist as private area to talk with clients. There is a desk with a computer, a couch, and some chairs. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. Bathroom #2: There is a bathroom in the therapy room that clients can but don't often use. The bathroom has a sink and toilet. There is adequate lighting. The water temp was 105 degrees F. Therapy Room #2: This room is used by therapist as private area to talk with clients. There is a desk with a computer, a couch, and some chairs. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. Bathroom #3: There is a bathroom in the therapy room that clients can but don't often use. The bathroom has a sink and toilet. There is adequate lighting. The water temp was 105 degrees F. Group Therapy Room: Located next to the living room, this is an area for clients to meet together and receive group therapy. There is adequate seating and a white board. This room leads to the back yard or the kitchen. There is a hallway with an old wine cellar that has been converted into a library/book storage area. Kitchen/Dinning Room: This room has 2 dinning tables each with adequate seating. There is a water cooler for clients. The facility license, disaster plan, menu, and activity schedule are posted. There is a fooseball table. The kitchen has a working 6 burner stove/oven. There are an adequate amount of plates, cups, bowls, and utensils. There are no cleaning solutions stored in the kitchen. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. There is a fridge and freezer. There are two sinks both with a water temp of 105 degrees F. Knives are kept on the chefs person and made inaccessible to clients. There is an adequate amount of perishable food. There is a snack mini fridge in the room. The kitchen leads to the back yard or the hallway to the education room. Pantry: There is a pantry in the hallway on in between the kitchen and education room. The pantry is locked and stores spices, snacks, cereal, canned goods, and other non-perishables. There is an adequate supply of non-perishable foods. There is also a monitor station for the facility cameras. It is locked and inaccessible to clients. It records live footage and stores it for a week.

Education Room: This is a room fro clients do do their online schooling. There are 6 desks with 6 computers for all clients. There is a TV and a fully charged fire extinguisher. There is a staff restroom that is locked and inaccessible to clients. This room leads upstairs to the administrators office, to the backyard or to the laundry room. Laundry room: The laundry room has a washer and dryer unit. There are cabinets which store cleaning solutions. They are locked and made inaccessible to clients. This room leads to the garage. Garage: The garage is used as a exercise room equipped with 2 treadmills, a weights rack, 2 bike machines, and open space. There is another fridge and freezer for extra food and snack storage. This room leads to the outside front yard. There is also a driveway with a basketball hoop. Upstairs Administrators office: Located above the education room, the office is for the administrator only and is kept locked and made inaccessible to clients. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher and a first aid kit outside the office. In the office there are 2 desks with chairs, a printer, and a bathroom. Upstairs Landing: There is a landing/walkway upstairs with rails and plexiglass to prevent clients from falling. There are two closets which are locked and used as storage for supplies like brooms, vacuums, ladders, and emergency supplies etc. This area leads to bedroom #1 and the Hang Out Area. Bedroom #1: Located above the living room, this room sleeps 2 clients. There are two full beds complete with an adequate amount of pillows, blankets, and bedsheets. There are 2 dresser and built in dressers under the bed. There is a fire place with a plexiglass cover and a balcony that is kept locked and made inaccessible. Bathroom #3: This bathroom is located in bedroom #1. There is 2 sinks with water temps measured at 105 degrees F. There is a toilet and shower. There is a tub but clients don't use it. This bathroom does have a door to the nurses station but it is kept locked and inaccessible.

Nurse Station: Located adjacent to bedroom #1 the nurse station stores clients meds, over the counter meds, extra hygiene equipment, the main first aid kit, and the medication logs. There is a med kit with tweezers, scissors, a thermometer, bandages, and wipes. LPA observed each clients meds labeled and kept separately. LPA's observed the medication distribution records. The nurses station is made locked and inaccessible. Hangout Area: Located across from Bedroom #1 this is an open area/hallway that leads to Bedrooms #2, 3, and 4. There are also 3 closets that are used as storage for extra towels, linens, and clients personal hygiene. Bedroom #2: Located above the kitchen, this room sleeps 1 client. There is 1 full beds complete with an adequate amount of pillows, blankets, and bedsheets. There is a closet and built in dressers under the bed. Bathroom #4: This bathroom is located in bedroom #2. There is 1 sink with water temp measured at 105 degrees F. There is a toilet and shower. Bedroom #3: Located above the kitchen, this room sleeps 1 client. There is 1 full beds complete with an adequate amount of pillows, blankets, and bedsheets. There is a closet and built in dressers under the bed. Bathroom #5: This bathroom is located in bedroom #2. There is 1 sink with water temp measured at 105 degrees F. There is a toilet and shower. Bedroom #4: Located above the kitchen, this room sleeps 2 clients. There are two full beds complete with an adequate amount of pillows, blankets, and bedsheets. There is a closet and built in dressers under the bed. There is balcony that is kept locked and made inaccessible. Bathroom #6: This bathroom is located in bedroom #4. There is 1 sink with water temps measured at 105 degrees F. There is a toilet and shower.

Outside Backyard: There is a pool in the back yard. There is a gate that is at least 5ft tall and with bars that you can see through. There is a lot of open space to run around. There is a dinning table with adequate chairs. There is a grill are and counter top. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher. There is a garden in the very back. On the side of the house there are some building materials left from previous house projects. LPA advised Admin to remove or make the materials inaccessible to clients, Admin agreed to do so. LPA's requested and received a copy of the staff and client roster. LPA reviewed the facility disaster training logs. LPA will return to interview staff and clients, review staff and clients files, inspect the facility vehicle, and review the medication logs. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Maria Sarkisian, Administrator. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shoua Xiong and Raulito Alarcon conducted an unannounced visit to the facility on 8/20/20 beginning at 10:00 AM. LPAs met with the Administrator and explained the purpose of today's visit is to conduct a Case Management on an Incident Report dated 8/13/20 regarding a client falling backwards and hitting their head on the ground. On today's date, LPAs interviewed the Administrator. The Administrator explained the chain of events leading to the incident and explained that the doctor did not have any health concerns. Administrator stated the client also has a follow-up doctor's appointment with their primary care physician today. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong and LPA Robert Sandles conducted an unannounced visit to the facility on 6/23/21 beginning at 11:30AM. LPAs met with the Administrator/Licensee, Dolfa Bomar, and explained the purpose of the visit was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. On today's date, LPAs conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. This facility is a four bedroom, two bathroom house. Three bedrooms are designated for clients in care. LPAs observed that there are no more than two clients to a room, each client is provided their own beds, beddings, dressers, and closet space. Each bedroom contained a night stand with lamps. A Smoke Detector/Carbon Monoxide Combo alarm was observed in each bedrooms, in the hallway, and by the front entrance. LPAs tested and observed that all alarms were in working order. The fourth bedroom is designated as a staff office. The office was observed to be locked. Upon inspection, the office contained client and staff files along with the Medication Administration Record binder. The Kitchen area contained a dining table that seated four. In the refrigerator and pantry, LPAs observed the required two days of perishable food items and seven days of non-perishable food items. Medications was observed to be stored and locked in a designated closet. This closet also contained a complete first aide kit. Sharps and cleaning chemicals/solutions was observed to be stored and locked in kitchen cabinets. LPAs observed a fire extinguisher that was charged and serviced within the last 12 months. The water temperature of sinks were tested and within the required range. The temperature inside the house was registered at 72 degrees and was comfortable. The front and back yard of the facility was observed to be clean and free of debris or safety hazards. LPAs inspected the facility vehicle and observe it had current, non-expired, registration and tags. The vehicle was observed to be in good shape with no safety concerns. On today's date, LPAs also reviewed four client files and nine staff files. All files was observed to be complete, containing the required documents. No deficiencies were cited on today. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator/ Licensee, Dolfa Bomar.

On August 15, 2022 at 12:00 P.M. Licensing Program Analyst Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced annual facility inspection. LPA met with, House Manager, Mariflor Dizon, and Dolfa Bomar, Facility Licensee and announced the reason for the inspection. Facility Licensee assisted with the inspection. LPA and the Licensee conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The group is licensed for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients, ages seven to 17 years old. There were two clients in care at the time of the inspection. One client was on an outing with the staff. The home is a one story home. The home consists of two single occupancy bedrooms and one double occupancy bedroom, and two bathrooms, a garage, and a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. The home had a kitchen, dining room, staff office, laundry room and living room. The facility license was posted in a prominent place, on the wall in the living room. The home had an Emergency Disaster plan, and Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights and the Grievance policy, Client menu, Client Daily Schedule, and a calendar of activities were posted on a cork board in the dining room. The living room contained two couches, and 3 chairs, along with a television and entertainment center. There was an XBOX gaming system and games, games, DVDs in the entertainment center, The kitchen contained a working landline phone. The home did not have a fireplace. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table was set up for placement of four and contained four chairs. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had the stove, oven, toaster, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen cabinets and drawers contained ample dishes, utensils, and cooking supplies, such as pots and pans, and PPE supplies. The sharps and cleaning chemicals were in locked cabinets. The pantry was located off of the kitchen in the entryway, with no lock on the door. continued on 809-c

LPA observed expired food items, including boxes or rice and bags of beans, and salad dressings, expiring between dates ranging from May 2021 - June 2022. The staff removed the items immediately from the pantry and refrigerator. There was ample storage of fresh and frozen foods located in the refrigerator, freezer, and pantry to supply meals and snacks to the clients in care. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days. Fresh fruits were observed on the kitchen island. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. No potentially hazardous items or areas were observed in the outdoor spaces. The backyard contains two seating areas with tables and multiple chairs, and umbrella shades to shade from the sun and a swinging bench. There were no locks on the side yard fence, and the side yard contains trash cans, and a bicycle. The garage contained a facility vehicle, lawn mower and weed eater, storage cabinets and a refrigerator and freezer. The cabinets contained paper supplies, games and toys, holiday decor, extra bags and backpacks, and kitchen supplies such as a crockpot. A table and chairs was also observed. The laundry room contained a washer and dryer, and locked cabinets which contained tools and chemicals, including paints. The locked cabinets also contained sponges, and flashlights. The locked cabinet near the ground contained cleaners, detergents, and a gas can will gas inside. The facility staff moved the gas can to a locked space in the garage when made aware. LPA observed that the bedrooms had a bed(s) and bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows, dressers with drawers for personal items, night stand, lamp, and ample closet space. One single occupancy bedroom had the dresser/mirror combination placed in front of a window which did not allow window and emergency exit access in the case of an emergency, violating the fire clearance. Staff immediately moved the furniture from the window when made aware that it hindered from an emergency exit. Window screens were in good repair aside from the sliding door screen which was observed to have a two inch by three inch hole in it near the handle. The licensee is in the process of repairing it. There were two bathrooms observed in the facility. One bathroom was located in a bedroom, and the other bathroom was located in the hallway. continued on 809-c

The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. The water temperature was measured to be at 108 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing, as well as hand washing guidelines were posted. Hygiene supplies were observed in the bathrooms for clients use. Ants were located near the toilet and trash can in the one bathroom. The staff sprayed bug spray and cleaned immediately to remove the ants. Both bathrooms contained a supply of gloves and hand sanitizers. The bathroom closet contained extra hygiene products, PPE, and bath mats. The hallways closet outside of the bathroom contained extra towels and wash cloths, and bedding. Trash cans with lids were observed in the bathrooms and kitchen. LPA observed a working Carbon Monoxide detector in the hallway and working smoke alarms in each bedroom, the entry area, staff office, and hallway. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the hallway and dining room. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in March 2022. The fire clearance was conducted in April 2020 and a copy was provided to LPA. Upon arrival LPA observed a scent of cigarette smoke from the garage/backyard area. The licensee admitted that staff are allowed to smoke cigarettes in the backyard. LPA informed the licensee of regulation 84087(c). The licensee informed staff of the regulation and to smoke off of the facility premise during breaks. LPA observed that the medications and documents, and first aid kit were stored in a locked hallway closet. The confidential client and staff files, including the Register of Clients, and staff background clearances were stored in locked staff office. LPA reviewed a total of six staff files, two licensee files, and four client files. LPA observed that all files contained the required documentation, including Medication Administration Records, Including for Psychotropic Medications distributed, signed Needs and Services Plans, Appraisal of Needs and Services, JV-220 for one client, Immunization Records and proof of TB testing, and Placement Agreements. The sole exception was that the the licensee does not have a document in which bedroom sharing compatibility was discussed with the clients who share a bedroom, but maintains that the clients who share a bedroom are compatible and the licensee will discuss with the clients, and complete and place documentation in the clients files. continued on 809-c

The facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, with the exception of being deficient related to the following, where: Technical Violations (TV) were issued, related to: California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80087(a) (1): The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility reasonably free of flies and other insects. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80088(b): All window screens shall be in good repair and be free of insects, dirt and other debris. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 5, section 84087(c): The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the ground of the facility; and Technical Advisories (TA) were issued, related to: California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80087(i): The items specified in Section 80087(g) above shall not be stored in food storage areas or in storage areas used by or for clients. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80076(a)(18): All food shall be protected against contamination. Contaminated food shall be discarded immediately. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 5, section 84087(e): "In every situation where children share a bedroom, the licensee shall document that the bedroom sharing arrangement ensures the health and safety of each child and that the children are compatible...." See TVs and TAs for more information. Two staff and two clients were interviewed. The facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80020(a) All facilities shall secure and maintain a fire clearance approved by the city or county fire department, the district providing fire protection services, or the State Fire Marshal. See 809-D for POC information. An exit interview was conducted with Dolfa Bomar, Facility Licensee and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Dolfa Bomar, Facility Licensee.

On 7/29/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility and met with Shirley Bordon, Administrator. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 110 degrees F. The thermostat measured 71 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance, with only the following exceptions: LPA Ng reviewed medication logs for the three clients. LPA Ng noticed that the psychotropic medication did not have their own separate log. LPA advises per CCR regulation, 84070(b)(13), Children's Records. Please see 809D. to have sex with C1. Record review provided confirmation that S1 took C1 to a motel on at least one occasion. investigation_findings: 13On August 23, 2021 at 1:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with Boys Hope/Girls Hope Program House Manager Chelsea Breckenridge to deliver the finding for the above stated allegation. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch Special Investigator (SI) Annette Renquist. The investigation included interviews with Program Director, Staff #1 (S1), Child #1 (C1), Child #2 (C2), Child #3 (C3), Child #4 (C4), Child #5 (C5), and Fullerton Police Department officers. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On June 4, 2021 Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging Staff member (Staff #1 [S1]) sexually abused group home child (Child #1 [C1]). Specifically, it was reported between August 2020 and February 2021, S1 would touch C1 inappropriately while in the facility and while being transported. Additionally, it was reported on at least two occasions S1 took C1 from the facility in the middle of the night ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE***

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights: (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child... specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, as applicable. (11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by Based on record review and confidential interviews the facility did not ensure Child #1 (C1) was free from sexual and emotional abuse when Staff #1 (S1) inappropriately touched C1 and took C1 from facility to have sex which posed an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care.

narrative: On September 2, 2021 at 1:30 PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the group home (GH) administrator, Briana Ramirez, to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On August 23, 2021, the Department concluded a complaint investigation under this GH. The complaint alleged that Child Care Coordinator #1 (S1) engaged in sexual acts with fifteen-year-old client #1 (C1) (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated September 2, 2021) The confidential interviews and S1 acknowledging performing multiple lewd and lascivious sexual acts, on separate occasions, with C1 were consistent. The allegations were substantiated and the GH was cited under the Title 22 Regulations, Section 84072(d)(11). Based on the analysis of the Fullerton Police report and Licensing Special Investigative Bureau report, the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for the physical abuse of C1. The Penal Code section 288a defines sexual conduct with a minor as physical abuse. This section describes a number of more or less direct and (always) willful acts that constitute sexual assault, as defined in the Health and Safety (H&S) code section 1548 (f)(1)(E). The Department will be issuing an immediate civil penalty of $2,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, Appeal Rights and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the administrator.

On September 21, 2022 at 10:30 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with Program Director Briana Ramirez. The home is a one story residence with a total of seven bedrooms (four staff bedrooms and three client bedrooms) and four bathrooms (two client and two staff). One client was present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. At 10:45 am, the hot water in client bathroom 1 of 2 was measured to be 121.6 degrees Fahrenheit. At 10:50 am, the hot water in the client bathroom #2 of 2 was measured to be 116.7 degrees Fahrenheit. At 11:00 am, the hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 120.7 degrees Fahrenheit . All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. In the staff office there is a locking cabinet for medications. At this time, there are two clients prescribed medication. Cleansers/chemicals, cooking knives are accessible to clients based on the prudent parent guidelines and program statement approval. The facility's smoke detectors in all bedrooms were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detectors located in the hallways were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Program Director Briana Ramirez. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, and current menu. LPA observed a minimum seven day non-perishable and a two day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

LPA reviewed four of four client files and all files contained necessary documents required for inspection. LPA reviewed four of four staff files. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigation and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. LPA left the facility at 1:30 pm to take a 30 minute lunch break and drive to the corporate office, located in Irvine, to review staff files. Based on records review, Client #1 and Client #2 did not have a Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record. The facility is being cited for violation of CCR Section 80075(k)(7), Health-Related Services. Based on records review, Client #1 and Client #2 did not have a record of current medications, including the name of the prescribing physician, and instructions, if any, regarding control and custody of medications. The facility is being cited for CCR Section 80070(b)(10), Client records. Exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were discussed. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report will be emailed to Program Director Briana Ramirez. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carolyn Flynn made an attempt to complete the annual inspection at the above listed facility on 9/10/2021 at 10:30 AM. The home was dark and there was a for sale sign by Intero Reality in the front yard. LPA waked around the facility and all doors were locked and no one answered the knocking or the facility listed phone number. During the course of conducting interviews for a complaint allegation, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder was made aware that a client AWOL’d from the facility. The client was upset throughout the day and according to staff interviews, the client’s interview, and the incident report related to the complaint, the client had communicated and attempted multiple times to leave the house and run away. Prior to awoling from the home, the client was involved in an incident that escalated, resulting in a restraint and then released from the restraint. Eventually the client exited the home while the staff observed the client from inside the home, at a window. There is discrepancy as to why the client was able to exit the home this particular time, when multiple attempts had been made and verbalized by the client about leaving the home and prevented. The client left the property and staff were not able to communicate which direction the client went, and at what time, nor did staff “shadow” the client. Staff did not have client in line of sight at all times, resulting in client leaving the grounds of the home, running into a grocery store and having law enforcement return the client to the home. Staff and incident reports indicate this client has a history of attempting and succeeding at Awoling from the home.

The police report states the client did not have any skin tissue or blood under fingernails or on the client’s hands. Staff involved in the altercation with the client state none of them scratched the client or saw another staff scratch the client’s face. Because of the inconsistencies and lack of corroboration, the allegation is determined to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal process was emailed to the administrator at pam@brightfuturesres.com.

On 12/23/2024 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan-Shanks conducted a Component II - Face to Face Meeting at the Monterey Park Regional Office via Teams. The following were present: Ayan Hill, Applicant/Licensee. LPA and LPM discussed their application and program statement and advised of the following corrections. The following information must be completed and submitted to Licensing: Section A · LIC 401 Monthly Operating Statement Operating section line 4 and 6 need to be completed and recalculated and other revenue added to line 4, fill out line 6. · LIC 402 Surety Bond with original embossed seal. LPA will pick it up from the Licensee at the time of pre-licensing. · LIC 403 Addition needs to be corrected on the form. · LIC 404 Financial Information Release and Verification – pending response from the financial institution. · LIC 500 has no Facility Manager Position for each shift that would require Facility Manager. No on-call person identified. Please provide the Administrator Qualification Verification according to the Title 22 Regulations {84064 (e)}. · LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential will require at least 3 people to be assigned to the tasks. Licensee can put TBD next to the position. Once positions and personnel are established, each designee’s phone number and e-mail will need to be provided on the form. We would need letters from the relocation sites for the permission to relocate children in a case of emergency. Licensee will change the park location to a different relocation site and will provide a letter. Continue on the Page 2

Page 2 · LIC 508D for the Administrator is not included. Licensee will send form to the LPA. · LIC999 All rooms need to be labeled for the ambulatory vs non-ambulatory, staff, or clients’ bedroom, how many clients in each bedroom, all windows and exits noted, locations of utility shut-off. Facility yard sketch needed to be attached with all the requested information. · Completed fire clearance form LIC 850 was e-mailed to the LPA by the applicant/licensee during the Component II Section B · Part I - Program Identification · Part II - Program Population, Services & Capabilities · Part III · Part III Section 6. Medical/Dental · Describe the procedures of administering medications, what forms will be used for regular medications and psychotropic medications and refusal procedures (Use of Medication Administration Records (MAR LIC 622A) and Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR LIC 622B)). Identify staff positions responsible for dispensing and destroying the medications. Consent forms, completed by the child's authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care. Section 7. Transportation. · Facility will utilize the facility vehicle, as a last resort will utilize staff vehicles. Safety of the vehicle will be checked. Driver licenses will be checked during the application process. Continue on the Page 3

Page 3 Section 8. Admission/Intake · Will you be taking emergency placement. Then describe the procedures. · If the placement is not compatible, how will the client and representative will be notified. · Admission agreement needs to be provided or if the agency will be using the placement agency admission form. Section10. Discharge/Removal Policies · How will the Policies and Procedures be provided to Children and Authorized Representatives. Written Removal/Discharge Policies Developed and Maintained by Social Work Staff. Discharge cannot occur without notifying the authorized representative. Timeline for emergency discharge. Section 11. Visitation rules and policies. · Add Visitation is allowed unless it is documented in the NSP or court order if visits from the person is not allowed. · Specify when visits are not permitted. Visits will occur based on the Needs and Services Plan. Section 12. House rules · Specify curfew hours and quiet hours. Policy of allowing children to be unsupervised away from the facility including issuing passes to children. How will the clients and their representatives will be notified and made aware of the house rules. Using Reasonable and Prudent Parent standard when crating and enforcing house rules. Bedroom sharing. Section 14. Emergency Intervention Plan · If manual restraints not used, what is the alternate procedures if the de-escalation techniques do not work? Continue on the Page 4

Page 4 Section 15 Runaway Plan: · No manual restraints should be used to prevent runaway. Section 16. Children complaints and grievance procedures. · How are the clients informed of their rights to file a complaint or grievance. Where is Complaint/Grievance form kept for easy access. How will clients and their authorized representatives and staff receive copies of the written complaint/grievance procedures. Section 17. Handling of Children’s Funds, Allowances and Salaries. · Provide the amount of allowance and the date it will be dispersed. It must be a set amount and age appropriate, and it may not be withheld for the children not doing their chores. The children can earn extra doing the extra chores. Accurate record keeping by maintaining the receipts and not comingle with licensee funds. Policies on handling the cash resources upon discharge. 18. Chores · How are clients and the representatives notified about the chores and earning extra money doing the chores. Applying Reasonable and Prudent Parent Standards to the process of teaching the children various chores. Section 21 Staff Schedule. · Add Facility Manager to the schedule. Section 22. Staff Qualifications. · Add Facility Manager position and Qualifications. · Add education for the Administrator based on the Title 22 Regulations. Continue on the Page 5

Page 5 Section 23. Facility Manager Job Description. · Therapist listed on the job description, change to social worker. Section 25 Administration · Provide a current organizational chart which shows lines of administrative authority. · Facility will not utilize cameras at this time, will add it if need arises. The Pre-Licensing inspection and Component III is scheduled for 01/17/2025. A signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant. Exit interview.

On 01/17/2025 at 10:33 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Olena Maico conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPAs met with Ayan Hill, Licensee. LPA Maico conducted a physical plant inspection inside and outside the home alongside with the applicant. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a single level home located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 4 bedrooms, 2 full bathrooms, a living room, kitchen, dining room, 2-car garage, laundry room, and a backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has no bodies of water. LPA observed the facility sketch posted on the wall as well as the Administrator Certificate, visitation policies, grievance procedures and children's personal rights. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 70 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 117 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguisher located in the laundry room. Knives and sharps are kept in a locked container above the refrigerator in the kitchen. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the cabinet located under the sink and are locked. The facility has a working telephone. The Emergency disaster plan is posted next to the telephone. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. Facility will be licensed for 5 clients and clients will be utilizing all 4 bedrooms. Bedroom #1, #2 and # 3 each has 1 full bed and a side drawer, storage drawer and adequate closet space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belonging. The closets have hampers and laundry bags, as well as the hangers for the clients. Bedroom # 4 has 2 full beds and adequate storage to accommodate 2 clients' needs as well as it has a side drawer and drawers for clients' belongings. Bedrooms have appropriate window blinds for client's privacy and the lights in the rooms work properly. Bedrooms can be used by ambulatory and non-ambulatory clients. Applicant was informed for the bedroom # 4 which has 2 full beds cannot have both ambulatory and non-ambulatory clients at the same time.

LPA observed two bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Bathroom #1 has 2 sinks, shower with the shower curtain and non-slip mat, and a toilet, and will be used by both staff and clients. Bathroom # 2 located inside bedroom # 4 and has 2 sinks, shower with a non-slip mat and a working toilet and will be used by clients. The shower and the sinks and toilets are in working condition. Individual beds are observed to be in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows, as well as appropriate clean linens in good repair. LPA also observed extra linens stored in the hallway closet. Medications will be centrally stored in the lockboxes in the kitchen cabinets. Complete first aid kit is readily available in the kitchen and contains all the necessary items. Clients' files will be stored electronically on the tablet in the kitchen area. Kitchen has a refrigerator, dishwasher,stove and adequate utensils and tableware to accommodate the number of clients. LPA observed the kitchen area to be clean and the refrigerator is clean. LPA observed emergency food supply storage in the kitchen. Licensee has no kids in placement, food will be stocked once children are in placement. LPA also observed a complete food menu posted on the kitchen table. Dining room has a table with 5 chairs to accommodate clients and the living room has a working TV and couches with enough room for 5 clients. Backyard is free of hazards and has enough space for the clients to use. There are no cameras inside the home. There is a ring door bell and licensee has no access to it. Licensee is aware if cameras will be installed, they will notify the licensing agency. LPA also received original surety bond from the licensee today at the pre licensing. The fire department clearance was granted. Before today's visit, the applicant submitted the final Program Statement/Plan of Operation to LPA Maico. LPA Maico will submit it for final review, and a new license will be mailed to the licensee upon approval. During the pre-licensing a Component III was conducted on what to expect after licensing. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.
