met_with: Travis Bates, Facility Manager Ayan Hill, Administrator
narrative:
On 03/26/2025 at 08;45 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of continuation of post licensing inspection. LPA met with the Administrator Ayan Hill and Facility Manager Travis Bates. Physical Plant domain was reviewed during the initial post licensing. During the previous visit LPA Maico requested documents and the administrator e-mailed the requested information to the LPA. LPA received a copy of the LIC 500 and the Client Roster LIC 9020, as well as LIC 308 and LIC 610C. A review of Licensing Information System on 03/25/2025 indicates that all facility staff associated to the Group Home have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Index clearances. LPA also reviewed 4 electronic staff files, 2 electronic children file, interviewed 2 staff. Residents were afforded the opportunity to be interviewed and all residents declined. Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. LPA reviewed emergency drill binder, no drills recorded in the binder yet, as they are conducted quarterly, and the facility has not done one yet. LPA advised the Facility Manager to add phone number and e-mails to the person designated on the emergency disaster plan. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client electronically, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party.

Client Records LPA reviewed two (2) client records. All client records are available to the licensing to review electronically. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, personal rights acknowledgement, immunization records, personal property and valuables, cash resources records, authorization to medical treatment. Facility also has medication administration record with the medication information, as well as the information for the prescriber and medication administration instructions. Clients do not take psychotropic medications currently. Clients are scheduled to have their doctor's appointment (one on 03/27/25 and one pending scheduling) before 30 days from placement date. Staff Records Staff records are stored electronically in the cloud. LPA reviewed 4 staff files. Staff files are electronic and contain staff job duties, resumes, CPR training, medical screening and TB test, personnel records, driver license, criminal record and child abuse clearances. Staff records were missing proof of initial 8 hour training for the staff, as well as emergency intervention training. Two deficiencies will be issued to the facility regarding staff training and emergency intervention training. LPA was not able to verify the health screening or TB test for the S3. Two deficiencies will be issued for this section. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC809Ds, LIC811 and appeal rights were provided and explained to the facility manager.

On 03/14/25 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Olena Maico conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPA met with Ayan Hill, Licensee. LPA Maico conducted a physical plant inspection inside and outside the home alongside with the applicant. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a single level home located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 6 bedrooms, 3 full bathrooms, office, a living room, kitchen, dining room, 2-car garage, laundry room, and a backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has no bodies of water. LPA observed the facility sketch posted on the wall as well as the Administrator Certificate, visitation policies, discipline policies, grievance procedures and children's personal rights. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 68 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 116 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguisher located between bathroom #2 and bedroom #2. Licensee installed manual fire hand pulled alarm per Bakersfield City Fire Department request. Knives and sharps are kept in a locked container in the kitchen cabinet. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the locked box in the garage. The kitchen sink also has a lock and that is where the cleaning solutions and chemical will be kept once the facility is operational. The facility has a working telephone. The Emergency disaster plan is posted next to the telephone. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. Facility will be licensed for 6 clients and clients will be utilizing all 6 bedrooms. All bedrooms have 1 full bed and a side drawer, storage drawer and adequate closet space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belonging. The closets have hampers and laundry bags, as well as the hangers for the clients to use. Bedrooms have appropriate window blinds for client's privacy and the lights in the rooms work properly. Bedrooms can be used by ambulatory and non-ambulatory clients.

LPA observed three bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Bathroom #1 has a sink, shower with the shower curtain and non-slip mat, and a toilet.. Bathroom # 2 located inside bedroom # 3 and with 2 sinks, shower with a non-slip mat and a working toilet. Bathroom #3 has a sink, bathtub with the shower with non-slip mat, and a toilet. Individual beds are observed to be in good repair, equipped with mattress in a good condition and pillows, as well as appropriate clean linens in good repair. LPA also observed extra linens stored in the hallway closet of the facility. Medications will be centrally stored in the lockboxes in the kitchen cabinets. Complete first aid kit is readily available in the kitchen and contains all the necessary items. Clients' files will be stored electronically on the tablet in the kitchen area. Kitchen has a refrigerator, dishwasher, stove and adequate utensils and tableware to accommodate the number of clients. Licensee has no kids in placement, food will be stocked once children are in placement. LPA also observed a complete food menu posted on the kitchen table and the schedule of activities. Dining room has a table with 6 chairs to accommodate clients, as well as 4 stools by the kitchen island area. and the living room has a working TV and couches with enough room for 6 clients. Games are located on the kitchen counter. Office has room for the employees to sit and the federal and stater labor law posters. Backyard is free of hazards and has enough space for the clients to use. No equipment stored on the back yard. There are no cameras inside the home. Each room has motion alarm attached to the wall and it is connected to the security system, alarm is not currently active. LPA also received original surety bond from the licensee today at the pre licensing. The fire department clearance pending. LPA sent another fire clearance request. LPA reviewed Guardian website clearance and the Administrator is cleared and associated to the facility. The facility will be utilizing the same Program Statement as the Brighter Day Group Home that was already approved by licensing. The copy of this report was provided and explained to the licensee.

narrative:
On 06/12/25 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Olena Maico conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPA met with Ayan Hill, Licensee and Administrator of the Facility and Travis Bates, Facility Manager. LPA also reviewed Guardian associations to the facility and found all the staff to have clearance or exemptions and being associated to the facility. LPA Maico conducted a physical plant inspection inside and outside the home alongside with the Administrator. The following were observed at the time of inspection: Physical Plant This facility is a single level home located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 6 bedrooms, 3 full bathrooms, office, a living room, kitchen, dining room, 2-car garage, laundry room, and a backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has no bodies of water. LPA observed the facility sketch posted on the wall as well as the Administrator Certificate, visitation policies, discipline policies, grievance procedures and children's personal rights. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 68 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 109 degrees (F). Facility has carbon monoxide and smoke alarms throughout the facility. The fire extinguisher located between bathroom #2 and bedroom #2 and fully charged. Continue PG 2

Pg 2 Knives and sharps are kept locked in the kitchen cabinet and also some of them are in the garage in the locked box. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the locked box in the garage as well. Some of the chemicals also kept in the kitchen drawers and are locked. The facility has a working telephone. The Emergency disaster plan is posted next to the telephone. LPA advised the Administrator to add phone number and e-mail for one staff in charge of the emergency plan. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards All bedrooms have 1 full bed and a side drawer, storage drawer and adequate closet space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belonging. The closets have hampers and laundry bags, as well as the hangers for the clients to use. Bedrooms have appropriate window blinds for client's privacy and the lights in the rooms work properly. Kitchen has a refrigerator, dishwasher, stove and adequate utensils and tableware to accommodate the number of clients. Dining room has a table with 6 chairs to accommodate clients, as well as 4 stools by the kitchen island area. The living room has a working TV and couches with enough room for 6 clients. First aid kit located in the kitchen and has all the necessary and required items. Medications will be centrally stored in the lockbox in the office. Currently no clients are taking medications. Office has room for the employees to sit and the federal and stater labor law posters. Backyard is free of hazards and has enough space for the clients to use. No equipment stored on the back yard. The facility has been approved to use cameras, but licensee has not installed any cameras yet. Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. LPA reviewed emergency drill records on the Administrator's laptop. LPA advised the Administrator to add phone number and e-mails to the person designated on the emergency disaster plan. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client electronically, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party. Continue PG 3

Pg 3 Emergency Intervention: Staff has training in Emergency Intervention and it is recorded in staff files. Staff being currently trained in CPI and facility has been just approved for usage of Manual Restraints. No restraint will be conducted until all the staff is trained in CPI. Staff files Staff records are stored electronically in the cloud. LPA reviewed 5 (five) staff files. Staff files are electronic and contain staff job duties, resumes, CPR training, medical screening and TB test, personnel records, driver license, criminal record and child abuse clearances, initial 8 and 16 hour training along with the Administrator's job performance review. Client Records LPA reviewed two (2) client files. All client records are available to the licensing to review electronically. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, personal rights acknowledgement, immunization records, TB tests, personal property and valuables, cash resources records, authorization to medical treatment, record of cash allowance received. LPA interviewed 2 (two) staff. LPA attempted interview 1 (one) client and client refused. Another client was asleep at the time of the visit and LPA was not able to conduct the interview. No deficiencies are issued at the time of visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report and LIC811 were provided and explained to the Facility Manager.

investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report that supersedes the report dated 03/02/2021. On 03/02/2021 at 1:15pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Tana Kinder met with Group Home administrator to deliver complaint investigation findings. Prior to the meeting, LPA Kinder reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports & facility personnel report summary. LPA conducted a tele-inspection of the group home in & out, using Facetime due to Covid19. LPA reviewed the following documents for the complaint: Facility Sketch, IPP for 1 client, Behavioral Plan for 1 client, Dr. Ward's recommendations for home medical treatment for an injury to 1 client, 1 client’s school behavioral plan & tracking & 2 pictures of injuries sustained by 1 client. LPA conducted confidential interviews that consisted of the following: 2 facility staff, 1 school employee & 3 clients from 2/8/21-2/22/21. The allegation is: Minor sustained injuries while in care. Staff indicated the client microwaved cocoa while the only staff on duty was helping another client get ready for school. The client that made the cocoa has a reported history of getting into & taking food; & recently of trying to use the microwave without supervision or assistance. Based upon the interview of the staff present for the incident, corroboration of the staff’s statement & documented photos the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 80078 (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This was not met as evidenced by: Based on the interview with staff present during incident, the facility did not ensure proper care and supervision to client resulting in client burning self while microwaving cocoa.This poses an immediate personal rights, health and/or safety risk to clients in care.

narrative:
An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 3/07/2022 with the Program Director. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the agency. The licensing fees are current. The Group Home Facility has a capacity of 6 and currently 6 residents. LPA reviewed 4 staff files, all which were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 2 child files were reviewed. The child’s needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan, and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. Additionally, the child’s file had a record of personal rights. Personal rights, menu, license, and emergency exit plan were posted. The facility was inspected jointly with the Program Director of the Facility. LPA interviewed 2 clients, all of which had intellectual disabilities. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Each client's bedroom had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket, pillows and personal affects. The common areas have couches and chairs to sit in, a TV and games for the clients. The facility is in good repair. There are cabinets in the hall way with additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets. The passageway from the front to the back of the facility is unobstructed. LPA observed 1 locked shed in the backyard with equipment. The backyard has exercise equipment and lawn furniture. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 6 clients for 4 days/3 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 1 fully charged fire extinguisher. Continued

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were in a locked cabinet. Sharps were kept locked. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 6 clients. The water temperature from the kitchen faucet was 108.8 degrees. Medication disbursement is logged and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs and the bottled medications that are stored in a locked cabinet. The client's hygiene kits are stocked and kept in their bedrooms. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the medication cabinet. Exit interview conducted and discussed with the Program Director. No citations were issued and a copy of the annual inspection report was provided to the Program Director.

Based on evidence obtained and witness interviews conducted during the investigation process, the above allegation cannot be substantiated because there were inconsistent statements. Witness interviews and evidence obtained revealed that C1 has a history of making false allegations and that C1 had a “crush” on a client residing in a different home. Furthermore, it was reported that children are never allowed in a bedroom unless it’s theirs, that children are properly supervised, and witnesses are adamant the inappropriate touching did not happen between the clients as there was no opportunity. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and Appeal Rights were provided to the licensee.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez made an unannounced inspection on April 25, 2024 at 10:30 A.M. During the inspection LPA met with Happy Omoighe and Irene Ogbeiwe who assisted with the inspection. LPA Luman-Gonzalez conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. At the time of LPA's arrival no one was at the facility. LPA called FA who arrived within 15 minutes. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection was 2 staff members with no clients present at the home. LPA interviewed 2 staff but there were 1 client(s) home by the time of the inspection was complete. LPA observed 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant LPA observed the Facility License posted upon entry, above the dining room table along with other necessary paperwork, including Personal RIghts, Emergency Prevention Plan etc. The refrigerator was observed to be well stocked with both perishable and non-perishable foods for a minimum of 7 days. The temperature of the fridge was below 45 degrees F and the Freezer was tested at below 0 degrees. The week's menu was posted on the fridge door with snacks available for clients to access in the pantry cabinets. A working telephone was observed in the facility, on the kitchen counter. All Smoke Detectors and Carbon Monoxide Detectors were functioning properly. First Aid, Medications, and Sharps are all locked in the cabinet. All furniture observed in the common area, dining area, and bedrooms was observed to be in good repair and adequate number of seats for the clientele placed in the home. Hot water was tested in at 105.6 degrees F. Fire extinguisher was observed to be fully charged. (Page 1 of 3)

Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good repair with hot water accessible to the rooms. Soap and Paper Towels were placed in each bathroom for clients use. Laundry Facilities are located in the garage area and all chemicals for laundry are locked away until time of use. Linens and Bathing Towels are located in the hallway closet. Red Mini-Van used for the facility was observed to be in working condition and properly maintained. Tires, lights, and seat belts all functioning properly. Vehicle is currently registered and insured. Facility was observed to be free of vermin. In the backyard, there is a locked storage shed containing extra chairs and holiday decorations. Operations LPA observed in the clients binders that contained the compliant procedures and grievance policy is reviewed with clients and families. LPA reviewed Board Meeting Minutes and the CQI Report. Disaster Preparedness Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan is updated on the board above the dining room table for LPA's review. Monthly fire drills are conducted in the facility with the clientele. Disaster preparedness supplies are ready in the garage area. Emergency Intervention Manual Restraints are not used in this Facility. Facility is certified for ProACT but have not had to use the restraints in a significant time period. Staff is trained annually. Staffing/Volunteers LPA reviewed 4 Staff files. All files contained Criminal Records Clearances, Current First Aid Certifications, Current Training Certificates for all Staff with logs. All files contained Personnel Reports, stating the job title and qualifications. Certified Administrators certificate valid and current. Client Records LPA reviewed 4 Client Files. All Needs and Services Plans were completed. Centrally Stored Medication Log was observed to be complete according to guidelines and Psychotropic Medications log was reviewed. Cash Resources was reviewed and Compatibility Assessment was observed to be completed in the clients file. (Page 2 of 3)

The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees · Administrator Certificate for: Happy Omoighe · Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565) · Annual Emergency Intervention Log · Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 500, LIC 610C and LIC 308 · Waivers and Exceptions An exit interview was conducted with Irene Ogbeiwe and a copy of this report was left with the Facility.

Physical Plant Room 1 is a client bedroom with a twin sized bed, two dressers and a locked closet that stored a water heater. Room 2 is a client bedroom with a twin size bed two dressers and closet. Room 3 is a client bedroom with a twin size bed two dressers and closet. Room 4 is a client bedroom with a twin bed, two dressers, a printer, and has a bathroom attached to it. Room 5 is the kitchen that has a menu listed on the refrigerator, sharps locked under the sink, and both the fridge and freezer are at the appropriate temperature. There is an alcove with a washer and dryer in the hallway leading towards the clients bedrooms. Room 6 is the family room with couches, a working telephone, games, and a television. There are two bathrooms, one is located in the hallways to the left of the washer and dryer and the other is connected to Room 2. The first bathroom had a working toilet, and running warm water with a temperature of 114 degrees. The second bathroom had a working toilet, and running warm water with a temperature of 112 degrees. The home has sufficient activities for the clients, including board games, coloring books, a television, and all furniture is in good repair. The backyard is gated with a covered back patio, a shed, and a variety of plant vegetation. The backyard is clear of debris and clean. Toilets wash basin, bath, and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature. Soap and paper towels are available to clients. Bedrooms had all required linens and furnishings. The facility is free of vermin. The following domains were also reviewed during today’s inspection, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, Staffing, and Client Records. A total of 4 staff files and 2 client files were reviewed. No out of compliance issues were identified for these domains. LPA also conducted 2 staff interviews and no concerns for follow up was noticed. LPA attempted 1 client interview but was unable to conduct it due to client being non-verbal. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility fees and all the staff were fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the facility, no deficiencies cited.

First Aid kit is complete and fully stocked. All smoked detectors are up to date and working properly. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. . All sharp objects and Medication, cleaning supplies and knives are locked away. Medication logs were inspected. LPA observed the facility using one MAR for both psychotropic and non- psychotropic medication. LPA left a copy of LIC 622 A and LIC 622 B, so the facility can update their medication logs.LPA also noticed that the facility does not have a section in the MAR for medication refusal. The facility is currently using the outdated LIC 613 (Personal Rights Form). During inspection, the facility obtained a copy of the current LIC 613 and will update each file. [please refer to LIC 809-C for continuation page]

At 11:02 AM LPA reviewed all 7 staff files. All files were complete and each staff have the required training. All staff are associated to the facility as well. LPA obtained copies of the following documents: LIC 500, LIC 610, Updated Administrator certificate, and LIC 308. No deficiencies were cited during todays inspection, but the facility was issued four advisory notes LIC 9102. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

On 11/14/22 at 12:11PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Mark Del Rosario and Licensee/Administrator Rhodora Del Rosario and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete today's inspection. LPA conducted a tour of the facility site and grounds, inspected facility records, and interviewed three staff and observed six residents. The residents are dressed in clean, well-fitting clothes and appear to engage comfortably with staff and with the home environment. Staff are responsive to residents, and residents are responsive to staff. Residents follow a routine upon return from school and have activities ready for them to keep them engaged at home. The house is clean and free of obstructions. The kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The backyard offers outdoor activities for the residents. Bedrooms are clean with plenty of storage, and each resident has their own bed with clean linens. Chemicals, sharps, and medications are stored where inaccessible to residents. Medication administration records match the prescription labels and medication documentation. There is food in the quantity and quality necessary to meet the needs of residents in care. Resident files are complete. Staff files are complete. All staff have received the required hours of annual training and are trained in emergency de-escalation. All staff whose files were reviewed are cleared and associated to the facility. Two items require follow-up: 1) A psychotropic medication, Keppra, is not logged on a separate log for residents taking this medication. LPA advises that this is an anticonvulsant, which are psychotropic medications, and thus should be logged as other psychotropic medications are; 2) One staff member's first aid certificate expired last month and needs to be updated. There are no citations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee Mark Del Rosario, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 11/28/23 at 1 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Celeste Aparicio and Mariah Hawkins made an unannounced annual inspection. LPA's met with Facility Manager Yvette Salandanan and spoke with Administrator Mark Del Rosario over the phone who was unable to be present for this annual inspection. LPA's inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. Bathroom water temperatures measured within range. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 73 degrees. No firearms or weapons are present in the facility. LPA's noticed an unanchored play structure outside and issued a Technical Advisory. At this time the inspection is not complete, so LPA Aparicio will return to complete the inspection. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Yvette Salandanan, Facility Manager. A copy of this report was provided at the completion of this inspection.

On December 1, 2023 an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Celeste Aparicio at Buenavista Home at Pepperwood III. At 10:10am, LPA arrived at the facility and met with the Administrator, Rhodora Del Rosario. LPA informed Administrator that the purpose of this visit was to complete an annual inspection and review records. During the visit, LPA reviewed the disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention plan, client files, and cash resources. LPA conducted two staff interviews and was unable to interview clients because they are Non-verbal. Records of personnel/ staff members were reviewed to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a secure location. Six client files were reviewed. All client files were complete and in a secure location. Administrator informed LPA of the facility's plan to convert to an adult facility, since 50% of the population is now over the age of 18. Facility has one pending age exception request that was submitted in October. Administrator has already obtained her license for adult facilities and will be submitting a request to our department to convert within the coming months. No deficiencies were observed or cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Rhodora Del Rosario, Administrator, at 2:45 PM. A copy of this report was provided at the completion of this inspection.

met_with: Facility Manager Arjay Ventura; Licensee Mark Del Rosario
narrative: On 7/10/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins visited the facility to deliver notice of additional deficiencies found during a complaint investigation. LPA met Facility Manager Arjay Ventura at the facility and Licensee Mark Del Rosario over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interview, record review, and observation, these additional deficiencies were found. It was found that a minor in care was administered 3 doses of robitussin on 3/10, 3/11, and 3/12 and a morning dose on 3/13/24. Per the PRN authorization letter signed by the minor's physician, the physician should have been called about the robitussin after 72 hours if no improvement in condition. The minor had been observed over the course of these dates to be increasingly lethargic. Later that day, the minor was found unresponsive after a nap around 3PM, at which point the minor was transported to the hospital. Per licensee, the minor's neurologist had been consulted about another medication but not the robitussin since the minor had been given it on previous occasions without issue. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80075 Health Related Services. See LIC 809-D. It was found that a resident in care was supplied with a lunch consisting of five bags of chips, a pack of 17 girl scout cookies, a gatorade, a capri sun, and a container of chicken and rice, which was witnessed to be similar to a lunch provided to another resident in care. The LIC 602 Physician's Report for the former resident indicates that the resident's food also needs to be minced. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84076 Food Service. See LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Arjay Ventura.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80075(b)(5)… nonprescription PRN medication… (B) Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure physician's directions on PRN authorization letter were followed due to not calling the physician after 72 hours of administering PRN medication, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

84076(c)(5)(D) Food served to the child shall be healthy and meet any special dietary needs or practices, as documented in the needs and services plan for a child as reported by the child, or as recommended by the physician of a child. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure food provided in packed lunches to resident(s) in care met dietary needs and practices due to including a lot of unhealthy and un-minced food, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
PAGE 2: Substantiated Findings No staff members accompanied or followed behind. During the minor's hospital stay, the minor was noted to have a high supervision requirement due to high needs. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 84078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and 80075 Health Related Services. See LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Arjay Ventura.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/10/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins visited the facility to deliver findings for an investigation conducted in part by the licensing agency's Investigations Bureau (IB). LPA met Facility Manager Arjay Ventura at the facility and Licensee Mark Del Rosario over the phone and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, it was found that a minor in care with high needs was observed by staff to become increasingly lethargic after starting a new seizure medication. The day following the start of the new medication, the resident showed signs of a cold or similar virus, for which medication was also given. After three days of becoming increasingly lethargic, the minor was found to be unresponsive after staff tried to wake up the minor. The staff called the administrator, who arrived at the facility shortly after. It was the administrator who called 911. The minor was transported by ambulance to the hospital where the minor was observed to have significantly low blood pressure and body temperature and to test positive for rhinovirus. SEE PAGE 2.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80075(a) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical or dental services, including arrangement for and/or provision of transportation to the nearest available services. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure minor's health care needs were met due to not responding in a timely manner to minor's health condition due to not calling 911 immediately, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

84078(b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in the individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure minor's care and supervision needs were met due to not accompanying minor to hospital and ensuring availability to hospital staff to pick up minor, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

met_with: Licensee Mark Del Rosario, Facility Manager Kristian Laxamana
narrative: On 10/25/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Mark Del Rosario and Facility Manager Kristian Laxamana and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the facility site and grounds. LPA observed the facility to be well-maintained and free of hazards or dangerous objects. Chemicals, medications, and sharp objects such as knives are stored in locked cabinets/drawers where inaccessible to residents. There is a large supply of food that is maintained in safe condition. Bathrooms and kitchen are maintained in sanitary condition. LPA observed the first aid kit to be complete and stored in a central location in the facility. LPA inspected 5 personnel records, 5 resident records, and other required facility records. LPA observed all staff to have a background clearance. Records reflected the necessary annual training hours, first aid certification, and intervention training certification. The administrator has a current administrator certificate. LPA observed files to contain accurate resident information and medication records and current medication authorizations and care plans. LPA observed current staff schedules, emergency protocols, and menus in the facility. LPA conducted interviews of 2 staff and observations of 3 residents. LPA observed staff to be knowledgeable of facility procedures and the residents' care needs. LPA observed the residents to appear to have their care needs met and to be well-supervised by present staff. No deficiencies were observed during this inspection, and no deficiency citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Kristian Laxamana, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On July 19, 2023, at 10:00 AM, Component III of the application process for Build Bright Group Home located in Granada Hills was held at the El Segundo Children’s Residential Regional Office in El Segundo. Attending Component III were the following individuals: Christina Kiesselbach, Compliance Specialist, Ahron Lefkowitz (CEO), Devon Wayt, Compliance Specialist, Stephen Smith, Administrator, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray, LPA, Christine Wilson, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), JoAunne Griffin. The purposes of this Component III meeting were to discuss the Child’s and Personnel Records, to be documented, retained, maintained, available and posted at the facility for inspections. LPAs and LPM discussed the specific problems and issues of operating a Group Home, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food and hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Pre-Licensing inspection has been scheduled for Friday July 28, 2023 at 10 AM. A copy of this report was provided to the Ahron Lefkowitz .

On 07/16/24 at 3:00pm, LPA Christine Wilson, LPM Kevin Sauk and CEO Ahron Leftkowich joined in a Teams meeting online. The purpose of the meeting was to gain clarification on the proposed residential use of the ADU location, and the processes CCL utilizes to potentially support an application for a provisional license. LPA Wilson: Is your understanding that you would provide an application for separate licensing of the separate address? CEO, I wasn’t thinking about it in that regard and that is because its connected to the house. Same as a house with a back house and to incorporate it into the existing group home. At the time it seemed the only issue was the fire clearance. There is a separate entrance and three rooms. I wanted to use the space as a therapy room and the larger room as an office. That would free up the current office as a third bedroom. I wanted the same license and just to add the ADU to it. LPM Sauk: This was my understanding also; that you wanted a capacity increase from 4-6. If there is a hypothetical approval to do this, where would staff be stationed during the night shift? CEO: Staff will be in the main house because that is where the bedrooms would be. LPM Sauk: There is no direct access to the ADU from the main home. The ADU would have no bedroom usage? CEO Yes. We do not want clients coming through the office and would not want to have one in the ADU and others in the main house. This office will primarily be used for administrative use, and used as a space for staff to have meetings, and work space. Any staff on shift is on shift in the presence of clients. LPM Sauk: What do you need to do to gain clearance from the City? CEO Label the floorplan as a bedroom, change deadbolt to a handle. I was trying to coordinate between Fire and DSS and I may have gotten the wrong impression as to the use of each room in the house compared to the labeling of the rooms. When it came to the ADU my struggle and hesitation has been around the labeling of the bedroom when I would rather use it as a therapy room. Continues on page 2

Page 2 LPM Sauk: Is there any way to not have a separate address? If we license that, you would have to have two separate facility numbers. CEO: We want to use it for whatever we want to use it for. To remove that address I would have to do a lot of construction to remove the kitchen and further construction to attach it to the main house. We want the current license to be added on to the ADU. It cannot be a separate free-standing group home because of the number of rooms. LPM Sauk: You are not allowed to have meetings and client files in an address that is not licensed by us. What I can do is I can reach out to my supervisor to confirm that it could be the same license number. The fact that it has a separate address is a hurdle. CEO: Its also difficult because we are leasing. LPM Sauk: A suggestion could be, to maybe file for a relocation. It will cost you half of the relocation fees and you can find another property with the number of bedrooms and office space you need. How many clients do you have? CEO: we have no clients at this moment. Our population is teens with mental/behavioral health challenges and offering therapeutic services. We do not deal with addiction. We receive direct referrals from other programs. No one is living on the premises. LPM Sauk: I will reach out to my manager to understand if/how we could license the ADU. We have to see if this is a possibility for licensure or not. LPA Wilson: I will send you a report today, as if we met in person, for your signature. End of meeting 3:32pm

On December 15, 2020 at 4:00pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Rosslyn Gray conducting a Case Management Initiated inspection CALENDA Group Home. LPA was granted access to the facility virtually via FaceTime with the facility Director of Operations who provided a tour of the entire physical plant, inside and out. The Group Home is to provide care and supervision for six (6) foster children, ages 12-17 years Ambulatory Only. There is a (10 feet gated pool) on the premises that meets regulations (self-latching; unlocked 10 feet pool; 4 feet gate) The Director of Operation confirmed that there are no guns or weapons on the premises. This is a 1-story three (3) bedrooms; 4 1/2 bathrooms Group Home. There is a fully furnished living room, dining room and Central Air conditioning unit. The outdoor perimeter front yard, side yard and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. There is a Ping pong table and Weather proof patio furniture. All windows, screens and blinds from the inside and outside of the facility were observed to be in good condition. Garage has been converted in a gym with weights and exercise equipment that is monitored by staff. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan and personal rights). All required posting are posted on the wall front entrance of the facility (Personal Rights and Grievance forms and a comment box). Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients (stored in the staff office). All the children prescribed medications are locked in the staff office . LPA observed a hard wired enter connected combined Smoke detector and Carbon Monoxide; tested to be operable. Report continues on LIC-809-C

Living Room/Dining room/Kitchen: Observed to be clean and organized; fully furnished seater; book shelf, games and an exit French doors. The Kitchen stove is gas operated with 5 burners a double door refrigerator with bottom freezer. The dining table Dining area six (6) chairs, tow 2 bar stool chairs the spacing meets CDC-Guidelines for Social Distances. The sharp knives and chemicals are made inaccessible locked in container in the LPA observed coverage trash cans in the kitchen, bathroom and staff office. The Linen closet is located adjacent to the single bedroom. There are two (2) Fire Extinguisher- 1 Special K Grease Fire. The Hot Water Heater is enclosed with a secured strap. Bedrooms: There are three (3) Bedrooms each bedroom twin size beds six feet apart, with a mattress clean linen, adequate closet and drawer space. Client Common Restroom: Bedroom #1, #2, and #3 is occupied by one (1) client. Bedroom #4 is occupied by two (2) clients. Bathrooms- 41/2: The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. LPA observed S1 test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. The community restroom has 2 sinks, 1 toilet, and 1 shower. The ½ bath inside bedroom #2 has 1 toilet and 1 sink. The on-suite inside bedroom #4 has 2 sinks, 1 toilet, and 1 shower. The is a Classroom six (6) computers desk and six (6) additional employee desk. There are three (3) offices; Program Director, Therapist office and office Staff. There is a Well-ness station for the medication logs and medical devices. The First Aid kit has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. The Garage has been converted to a school setting for the clients and school supplies are provided by the facility. The facility has a working telephone and clients can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The staff accompanies clients to local recreational facilities based on the rules of the COVID-19. Other outside extracurricular activities and social events that take persons into public or crowded places have been canceled. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. The facility uses the “Token Economy System” for exhibiting appropriate behaviors and compliance. Report continues on LIC-809-C

LPA recommended that staff ensure that CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevent other from contracting the COVID-19 virus (i.e wash hands with alcohol based hand sanitizer, display colorful preventative hygiene posters, temperature checks, maintain social distancing (six feet of space), disinfect commonly used areas and items (remote controls, mouse’s, cards cell phones, practice “cough etiquette”. LPA suggest that the facility keep an inventory of the PPE supplies and to report when they are depleted. The Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 12/15/2020 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility administrator for signature 12/16/20200.

met_with: Kaycie Peterson, Trainer Toni Jackson-Rainey, Director of Operations
narrative:
On March 5, 2024, at 1:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up Case Management-Incident inspection to deliver findings concerning self-reported incident dated May 8, 2023. LPA Martin met with Toni Jackson-Rainey, Director of Operations to discuss the investigative outcome. On May 9, 2023, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) received an incident report from CALENDA facility reporting the death of youth #1 (Y1) who eloped from the facility by walking out the front door resulting in youth’s fatality as Y1 was struck and killed on the Northbound 101 Freeway (see LIC811, dated 3/5/2024). The incident was referred to and investigated by CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Douglas Real. On May 10, 2023, LPA Rosslyn Gray and Licensing Program Manager, JoAunne Griffin conducted a Case Management-Incident visit in response to the incident report, met with facility representative and obtained related documentation. The investigation, including confidential interviews with facility residents and employees as well as review of facility incident report, program, and protocols, determined a lack of evidence to support neglect or lack of supervision. The interviews revealed the residents felt safe in the facility and there was no concern for neglect or lack of supervision. There was no external factor such as conflict which triggered Y1 to elope from the facility. The staff members attempted to talk with Y1 and encourage Y1 to remain in the facility; however, their efforts were unsuccessful, and Y1 left the facility without warning on May 8, 2023, at approximately 10:00 PM. The facility was operating within approved staff to client ratios at the time of the incident. --(Continued on page LIC809-C)--

Based on employee interviews and the written report submitted by the facility the staff member followed the facility elopement policy. Y1 left the facility on their own free will and went onto the freeway where Y1 was struck by a vehicle. The staff called 911 immediately when Y1 eloped and reported the elopement as per facility policy. Based on confidential statements and documentary evidence, the investigation findings concerning neglect/lack of supervision are determined unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to Facility Representative.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and conducted an announced inspection of the facility on 10/6/2020 at 9:30 AM. LPA Belfield program administrator Dorothy Powers who assisted with the inspection. Also present during this inspection Shona, Jose, and Lydia. The department received and incident report describing that C1 and C2 ( see LIC 811 dated 10/6/2020) were involved in a physical altercation that resulted in both youth being discharged. LPA Belfield discussed the incident with the above staff of the facility. LPA Belfield requested the following documents from the facility; revised incident report to include missing information, client file documents, policies and procedures, staff, and client rosters. At this time the case management is not complete and a follow up will be conducted with the facility. There were no violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Dorothy Powers and a copy of this report will be sent to Dorothy Powers.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced tele-inspection ( via Microsoft Teams) of the facility on 2/3/2021 at 1:00 PM. LPA Belfield program met with Lydia Beall, Shona S. and staff Jose G. who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to discuss the facility not having an administrator present. Based on communication with previous administrator Dorothy P., Lydia Beall would possibly transition in the position of administrator once she left the program on 12/1/2020. LPA Belfield requested the information on the new administrator as well as a new LIC 500. This information was not received by the department. Today, LPA discussed with facility representatives that per the regulations, the facility must have an administrator on staff that is qualified and certified. Based on conversation with facility representatives today, it was confirmed that there has not been an assigned administrator since the departure of Dorothy P. and no information that was requested has been received in regards to hiring an administrator or transitioning a current staff member to be the administrator, which was previously discussed as a possibility. Facility cited for violation of section 84064 (b) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. LPA discussed with facility representatives that there have been no incident reports received by the department from their facility. Facility representative Lydia, stated they had incident reports that they would be sending to the department today.

It was also stated by Lydia B. that she experienced some computer malfunctions and was currently working on recovering the reports to submit to the department. Also discussed during this inspection was the need to make sure that the title 22 regulations are incorporated in the staff training's as it observed by this LPA that the licensing regulations and requirements are not completely known by staff due to all of the changes in staffing. A copy of the regulations regarding administrators was sent to Lydia B. and LPA Belfield advised the facility representatives to visit the CDSS website to obtain a copy of the entire regulations and obtain all required information. Lydia agrees to submit required information and proof of qualifications for the new administrator John Mulvey, who will be taking over the role of administrator for the facility. Information will be sent to the department by 2/17/2021. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84064 (b) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Lydia Beall.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced tele-inspection ( via Microsoft Teams) of the facility on 2/3/2021 at 1:05 PM. LPA Belfield met with staff Lydia Beall, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to discuss concerns with the program. The following topics were discussed: Based on communication with Lydia Beall on 2/3/2021 incident reports were submitted to the department. Upon review of these incident reports, it was noted that the signature was not updated and was signed by a past administrator, the incident reports were completed using the wrong form, and the incident reports lacked preventative and follow up information. These updates were addressed with Lydia Beall and LPA Belfield requested this updated information on a blank form. Staff Beall stated that she would submit this information to this LPA by the following business day 2/25/2021. Based on the inspection completed on 2/3/2021, the program had hired an administrator and was to send their information to the department to add them to their program. Staff Shona Sullivan sent LPA Belfield information for Lydia Beall to become the new administrator. LPA requested a letter from the board to confirm this change. LPA has not received this letter as of today 2/24/2021. LPA Belfield requested an new LIC500 to reflect staff schedules and positions. At 1:35 Shona Sullivan joined the meeting and at 1:40 Jose Gaona joined the meeting.

Next, LPA Belfield discussed with the facility staff, where to find all required forms on the CDSS website. LPA then sent emails to Shona and Lydia with the links to find the forms needed for incident reports (LIC624 and 624LE), program statement documents (LIC9106), application forms ( LIC200). LPA Belfield then requested a copy of the floor plan and policies and procedures for runaway's. LPA then discussed the program statement that was to be updated. An office visit was conducted with facility staff and it was reviewed that the program statement had not been updated in over 20 years. Due to all the changes the program has confirmed to have made, it is important that all necessary changes and updates be reflected. Upon discussion with staff Lydia a deadline of 3/15/2021 was given for the submission of the updated program statement for review. LPA had not received training information that was requested on 2/3/2021. staff Shona stated that she would send this information tomorrow 2/25/2021 in the afternoon. LPA informed staff that it appeared that were not as knowledgeable as they could be regarding the regulations and all that is required. LPA offered assistance in any way the department was able to assist them in coming into compliance. LPA also offered the use of attending a group home orientation if they were interested. Staff agreed to the lack of knowledge and stated they would be able to come into compliance. LPA discussed fingerprint clearances and staff associations. Staff Shona stated they previously sent disassociation's to the regional office and had not heard back on if they were complete. LPA discussed the Guardian website and the abilities that facilities have in checking statuses. LPA asked if there were any questions they had. There were none at this time. LPA contacted Lydia Beall on 2/25/2021 and asked if they would like to be referred the Technical Support Program (TSP). Lydia stated they would let this LPA know if they would participate.

During the discussion LPA Belfield explained the severity of the programs need to come into compliance. Staff stated they understood and were working on getting everything accomplished. LPA asked if program statement was almost complete and it was stated by Lydia that not much had been completed but it had to be reviewed further to know what was completed for sure because staff had changed. LPA stated they understood the changes that had taken place. LPA stated that it was important as well as their responsibility to review the regulations. There were no violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Shona Sullivan and Lydia Beall.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced tele-inspection ( via Microsoft Teams) of the facility on 3/9/2021 at 1:00 PM. LPA Belfield met with administrator Lydia Beall, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to discuss concerns with the program runaway policy. Based on communication with Lydia Beall on 2/3/2021 and 2/24/2021, protocol that is currently in place, requires residents to sleep in the classroom for the first night upon return form being awol, so that staff can monitor the resident. Upon review of this protocol by the department, it is determined that this protocol is in violation of the regulations. The facility is being cited for violation of section 84087(b)(4) Buildings and grounds. During this inspection, LPA discussed the progress of the program statement for the facility and asked administrator Beall if they would like to utilize Technical Support Program? Administrator Beall stated that facility would not like to participate at this time. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84087(b)(4) Buildings and Grounds. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to administrator Lydia Beall.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced tele-inspection ( via Microsoft Teams) with the facility on 4/2/2021 at 1:00 PM. LPA Belfield met with administrator Lydia Beall, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to discuss concerns with reporting requirements. Based on communications with Administrator Beall on 2/3/2021 and it was discussed that incident reports have not been received by the facility. Administrator Beall submitted incident reports to the department on 2/10/2021. On 3/29/2021 the department received three incident reports and one of the incidents was over a month ago, the other two were close to a month. Facility failed to report incidents within seven days as required by the California Code of Regulations. Facility cited for violation of section 80061(b)(1) reporting requirements. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80061 (b) (1) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Lydia Beall.

On 6/29/2022 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the above licensed facility. The purpose of the visit is to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Phyllis Meagher, CEO, and Alisha Eipp, HR Coordinator at the facility office at 11:35AM. LPA conducted a review of ten staff files. LPA conducted an interview with 1 staff member. The facility is in the process of putting files digitally. There were some documents missing from the staff files, but the facility was able to provide the documentation before the end of the inspection. LPA reviewed the emergency binder, which documented the training plan, emergency contacts, and quarterly emergency drills. LPA observed that the office was organized and in good repair. At 2:10PM, LPA Hood went to the facility grounds at 3192 Glen Canyon Rd. Scotts Valley, CA 95066. LPA was met by Ty Newcomb, Director of Facility Operations and Lydia Beall, Administrator. LPA, Director of Facility Operations, and Licensee conducted a walk through of the grounds. The facility had a current census of seventeen resident youth. The grounds include both adolescent and adult treatment centers, but the facility has multiple ways to keep the populations separated. The facility currently has female residents in the lower unit and male residents in the upper unit. LPA observed all rooms, bathrooms, common eating area, outdoor gym, outdoor pool, and kitchen. LPA observed that the pool had a fence over five feet tall. All chemicals and cleaning supplies are kept behind locked closets. Due to the nature of the residents' needs at this facility, staff also keep personal items such as mouthwash that may contain alcohol locked in the staff offices as well.

The facility has cooks which provide three meals and two snack times for the residents. LPA observed a posted menu and sufficient amounts of food in the kitchen. LPA measured water temperature in the bathroom of the male "suite" unit, which measured 111 degrees which is appropriate. LPA observed the facility to be clean, tidy, and in good repair. During the inspection, LPA observed that the facility had Naloxone in multiple places in the facility in locked first aid kits. The medical unit did have prescriptions on file for some residents as well as a statement about the use of Naloxone. LPA will follow up with a case management with the Health Assistant Director, Hillary Brandt, regarding training that staff have received on Naloxone. LPA was assisted by Lydia Beall, Administrator, in receiving the resident roster and client files. LPA observed the emergency binder which contained a face sheet for all of the residents with their names, authorized representatives, current medications, and physicians names. Of the seventeen residents, six of the residents had been at the facility for longer than thirty days. LPA reviewed the six residents files. LPA also reviewed the immunization records, medication logs, and medication binders which are kept in a separate health office on the grounds. LPA did not interview any residents at this time. All residents present had legal guardians or authorized parents, so LPA would need to ask permission from their guardian's before speaking with the residents. LPA did not observe any Title 22 deficiencies during this inspection. Due to the different offices, LPA conducted an exit interview via phone call with Phyllis Meagher, CEO, at 4:49PM. LPA will provide this report to CEO virtually to sign and return.

On 7/10/2023 at 11:58AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the office of the licensed facility, located at 1800 Glen Canyon Rd. Scotts Valley 95066. The purpose of the visit was to conduct the annual inspection. LPA met with James Schmidt, Director of Quality and Risk at 12:16PM. LPA reviewed the files for five staff members utilizing the CARE Tools. LPA conducted a site inspection at the facility address at 2:02PM. LPA met with Administrator, Tea Beradze. LPA observed the outdoor area, nurse's station, dining area, kitchen, female sleeping quarters, male sleeping quarters, and bathrooms. LPA observed the facility to be clean and in good repair. LPA observed there to be a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods. LPA surveyed the pool, which had a locking fence that was five feet high. The facility location services both adult and minor clients, the living quarters are separate and meal times are staggered to prevent the two groups coming in contact. LPA returned to the office at 1800 Glen Canyon Rd. Scotts Valley, 95066 to conduct the rest of the file review. Administrator, Tea Beradze assisted obtaining the files. LPA reviewed the e-files for four clients, LPA also reviewed medical binders and intake assessments. LPA will return at a later date to review operations, emergency management, and conduct interviews. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with James Schmidt, Director of Quality and Risk, at 4:02PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. LPA discussed this with Tea Beradze, Clinical Director (CD) at 11 AM on 2/15/24. This case management was opened to discuss an incident report the department received on 1/22/24 regarding two clients having sexual relations. Please see LIC 812 for details. Facility staff did not adequately supervise clients. This lack of supervision resulted in the incident happening and the facility will be cited. LPA Simien requested a client/legal guardian roster/contact list for September 2023. As a result of this visit, there is one General Licensing Standards violation (80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision(a)). The facility will be cited (see 809-D for details). Appeal rights were discussed and provided. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to CD.

On November 8, 2021 at 9:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted an announced Pre-licensing inspection at the above address. Upon arrival, LPA met with, Administrator, Michelle White (MW). LPA and MW toured the external and internal area of the facility. The following was observed at the time of inspection: Physical Plant This facility is a single level home located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 5 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, living room, mud room, kitchen, pantry, dining room, 3-car garage, laundry room, patio and backyard and a gated pool. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Knives and sharps item are kept locked in the mud room storage with disinfectants, cleaning solutions and first aid kits which contains all required supplies. Per MW, there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 71 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 115 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguisher located by the kitchen is fully charged. The facility has a working telephone including WIFI. A fire inspection was requested on November 1, 2021 conducted by Los Angeles County Fire Department for ambulatory clients. (cont...)

Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies Facility has five (2)(toilets), five (3) wash basins, and four (2) showers for clients' use. LPA observed adequate hygiene supplies including but not limited to shampoo, soap, toothbrush, toothpaste, and toilet paper. Clients will be utilizing bedroom #1 that has two twin size beds, one dresser and a closet. Bedroom #2 has two twin size beds, one dresser and a closet. Bedroom #3 has two twin sized beds, dresser and a closet. Bedroom #2 and bedroom #3 have a shared bathroom that has a lock for privacy. Bedroom #4 is a staff bedroom with a separate closet and bathroom. Bedroom #5 is a staff bedroom with a separate closet and bathroom. Each bed has clean pillows, pillow cases, bed sheets and blankets. Facility sketch, emergency disaster plan, house rules, grievance policy, menu, sexual and reproductive health care related rights, foster youth bill of rights and foster youth mental health bill of rights are posted on the wall in the kitchen area. Heath Related Services and Record Keeping Medications, client and staff records will be centrally stored and locked in the mud room locked door. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

On 08/22/2022 at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan, LPA Carrie Palmer, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan-Shanks, and San Bernardino Child Welfare Service Manager, Tracy Raymond conducted an meeting with facility representatives Michelle and Bruce White. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the issues of being dually licensed as a Group Home and County Resource Home. Michelle and Bruce White stated they are planning on moving out with their San Bernardino placement dependent to another address in order to keep both licenses. There is currently no clients in care in the Group Home. It was discussed that licensee cannot currently accept any placement's until licensee has relocated their Resource Family Home license. Michelle and Bruce White stated they will submit a timeline plan relocation of their County Resource Home license to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on or before Thursday, August 25, 2022. A copy of the report was provided to licensees.

met_with: Michelle White, Administrator & Bruce White, Facility Manager
narrative: On October 12, 2022 at 09:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility above for conducting a Post Licensing inspection of the Group Home (GH). The LPA met with above staff. LPA and above staff provided the LPA tour of the facility. The physical plant layout for the Group Home remains the same as was observed by the LPA during the Pre-Licensing Inspection conducted on November 08, 2021. The group home is adequately equipped to provide privacy for interviewing and is conveniently located for the public. The LPA observed locked file cabinets in storage rooms. The license is posted in a prominent and public location. There are currently no placements at this time. There is no other hired staff at the moment other than the Administrator and Facility Manager. LPA observed the licensee to be occupied in the home, however they are in the process of moving out. A new residence has been secured for the licensee to move in to. The lease agreement has been signed for the new residence. Licensee is waiting for county representatives to make a visit to the new residence in order for them to fully move in. Licensee will be moving out of this location within the next couple weeks. Licensee will send a weekly update to the Regional Office via e-mail every Monday until they are fully moved out. During today's inspection, the LPA observed no deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was provided to above staff.
