On April 11, 2022 at approximately 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a visit at the facility for the purposes of initiating a 2 Year Required inspection. LPA met with the representative listed above and discussed the purpose of the visit. During the visit, a walk-through of the facility was conducted. The facility is currently vacant and the last client moved out approximately 2 years ago according to the Administrator. PHYSICAL PLANT A walk-through of the physical plant was conducted at approximately 10:45 AM. The facility is a single-story home situated in a quiet residential area. The exterior of the facility was observed to be well-maintained and in good repair. After entering the front door, postings, including the License, Emergency Disaster Plan, and Complaint hotline numbers were prominently placed for any potential clients. Towards the left, a living room was observed to be clean, in good repair, and furnished with furniture and entertainment items for potential clients. Moving up, there is a kitchen and dining room. All kitchen cabinets and appliances were observed to be in good repair. No perishable food was observed due to the facility being vacant. There were a total of 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms for client use. All rooms were observed to be clean and furniture was observed to be in good repair. Mattresses were outfitted with mattress covers and linens were clean and tidy. Bathrooms were observed to have paper towel dispensers, trash bins with covered lids, and soap for potential client use. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be functional and a fire extinguisher was observed to have been serviced in the past year. Sharp objects, chemicals, and medication were securely stored in the staff office. In the back, there is a secure garage used for storing supplies. All indoor and outdoor passageways were free from obstruction. LPA advised that an annual continuation visit would need to be conducted. No deficiencies were observed or cited during this date.

On March 22, 2024 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted a visit at the facility for the purpose of an Annual inspection. LPA met with Luis Tobar, Supervisor and discussed the purpose of the visit. During the visit, a walk-through of the facility was conducted. The facility is currently vacant, with no clients. LPA observes that rooms 1 & 2 flooring needs to be replaced. Per Supervisor, the repair is scheduled after the basement flooring dries up well. The facility Supervisor will email LPA Robles once the repair is completed sometime in Summer. During the inspection, LPA conducted a physical tour (inside and out) and reviewed operational requirements: (physical plant; operations; disaster preparedness; emergency intervention plan and staff files). LPA was provided with the LIC 500, current LIC 610C, LIC 309, LIC 308. The new Group Home Administrator documents will be mailed to the Regional Office. LPA observes postings, after entering the front door. The License, Emergency Disaster Plan and complaint hotline numbers were prominently placed for potential clients. No perishable food was observed due to the facility being vacant. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be functional, and a fire extinguisher was observed. Sharp objects, chemicals, and medication were securely stored in the staff office. In the back, there is a secure garage used for storing supplies. All indoor and outdoor passageways were free from obstruction. LPA reviewed two (2) staff files that were provided by Human Resources staff, Sheila Davis. A review of Guardian and Licensing Information System on 03/21/24, indicates that all facility staff associated with facility have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index clearances. LPA interviewed one (1) staff at the facility. Based on the physical inspection of the facility and the records review, there are no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted with the facility representative and a copy of LIC 809, and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative Luis Tobar.

On 01/15/2021 at 11:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez conducted a Tele inspection via Microsoft Teams at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Post -Licensing inspection. This facility is to care for six (6) male, ambulatory clients, ages 12 through 17 years of age. LPA met with adult #1 (A1) and adult #2 (A2), who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out via Microsoft Teams. The home was observed as follows: This is a one-story home, located in a residential area with 3 dual occupancy bedrooms, 2 bathrooms, 1 staff office, Living room, kitchen and dining area. All bedrooms were observed to be equipped with two twin size beds, adequate drawer/dresser space, and lighting in each bedroom, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. There are no security bars on the windows throughout the facility, there are no bodies of water on facility premises, there are no fireplaces, and there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. Disinfectants/poisons were observed to be inaccessible to children, and in a securely locked area in the staff bathroom that it was locked at the time of the inspection. , Hallway closet: is locked and stores the first aid kit fully stocked, log binders, small refrigerator for medication, Epi pen and log medicine. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are operating properly in the home at the time of tele visit inspection. LPA observed two fully charged fire extinguishers available in the facility. All living areas within the facility were observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. (Continued on LIC809-C)

Bathrooms: There is a total of 2 bathrooms (1 in the hallway, and 1 by the staff office that is utilized for staff only), that are clean, safe, and in good repair. Kitchen: There is a refrigerator, microwave, fire extinguisher, and plenty of cabinet space. There is an adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable food supply. All stove burners self-ignited at the time of this inspection. A weekly menu was not posted in the refrigerator at the time of the inspection. There is also one adjacent and attached by the kitchen there is locked room call the lockout is where the staff bathroom is located more storage for basketballs, slip and slide and paperwork for the unit. Garage Area: is locked and equipped with refrigerator for staff, cabinets for cleaning supplies / detergents, Backyard: This large open area is free of obstructions. A detached storage shed was observed to be securely locked. Office: is located by the garage structure. This office stores staff and clients' files, client medication logs, computer, printer. Behind a locked door within the office During the inspection LPA discussed with A1 and A2 the deficiencies that were observed: 1. The bucket that was used for mopping was in the backyard next to a client without anyone supervising. 2. The tiles next to the sink did not have cocking at the edge of the sink 3. The Tupperware in the fridge had food on it, with no date on it. 4. There was no menu posted 5. The new STRTP provisional license with conditions was not posted in the facility . 6. The water heater was located in the living room, without a lock door. 7. The wood floor is scraped throughout the house. 8. Patches all over the house without painting. 9. Bathroom cabinet, without mirror just cover with a sheet of paper 10. No toilet paper holder in the bathroom. 11. Dresser in room #2 the paint was peeling . 12. The door frame of the room no. 3 paint was peeling walls need to be repaired and painted. 13. The staff restroom, should be clean and remove the following items: cleaning supplies, employee mailboxes, and the cooking knives. See 809-D Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Licensee, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

Additionally, during confidential interviews, clients and staff confirmed that the facility has not done randomly checked in the clients' rooms for contraband. C1 confirmed that he obtained the knife, the night before when he awoled the facility. Based on the interviews and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the Facility, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.
investigation_findings: 13On February 23, 2021 at 8:57am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an announce telephone call to Casa De Esperanza Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. LPA spoke with Staff #1 (S1) by phone, and together discussed the investigation details. During the confidential interviews conducted with all the parties involved during the investigation process and information gathered, the above allegations are substantiated, because there was corroboration from all relevant parties that S2 engage in a verbal altercation with C1, shoved C1 and C1 wanted to stab S2 with a rusty knife that was in his room. S2 confirmed that he shoved C1, because C1 shoved him first. Clients confirmed that S2 shoved C1 during the verbal altercation they were having. Clients and staff confirmed that C1 went to his room and came out with a rusty knife to follow S2 out in the street. Clients and staff also confirmed that during the verbal altercation between C1 and S2, the other staff was in the facility office. Continue on LIC9099-C

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights 87072 (10)(11) To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons.To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews with staff and clients, it was confirmed that a staff pushed and had a verbal argument with the client. The staff confirmed that he shoved the client. This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of the children in care.

(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews with staff and clients, It was confirmed that no inspections were made in the client's room after he left the facility and he had a knife hidden in his room without the knowledge of the staff. This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of the children in care.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Olivia Rosas, Enrique Hernandez, and Licensing Program Manager (LPMs) Lakescia Smith and Alan Henry, and Regional Manager (RM) Kellee Coleman conducted an Informal Meeting for Garza & Rodriguez Family Services. The informal meeting was conducted virtually on 04/16/2021 with Microsoft Teams meeting at 2:00pm-3:30pm. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the current administration changes, personnel associations, relocation and outstanding lease payments. Attendees: · Lupe Rodriguez, Administrator with Casa de Esperanza and Serenity House · Lorie Vos, CEO · Kristine Hart, Consultant Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) explained that the goal for this meeting is to determine the recent changes in the facility, relocation, and staff changes for the Casa de Esperanza and Serenity Facility. Outstanding Financials: Lorie Vos stated that the lease payments for the facilities are up to date. Angelo Naemi, Former Board member, was asked to not participate in the meeting as he stated he has no insight on the lease or mortgage. Lorie explained that by doing financial audit she found out that Lupe Rodriguez has been doing 'non-accountable’ expenses. Kristine stated she resigned from the Board due to unethical issues in 02/2021. A copy of the resignation letter was sent to LPA Rosas and Hernandez. CCLD was informed that the following individuals are on the Board: Lorie Vos, Mariam Adrada and Deanda Degronde. Lorie stated that two board members quit: Angelo Namoni and Gerald Hernblad. CCL advised to submit new board of director statements for the new board members. Lorie reported she will hire two new board members. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2)

(Continued on LIC809-C, page 1) Personnel/Board/Role Updates: CCL learned that Lorie Vos was designated to be CEO of Garza & Rodriguez Family Services in October 2020. Lorie stated she was brought in to help the facilities transition from Group Home to a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). CCLD recently learned that the change in corporation was not reported to CCL and no applicant documents were submitted to CCLD regarding the new CEO. RM Kellee Coleman asked Lorie to submit the following LIC forms to LPA Rosas and Hernandez for each facility. · LIC309 – Administrative Organization · LIC308 – Designation of Administrative Responsibility · LIC 501 Current Application or Personnel Record · LIC503- Health Screening/TB Results Report within last year. This form MUST be sign, date and stamped by a MD (medical doctor) NOT a PA (physician assistant). · Board of Resolution sign by all the members (designating Lorie as the new CEO) · LIC508 - Criminal Record Statement · First Aid & CPR Criminal Record Clearance: Two staff members listed on the LIC 500 (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 04/7/23/21) as active staff scheduled are not associated to the facility. Lorie said she just received access to Guardian and would be associating staff. LPM Smith confirmed Staff #1 (S1) does not have a fingerprint clearance and Staff #2 (S2) has not been associated to the facility. In addition, Lorie is not associated to the facilities. Kris and Lorie said they do not provide direct care services to the clients or go to the facilities. However, Lorie was informed that as a CEO she is required to be associated to the facilities. CCLD staff discussed the following concerns: Lease agreement on file terminated on 6/15/2019, no current lease agreement on file. CCLD requested updated lease agreement. CCLD suggested that they renew lease temporarily. CARF Accreditation on file expired 5/31/2019. Lupe confirmed accreditation has not been renewed. CCLD was informed that the Head of Service at Serenity House left, and the Head of Service at Casa De Esperanza is leaving at the end of the month. The administrator confirmed that the Mental Health application has not been submitted. Lupe’s administrator certificate on file expired on 11/29/2020. CCL requested a current one from Lupe Rodriguez. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 3)

(Continued from LIC809-C, page 3) Reporting Requirements: CCLD learned that there was a discussion of a possible merger agreement and Santa Barbara County was notified but CCLD was not. RM Coleman and LPM Smith reminded the facility the importance of reporting special incident reports to the facility and any changes to the staff and/or to the corporation and board members. If the facility needs assistance checking background checks, they should contact the El Segundo office and talk to the “On Duty” worker of the day. Facility is always able to reach out to their assigned LPAs for questions. Recommendations: RM and LPMs reminded facility staff to always report changes to CCLD. If they need assistance, they can contact their LPAs. In addition, the facility needs to ensure staff is clear and associated to work in the facility. Lorie would send the required documents to LPA Rosas and Hernandez for review. RM Coleman suggested that they be referred to the technical support program to provide training and assistance to their staff. For example, reporting procedures, Title 22 Regulations. In addition, the facility would be given a copy of Title 22 Reporting Requirements, Assembly Bill 388 Law Enforcement Contact Regulations PIN 17-11-CPR, Revision of LIC624-C, Law Enforcement Contact Report and Reporting Law Enforcement Contacts PIN 17-04-CRP. Lastly, LPAs would follow up with the facility to provide additional support on reporting procedures. CCLD also recommended that Lorie attend the STRTP Orientation. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator for signature.

The investigation, including confidential interviews with resident and staff members, revealed C1 made sexual abuse allegations a month after they no longer resided at the facility and almost a year after the alleged incidents occurred. Staff were not informed nor observed any sexual activity between C1 and other clients. Interviews produced no additional alleged victims or witnesses to the alleged abuse. As to claims that staff failed to prevent drugs in the facility, the investigation revealed that C1 and other client at the facility would at time smuggle illegal drugs into the facility after they returned from home visits. Clients were also suspected of using the internet to purchase narcotics and have them delivered by the facility’s fence area and sidewalk. It was revealed, due to client’s personal rights, staff were not able to search clients who were suspected of possibly being involved in drug activity. The investigation did not produce any independent witnesses to the allegation. Observations of the facility physical plant during the investigation on unannounced complaint inspections, found facility grounds in substantial compliance. The facility was observed overall to be clean and or orderly. On site inspections produced no deficiencies concerning a lack of cleanliness. Due to a lack of evidence, the allegations can not be substantiated at this time. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove the allegations occurred; therefore, the allegations are determined Unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during the investigation. Exit interview conducted; appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report will be emailed to Facility Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On June 29, 2021 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. LPA Martin met with Facility Representative, Lupe Rodriguez to discuss the investigative outcome. The investigation was conducted by the California Department of Social Services (CDSS), Investigator Olivia Spindola of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. On November 6, 2020, CCL received complaint allegations concerning neglect and lack of supervision. It was reported that a lack of supervision resulted in inappropriate interactions between minors in care as Client #1 (C1) was allegedly sexually abuse by another minor resident; that staff failed to prevent drugs in the facility; and that the facility is not clean. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to Casa de Esperanza on 08/11/21 at 10:00 am for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1 (S1) who granted access to the facility. LPA Rosas, will return to the facility to conduct a physical plant inspection. LPA Rosas, was not able to interview clients or staff as they were off site. Staff and Client files were not reviewed due of being store in different facility due to the construction. LPA Rosas, will return to the facility to conduct review files. LPA Rosas provided S1 a copy of PIN 21-20-CPR Statewide Launch of New Inspection Tools for Children's Residential Licensees with a copy of Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) Tools inspection for Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Inspection Tool. LPA Rosas, explained the CARE tools and how the annual inspection process. In addition, LPA Rosas provided a link to CDSS Forms, and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 3.1. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 08/09/2021, indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to A#1 to obtain signature.

The facility is licensed to care for six (6) male clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only (See confidential name list LIC-811 dated 02/25/2022). During the inspection the following was observed: Outdoor: · Broken window not boarded up at the time of the inspection with sharp edges exposed and broken pieces on the ground of the backyard of the facility. · Metal BBQ rack in backyard of facility · Nonfunctional dirty BBQ in the backyard of the facility. · Window screens of the client’s room broken and lying on the floor of the facility, · Pieces of wood laying on backyard grass · A metal bed frame on the side of the back yard · A mattress on the side of the backyard · Rocks lying down in the backyard · Parts of the backyard grass is one foot tall · Missing pieces of wood on the backyard fence · Graffiti in the front entrance of the facility and on the backyard Continue on LIC809-C

LPA took pictures of all the deficiencies observed during the time of the inspection. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing standars (ILS), the following deficiencies were observed and cited at the time of this inspection. On March 17, 2022, at 11:50 am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Nancy O'Connell and Enrique Hernandez, conducted an unannounced Case Management- inspection to Casa De Esperanza Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at the above address. Marina Herrera Facility Manager (FM) Lupe Rodriguez Facility Administrator granted access into the facility. During the time of the inspection LPAs were conducting confidential interviews at the dining room table, near the living room couch, and wall outlet with computer charger could be heard surging. LPA O'Connell could smell the area near the outlet burning. The FM confirmed the smell of something burning and proceeded to unplug the charger from the outlet. LPA took pictures of all the deficiency observed during the time of the inspection. continued from page 1 A query of Zillow resulted that the property at this location is currently on the market and in pending sale status. An official eviction notice was not done (meaning the legal steps for doing an eviction was not taken), however the Landlord did leave a 60-day Notice to Vacate under the front door mat. AGPA Woodard has determined the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met. Therefore, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

narrative: The investigation, including confidential interviews with staff members and a tour of the facility revealed the ceiling was damaged due to excessive rains and doors were damaged due to clients having anger episodes. Observations of the facility physical plant during the investigation on unannounced complaint inspections, found facility doors to be repaired, however the ceilings have not been repaired in the therapist office or laundry room. Based on observations, AGPA Woodard has determined the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegations are found to be substantiated. Deficiencies were cited to the facility for physical plant. Exit interview conducted; appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report will be left at the facility.

During today's inspection the ceiling in two rooms are still in disrepair which possess potential Health, Safety risk to children in care.

investigation_findings: 13On March 25, 2022 at 11:55 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings on the above allegations. Upon arrival, AGPA was greeted by Marina Herrera, Facility Manager. On November 18, 2021 CCL received complaint allegations concerning a child who is being verbally sexually harassed by his peers at his current group home. The child did not provide examples of his concerns and stated that he did not want to talk about it. The child also did not disclose if group home staff are aware his peers were sexually harassing him. The investigation included confidential interviews with staff members and clients, and a review of supportive documentation. The alleged victim declined to be interviewed and there were no witnesses who corroborated the alleged incident. Based on the above, AGPA Woodard has determined the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to support the allegation of a violation of client’s personal rights. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the facility representative.

narrative: On 7/14/2022 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at Casa De Esperanza STRTP, and met with Marina Herrera Facility Manager (FM), during the inspection it was discovered that Lupe Rodriguez the Facility Administrator assigned to the facility on the LIC 500 the schedule does not show the administrator scheduled for 20 hours per week. LPA conducted confidential interviews at the time of the inspection [see LIC811 Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 07/14/2022, for names]. Based on the documentation received and the confidential interviews, there is no administrator on site 20 hours per week. This poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 4, The following deficiency is cited A copy of this report will be emailed to FM, due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer.

On 7/14/2022 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez conducted a Case Management - Deficiencies at Casa De Esperanza STRTP, and met with Marina Herrera Facility Manager (FM) who granted access into the facility and together discuss the Case Management. During the investigation of the complaint received on 7/8/2021, it was revealed that Angelo Naemi was hosting a party at his home for the 4th of July 2021. During the party at Angelo's house, an incident occurred between a client and a staff. It was corroborated by clients and staff that there was alcohol and a staff member got drunk and began arguing with the client. After reviewing the complaint investigation, it was discovered that Angelo Naemi did not have criminal record clearances during the time of the incident. Based on records review, the licensee failed to ensure that fingerprint clearance was obtained which poses an immediate Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to residents in care. A deficiency and immediate civil penalty of $100 is cited Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing standars (ILS), for criminal record clearance. A copy of this report will be emailed to FM, due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer.

investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report On June 25, 2022 at 11:00 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard met with Lupe Rodriguez to deliver findings on the above allegation(s). Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez and Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted the investigation into the above allegations. LPA Hernandez conducted the initial 10-day complaint inspection on February 25, 2022 and conducted confidential interviews with three staff. AGPA Woodard conducted subsequent visits to the facility on April 8, 2022 and May 20, 2022; confidential interviews were conducted with three staff members, and one client. Additional phone interviews were conducted on May 20th, 21st, and June 15th, 2022. Confidential interviews revealed that there are two staff present for each shift, including NOC. The day of the incident there were two staff on shift. While staff person was being attacked by four clients, one client blindsided staff and punched staff in the face. In return, Staff punched one of the boy’s in their chest who was not the alleged victim. In interview with the minor who was punched in the chest, minor didn’t disclose the attack against staff or that he was punched by staff but referenced another staff member who swung on the alleged victim. The alleged victim has a history of verbally going after staff as well as physically assaulting staff and people in the community. After staff didn’t receive any support from other staff member at the facility, staff gathered his items and left the facility to report the incident to the police, leaving the staff person with five clients temporarily until additional staff arrived. Based on confidential interviews and review of supportive documentation, the Staff member admitted to hitting a minor in self-defense when he was being attacked by four minors, and leaving the facility to report it with Law Enforcement, which left one staff alone with five clients, therefore the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the personal rights and lack of supervision allegations are substantiated. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing standars (ILS), the following deficiencies are cited. (See LIC9099-D) A copy of this report was left, and appeal rights were discussed

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interviews and record review the staff did confirm he left the facility leaving one staff with five clients. This possess an immediate health and risk for the children in care.

In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment…. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on interviews and record review the staff did confirm he did hit the minor in self-defense after he was being attacked by four minors; staff is no longer employed at the facility. This possess an immediate health and risk for the children in care.

investigation_findings: 13On June 21, 2022, at Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Enrique Hernandez and Nanacy O' Connell arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Hernandez met with Marina Herrera Facility Manager (FM) and discussed the investigative findings. On July 8, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging Staff member is having an inappropriate relationship with group home minor(s). During confidential interviews and documentation obtained, there was insufficient evidence to substantiate the allegation, although there were some statements claiming that a client and staff had a relationship, the two denied the allegation. Other confidential interviews denied seeing or hearing anything inappropriate between the client and the staff. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation is unsubstantiated, but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and findings can be changed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with FM

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights 87072 (c)(10)(11) To be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons. To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews with staff and clients, all relevant parties confirmed that a staff member had a verbal altercation with one of the clients. Additionally, LPA Hernandez received a recording of the actual verbal altercation and staff can be heard yelling at the client. This poses an immediate risk to the health and safety of the clients in care.

investigation_findings: 13On June 25, 2022 at 11:00 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard met with Lupe Rodriguez to deliver findings on the above allegation(s). Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez and Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted the investigation into the above allegations. LPA Hernandez conducted the initial 10-day complaint inspection on February 25, 2022 and conducted confidential interviews with three staff, and on March 22, 2022 conducted a subsequent visit at the facility. AGPA Woodard conducted subsequent visits to the facility on April 8, 2022 and May 20, 2022; confidential interviews were conducted with three staff members, and one client. Additional phone interviews were conducted on May 20th and 21st, 2022. Confidential interviews revealed that a rock was not thrown at the minor and the minor threw a rock breaking a window in the rear of the home. After the incident minor AWOLed as soon as Law Enforcement arrived; it is unknown if minor returned and was not let into the house. Staff follow AWOL protocol and will do a debriefing with the residents prior to being allowed in the home. Staff deny the allegation that they do not allow minor’s back into the home. Staff deny slamming a minor’s arm and foot in a door, and there have not been any injuries reported. Based on confidential interviews and review of supportive documentation, AGPA Woodard determined the personal rights allegations that staff threw a rock at a minor, staff did not prevent a minor from AWOLing, and staff member slammed a minor’s arm and foot in a door, the allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the findings are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

met_with: Lupe Rodriguez, Facility Administrator and Ann Guttierez, Mental Health REhab Specialist
narrative: On 7/20/2022, at 3:15pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell, made an unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility, and met with Ann Guttierez (Mental Health Rehab Specialist) and Lupe Rodriguez Facility Administrator, who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the facility, inside and out. The purpose of this inspection was to address and deliver findings related to complaint. Upon entering the facility property at 3:15pm, LPA O'Connell observed a silver Chevy Equinox car parked in the driveway. Upon further inspection, LPA observed that the car did not have a state issued license plate on bumper area. LPA observed that a picture of a license plate was taped on the inside of trunk window, which reflected a license plate showing expired tags (expiration: 10/23/2021). LPA asked MHRS about reason for expired tag and MHRS acknowledged expired tag and stated that she was not aware of reason for car not having current tags. MHRS stated that the regular facility car has been "in the shop" for two weeks and this car has been used since then to transport clients. LPA obtained a picture of car and license plate for records. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 4, the following deficiency: 80074(c), was cited at the time of this inspection. (See attached LIC9099D) Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

account. The balance from both joint accounts was eventually paid to C3’s adult sister (A1), and there is no evidence that any money was withheld from C3. Whether or not A1 returned C3’s money to C3 could not be determined. Based on LPA’s interviews and documents obtained, the allegation is found to be Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/20/22, at 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of delivering findings, regarding the above allegation. LPA met with the Facility Administrator (ADM), who granted access into the facility. During the investigative process, all relevant parties have been accounted for, and LPA obtained bank statements, as well as a series of text message screenshots between the Facility Administrator (ADM) and the client’s (C3’s) adult sister (A1) were obtained. Confidential interviews confirmed that the ADM held both a joint checking account, and a joint savings account with C3, even though C3’s Deputy Probation Officer (DPO) did not approve of these joint bank accounts. C3 was discharged from the facility, on 08/18/2021, and an outstanding balance remained on both joint bank accounts, until December 2021, when C3 and C3’s adult sister (A1) requested that the balance be paid to A1’s Zelle

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres, and Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Angela King conducted a case management inspection August 2, 2022 at 9:00 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 02, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee does not always use trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. LPA David Torres and LPM Angela King did not observe documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Lupe Rodriguez, Administrator.

met_with: Marina Herrera, Facility Manager, (FA), Chris Thompson, Mental Health Rehab Specialist (MHRS)
narrative:
On August 16,2022 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell conducted an unannounced annual inspection at the above-listed facility. Licensing staff was met by Christopher Thompson, Mental Health Rehab Specialist (MHRS) and Marina Herrera, Facility Manager (FM). Census was reported to be 5 residents (4 in the facility and 1 on a home pass). LPA observed the following during inspection: Living Room: there was enough seating on the couch for all residents and additional staff. All furniture appeared to be in good repair. There is no fireplace or open faced heater. Rugs were being cleaned outside of the facility. The living room is used as an area for relaxation. The main facility door is located in living room. The facility telephone is cordless and is accessible to clients to use within this space. Kitchen: Equipped with a refrigerator, functional stove, microwave, pantry area with limited non-perishables. LPA observed that there were enough dishes, and utensils for number of residents. Kitchen was clean, and orderly. Trashcan was secured with a lid. Refrigerator was at correct 45degree temperature to prevent spoilage and contamination. There was enough perishable food to last required amount of time. Sharps were stored in locked box in garage storage and inaccessible to clients. A weekly menu was posted in clear view but did not have a date. All appliances appeared to be in working condition. · Upon entering the kitchen, and inspecting the refrigerator contents, LPA observed multiple Continued on LIC809C

food items that were not dated or were expired. LPA inquired about reason for missing date and FA stated "yes, staff should have dated that." LPA directed FA to dispose of expired food prior to continuance of inspection. Dining Room: equipped with a a large table with 5 chairs and separate seating (3 can occupy table and 2 can occupy the counter table adjacent to kitchen). There is not enough seating for additional staff. Garage: is being utilized as facility storage and contains items that are not currently in use. there is an additional refrigerator, and freezer that store additional food items for residents. Knives are stored in this area and are inaccessible to clients. At time of inspection, LPA observed cleaning supplies left on cabinet adjacent to garage freezer. FM communicated that staff was using the supplies and didn't put them away. Hallway: there is a linen cabinet that contains additional bedsheets and linens, but not enough observed to accommodate all residents. There is also a medication closet that is locked and inaccessible to clients. Medication closet was observed and contained locked and labeled medications. First aid kit was observed to contain all required supplies. · Smoke detector were observed to be missing from kitchen/hallyway location and smoke detector adjacent to client bedrooms was non-functional. · Fire extinguishers (3) were observed and appeared to be charged. Fire extinguishers were located in kitchen, garage, and hallway. Laundry area: equipped with a washer and dryer and no space for storage. LPA observed dust and rags on floor on left side of washing machine. Additional rags and clothes were laying on the ground adjacent to dryer. Continued on LIC809C

Bedroom #1 is occupied by two clients with two twin size beds on each side of the room, adequate closet and drawer space. Closet did not have doors or enclosures for items in closet. Bed #1 did not have a fitted sheet or pillow. Bedroom walls were observed to be in disrepair, with stains and dirt markings/graffiti. Bedroom #2 is occupied by two clients it has two twin size bed, adequate closet and drawer space.Closet did not have doors or enclosures for items in closet. Walls were observed to be in disrepair and buckling away from foundation. Bedroom #3 is occupied by one client; it has two full twin size beds and drawer space. Bathrooms- 1 full bathroom is located in the main hallway. LPA observed bathroom to be in disrepair with strong odor, collection of dust at perimeter of flooring, rust stains in tub, and cracked interior of tub. There is a second bathroom adjacent to the kitchen and is used solely for staff, and for residents if necessary. Staff bathroom maintains cabinet that holds cleaning supplies and laundry detergents. At time of inspection, LPA observed cabinet to be unlocked but inaccessible to clients due to lock on bathroom door. Backyard/Front yard- LPA observed broken gate that could not latch on left side of home. LPA also observed item intended for disposal in backyard (punching bag), and broken sewage lids in ground, where clients have access to walk across. Facility Vehicle: Car was inspected to be in good repair and with functional lights, blinkers, emergency lights, and headlights. Registration and insurance was verified. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 4, there are deficiencies to be cited at this time. Refer to 809D for details. Due to time constraints, the annual inspection will be completed on another day. A copy of this report was discussed with the facility manager and appeal rights, along with copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 8/18/2022 at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nancy O'Connell made an unannounced Case Management Deficiencies Inspection to the above listed facility. LPA was met by the facility administrator (FA) who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the home. Upon arrival at the facility, LPA O'Connell observed S1 at the exterior portion of the facility, in the garage and observed a male exit from the facility and walk towards to open garage. LPA O'Connell confirmed name and role of S1 and inquired about the presence of the unknown male. S1 stated "no, hes not a client, he's my son." Upon entry to the facility, LPA informed the facility administrator that the presence of an uncleared adult is prohibited. FA stated "he comes to help sometimes. He's a former client who volunteers. He's 18 years old." LPA informed FA that all volunteers must be reflected on the LIC500 and are subject to a criminal record clearance prior to entering the facility. FA informed the male volunteer to leave the facility immediately. During the time of inspection, LPA O'Connell inspected the contents of the refrigerator and observed multiple food items without a date and/or with an expired date. LPA inquired about the reason for expired items and FA stated "the staff should have thrown them out." LPA O'Connell inspected all items and observed FA discard of all food items that were expired. A total of 25 items were discarded together with FA (pictures retained for records). During the time of inspection, LPA reviewed records related to client allowances for the month of August 2022, and found that client records were not maintained accurately. LPA Continued on LIC809C

inquired about reason for missing $20 from C1s cash funds and FM reported that the funds were used in order to purchase necessary supplies for facility purposes (items from Dollar Tree were observed on receipt). Picture of receipt retained for records. LPA inquired about reason for usage of clients funds to purchase needs for facility and FM stated that there wasnt any other available cash resources. LPA inquired about policy to provide cash resources to staff for necessary facility purchases, and FA reports that staff are reimbursed through cash or Venmo when they utilize their own funds for facility needs. LPA O'Connell obtained pictures of all deficiencies for records. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7.5 Version 4, a deficiency will be cited at this time. A copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and left with the facility administrator.

met_with: Wanda Nelson, Operations Manager and Kristin Reynolds, Facility Manager
narrative:
On August 29, 2022, at10:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of delivering a deficiency citation. LPA and LPM were met by Wanda Nelson, Operations Manager, who granted access to the facility. On 8/26/22, the Department received a report that a fire inspection was conducted on 8/25/22 by the Ventura County Fire Department. During that time, the fire inspector observed that the facility retained an non-permitted construction that poses an unsafe condition for a portion of the home. The fire clearance was denied on 8/25/22, and the facility was directed to seek permits for the structure, or demolish the non-permitted portion immediately. During the time of inspection on 8/29/22, Ventura County Fire Department (VCFD) Fire Inspector (FI), property owner, Facility Manager (FM), and Operations Manager (OM) [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 08/29/22, for names] were present to conduct a walk through and develop corrective plan to address denial of fire clearance for back portion of facility. Further, during the inspection, LPA observed the laundry and therapy room addition, which was built without a permit, was found to be in disrepair. The ceiling was caved in, the insulation was exposed, and the structure was unstable. VCFD issued a Red Tag notice to restict access to the unpermitted areas. The doors to the bedrooms #1 and #3 does not close all the way and one door to bedroom#2 is missing. The door frame for the main entrance to the facility is cracked. The garage door exterior has a hole on the bottom right corner. Continued on LIC809C.

The closet door in main hallway which contains the furnace has a broken door and does not lock. The following deficiencies were observed and cited at the time of this inspection. See LIC809D for details. Exit Interview conducted with the facility administrator, and a copy of this report was left at the facility

met_with: Wanda Nelson, Operations Manager (OM) and Kristin Reynolds, Facility Manager (FM)
narrative: On September 21, 2022, at 09:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of delivering the documentation related to a recent Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) held with the provider, Operations Manager, Board of Director President, Community Care licensing Staff, and county representatives, at the office. LPA was met by FM and OM and together, they discussed the results of the NCC. On 9/14/2022, Community Care Licensing Division held a meeting with the Licensee (and her management team), as well as county placing referrals agencies (Ventura County, San Bernadino County, Santa Barbara County, and San Luis Obispo County) to address an ongoing pattern of concerns related to multiple topics. The NCC meeting was conducted at the Woodland Hills RO to go over the categories (1. fire clearance denial, 2. notice of rate termination, 3. Unfingerprinted staff / unassociated staff, 4. Expired Accreditation for over 2 years, 5. Mental Health Program Approval denials, 6. Reporting Requirements, 7. Insufficient/Expired foods, 8. Facility Administrator duties and responsibilities, 9. Staffing issues and training, 10. Solvency Issues and Misuse of Funds, 11. Many Physical Plan Citations). Due to ongoing noncompliance issues, the matter of conducting an administrative review on the licensee’s provisional license will be presented to the department’s legal counsel. Exit Interview conducted, and (due to technical difficulties with printer) a copy of this report will be emailed to the Operations Manager.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Care and Supervisison 80078(a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. narrative: continued from 9099 (unsubstantiated findings) During confidential interviews conducted with clients and staff, and a review of supportive documentation that was obtained, there was insufficient evidence to substantiate the allegations. The alleged victim C1 (6’ tall, 249 lbs) attempted to assault a female staff (S9), and C3 intervened by pushing C1 out of the way so he wouldn’t hurt S9. C1 called Law Enforcement (L/E) and reported he was being attacked. C1 threw a big rock towards a C3 who was sitting outside with a staff, almost hitting the client in the face. C3 got up and began chasing C1, caught him and pinned him against the facility van. Staff separated the boys. C1 then proceeded to vandalize staff (S8)’s vehicle. L/E arrived and attempted to de-escalate the situation. C1 was given a citation for vandalism. C1 was assessed and transported to the hospital by emergency services. According to the ‘Patient Visit Information’ sheet, C1 was assessed for a closed head injury, cervical strain, and left knee contusion; SIR stated C1 required medical treatment for hurt left knee, head injury, cervical strain and headache from emotional state, and other documentation states C1 was transported to the hospital to tend to a hurt ankle by running and was checked out at the hospital for his neck and knee hurting. According to citation (A448614) the date of violation was 05/25/21 at 1637 (approximately 4:37 PM). C1 was released at 6:30AM and returned back to the facility by Ventura County Sheriff’s Deputy and Child Welfare Social Worker. There is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations occurred, therefore the Department has decided that the allegations are unsubstantiated. If any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and findings can be changed.
investigation_findings: 13On September 23, 2022 at 11:30 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings on the above allegation. continued from 9099-A (unsubstantiated findings) During confidential interviews conducted with clients and staff, and a review of supportive documentation that was obtained, there was insufficient evidence to substantiate the allegations. If any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and findings can be changed. continued from 9099-A (unsubstantiated findings)
investigation_findings: 13On September 23, 2022 at 11:30 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver findings on the above allegations. Upon arrival, AGPA Woodard was greeted by Christopher Thompson, Mental Health Rehabilitation Specialist (MHRS). AGPA met with Lupe Rodriguez, Facility Administrator and discussed the investigative findings. On April 12, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging staff/upper management telling a youth that expired food was “ok to eat”, and staff bringing in food they know is expired. It was also alleged that facility staff are not qualified and are not sufficient to meet the youths’ needs. Based on all interviews and documents obtained there was sufficient evidence to substantiate the allegations. Interviews indicated that staff are forced to go to the food bank and get donated food for the facility; food from the food bank usually has a 3-day window of expiration. If clients make a big deal about it, they are told it’s ok to eat because it’s been in the freezer. continued on LIC 9099-C

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Food Service (a) In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply: (1) All food shall be safe and, in the quality, and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews the licensee failed to provide quality food to the clients when clients were given expired foods from the food bank, and if clients questioned it, they were told it was ok to eat. This posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to children in care.

Personnel Requirements (g) The licensee shall employ the number of direct care staff necessary to comply with the staff to child ratios specified in 87065.5, meet the needs of the children as specified in 87065.2, and provide adequate care and supervision to children. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and supportive documentation the facility is understaffed and there are not enough direct care staff to meet the needs of the clients in care. There are written documentation of AWOL, physical altercations, property damage, etc. This posed an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk to children in care.

Personnel Requirements (b) The licensee shall employ those administrative, social work, licensed or certified mental health professional, …. To perform the assigned duties specified in applicable law and regulation. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and supportive documentation the licensee did not employ a licensed or certified mental health professional to perform the duties of a licensed therapist. The Residential Therapist was an Associate Marriage and Family Therapist.

narrative: interviews confirmed that BOD was present in the facility and carried out an unauthorized restraint on a minor (staff was not trained to perform restraint), resulting in a physical altercation. A report obtained by law enforcement reflects that BOD and the minor sustained bodily injuries due to an unauthorized restraint initiated by BOD. Further, LPA O’Connell reviewed database records and found that the licensee did not submit a report to CCLD regarding this incident. Upon interview with the licensee, LPA O’Connell made an additional request to obtain evidence of submission of a serious incident report, and was informed that a report was not available for the date in question. Further confidential interviews revealed that staff present in the facility did not have the training needed to deescalate C1 and required additional support of BOD who was not approved as a direct care provider, or a staff authorized to conduct restraints. In addition, the licensee did not inform the authorized representative or CCLD about the incident and did not take steps to review actions taken to mitigate future occurrences of this nature. Based on LPA interviews and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Based on California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 2 deficiencies are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. See 9099D for details. A copy of this report was discussed with the Operations Manager and emailed to the facility.

During the investigative process, LPA O’Connell conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties and collected information on the above allegations. After reviewing all the statements and the information obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential Continued on LIC9099C

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights:80072(a)(1) Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights ...not limited to, the following:(1)To be accorded dignity in his/her personal relationships with staff and other persons. This requirement was not evidenced by the following: Based on interview, and record review, the licensee did not ensure that all individuals entering the facility are trained on restraint and principles of deescaltion.

Reporting requirements:(b)The licensee shall ensure that the child's authorized representative is notified no later than the next business day if the following circumstances have occurred ...:(3) Each time the child has been placed in a manual restraint, ...] Based on interview and record review, the licensee did not ensure that the authorized representative and CCLD was informed of incident that occurred on 8/21/21.

narrative: On November 3, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made an unannounced case management inspection to the above facility for the purpose of inspecting the rear portion of the facility. LPA was met by the facility administrator and provided a tour of the facility. During the inspection, LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility and inspected the rear portion of the facility, adjacent to the backyard. LPA observed that the room that was previously used as a therapy room and laundry room has been demolished. LPA inquired about date of completed demolition and FA reported that it was completed on 10/22/22 . LPA retained pictures for records. No deficiencies will be cited at this time. Due to technical difficulties, a copy of this report was emailed to the licensee.

continued from page 1 (LIC 9099) C6 has a history of drug and alcohol abuse and has been caught with drug paraphernalia in his room and/or personal property. CDE did not provide adequate supervision when C6 and client (C9) were placed off-site at a motel during the time the facility was going through renovations and being repaired; this is evident by the change of motel due to clients smoking marijuana in the room and on the property by the pool. During a room check at 2:30AM, staff noticed C6 was not in the room. It was also reported that when staff (S3) left the clients in the room and went to the restroom somewhere outside of the room, and upon S3's return, S3 was locked out, and could not get back in. There were conflicting stories as to whether staff stayed in the motel room with the two clients or stayed outside the door. SIR dated 08/08/2021 states that staff (S5) took C6 and C9 to the facility to pick up more clothes. S5 stayed in the vehicle with C6, while C9 was allowed to enter the facility during the time construction workers were doing renovations. Upon entering the facility, C9 was upset that his belongings were dirty and blamed construction workers. C9 became enraged and destroyed facility property as well as power tools. The Facility Administrator (FA) requested that clients be taken off-site between August 4, 2021 to August 8, 2021 during the time the facility was being repaired. FA provided the repair list which included: painting the inside of the house, fixing the broken cabinets and adding granite, updating flooring, adding new cabinetry in the hallway, fixing both bathrooms, adding new appliances and furniture in client's rooms, and adding an extension for a new therapy room. The repairs took longer than expected, and the clients did not return until August 17, 2021. continue on page 3 (LIC 9099C)

continued from page 2 (LIC 9099C) Based on interviews and supporting documentation, although the bathrooms were repaired, the toilets sometimes didn't work; plumbing was backed-up/clogged and clients had to go to the gas station down the street to use the restroom or would go to the backyard. Based on recordings on C6's cellphone, the Deputy Probation Officer (DPO) viewed recordings of the facility having incomplete repairs, lacking furniture, and C6 pouring water into the tank to flush the toilet. DPO also observed incomplete construction on the back patio and a video of clients jokingly placing their arm under the blade and stating that it could cause an injury. Through AGPAs investigation it was noted that the completed construction occurred in late October/early November 2021, however during a heavy rain in December, the ceiling collapsed in both room additions. AGPA Woodard verified that building permits were not pulled for the alterations to the facility. C6 has a standing appointment in person at the clinic every Tuesday at 10:30AM with the Behavioral Health Clinician (BHC). Both the facility staff and C6 are aware. In the month of July 2021, C6 last attended therapy on July 6th. On July 13th, the BHC walked into the lobby to see if C6 was there for his regularly scheduled appointment. BHC called the facility and spoke with staff (S4), who stated that C6 had to work. S4 was informed on July 13th that C6 has not been participating in therapy and there were no future appointments scheduled or contact made by group home staff or C6. BHC states that therapy sessions were cancelled on July 13th, 20th, and 27th. On August 13th, 2021 C6 had a medication appointment with psychiatrist (DR). DR shared with BHC that the follow-up was done by phone instead of in-person per the group homes manager's request due to the facility remodel. DR phoned S4 and S4 reported that C6 was taking a shower and not available for an interview. continue on page 4 (LIC 9099-C)

continued from page 3 There have been ongoing concerns with Casa De Esperanza not providing adequate supervision, concerns with their lack of communication with the Department, Placement Agencies, and Behavioral Health, as well as their ability to ensure clients in placement are receiving needed services in a timely manner. Therefore, the Department has determined the above allegations are substantiated, meaning that the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The following deficiencies have been cited. (See LIC 9099D)

continued from page 1 (LIC 9099A) Therefore, the Department has decided that the above allegation is unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. If any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and findings can be changed.
investigation_findings: 13On October 21, 2022 at 10:45 AM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Tonya L. Barnes-Woodard conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Casa De Esperanza (CDE), to deliver findings on the above allegations. Upon arrival, AGPA Woodard was greeted by Christopher Thompson, Mental Health Rehab Specialist, and discussed the investigative findings. On August 19, 2021, the Department received allegations that were investigated by AGPA Woodard and LPA Olivia Rosas. During confidential interviews conducted with clients and staff, and a review of supportive documentation, there was sufficient evidence to substantiate that client (C6) was heavily intoxicated to a point that his judgment was impaired, and staff (S2 and S8) did not seek medical attention for him. [See Confidential Names for (LIC 811), dated 10/21/2022 for names] continue on LIC 9099C

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personnel Duties Direct Care Staff shall perform the following duties: Supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups, This requirement is not met at evidenced by: Clients were not supervised while at the facility or placed off-site. While C6 and C9 were placed at the motel S3 left clients unattended to use the bathroom outside of the motel room; upon her return she was locked out. S5 took C6 and C9 to the facility during the time of renovation and S5 stayed in the vehicle with C6 while C9 went inside alone. C6 and C9 had access to dangerous items, such as power tools on at least two occasions, one of which they jokingly placed their arm under the blade, stating that it could cause an injury.

Personnel Duties Direct Care Staff shall perform the following duties: Any other duties that may be necessary to ensure the health and safety of children in the facility. This requirement was not met as evidence by: C6 was heavily intoxicated to the point that his judgment was impaired, and S2 and S8 did not seek medical attn for him. Facility staff did not ensure that C6 attended regularly weekly scheduled therapy appointments with BHC or his medication appt. with the psychiatrist DR.

Buildings and Grounds The licensee shall prohibit smoking in the facility and on the grounds of the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: C6 had access to alcohol, marijuana, and other paraphenalia while at the facility, as well as had access to marijuana while placed off-site at a motel. Multiple incident reports of marijuana smoke coming from client(s) rooms and drug paraphernalia (battery/vape pen) being charged.

Buildings and Grounds The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Although the bathrooms were repaired, the toilets sometimes didn't work due to plumbing was backed-up/clogged. C6 had to pour water down the tank to flush the toilet and/or clients had to go to the gas station down the street to use the restroom or would go to the backyard.

Alterations to Existing Building or New Facilities Prior to construction or alterations, state or local law requires that all faciltiies secure a building permit. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Through AGPA's investigation it was noted that completed construction on the room addition occurred in late October/early November 2021, however during a heavy rain in December 2021, the ceiling collapsed in both room addtions. AGPA Woodard verified that building permits were not pulled for the alteration to the facility.

narrative: After reviewing all the statements and records obtained, the above allegation is supported, as the confidential interviews confirmed that medication for C3 was not disbursed as prescribed, and a medication log was not created or maintained for C3 even though a prescription medication was observed within the secured area designated for medications. On 9/21/22, LPA noted that a prescription medication for C3 was obtained within the last seven days, but zero pills had been disbursed to C3, as evidenced by observation of a full pill count within precription container. Upon further interview, the facility manager could not produce records showing that medication had been disbursed to C3 and C3 reported that he had not received any medication related to identified prescription. Further confidential interviews revealed that there is no single identified facility staff responsible for the oversight of administration of medications for residents. Based on LPA observations, record reviews and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A deficiency is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.

met_with: Lupe Rodriguez, Former Licensee and Facility Administrator (FA)
narrative:
On 7/3/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell met with Lupe Rodriguez , former facility licensee and administrator for the facility. This case management- deficiencies meeting was conducted via telephone due to the facility no longer being operational (effective 10/31/22). This meeting is being conducted in response to a completed Solvency Audit Report conducted by the Community Care Licensing Division- Audit Section, initiated on 9/13/22. On 3/24/23, the Department completed a Solvency Audit for Garza and Rodriguez Family Services and found the organization to be deficient in several areas including: Finances, Accountability, Administrator Qualifications and Duties, and Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency. The following information reflects the findings of the completed Solvency Audit: The licensee does not have an adequate financial plan in place. Licensee provided some records, however, the records provided were not sufficient to complete the audit. For operational expenses, the licensee did not provide records to vouch income to support the revenue for the facilities income statement. The licensee did not provide six (6) months of utility statements for each facility. Records for rent payment history or any amount of unpaid rent for the facilities was not submitted. For the balance sheet, the licensee did not provide the records to support the amounts submitted. The licensee did not provide 12 months of bank statements for Serenity House. Further, records provided show the licensee had not paid rent, facing eviction from the landlord and vacated the facilities. Licensee has not been transparent and avoided providing the required documents needed to conduct the solvency audit. Documentation was not received after an extension was granted. CONTINUED ON LIC809C.

this audit review also disclosed outstanding annual fees owed to the department for both facilities. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division 6. Chapter 1, General Licensing Requirement Section 80062, Finance; Section 80063, Accountability; Section 80064 Administrator Qualifications and Duties and Section 80044 Authority to Inspect of the Licensing Agency. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the former facility administrator for review and signature.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Finances-(a)The licensee shall meet the following: (1) Development and maintenance of a financial plan..(2) Maintenance of financial records.(3) Submission of financial reports as required... This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record reviews conducted, during the Solvency Audit, the licensee did not provide sufficient financial records to reflect that a financial plan was developed and in place. This poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to children in care.

Accountability-(a) The licensee,... is accountable for the general supervision of the licensed facility, and for the establishment of policies concerning its operation.(1)...the governing body shall be active and functioning in order to ensure such accountability. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record reviews and interviews, the licensee did not ensure that she was accountable for the oversight of the facility program. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care.

Inspection Authority-(a) The licensing agency shall have the inspection authority specified in Health and Safety Code Sections 1526.5, 1533, 1534, 1538, and 1538.7. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on record reviews, the licensee was not cooperative, not transparent and failed to comply with all applicable laws and regulations. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care.

Administrator Qualifications and Duties-(a)The administrator shall have the following qualifications: ...(2) Knowledge of the requirements for providing the type of care and supervision needed by clients, .... (3) Knowledge of and ability to comply with applicable law and regulation. (4) Ability to maintain or supervise the maintenance of financial and other records...(6)Ability to establish the facility's policy, program and budget. ... This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on record reviews, the licensee was not cooperative, not transparent and failed to comply with all applicable laws and regulations. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care.

California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.
