met_with: Debra Camarillo, Salvador Blancas, Rebecca Mathew
narrative: On 8/8/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Applicant Latino Commission on Alcohol & Drug Abuse Services for the scheduled Component II face-to-face meeting. Representing the Applicant were Executive Director Debra Camarillo and Administrator/Director of Residential Services Salvador Blancas. Also in attendance was Rebecca Mathew, Youth/CYF Director of Substance Use Prevention & Treatment Services with the City & County of San Francisco, Department of Public Health. During the meeting, the following topics were discussed. Application Process Overview Goal/Purpose of the Facility Basic Services and Planned Activities Needs and Services Plans Care and Supervision Policies Emergency Intervention Policies Emergency Disaster Procedures Reporting Requirements Background Clearance/Guardian Process At the conclusion of the meeting, LPA discussed that the prelicensing inspection will be scheduled upon receipt of the fire clearance. LPA thanked the Applicant representatives for attending the meeting. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant representatives.

On November 04, 2020 at 11:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray made an announced Tele-Inspection via Face-Time at the GROUP HOME Facility (1722 S. LEWIS RD. CAMARILLO,CA 93012). The purpose of the Tele-Inspection was due to a SIT ALERT (1 client tested Positive for COVID-19).LPA and the participants objective were to ensure the Health of Safety of the Children in placement will be exhibited by ensuring that CDC Guidelines are implemented; in effort to prevent others from contracting the virus. Present in the inspection conducted via FaceTime and are three (3) staff; including this LPA-Gray. Staff #1 (S1)-Facility Administrator and Staff #2 (S2) Health Facilities Evaluator Nurse.LPA-Gray ensured that all participants were linked and present. LPA-Gray introduced herself and cross introduced the participant (S2). LPA-Gray asked a series of questions and observed the following preventive measures regarding COVID-19 as S1 gave a tour of the Group Home facility. LPA -Gray and the HFEN observed following three (3) cottages for the Group Home facility;(Archies, Rainbow and Wells Fargo Cottage). S1 also provided to capacity and census for the three (3) cottages. 40 - bed capacity (3 cottages) 12 -census. Archies Cottage: is currently occupied by seven (7) female clients. The cottage has 8 bedrooms, where there are currently five (5) dual occupancy rooms, and three (3) single occupancy bedrooms for a total of 13 beds. There are also 4 bathrooms, 1 staff office, 1 staff bathroom, kitchen, dining room, TV room, and laundry room. The staff office has en extra refrigerator to store any medication that may need refrigeration. The common living area was set up with tables, couches, and a shuffleboard table. Rainbow Cottage: Currently being utilized to quarantine the three (3) youth that tested positive to COVID-19. The cottage is divided by permanent wall that divides female and male clients. The cottage uses one shared kitchen, and dining room. LPA observed 8 bedrooms (2 single occupancy, and 6 double occupancy bedrooms), for a total of fourteen (14) beds.

Wells Fargo Cottage – Currently occupied by male clients. The cottage has 8 bedrooms and has five (5) dual occupancy rooms, and three (3) single occupancy bedrooms for a total of 13 beds. There are also 3 bathrooms, 1 staff office, 1 staff bathroom, kitchen, dining room, TV room, and laundry room. The staff office has en extra refrigerator to store any medication that may need refrigeration. The common living area was set up with tables, couches, and a shuffleboard table. LPA observed the stabilization room equipped with one twin bed, located next to the staff office within the Wells Fargo cottage; this room has two emergency exits, and is utilized primarily for the clients from the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA and the S2 observed that disinfectant/cleaning agents were alcohol based recommended by the CDC. LPA asked “If one or more of the youth Test positive, will the facility be able to isolate the youth from others? S1 disclosed that that two 2 additional clients COVID-19 test results were positive, in addition to three (3) staff. S1 ensured that the staff is not on duty and ordered to quarantine at home. LPA observed six (6) feet of spacing between the beds were not in compliance with the CDC Distancing guidelines. LPA and the HFEN recommended the beds be moved 6 feet apart or the clients sleep Head-To-Toe. LPA-Gray asked were the youth and staff’s temperature checked daily and logged as well. S2 inquired about the number staff that has been tested who are assigned to the facility and came in close contact with the staff that tested positive. S1 did not disclose the names of staff that came in contact with the staff that tested positive; Due to the HIPAA Privacy Rule, Staff to protect individuals' medical records and other personal health information cannot be disclosure. S1 stated that he, other staff and youth temperatures are tested 1x a day, logged and the Health Department is notified. S2 recommended that temperature be tested twice a day; "When the staff arrive and when the depart for the day". LPA and S2 observed limited COVID-19 postings particularly in the hallways and on the door of the children's bedroom door. S2 and LPA recommended that additional colorful visual aids consolidating COVID-19 CHHS Positing; hygiene hand washing signs be posted in the hallways and on the door of the bedrooms. S2 suggest that the signs be laminated to prevent from fading and or ripping from moisture; particularly the signs that are posted in the bathroom and kitchen. LPA-asked has a plan been developed in the event when a youth returns from AWOL for short-period and extended period. S1 discussed the emergency plan in event that a child or staff displays asymptomatic. S1 stated that youth’s temperature are taken; they are instructed to shower and quarantined depending on how long they have been gone on AWOL. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2)

LPA-asked have all staff, residents, families and officials been informed and understand that they must always maintain social distancing (six feet of space). S1 stated that essential visitors are limited (i.e Social Workers, Probation Officers) and have been notified of the that a staff tested Positive for COVID-19. The Facility Industrial kitchen cooks the food and all meals including snacks are delivered to each cottages.Youth eat in the dining area at six feet distance. LPA recommended that resident youth and staff are directed to wash hands upon return to the facility. S1 ensured that the youth rooms are cleaned, commonly used areas and items (laptops, key boards, computer mouse, remote controls, cell phones, playing cards, are disinfected throughout the day and evening. S1 also ensured that social distancing, correctly wash their hands and displayed by practicing “cough etiquette”. LPA observed uncovered trash can and highly recommended that S1 place lids on all trash cans. LPA observed ample paper towel dispensers mounted on the wall. LPA asked did the facility have enough PPE supplies and informed S1 that the department has ample PPE upon request with the options to pick up from CRP in EL Segundo. S1 displayed the PPE supplies in the cottage and stated that additional PPE's are stored in another building on the campus grounds. LPA recommended that the facility staff S1 review the CDC Resource Packaged items that was emailed in reference to reporting requirements for confirmed COVID-19 cases (County Public Health Department, Primary Physician, Responsible party/family, CCL Regional Office). S1 agreed to make the contact LPA when the changes have been made via email or telephone. LPA-Gray concluded the Tele-Inspection Positive and ask the S1 if any questions or needed further technical assistance. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Administrator for signature. Signature will be on file. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 3.)

On 07/06/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at Casa Pacifica, and met with the Facility Administrator, in response to two Special Incident Reports that were submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL), in order to investigate a possible violation. One incident, which occurred on 06/27/2021, involved client (C1), who was given another client's (C2's) 12pm psychotropic medication by staff (S1); the other incident, which occurred on 06/13/2021, involved client (C3), who was given another client's (C2's) psychotropic medication by staff (S2). [See LIC811 Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 07/06/2021, for names]. LPA interviewed the Facility Administrator (FA), and Health Care Manager (HCM), and Youth Development Specialist (S2), who confirmed that client (C2's) psychotropic medication was administered to clients (C1 and C3) by mistake. Due to a shortage of nursing staff, medications have been pre-packaged by Health Clinic nurse to be administered to the clients by Youth Development Specialists, which have resulted in mistakes in the administration of medication by Youth Development Specialists. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 5, the following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC9099-D) Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On July 23, 2021 at 2:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin initiated a Case Management - Incident investigation at Casa Pacifica and met with Facility Administrator, Tone Reyes. The purpose of this inspection was to inform Licensee of an investigation currently ongoing regarding self reported incident, concerning an alleged sexual assault by a "Staff Member" on Youth Resident Client #1 (C1) [see LIC811 dated 7/23/2021]. This incident has been referred to Community Care Licensing, Investigations Bureau. During this inspection, LPA Martin was informed that the subject incident was in fact alleged sexual assault by a "staff member" at the hospital where C1 was being held for observation and not an individual or "staff member" at Casa Pacifica. LPA Martin requested the following documents: Client Rosters and Personnel Schedule (LIC 500); Client #1's: Needs and Service Plan, Placement Agreement, Child and Family Team (CFT) Planning Matrix, and incident reports related to C1. Please emailed requested documents to LPA Martin at - regina.martin@dss.ca.gov Incident requires further investigation. Upon conclusion, LPA will deliver and discuss the findings. There were no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 during this inspection. A copy of this report will be emailed to Facility Administrator.

On 08/04/2022 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Olivia Rosas made an unannounced visit to Casa Pacifica Group Home for the purpose of conducting Case Management inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1), Staff#2 (S2), and Staff#3 (S3) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 08/04/22. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area in the Founders Building. LPA met with Staff#1 (S1), who granted access into the facility, and who provided a tour of the physical plant. This facility provides mental health services and has a Group Home (GH) license to provide care and supervision for forty (40) children ages 13-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is a swimming pool on the premises which meets licensing requirements. The facility has an approved camera waiver. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. The facility currently has an approved Council on Accreditation through October 31, 2023. The Group Home license has with three (3) cottages the Wells Fargo Cottage, Archie's Cottage, and Rainbow Education Cottage. LPA Rosas inspected the Rainbow Education Cottage that is currently not being used and is expected to be used for Education services. The Wells Fargo and Archie’s Cottage will be used for mental health services. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 2

LPA Rosas inspected the following: Rainbow Education Cottage- Is currently unoccupied. The cottage has eight (8) double bed bedrooms. There are also four (4) bathrooms, three (3) staff office, two (2) staff bathroom, two (2) therapy offices, kitchen, dining room, TV room, and laundry room. The staff office has an extra refrigerator to store any medication that may need refrigeration. The common living area was set up with tables, couches, and storage. During the facility was inspected, the following was observed: LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. There were multiple fire extinguishers and was fully charged and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the facility. The passageways are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children’s Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The cottage has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted. All posting requirements were met. LPA Rosas inspected the Rainbow Cottage and found the cottage to met physical plan requirements. Facility is still pending approval of Plan of Operation review. Upon the approval of the Plan of Operation the Rainbow Cottage will be placement ready. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

LPA Rosas reviewed Child#1 (C1) discharged Progress Notes written on 10/05/2021 that provided summarized discharge summary and a copy was provided to the parent. C1 was in placement in the facility for total of five (5) days from 10/05/2021 to 10/10/2021. C1 was discharged from the facility per family request. On 02/11/2022, late addendum was written by Staff#2 (S2) regarding discharge summary and adding that discharge was not a result of any negative behaviors or presentation on C1 part. Interviews reported that C1 was in a verbal argument with another resident and C1 reported to parents before facility can submit Special Incident Report. There was not enough information to corroborate the allegation. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. The Department has decided that the allegations of Neglect/Lack of Supervision are unfounded, meaning that the allegation was false, could not have happened and/or is without a reasonable basis. investigation_findings: 13On December 8, 2022, at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced inspection to Casa Pacifica for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. During the investigation process, LPA Rosas conducted inspection and conducted interviews on January 13, 2022, and November 21, 2022. In addition, LPA Rosas interviewed witnesses and pertinent parties related to the investigation. Individuals mention in this complaint are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated December 8, 2022. Based on the confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process, record review, statements obtained, LPA Rosas concluded the allegations of minor attacked another minor while in care, staff unlawfully removed a minor from the facility and staff behavior poses as a risk to the minors while in care. narrative: On December 20, 2023 at 12:40pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management deficiency. LPA was met by Assistant Director of Campus Services (ADCS) who granted access to the facility. A medication incident report SIR #22781, dated 12/7/23 was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) and did not contain information on type of medication missed due to medication not being "packed." LPA requested licensee to provide further information and to re-submit SIR. On 12/11/23, licensee sent the revised SIR to the regional office. During the course of the deficiency investigation it was discovered that licensee did not ensure psychotropic medication for youth (C1) were taken or administered as prescribed, "due to being forgotten about until after window to pass medication." LPA Wilson and Licensee discussed the possible mitigating factors which led to the missed medication dosage. Licensee stated the nurse did prepare the medications to be administered, however, were not administered to client (C1). Further, staff signed off on the medication form which had a discrepancy. The pre-shift form was not completed that day. A (1) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (ADCS) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Health Related Services (b) Clients shall be assisted as needed...(5) If the client's physician has stated in writing that the client…(B)...the medication is given according to physician's directions.This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on incident report 12/11/23, LPA records review and interview conducted the licensee did not ensure client received psychotropic medication according to physician's direction which poses an immediate danger to the health safety and personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an unanounced Case Management Incident inspection at the above listed facility. LPA met with Assistant Director of Residential Services (ADS) and the Facility Clinic Manager (FCM). This case-management-incident inspection was conducted due to the Department receiving a serious incident report (SIR) reflecting that on 02/11/2024 Youth (C1) missed 3pm Lithium 450 MG due to medication not being packed by the facility nurse (S1). LPA reviewed the relevant documents and confirmed that staff did not provide medication. LPA Wilson inquired about reason for missed medication. Per the Facility Clinic Manager, there is a new nurse who was right at her 90-day probationary period and she may not have been aware of the need to pack the medication at that time. Normally the 4pm nurse arrives and gives the 3pm medications. There was no nurse on that day so that window was missed. There is a board with the in-between medications listed and she needs to check the board where they shifts are covered and medications written. While she has been on there has been no need for packing. The new nurse was shadowing the regular nurses during her probationary period. LPA and FCM discussed the deficiency and a plan of correction. A type B (1) deficiency will be cited today. See LIC809D for details. A copy of this report was discussed with ADS and a copy of this report was left at the facility

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (B) Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The licensee did not ensure that C1 was administrered the prescribed medications as ordered by their physician. This poses a potential risk to the health, safety and personal rights to children in care.

narrative: On August 6, 2024 at 9:15AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Rosslyn Gray, Emelyn Sanchez P. and Kenrick Ellis made an announced visit at CASA PACIFICA GROUP HOME to conduct the Psychotropic Case Medication Inspection. LPAs conducted a Health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Gray, Sanchez P., and Ellis met with the Administrator Theresa Plante conducted a brief walk through of the physical plant inside and out. LPAs did not review clients psychotropic medications records due the status of the facility type that accepts private placement. LPA did not interview any clients currently prescribed psychotropic medication due the facility type that accepts private placement. LPAs reviewed three (3) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs interviewed three staff on site at the facility. LPA's reviewed the LIC500 to confirm the shift which starts in the evening and ends early morning and reviewed the staff Criminal Records Clearances. The Administrator provided a physical hard copy of the psychotropic medication training topics during the training for LPA’s to review. No deficiency were cited per Group Home Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator Theresa Plante.

On August 16, 2024 9:50 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR for incident dated 08/11/24. LPA Wilson was greeted by the Regional Director (RD) and the Health Clinic Manager (HCM). During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 08/11/24 the youth (C1) was witheld medication, due to staff (S1) having a lack of access to a blood pressure cuff. Per the SIR, the youth's blood pressure must be taken prior to medication administration. LPA Wilson interviewed (RD) and (HCM). Staff (S1) was not on campus this day. . LPA obtained a copy of the LIC500 and client roster, Medication Sign-Out Form and MAR records for (C1). LPA Wilson viewed the Chart Meds 08/01/24 to 08/16/24 for (C1) and observed that for each date prior to the incident that the youths (C1) blood pressure was taken measured and recorded on the MAR. LPA and (RD) and (HCM) discussed the incident regulation 80075(b)(5)(B). LPA Informed the licensee there was an exact same violation issued on 04/04/24, and that today is a repeat. LPA will issue a Type A violation. A civil penalty of $250 for a repeat violation is assessed. See LIC809D and LIC421FC for details. No other deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

narrative: On 08/15/2025 at 11:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendely Moodie-Naranjo and (LPM) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management inspection. Licensing staff met with Facility Administrator (FA), Theresa Plante, who granted access to the facility. Community Care Licensing received four incident reports that were reported late. After further investigation, cause for the late reporting was due to transition of staff responsibilities. Because those four incident reports were submitted late, the following deficiency has been cited regarding reporting requirements. (See LIC 809-D) A corrective action plan has already been submitted and this deficiency will be cleared. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 08/15/2025 at 11:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendely Moodie-Naranjo and (LPM) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management inspection. Licensing staff met with Facility Administrator (FA), Theresa Plante, who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct a follow up investigation regarding incident that occurred on May 29, 2025, involving and attempted suicide by client (C1). Licensing staff interviewed C1 and found no violation of a neglect or lack of supervision. No deficiencies were observed or cited at this time Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On December 30, 2020, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that facility staff do not supervise the children which allowed a youth to use illegal drugs. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 ingested an unknown substance while in the restroom. Confidential interviews stated the facility conducts searches of children when they arrive at the facility and are supervised by staff. Confidential interviews and documents reviewed revealed though staff supervise children, staff are not allowed to supervise children while in the restroom and shower. Confidential interviews revealed that staff was not aware C1 was ingesting an illegal drug because no one ever told staff. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that due to a lack of supervision a youth is using illegal drugs in the facility may have occurred; however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to the facility representative for signature. The original signed report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On April 16, 2021, at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted a tele-visit using Microsoft Teams due to COVID-19 with facility representative Amy Lakin, to issue the investigative finding of the allegation listed above. On January 08, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jesus Cervantes, conducted a tele-inspection of the facility, and no deficiencies were noted. LPA Cervantes conducted interviews with Foster Child #1 (C1), Foster Child #3 (C3), Foster Child #4 (C4), Foster Child #5 (C5), Staff 1 (S1), Staff 2 (S2), and Staff 3 (S3). During the investigation, LPA reviewed documents for C1 and C2, LIC 500 (dated 01-08-2021), City of Los Alamitos Police Department report and facility policy and procedures. See Page Two.

narrative:
The facility is set up as follows: Facility has six (06) bedrooms totaling a full capacity of twelve (12) clients. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. There is a staff office located in front building. The client and staff records are located and locked in the staff office in file cabinets. Three (03) Bathrooms- used by all the clients. The medication and knives/sharps is stored in the locked cabinet in the staff office. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies. Facility has complete first aid supplies. The cleaning products are stored in the locked cabinet. The facility is clean, organized and very well maintained. The facility has a sufficient supply of sheets, bedding and linens. The facility's smoke detectors in bedrooms and hallways were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in the hallways near kitchen/dining room area were operable. All smoke detectors/sprinklers are connected to a fire safety monitoring agency Beacon Security. Detectors are tested quarterly and semi-annually and last tested on 02/11/2022. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Ms. Hettig. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. Hot water temperature tested within regulatory requirements. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. No expired food was located in the supply. All toxins and cleaning agents were secured at the time of visit. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool/bodies of water located on the facility premises. -----continued on next page-----

A sample of client and staff files were reviewed during the inspection. Eight (08) client files and ten (10) staff files were reviewed. All the files reviewed were well organized and contained all pertinent documents required per Title 22 regulations. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, the facility has demonstrated compliance in accordance to Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. There are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given Shelter Program Manager, Josue Montenegro along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811). The facility was advised to list each psychotropic mediation on a separate form. LPA Smith provided facility representative with a copy of the LIC622B.

There were no witnesses to the said incident. Regarding privacy during phone calls: It was also reported that staff was present during C1’s phone calls to their mother. Confidential interviews revealed that clients can make phone calls at the dining room table and the front reception area. Confidential interviews reported inconsistencies with the doors being shut to the reception area, however, LPA observed there were individuals talking in the reception area and their words were not discernable. Confidential interviews and records reviewed did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegations that staff did not prevent C1 from being attacked by C2 and C1 was not allowed any privacy during phone calls. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Christina Garcia and Jessica Hubbard. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, along with the LIC 811, and appeal rights will be emailed to the Facility Administrator. A signed copy of this report will be kept in the Facility file.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jacqueline Garcia and Rachel Vanegas on February 3, 2025 at 10:00 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA's met with Chief Operating Officer, Lupita Gutierrez. LPA's inspected the facility inside and out and did not observe any deficiencies. LPA's reviewed 0 child records and 6 staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA's reviewed 0 of 0 child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA's interviewed 2 of 6 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA's interviewed 0 of 0 youth currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection LPA's did not observe any violations therefore no deficiencies are being cited at this time. On 04/01/2025 at 09:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez conducted an unannounced annual inspection at the facility listed on this form. LPA met with the facility manager, Kathleen Cyr. LPA and facility manager toured the facility inside and out. Review of the facility's operations shows that the facility is licensed to serve twelve (12) clients ages 12 - 17 years of age for shelter care with stays for 21 days. The facility currently has a census of five (05) clients in care at this time. LPA noted that the facility has an exterior camera system. LPA noted that the monitors are located on the outside of the facility. The facility is set up as follows: There is a parking lot behind the building, and some street parking in the front of the building. Facility has six (06) bedrooms totaling a full capacity of twelve (12) clients. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. There is a front lobby, and an intake office located in front of the building. The client records, their medications, and knives/sharps are located here in file cabinets. There are four (04) bathrooms, one used by staff only, and three by only the clients. There is a recreation room upstairs, and nothing else is on the second floor. Facility has complete first aid supplies. The cleaning products are stored outside in another locked cabinet. The facility is free of debris, organized and well maintained. The facility has a sufficient supply of sheets, bedding, towels, and toiletries. The facility uses one van for transportation, and no maintenance lights were on. **Continued on LIC809-C**

**Continued from LIC809** Hot water temperature tested in bathroom #2 at 108 degrees Fahrenheit and that is within regulatory requirements. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. No expired food was located in the pantry supply area. The facility's smoke and carbon monoxide detectors in bedrooms and hallways were checked by one staff pulling the signal system, which in all alarms and lights going off. Owens Security maintains the fire system. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by facility manager. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, and current menu. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. No client windows had locks on them, and all window screens were in good repair. A second building on the campus holds two floors, and only the therapy rooms are visited by the clients. The second floor has four offices that are used as therapy locations or for office work for the administrators. The operations manager office has the staff flies in a locked cabinet; some files are also on the digital server. On the bottom floor is the conference room, and two staff offices. A sample of client and staff files were reviewed during the inspection. Five (05) client files (C1-C5) and five (05) staff files (S1-S5) were reviewed. All the files reviewed contained all pertinent documents required per Title 22 regulations. All staff that work at the facility had criminal background clearances. Two of five clients were interviewed (C1 and C2), and two of forty-six staff (S3 and S4) were interviewed. Based on the facility inspection, files reviewed, and interviews, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Interim Executive Director Lupita Gutierrez. A copy of this report was reviewed and given along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811).

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with administrator Patricia Chaidez to complete the inspection which began on 04/28/22. Ms. Chaidez will submit a copy of the clearance letter via email to this LPA. The COVID positive staff has returned to work as of 05/06/22. No clients tested positive during this outbreak. The facility is licensed for a Group Home with a capacity of 16. The census today is 5. The facility is an emergency shelter for children ages 10 through 17 with an average stay of 30 days per client.. Clients are placed in the shelter on a voluntary basis and usually no other placement agencies are involved however Catholic Charities/Angel's Flight does occasionally accept DCFS placements and unaccompanied minors. Facility is a two story building. All residents sleep on second floor. There is no signal system in place. Program Director Patricia Chaidez states that there is always at least one full time staff located on the second floor during the night or when children are in their bedrooms. Due to COVID, children are usually in their bedrooms when they are home. Social distancing is maintained when clients are in the day room or using any common area There are a total of 10 bedrooms and 16 beds. The kitchen area, bedrooms and bathrooms were all clean and well maintained. Hot water temperature was within the required range. There is food available to meet the requirements of Title 22. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no security bars on windows Hazardous items are stored in locked cabinets as required. Fire alarm panel is working and fire drills are conducted on a monthly basis. The last fire drill was conducted 04/14/22 and is conducted monthly

LPA reviewed 5 client files and interviewed 2 clients. Review of staff files and staff interviews will be conducted at a later date. There were no deficiencies cited as a result of this inspection.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Program Director Patricia Chaidez to commence the annual/random inspection. The facility is licensed for a Group Home with a capacity of 16. The census today is 7. The facility is an emergency shelter for children ages 10 through 17 with an average stay of 30 days per client.. Clients are placed in the shelter on a voluntary basis and usually no other placement agencies are involved however Catholic Charities/Angel's Flight does occasionally accept DCFS placements and unaccompanied minors. Facility is a two story building. All residents sleep on second floor. There is no signal system in place. Director Patricia Chaidez states that there is always at least one full time staff located on the second floor during the night or when children are in their bedrooms. During the day, clients are usually in the common area. There are a total of 10 bedrooms and 16 beds. All bedrooms have one or two twin beds with the required linens. Each bedroom has the required closet space. The kitchen area, bedrooms and bathrooms were all clean and well maintained. There is food available to meet the requirements of Title 22. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no security bars on windows of bedrooms. There is a complete first aid kit. Disaster drills are conducted on a monthly basis. The last drill was conducted on 04/24/2024. There is a working fire alarm panel and several fire extinguishers throughout the facility and on both floors. There are carbon monoxide detectors throughout the facility. A review of client records was conducted. Licensee was cited under sections 80069(a), 84070(c)(3), 84070(b)(12) and 84070(b)(13)(H). Staff files will be reviewed at a future date.

On July 25, 2025 LPA J. Armstrong arrived to the facility at 12:15pm, CATHOLIC CHARITIES/ANGEL'S FLIGHT to deliver the findings for a complaint allegation. Upon arrival LPA spoke with Residence Attendant Christie Rubalcava who informed LPA she was the only staff present due to all staff being off site at a Staff Appreciation Event. LPA then received a phone call from the Facility Administrator Tracy Alvarez who informed LPA that the Staff Appreciation Event is in Marina Del Rey and she could leave the event to come back to the facility. The facility is being cited for not having a Facility Manager or Administrator present at the facility while clients are in care. LPA J. Armstrong issued a citation in accordance with the Group Home Licensing Standards, Chapter 5 Division 6 Personal Requirments. The facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, as stated in Title 22 84065 (d)The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present this poses an potential health, health and safety An exit interview was conducted, a Plan of Correction was discussed, and a copy of the report was provided to the facility.

The following documents were reviewed: the Client Inventory Form, House Rules, Visitation Rules, Handbook, and Food Menu. After completing the interviews and reviewing the documentation, it was determined that there was insufficient evidence or testimony to substantiate the allegations. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation(s) are Unsubstantiated, but if any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On July 25, 2025, at 12:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Justine Armstrong conducted an unannounced visit to CATHOLIC CHARITIES/ANGEL'S FLIGHT facility for the purpose of delivering findings for a complaint investigation alleging, (1) Staff did not seek timely medical and mental attention for a minor (2) Staff do not provide adequate food service to a minor (3) Staff demonstrated inappropriate form of punishment (4) Staff mistreat a minor while in care (5) Staff do not prevent a minor from being bullied while in care (6) Staff interfere with a minor's visitations (7) Staff are retaliating against a minor This complaint was received by the Department on February 27, 2024. narrative:
An unannounced inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer on 06/21/21 at 10:01 am. During this visit, LPA met with Facility Manager Samuel Edman and Kelly Gonderman Assistant Program Director toured the facility inside and out. LPA Gilmer reviewed six staff files, and five client files today. The facility has two (2) buildings 11913 is the residential area where clients live, eat and receive therapy. There are eight (8) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, three (3) staff offices, a kitchen, a dining room, and a common. 19111 is the administrative building there are therapy six (6) therapy rooms, a processing room, kitchen, restroom, and reception area. This facility is licensed for 25 children ages 12-17 both males and females there were 25 clients in placement. The sleeping areas at the time of this inspection were divided into three color sections based on the children's needs. The facility was observed to clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, passageways were unobstructed and there were no bodies of water observed. Cleaning solutions, poisons, sharps, and medications are kept locked and inaccessible to clients. Staff states that there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has an adequate amount of perishable and nonperishable foods, and snacks available for clients. Smoke and carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were not tested today because it mainlines wirer that's directly linked to the fire department. LPA observed the children's rights, children's group home Ombudsman flyer, emergency disaster plan, and foster youth bill of rights were posted.

As per Title 22, the following deficiencies were observed during this inspection and were cited, discussed. The facility was given two technical assistance advisory notes for the staff that did not have a first aid cardiopulmonary resuscitation card on file. The second one was for the staff that did not have a health screening in the file. The group home will also be assessed a $500.00 civil penalty for one of their staff that is working at this facility and not associated with this facility. An exit interview was held and copies of these LIC 809s LIC 858, LIC 859, LIC 9102, and civil penalty assessment -caregivers background check were provided during this exit interview.

On July 20, 2021, at 11:05 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Belinda Gilmer conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection to the above agency and spoke with Kelly Gonderman Assistant Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss and investigate a special incident reports Community Care Licensing (CCL) received on 07/14/21. The incident occurred on 07/03/21 but wasn't reported until 07/14/21. When the group home was made aware of the incident. The C2 and C3 weren't interviewed today as they were both discharged on 07/14/21. LPA spoke with C1 about the incident and C1 confirmed the incident took place between the time the staff conducted their 15 minutes rounds. LPA Gilmer also discussed a special incident report that Community Care Licensing received on 07/16/21. Involving C4 and C5 engaging in a sexual act. Both C4 and C5 were discharged after completing their program. An exit interview was held and copies of the facility evaluation form, confidential names list, and the technical assistant were emailed to Kelly Gonderman.

Additional interviews reveal that clients are checked every 15 minutes; doors are required to be open and staff supervising clients in groups always have a line of sight. Due to high risk behaviors of some clients in placement, staff are on standby within the vicinity of restrooms if clients need to use the restroom. Clients are monitored when going inside and when coming out of restrooms. No statements were obtained from the alleged involved clients; parents did not grant consent for interviews. One client and parent requested one agency case to be closed and signed a complaint refusal form. Information obtained from additional records reviewed showed no evidence of any sexual acts between clients. Based on information obtained, there is insufficient evidence found to support the allegation, so the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this signed report, the Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights forms were provided via electronic mail. There was no deficiency citation issued.

narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Carrie Palmer and Johanna Lofton on October 5, 2022 at 9:00am. During this visit, LPAs met with Facility Manager Samuel Edman and Kelly Gonderman Assistant Program Director. LPAs and staff toured the facility inside and out. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 25 clients. Current census is 19. The facility consists of two (2) buildings with addresses 119111 and 11913. Unit 11911 is the administrative building and therapy services for the clients. This building has a reception area, six (6) therapy rooms, a processing room, reception area, kitchen and restrooms. Building 11913 is the residential building which consists of fifteen (15) bedrooms, recreational rooms, nursing stations, bathrooms, laundry area, staff offices, outdoor activity space, dining room and kitchen. LPAs were able to see food supply and verified there was enough perishables and non-perishables items. The facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, in good repair and passageways were unobstructed. There were no bodies of water on the premises. Cleaning solutions, poisons and sharp objects were locked and inaccessible to clients. Medication was observed to be double locked in a cart in the nurse’s office. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were not tested today because it mainlines are wired directly to the fire department. Staff reported having a fire drill the day before (10/04/22). During the inspection LPAs observed the children's Personal Rights, Ombudsman flyer,emergency disaster plan, facility sketch and foster youth bill of rights were posted. LPAs received a copy of the LIC500 and the Client Roster. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to staff. This annual requires a continuation.

On June 19, 2023, Licensed Program Analyst (LPA), Carrie Palmer conducted a Case Management visit. Upon arrival, LPA explained the nature of the visit. The facility has a current census of 23 clients. During the visit, LPA Palmer was able to interview one staff and one client. Documents were reviewed such as: shift notes from May 17, 2023 and one child's electronic file. LPA requested a printed file for the client. The Program Director made the request to the facilities Human Resources team. The Program Director was unable to provide documents during the visit. The documents will be emailed to the LPA on or before June 20, 2023. LPA also took photographs of the areas of where each incident took place. LPA requested copies of the staffing schedule for the weeks of May 8th and May 15th of 2023 and a copy of the discharge summary. Program Director unable to provide the staffing schedule during the visit. LPA was provided with the discharge summary. LPA requests that the schedule be sent via email to LPA on or before June 20, 2023. Additional time is needed to conduct this Case Management. A copy of this report has been provided to the Program Director. And a Form 811 and two 811c's were completed.

On June 23, 2023, Licensed Program Analyst (LPA), Carrie Palmer conducted a Case Management follow up visit. Upon arrival, LPA explained the nature of the visit to the Program Director. The facility has a current census of 21 clients. During the visit, LPA Palmer was able to conduct a follow interview with one client to ensure a comprehensive interviewing process. LPA Palmer requested a list of all current clients in care. The Program Director provided a list of clients to the LPA. Additional time is needed to conduct this Case Management. A copy of this report has been provided to the Program Director And form 811 has been completed.

On July 14, 2023, at 12:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carrie Palmer conducted an unannounced Case Management visit with the above facility and met with Program Manager, Kelly Gonderman and Samuel Edman. The purpose of the visit is to follow up on a Case Management concerning information received regarding one client being inappropriately touched by another client over the clothes and kissing. On June 5, 2023, LPA conducted an in-person interview with Program Director Kelly Gonderman at Center for Discovery- Whitter. LPA Palmer asked the Program Director to explain her understanding of what happened. The Program Director stated on two separate occasions, that other clients distracted a teacher while clients were playing in the milieu. While the teacher was distracted, C1 (See confidential names list dated 7/14/23) leaned over to kissed C2. Further, the Program Director stated during school time, someone distracted the teacher and C1 touched C2 over the clothes. The Program Director shared that C1 was discharged from the facility, the day the kissing was reported and later C2 was interviewed by a sheriff. The Program Director shared that C2 was touched over the clothes at the table in the milieu and the kissing happened someplace else. The Program Director shared that after C1 left, C2 spoke to a staff member about what happened. The staff member shared with C2 that she should not be kissing boys and allowing them to touch her in private places because that is the number one rule for getting in trouble at the facility. The Program Director was unable to share the exact number of staff in the room for either of the instances, but stated there were approximated between 5-10 staff or less. On June 19, 2023, LPA Palmer met with C2. C2 stated the inappropriate touching and kissing happened on different days, both at the facility sometime in the early or middle of May. C2 shared, the first time she was touched over the clothes was on a Monday or a Tuesday, but she didn’t report it to

anyone until Friday. Per C2, on the following Monday, C1 kissed C2. This was the first day C1 and C2 did not sit together. C2 stated 3 other clients were siting at the table when the inappropriate touching happened, but C2 is unsure of the staff that were present because staff change daily. C2 reported, C2 being backed up against the wall when being kissed, which is how the kiss was able to happen, but C2 stated she moved out of the way because the tongue kiss was unpleasant. C2 stated, the kiss took place in the foyer. C2, elaborated; there are rooms and bathrooms in that area and no staff were present. C2 stated they were away from staff for about 5 minutes. On Monday, June 19, 2023, LPA Palmer interviewed a staff member (S1). The staff member stated, C2 wanted to talk about big track vs. green track. C2 also wanted to talk about C1. The staff member states C2 reported during the check in that all the clients on big track don’t like her because of the kissing. The staff member also reported that C2 stated, she didn’t kiss C1, but that C1 kissed her. The staff member stated, this conversation happened one day before or the day that C1 left. The staff member did not speak to C1 about the incident and did not report it to her supervisor. She only placed the information in her shift notes. The staff member states, in situations like this, there is no policy or procedure stating we must report to the supervisor. On June 23, 2023 LPA Palmer conducted a follow up visit to the facility to interview C2. C2 was able to show LPA the area where the kissing occurred, and the inappropriate touching occurred. LPA Palmer observed that the inappropriate touching happened in an open space, but the kissing happened in a secluded area away from the community areas of the facility. During this observation, the Program Director was also present. On 7/12/2023, LPA Palmer spoke to a family member of C2. C2 told her family member she was assaulted but didn’t want to talk about it in detail. The family member stated, she looked distressed but wasn’t crying. Based on the observations, interviews, and record review a citation was issued. The licensee did not, provide the appropriate care and supervision as necessary to meet the needs of the child, which poses an immediate risk to the Health and Safety or Personal Rights to clients in care. LPA was unable to interview C1. A copy of this report, LIC 809D and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Care and Supervison - ILS - Section 80078(a) Care and Supervision; a licensee shall proivde care and supervision as necessary to meet the cients needs. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: The faciliy did not provide adequate supervision to children while in care. Children engaged in inappopriate behaviors while not being supervised. This poses an immediate risk to the health, safety and well-being of the children in care.

narrative:
An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Carrie Palmer on 7/26/2023. During this visit, LPA Palmer met with Facility Manager Samuel Edman and Kelly Gonderman Program Director. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 25 clients. Current census is 14. The facility consists of two (2) buildings with addresses 119111 and 11913. Unit 11911 is the administrative building and therapy services for the clients. This building has a reception area, six (6) therapy rooms, a processing room, reception area, kitchen and restrooms. Building 11913 is the residential building, which consists of fifteen (15) bedrooms, recreational rooms, nursing stations, bathrooms, laundry area, staff offices, outdoor activity space, dining room and kitchen. The facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, in good repair and passageways were unobstructed. There were no bodies of water on the premises. Cleaning solutions, poisons and sharp objects were locked and inaccessible to clients. Medication was observed to be double locked in a cart in the nurse’s office. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested today in the front of the building only and are in good repair. Fire drills are being conducted monthly; evidenced by the Origami electronic tracking system, which the agency uses . Disaster drills are conducted quarterly. The following have been conducted: Natural Disaster of Hurricane in March 2023 and Earthquake in January 2023. LPA Palmer observed the children's Personal Rights, Ombudsman flyer, emergency 809 Continued Pages 1 of 2

disaster plan, facility sketch and foster youth bill of rights were posted. LPA Palmer received a copy of the LIC 500 and the Client Roster. LPA Palmer reviewed Board Meeting Minutes from March 2023, Emergency Plan Binder, which included information on staff contacts, mandatory evacuations, response plans, hazardous materials, emergency food and water, shelter, emergency medication protocol, interim life safety protocol and fire prevention and instructions on water shut off valves. LPA also reviewed 5 electronic staff files, 5 electronic child's file, interviewed 5 clients and 5 staff. LPA was provided a copy of the administrators resume. During an interview with the Director and Administrator, it was determined that both have regularly scheduled hours (Monday - Friday) and are on call 7 days a week to ensure the safety of the clients and optimal service operations. Several electronic tracking systems continue to be used to track and monitor compliance relative to training's, scheduling, updates of the emergency disaster plans, staff files, and manual restraint usage. Client file reviews were conducted showing current immunization's, doctors reports, and written authorizations from parents to administer medication. During the staff file review and interviews, it was determined that staff receive a large amount of training. The Director also provided LPA Palmer with a the Gender Inclusive Rooming Policy. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to administrators. No citations were issued at the time of the inspection. \ Page 2 of 2
