The facility is licensed for a capacity of 25 clients. Current census is 17. The facility consists of two (2) buildings with addresses 119111 and 11913. Unit 11911 is the administrative building and therapy services for the clients. This building has a reception area, six (6) therapy rooms, a processing room, reception area, kitchen and restrooms. Building 11913 is the residential building, which consists of fifteen (15) bedrooms, recreational rooms, nursing stations, bathrooms, laundry area, staff offices, outdoor activity space, dining room and kitchen. The facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, in good repair and passageways were unobstructed. There were no bodies of water on the premises. Cleaning solutions, poisons and sharp objects were locked and inaccessible to clients.. Fire drills are being conducted monthly and disaster drills are conducted quarterly. LPA Palmer observed the children's Personal Rights, Ombudsman flyer, emergency And exit interview was conducted and an 809 and 811 where issued to the administrator. No deficiencies cited at the time of inspection.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Carrie Palmer on 8/23/2024. During this visit, LPA Palmer met with Colleen Kunniff, Assistant Program Director. The purpose of todays visit was to interview staff and clients. LPA Palmer interview 4 staff. The clients were in a group session and were unavailable to interview. And exit interview was conducted and an 809 and 811 where issued to the assistant administrator. No deficiencies cited at the time of inspection.

On Wednesday 5/18/22 at 9:51AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required 2-year inspection. LPA met with Interim Administrator Virginia Parish and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. The facility is a house in a residential neighborhood. The yard and facility grounds are well maintained. There is a pool in the backyard secured by a fence and locked gate. There are three double-occupancy bedrooms. All residents have their own beds, and beds have clean linens. The kitchen is stocked with quality food that is stored safely and in a quantity to meet the needs of residents in care. Special diets are being followed. First aid kit was observed to be complete. Files were observed to be complete and contained required documentation. The following deficiencies were found (See LIC 809-D and LIC 9102s): 1) Seven (7) staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, and S7 -- See LIC 811 Confidential Names) do not have a clearance associated to the facility and are therefore not cleared to work at the facility. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80019(e) as well as an immediate civil penalty, per Section 80019(g), of $100 per day, for a maximum of 5 days, per individual in violation, for a total of $3,500. 2) One youth (R1 - See LIC 811) did not have a medical assessment on file and was admitted just over 30 days ago. LPA is issuing an advisory of CCR, Title 22, Section 80069(a). 3) There is one designated facility manager for this facility and nearby sister facility. LPA advises that there should be a facility manager present at all times children are present when the administrator is absent, and the facility may designate more than one facility manager. LPA is issuing an advisory of CCR, Title 22, Section 84065(d). 4) Hot water measured very slightly above the upper limit of the hot water range, at 120.2 F. LPA is issuing an advisory, in case of fluctuations in hot water that may result in hotter temperatures, of CCR, Title 22,...

...Section 80088(e)(1). 5) There is a pool on the premises, but staff do not have valid water safety certificates on file. LPA is issuing an advisory of CCR, Title 22, Section 80065(e)(2). 6) There was no bedroom sharing agreement documentation. LPA is issuing an advisory of CCR, Title 22, Section 84087(e). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Program Director Virginia Parish, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 7/1/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the residential treatment group home facility for a case management visit. LPA met with Mental Health Technician Latiesha O'Neal and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, it was discovered that a youth made a disclosure of inappropriate sexual behaviors from a staff toward the youth, but the facility did not report this incident due to not believing the youth's statement. Additionally, during the investigation, an investigator with the Licensing agency's Investigations Branch (IB), after introducing self and requesting to interview residents, was denied permission to do so. The investigator went over the Licensing agency's inspection authority and was still denied. Lastly, during today's visit, LPA was informed that Interim Administrator Virginia Parish is out on sick leave, and the facility manager is working "virtually." There are currently four (4) residents and three (3) staff, including two (2) direct care staff (mental health technicians) and one (1) therapist. The therapist was in a session and not able to provide supervision on the floor nor represent the facility during today's visit. The facility was previously issued an advisory on 05/18/2022 that the facility needs to ensure there is always a facility manager present when children are present whenever the administrator is absent and that the facility may designate more than one facility manager at a facility. LPA is issuing three (3) citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061 Reporting Requirements, Section 80044 Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency, and Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84065 Personnel Requirements. See attached LIC 809-D pages. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Mental Health Technician Latiesha O'Neal, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/1/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the residential treatment group home facility to deliver findings of an investigation of the above allegation, which was conducted by the Licensing Agency's Investigations Branch (IB). LPA met with Mental Health Technician Latiesha O'Neal and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, an overnight staff member would kiss a client on the forehead when helping the client to bed and took another client out of their bedroom on their 18th birthday, kissed the client, and touched the client's buttocks, vagina, and breasts. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights (d)(11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review, licensee did not ensure residents were not abused due to a caretaker displaying sexualized behaviors toward residents in care. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

met_with: Administrator Sara Stokes; Interim Administrator Virginia Parish
narrative: On 9/16/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to deliver notice of deficiencies found during an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and Interim Administrator Virginia Parish and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation conducted by the Licensing agency's Investigations Branch (IB), the following deficiencies were discovered. Based on record review and confidential interviews, a resident was assaulted by another resident with whom they shared a bedroom, and the resident reported the assault the night of the incident to staff on the overnight shift. Staff did not report to police or facility management and advised the resident to report it to staff in the morning. The facility then reported the incident to the victim's authorized representative but did not report the incident to the police and instead advised the authorized representative to contact the police. When the police responded to the facility, staff initially did not permit the victim to be interviewed by the police until the authorized representative approved the interview, despite the police responding due to the authorized representative contacting the police, per the facility's direction. Additionally, four staff indicated they were unfamiliar with a suspected child abuse report (SCAR). Lastly, the facility did not submit an incident report to the Licensing agency until the IB investigator advised the facility of reporting requirements. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Requirements, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Sections 84065 Personnel Requirements and 84061 Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/21/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility. LPA met with Interim Administrator Virginia Parish and informed of the purpose of the visit. On 7/1/22, the facility was issued a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84072(d)(11) Personal Rights, and on 9/16/22, the facility was issued another citation of Section 84072(d)(11). LPA is issuing a civil penalty for repeat violation of $250. See LIC 421FC, dated 9/21/22. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Interim Administrator Virginia Parish, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Sara Stokes; Interim Administrator Virginia Parish
narrative: The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072 Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this form was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 9/16/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and Interim Administrator Virginia Parish and informed of the purpose of the visit. The investigation was conducted the Licensing agency's Investigations Branch (IB). During investigation, relevant record review, including medical records and police report, and confidential interviews with involved parties were conducted. Based on record review and confidential interviews, a resident was sexually assaulted by another resident with whom they shared a bedroom during the night. Staff on the overnight shift did not conduct room checks between 12:35AM and 2:20AM, and when the victim reported the incident to staff, staff did not respond by reporting the incident to police or facility management staff. The resident was offered to sleep in another room but was permitted to return to sleep in the bedroom. The resident sustained bruising as a result of the incident. Additionally, based on confidential interviews, a resident was sexually assaulted by another resident, and staff did not witness incident due to being on their phone.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personal Rights (d)...the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: (11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure residents were free from abuse due to a resident sexually assaulting another resident during the night while at the facility, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

met_with: Division President Amy Brown, Chief Operating Officer James Bailey, Regional Director Monica Powers, Program Director Virginia Parish, and Administrator Sara Stokes
narrative: On January 11, 2023 at 2:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Mendoza, and Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez conducted a scheduled Office Meeting in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) for a violation found during an investigation at the facility. LPA, LPM, and RM met with Division President Amy Brown, Chief Operating Officer James Bailey, Regional Director Monica Powers, Program Director Virginia Parish, and Administrator Sara Stokes. On 09/16/2022, the Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division concluded an investigation into the allegation that the facility failed to provide care and supervision resulting in resident R1 being sexually assaulted by their roommate, resident R2 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List, dated 01/11/23). The assault included digital penetration of the vagina. Based on confidential interviews conducted during the investigation, the staff member on shift did not conduct bedroom checks per the facility procedures in the facility's plan of operation and did not check the room for a period of almost 2 hours, during which the assault occurred. Additionally, the facility was aware that R2 had a history of sexualized behavior toward other residents. On 09/16/2022, the Department issued substantiated findings and a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(11). The Department has concluded an analysis of applicable laws and regulations and has determined that an Enhanced Civil Penalty is warranted for a violation resulting in physical abuse. Therefore, on this date (01/11/23), pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1548(f)(1)(C), the Department has issued a civil penalty of $2,500. See LIC 421, dated 01/11/23. The above information and appeal rights were discussed during the meeting, and a copy of this LIC 809 report, the referenced LIC 811 and LIC 421, and the appeal rights were provided to Division President Amy Brown, Chief Operating Officer James Bailey, Regional Director Monica Powers, Program Director Virginia Parish, and Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/19/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE inspection tool was used to complete this inspection. LPA conducted a tour of the facility and grounds, interviewed 2 staff and 2 residents, and reviewed 5 staff files. A continuation visit is required to complete the resident file reviews. Staff interviewed are aware of facility procedures and personal rights. Staff files reflect valid CPI and first aid. Residents appeared content and dressed in well-fitting, comfortable, and clean clothing. Residents interviewed reported finding the facility a safe and supportive environment. The facility was observed to be clean and tidy and kitchen and bathrooms sanitary. No hazards were observed outside or inside. The backyard pool has a tall fence around it with a locked gate, the key to which only staff have access to. Bedrooms are double-occupancy, and beds have clean linens. Staff and residents report linens are changed regularly. Knives and medications are locked away and inaccessible to residents. Food supply is plentiful with a selection of healthy, fresh, and within date foods. The following deficiencies were observed during today's visit. -- Two staff present during today's visit do not have a background clearance associated to this facility and have been working since 4/17/23 (3 days). LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80019 and assessing a civil penalty of $100 per day per individual for a total of $600. -- Hot water at the bathroom sinks measured above the permitted range, at 122 F and 125.8 F. LPA is issuing a citation of Title 22, Section 80088. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 7/28/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit as a follow-up to the January 2023 noncompliance conference (NCC), per the first NCC term. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the NCC terms and previous inspection(s), the following was required and reviewed: (2) Ensure staff were fully trained, per applicable regulations, at hire and additionally on no less than a quarterly basis. | The annual inspection was completed on 7/28/23, and based on review of personnel files were complete, and training records reflect complete training. (3) Designate two overnight staff each night with at least one being a facility manager. | The facility has staff hired to have two overnight staff but is currently waiting for the third staff to receive a background clearance. The facility continues to conduct 15 minute rounds during the overnight shift and document them on paper and electronically. (4) Designate an administrator to oversee only one facility. | The licensee had two candidates who did not remain in the role. The licensee has a third candidate who has been enrolled in the administrator training. (5) Revise the plan of operation / program statement (POO/PS) and/or develop an addendum to include discussion of the use and purpose of motion sensors in the facility. | An extension was granted. Administrator confirmed it was in progress, and the draft document was shown to LPA during visit. LPA is requesting submission no later than 8/31/23, allowing time for internal approvals. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 10/24/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a quarterly inspection (case management), per the agreed upon terms of the January 2023 noncompliance conference (NCC). LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the NCC terms and previous inspection(s), the following was required and reviewed: (2) Ensure staff were fully trained, per applicable regulations, at hire and additionally on no less than a quarterly basis. | LPA reviewed five personnel records and observed all staff to have background clearances and up to date training, either surpassing required training hours or on track to complete training hours. (3) Designate two overnight staff each night with at least one being a facility manager. | The facility has continued to maintain two overnight staff, and staff conduct 15 minute rounds during the overnight shift and document them on paper and electronically. LPA reviewed rounds documentation at visit. (4) Designate an administrator to oversee only one facility. | The licensee has a candidate who has completed the administrator training and will be taking the exam soon. During file review, LPA observed that two incident reports were not received by the licensing agency, and evidence of faxed submission could not be supplied during visit. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80061 Reporting Requirements. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Reporting Requirements (b)...a report shall be made to...licensing agency within...agency's next working day during its normal business hours...a written report... shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, record review, and interview, licensee did not ensure reports made within required time frame due to 2 incidents not reported by next business day nor written report within 7 days, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

met_with: Director of Regulatory Affairs Jeff Marshall; Administrator Sara Stokes
narrative: On 12/5/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility to confirm the facility is closed. The licensee sent a notification on 11/30/23 that the facility was closed effective 11/10/23. The facility has not had any clients since. LPA spoke with Director of Regulatory Affairs Jeff Marshall over the phone. LPA confirmed closure at the facility site. Licensee agreed to locate and mail the facility license to LPA. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Sara Stokes.

On 4/19/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility and met with Administrator Sara Stokes. LPA informed Administrator that the purpose of the visit was to meet the requirement set during the noncompliance conference (NCC) for quarterly inspections to review staff training and knowledge of supervision and reporting requirements. The additional terms of the NCC were: (2) to ensure staff were fully trained, per applicable regulations, at hire and additionally on no less than a quarterly basis; (3) to designate two overnight staff each night with at least one being a facility manager, meeting this requirement by March 13, 2023; (4) to designate an administrator to oversee only one facility, meeting this requirement by March 13, 2023; (5) to revise the plan of operation / program statement (POO/PS) and/or develop an addendum to include discussion of the use and purpose of motion sensors in the facility, meeting this requirement by March 13, 2023; (6) to provide notification of desire to utilize technical support program (TSP) services by January 25, 2023; and (7), if desired, submitting a central administrative facility waiver by January 25, 2023. See the notes by the corresponding number below. (2) During the visit, LPA reviewed staff training and interviewed staff. Interviews and training records reflect that trainings are conducted at monthly staff meetings and include topics such as supervision, de-escalation, reporting requirements, and cultural competency. Staff interviewed were knowledgeable of facility procedures. The facility also has verbal de-escalation tips posted in the facility. (3) LPA obtained a current LIC 500. The facility has designated two staff for each night. There is at least one facility manager on each night shift. The facility is conducting 15-minute bed check rounds from 10PM to 6AM, and staff log and sign off on each check for each resident. The logs were available for LPA's review, and LPA observed checks each night for each resident. [CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE]

(4) The facility had a candidate for the administrator role who ended up leaving the organization. Another candidate has been hired but still needs to complete administrator training. (5) LPA has not received a POO/PS addendum or revision. LPA is granting one extension. The revision/addendum to meet the requirement as stated above and in the NCC report provided to the licensee is requested to be submitted no later than May 1, 2023. (6) The licensee was referred for TSP services. (7) The licensee has decided to not request a central administrative facility waiver at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On June 03, 2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPA met with Program Administrator (P1) Nicole Seibert. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA inspected the facility inside and out with facility administrator. All six (C1-C6) ambulatory clients were present at time of inspection. LPA inspected the physical plant, operational requirements, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention plan and reviewed six of six client files (C1-C6) (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 06/03/2022) and four of four staff files (S1-S4). LPA conducted two of two staff interviews (S1-S2) and three of three client interviews (C1-C3). The client and staff files are maintained online and readily available. Medication is kept inside a locked closet in a locked cabinet and centrally stored in the Administrator office. The hot water was measured 110.0 to be within the regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly locked and made inaccessible to clients. The two story residence facility is set up as follows: The first floor consists of the milieu room, dining room, kitchen, four offices located downstairs used for the therapist, psychiatrist, program director, dieticians, and counselors. The second floor consists of bedrooms: Bedroom #1- is set up with two twin beds, adequate dresser, night stand and closet space for two clients with a full bath room attached. Bedroom #2- is set up with two full beds, adequate dresser, night stand and closet space for two clients with a full bath room attached. met_with: Chris Oliano, Mental Health Lead Tech & Karla Carrillo, Program Director
narrative:
On October 05, 2022 at 08:30 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Noubar Yerkatyan & Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an annual/required inspection. LPA’s met with above staff. LPA’s and staff toured the facility. LPA’s obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: · LIC 500 Personnel and Client Roster · LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan · Board of Directors report and Program Statement · Employee Grievance Policy/ Grievance Procedures · Crisis Prevention Intervention Training's · Emergency Preparedness: Disaster and Mass Casualties Drills · Emergency Evacuation Routes · Facility Monthly Activities Calendar · Emergency Intervention Plan · Complaint Procedures The facility was in full compliance with 7 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools for Children’s Residential Licenses. Annual compliance review consisted of the following domains: Physical plant, operations, disaster preparedness plan, emergency intervention, staffing, and client records. Community Care Licensing (CCL) focuses its efforts on three priority areas: prevention, compliance, and enforcement. There are 3 fire extinguishers throughout the facility, all fully charged and all last serviced

on 10/04/2022 & 09/15/22. The facility has (7) working telephones that is accessible to clients and staff. All passageways and grounds were free of any obstructions. The medications and cleaning solutions were locked inside the cabinets in separate storage rooms. There were perishable foods enough for 5 days and non-perishable foods enough for client's consumption for more than a week. Each bedroom has two twin beds with clean sheets and linens. There were drawers and closet space in each bedroom for client use. The hot water temperature was tested and was in working order. At the time of this inspection the facility was observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair. Administrator is on site 12 hours a day and on-call 24/7. The facility has a 2020 Kia Sedona mini-van used to transport clients. The vehicle has an active insurance policy. The facility maintains an equipment/vehicle safety log that is monitored by the Mental Health Lead Technician. The vehicle is serviced every month or as needed. For this review, one (1) Private placement client was selected for the sample to assess the level of care and services they receive. Additionally, LPA reviewed two (2) staff files for compliance with Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Requirements. LPA also conducted interviews with two staff members and two clients. An exit interview was conducted. LPA provided the facility representative above a signed copy the LIC 809 and LIC 811 reports. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of this inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carrie Palmer conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility on 4/28/2023 at 10:30 AM for the purpose of conducting a required annual inspection. LPA met with Program Director Karla Carrillo. LPA reviewed a copy of an updated Personnel Report (LIC 500), The Register of Facility Clients/Residents listing 6 children and the Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities. LPA along with the facility staff conducted a tour of the facility inside and outside of the home. There are 6 clients currently residing in the home. The following was observed during the inspection: Physical Plant/Personal Accommodations (Buildings and Grounds) - The facility is a two story home. LPA observed the following on the first floor: Four (4) bedrooms,1 office (for Program Director), 1 dining room, 1 kitchen, 1 storage area for medications and bio hazards, 1 pool, 3 bathrooms (2 for clients 1 for staff), 1 living room, and added storage space / laundry room. On the 2nd story, LPA observed 2 office spaces (For therapist), an entrance to the roof, 1 process group room, 1 bathroom (for staff), and the water heater/broiler. In the living room area on a table is a Facility License and a HIPPA Confidentiality Information pamphlet. LPA observed privacy practices documents. Emergency Disaster Plan, client grievances and Title 22 Personal Rights (LIC 613B) were also posted. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom # 1 sleeps 2 clients and has two twin beds, two dressers and closet Bedroom # 2 sleeps 2 clients and has two twin beds, two dressers and closet Bedroom # 3 sleeps 2 clients but only has one child in that room and has two twin beds, two dressers and closet. Bedroom # 4 (VIP Room) sleeps 1 client and has 1 twin beds, 1 dresser and locked closet. . All beds are clean and in good repair. Bedding and sheets were sufficient.

Food Service - The facility maintains adequate perishable and non-perishable food supplies; the menu plans for the week and weekly program schedules is located on the refrigerator. The kitchen utensils, glasses and dishes were found to be in good condition. In the laundry room next to the kitchen is a backup refrigerator, locked cleaning supplies and a sharp log to track the number knives being used. Emergency evacuation plans are visually placed near the client’s restrooms and near exits. On the second floor, LPA observed an emergency plan booklet and clients rights posted. Additionally, there are two couches used for staff meetings. The Administrator’s office and an open office are located upstairs. All windows and doors are operable in the home. LPA observed a properly secured swimming pool and jacuzzi (used as a small pool; as the hot water is turned off for safety) in the backyard enclosed with a five foot fence with a self- latching gate. The front and backyard were inspected and found to be free from hazards. The sliding glass door in the staff area faces the backyard and was operable. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be in the mandated range (degree). All exits were free of hazards and all doors opened freely. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activity. Exit signs were posted throughout the facility. Sharp knives, medications, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to children. A review of staff records indicates that all facility staff or other individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Interviews: LPA interviewed 3 staff ( The Program Director, and 2 Mental Health Tech 2's) There are currently 14 staff working at the facility. File Review: No file reviews were conducted during this inspection.

All adult individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemption. In accordance with California Code of Regulation, Title 22, Division 6. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of the LIC 809, 809C, and LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative. At the time of this inspection there are no deficiencies cited per Title 22 regulations.

facility_name: CENTER FOR DISCOVERY MOOD&ANXIETY PROGRAM, SAC MH
narrative:
On June 24, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jessica Caplinger and Yuvi Diaz conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of the required 2 year inspection. LPAs met with Rob Thomas, Regional Director, and Armando Orneles, Facility Manager (FM). Walk through was conducted with FM. Administrator (AD), Britney Gay arrived and conducted the remainder of the inspection with LPAs. During the course of this inspection, LPAs observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. Six staff and six clients were present during inspection. Two staff took five clients on an outing shortly after LPAs arrived to facility and returned later in the inspection. Postings observed in the entryway included the facility license, personal rights and accreditations. The facility is equipped with 4 bedrooms for client use and 3.5 bathrooms. Bedroom #1 is a single set up while bedrooms #2-4 are doubles. The home has a large family room inside the entry way to be utilized for visitation, relaxation and phone conversations, and a large dining room on the other side of the entry. The home has a large kitchen which opens to the main family room/group space. Kitchen was observed with a stocked fridge and freezer with adequate food supply and perishables. Menu was observed posted. On the back of the family room is a small separate space that has been designed to be an art therapy studio. Both the family room and art room open up to a large covered patio with outdoor bbq, ping pong table and several sitting areas. Over the counter medications, first aid supplies and a refrigerator for medication that may need cold storage are all locked . There are several cupboards in the bathrooms and hall with an abundance of linens, towels and cleaning supplies. The attached two car garage has an extra refrigerator and storage space. Report continues on LIC 809-C

There is a second separate building with a garage and an apartment suite on the second floor that is being utilized for the therapy offices. There are no fire arms or bodies of water. All dangerous objects and chemicals are locked. Facility is well maintained and clean through out, the facility is comfortable and set up to support clients. Fire extinguishers are up to date, carbon monoxide was tested and in working condition, water temperature was on average at 110 degrees throughout the facility, and the first aid kit was stocked. Medication is stored correctly and locked. Sharps are kept locked in the locked office. Staff and client files are kept secured. A review of licensing information system was done on 5/31/22 indicating that all staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. The facility currently has six clients, two full time clinicians, six full time staff and two part time staff. LPAs interviewed three clients and two staff. LPAs reviewed three staff and three client files. Review of staff files indicate that staff have current training in CPR, FA, AED, disaster preparedness and meet the educational and medical health requirements. Client files contained copies of personal rights, needs and services plans, medical history and consent form. CARE Tools completed. The following domains were completed: Physical Plant, Operations, Emergency Intervention, Disaster Preparedness, Client Files, and Staffing. No deficiencies were noted at this inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Britney Gay, administrator, and a final copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

met_with: Executive Director Rob Ayala, Administrator Britney Gay, Facility Manager Sara Stokes
narrative: Based on interviews and record review, it is unclear how R1 obtained the pods, but R1 reported to have obtained them by picking a lock and pulling the container open. However, LPA was not able to speak to R1 directly to confirm this. The facility does not keep a record of when residents do their laundry or which staff is assigned to supervise, and staff reported that they do not know which staff would have been on shift when R1 obtained the pods. The facility’s system is to have residents assigned a color corresponding to a day of the week, based on their day of admission, and on their day of the week, they wash, dry, and put away their laundry. Due to this lack of record keeping, it cannot be determined how R1 obtained the laundry pods. The laundry pods were kept locked but were accessible to residents during laundry time. If R1 obtained the pods during laundry time, it is possible that R1 was not supervised well enough, allowing R1 to grab one or two in excess or grab them and not place in the washer and then hide them on R1’s person to later hide in R1’s room. If R1 obtained the laundry pods outside of laundry time, it is possible that during a lapse of supervision, R1 was able to break into the laundry pod container. The facility has since improved their laundry procedure to keep laundry pods locked at all times and ensure staff supervise more carefully, including having staff access the laundry pods themselves for the youth rather than youth grabbing them themselves. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. The facility is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84065.2 Personnel Duties. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Executive Director Rob Ayala, Administrator Britney Gay, Facility Manager Sara Stokes, Regulatory Affairs Coordinator Jin Kim, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA.
investigation_findings: 13On Monday 11/09/20 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to open a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Executive Director Rob Ayala, Administrator Britney Gay, Facility Manager Sara Stokes, Regulatory Affairs Coordinator Jin Kim. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with program staff and victim R1’s (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) therapists and authorized representative and reviewed R1’s records and staff shift note related to the incident. Based on interviews and record review, R1 obtained two laundry pods, stored them in R1’s drawer, and ingested them at night while in their room. R1 was feeling upset and showed them to R1’s roommate as R1 swallowed one pod. The roommate immediately informed staff S1, who called 911. S1 had offered to counsel R1 earlier in the day, after noticing that R1 seemed “off,” but R1 refused the meeting with S1.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84065.2 Personnel Duties (b) Child care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review, the licensee did not ensure that youth were supervised at all times, allowing for R1 to obtain two laundry pods, which are kept locked in the facility, and R1 then ingested one. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

deficiencies.title: Personnel Duties (b) Child care staff shall perform the following duties
deficiencies.description: (1) Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times.

narrative: At 11:23AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madeleine Fremont traveled to the home above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Required - 2 Year Inspection. LPA met with Program Director Virginia Parish, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 3 ambulatory clients. During this visit, LPA toured the home inside and out. The home has 4 client bedrooms, 5 bathrooms, and 3 therapists offices. No bodies of water. All walkways are unobstructed. The home is well lit and equipped with comfortable furnishings. LPA observed 3 fire extinguishers, all of which were inspected on 03/28/2022. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are located throughout the house. Smoke detectors were tested and are functional. The thermostat was set to 70 degrees upon arrival. In the kitchen, LPA observed at least 2 days of perishable food and at least 7 days of nonperishable food. The kitchen was clean and free from hazards. Sharps are kept locked away from client access. LPA toured the backyard and front yard on the property. The front yard has an enclosed courtyard which has a table and chairs for client leisure. There is a non-operational fire place in the courtyard that is closed by a glass cover. One non-operational fireplace in the living room as well. The backyard surrounds the home on 2 sides, and is enclosed by a wooden fence on all sides. LPA observed 3-4 boards which had come loose in a recent wind storm, and the facility will be submitting a work order to their handyman today 04/27/2022. Facility will send proof of this fix to LPA once it is completed. During this visit, LPA inspected 3 client files. All files were in order with required documentation. One client's admission agreement is missing authorized representative signature, but it is noted this form was sent for signature and has not been returned. LPA Mariah Hawkins will return on another day to inspect staff files, med count, and conduct interviews with staff and clients. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility for their records.

narrative: On Thursday 5/5/22 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a continuation of the 2-year required inspection initiated on 4/27/22. LPA met with Program Director Virginia Parish and Assistant Milieu Manager Cecily Smith and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. During the 4/27/22 inspection, the physical plant was inspected and resident/patient files were reviewed. During today's inspection, LPA inspected resident/patient medications and personnel records and conducted staff and resident interviews. No deficiencies were found during medication record and storage review. During review of personnel records, which are stored electronically, it was observed that four (4) staff [S1, S2, S3, and S4] (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 5/5/22) had no LIC 508 Criminal Record Statement in their personnel records. Licensee's Human Resources Department stated that the form was not maintained in the records for staff hired prior to the program switching to a new electronic filing service. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80066(A)(12)(a) Personnel Records. Staff S4 is also missing the LIC 501 Personnel Record. LPA is issuing an advisory of Title 22, Section 80066(a)(6). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Program Director Virginia Parish, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Program Director Virginia Parish, Assistant Millieu Manager Cecily Smith
narrative:
... oral sex, “fingering” (or digital sex) in the living room while night staff was not looking, and kissing and sexual acts in the laundry room during the day. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Program Director Virginia Parish, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

... the full movie was shown or that residents have felt traumatized/re-traumatized by media at the facility. Additionally, a book on the Wicca faith was read by R1 while in care, but it could not be determined how the youth obtained the book, and staff named as the one who brought it in and approved it denied doing so, stating, as supported by the plan of operation and staff statements, that they are not the one responsible for approving books and would not have done so. The facility removed the book upon authorized representative’s request. The facility policy is to have the therapist and/or facility manager approve media (books, movies) available to clients while in care. However, the facility does not keep a list of already approved books or movies nor of movies or media shown to residents. LPA advises, as best practice, that the facility consider maintaining a list of approved films and books and/or maintain a log of films shown on movie nights. Based on the report, the allegation “Facility not meeting minor's educational needs” pertains to resident R1 not completing homework while in treatment. Based on interviews and record review, R1 was not completing all homework assignments, but was completing treatment goals. R1 was allowed to schedule therapy sessions during homework blocks, but 20 hours are provided a week for homework completion. In the remainder of that time, R1 did not complete all homework assignments. Staff statements indicate that, as a short-term treatment program, the program prioritizes patients’/residents' well-being and treatment goals. The program plan of operation provides that completing homework is a house rule, but staff statements indicate that staff cannot force patients to complete homework. Based on the report, the allegation “Facility not following admission agreement” pertains to R1 not receiving 24/7 supervision, as stated in the parent welcome packet provided at admission. Based on interviews and record review, R1 was to receive 24/7 care and be checked at least every 15 minutes. The parent welcome packet provides for four phases with different supervision requirements and privileges. R1 achieved a higher phase and was dropped according to behaviors. Following R1’s suicide attempt, supervision was enhanced. Additionally, shift notes indicate staff were attentive to R1, and R1’s statements indicate that R1’s incidents occurred in part specifically in brief moments when staff turned around and that R1 felt comfortable talking to staff about their treatment goals. The investigation found that there was a lack of supervision resulting in residents engaging in sexual behaviors at the facility, but it could not be determined that a lack of supervision resulted in other violations.

Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents, staff, and witnesses, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Program Director Virginia Parish, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

The investigation found that residents disclosed the incidents and confirmed there were multiple incidents of sexual acts between these residents, including...

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview, licensee did not ensure the provision of the necessary supervision due to residents R1 and R2 (See LIC 811) engaging in multiple incidents of sexual acts while in care. narrative:
On 4/26/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE inspection tool was used to complete this inspection. During visit, LPA conducted interviews with two staff and two residents and toured the facility site. LPA verified that everyone on the staff schedule has a background clearance reflected on Guardian. LPA observed that the facility was clean, organized, and pathways free of obstructions or hazards. There are no bodies of water. The kitchen was fully stocked with a varied supply of food within date. Bathrooms were sanitary. Bedrooms have clean linens and ample storage space. Hot water temperature measured within permitted range. LPA observed that there are seven beds, three double-occupancy bedrooms and one single-occupancy bedroom. Administrator stated the extra bed is to better accommodate youth with different needs or different gender identities and that the facility has not used the bed to exceed the capacity. LPA advised that the facility cannot have more beds than the licensed capacity and advised either removing the bed in the single-occupancy room or removing the second bed in the room next to it, as these are the two smaller rooms and share a bathroom. A continuation visit will be required to complete the personnel file review. The LIC 311B was provided for the future to allow the licensee to consider different methods for ensuring these forms, which the licensee maintains but which are not all easily accessible during licensing visits, are available for future visits. For the continuation visit, LPA requested the following be consolidated in a printed or electronic format that is ready for review by LPA for staff S1, S2, S3, S4, and S5 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names): LIC 501 or resume; LIC 503 or health screening and TB test results; LIC 508 criminal record statement; LIC 9108 mandated reporter statement; LIC 9052 employee rights; initial training documentation; annual/continued training, including intervention/de-escalation training, with verification of hours received and training certificates, for no less...

... than the last 12 months; CPI certificate; and first aid certificate. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/26/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit as a follow-up to the January 2023 noncompliance conference (NCC). LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the NCC terms, the following was to be completed: (2) to ensure staff were fully trained, per applicable regulations, at hire and additionally on no less than a quarterly basis; (3) to designate two overnight staff each night with at least one being a facility manager, meeting this requirement by March 13, 2023; (4) to designate an administrator to oversee only one facility, meeting this requirement by March 13, 2023; (5) to revise the plan of operation / program statement (POO/PS) and/or develop an addendum to include discussion of the use and purpose of motion sensors in the facility, meeting this requirement by March 13, 2023; (6) to provide notification of desire to utilize technical support program (TSP) services by January 25, 2023; and (7), if desired, submitting a central administrative facility waiver by January 25, 2023. See the notes by the corresponding number below. (2) During the visit, LPA reviewed staff training and interviewed staff. Interviews and training records reflect that trainings are conducted at monthly staff meetings and include the topics of supervision, de-escalation, and reporting requirements. Staff interviewed were knowledgeable of facility procedures, and resident reports support appropriate staff supervision. (3) LPA obtained a current LIC 500. The facility has designated two staff for each night. There is at least one facility manager on each night shift. The facility is conducting 15-minute bed check rounds during the night, and staff log and sign off on each check for each resident. The logs were available for LPA's review, and LPA observed checks each night. LPA advises that staff sign/initial at each check rather than drawing a line down the page to indicate no change, as better verification of separate checks. [CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE]

(4) The facility had a candidate for the administrator role who ended up leaving the organization. Another candidate has been hired but still needs to complete administrator training. (5) LPA has not received a POO/PS addendum or revision. LPA is granting one extension. The revision/addendum to meet the requirement as stated above and in the NCC report provided to the licensee is requested to be submitted no later than May 1, 2023. (6) The licensee was referred for TSP services. (7) The licensee has decided to not request a central administrative facility waiver at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

(3) Designate two overnight staff each night with at least one being a facility manager. | The facility had some overnight staff leave the agency, but the facility is hiring and has an on-call for overnight. The facility is continuing to work toward maintaining two overnight staff and has reduced their census to 3. (4) Designate an administrator to oversee only one facility. | The licensee had two candidates who did not remain in the role. The licensee has a third candidate who has been enrolled in the administrator training. (5) Revise the plan of operation / program statement (POO/PS) and/or develop an addendum to include discussion of the use and purpose of motion sensors in the facility. | An extension was granted. Administrator confirmed it was in progress, and the draft document was shown to LPA during visit. LPA is requesting submission no later than 8/31/23, allowing time for internal approvals. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 3/6/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit in order to deliver notice of deficiencies found during the course of an investigation or inspection at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and Lead Tech Carolyn Williams and informed of the purpose of the visit. It was learned that two residents of different genders were allowed to share a bedroom. One resident identifies as a boy and one as a girl. An investigation of a report that one of these residents sexually assaulted the roommate found that the incident occurred in part due to the residents sharing a bedroom. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 84072 Personal Rights. Additionally, no documented bedroom sharing arrangement could be supplied upon request. Therefore, LPA is issuing a citation of CCR, Title 22, Section 84087 Buildings and Grounds. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sara Stokes, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 4/22/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Sara Stokes and informed of the purpose of the visit. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA toured the facility site and grounds, reviewed facility records, and conducted confidential interviews with two staff and two residents. Personnel records reflect staff have completed required training and are on track to complete the required hours of training this year. Additionally, all staff whose files were reviewed have a background clearance and eligibility to work on site. Resident records were complete, and emergency contact information is contained within their records. Each resident has an individual care plan. Medications are locked away. Chemicals are stored where inaccessible to residents. No hazards were observed on the premises, all bedrooms offer individual beds and ample storage, and all kitchen and bathroom spaces are maintained in sanitary condition. Based on LPA's observations and the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiency citations were issued. LPA observed one area where technical support may be beneficial. See LIC 9102 dated 4/22/24.
