narrative:
On 1/23/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a quarterly case management inspection in accordance with the terms agreed upon during the January 2023 Noncompliance Conference (NCC). LPA met with Administrator Carolyn Williams and explained the purpose of the visit. As outlined in the NCC terms and previous inspections, several requirements were reviewed. Staff training records showed compliance, with all staff fully trained at the time of hire and receiving additional training on a quarterly basis. The Administrator agreed to submit an updated LIC 500 along with specific documents for all Staff, including LIC 501 forms, First Aid and CPI training certifications, and current training records for the past 12 months, by end of today. Overnight staffing requirements have been met consistently, with two staff members present each night, including at least one facility manager. Bed check logs were complete and organized, though some discrepancies were noted. The Administrator clarified these issues and described the corrective actions taken promptly. Regarding administrative oversight, the facility has transitioned leadership roles. The former administrator has been promoted, and the previous lead facility manager has assumed the administrator position. Carolyn Williams passed the Administrator exam on 11/27/24 and now is a certified Administrator. LPA reviewed the facility’s overall compliance over the past quarter. Although no reports requiring follow-up had been submitted, it was discovered during the inspection that some reportable incidents had occurred in recent months. These were determined to be high-priority incidents that could require a follow-up. LPA provided guidance on proper reporting procedures and requirements and was assured by Administrator that the incident reports will be submitted by tomorrow. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 80061(b)(1).

The facility has received two complaints, but no deficiencies in the past quarter. One deficiency was cited during todays inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator, Carolyn Williams.

Control Number - 0001526-FN On March 11, 2025, at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jonathan Medina and Cole Oliver conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPAs met with Carolyn Williams, Program Administrator. An IR was submitted regarding an event that occurred on February 23, 2025. According to the IR, a CPI restraint was conducted to bring client back into the facility. Administrator was able to provide further details about the clients elevated state that made the CPI restraint possible to protect the client from being a danger to themselves. Administrator noted that the client admitted to having suicidal ideations. Administrator explained that the client is now stable and a safety plan was created to improve the clients care outlining preventative measures. During the visit LPAs were able to confirm all involved staff are CPI certified. LPA's interviewed 3 staff and 4 clients. No violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Carolyn Williams, Program Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 03/25/25 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint investigation visit to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Administrator Carolyn Williams and informed her of the purpose of the visit.The complaint alleged that the Licensee is not addressing pest issues at the facility, staff do not distribute residents' medications as prescribed, staff do not ensure that the facility is maintained in a sanitary condition, and staff sleep during the overnight shift. Based on confidential interviews, record reviews, and observations, although the above allegations may have occurred or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the above-listed allegations did or did not occur. Therefore, the above allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Carolyn Williams, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On May 14, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a visit to the facility in connection with an incident that came to light during interviews conducted on a prior visit on May 7, 2025. LPA met with Carolyn Williams, Program Administrator, and informed her of the reason for the visit. The incident involved a client being discharged from the facility due to inappropriate physical contact with other clients. The Administrator confirmed that the incident occurred and stated that law enforcement had been contacted. The facility discharged the client immediately in accordance with proper follow-up procedures. Reported client was transferred to higher-level of care. However, because the facility failed to report an incident that is considered reportable, a citation is being issued for a violation of the California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 80061(b)(1) – Reporting Requirements. The Administrator explained to LPA that there had been a mix-up in the spelling of the email address to which the incident report was sent. At this time, one deficiency has been issued. Additionally, a civil penalty of $250 was assessed for a repeat deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Carolyn Williams, Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80061(b)(1) Reporting Requirements (b)Upon the occurrence... within seven days following the occurrence of such event. (1)Events reported shall include the following: This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the administrator did not ensure reportable incidents were being sent to licensing, which poses a potential risk to Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On 5/15/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina made a visit to the home regarding outstanding Plans of Correction (POCs). Upon entering the home, LPA met with Carolyn Williams, Facility Administrator, and informed her of the reason for the visit. During LPA’s initial annual inspection on 4/30/2025, three POCs were assessed for deficiencies observed during the inspection. For the deficiency cited under Title 22, Section 84068.2(a), regarding clients’ Needs and Services Plans not being completed, the Administrator provided completed Needs and Services Plans for five clients. LPA reminded the facility that Needs and Services Plans must be developed upon each client's admission to the facility. For the deficiency cited under Title 22, Section 84070(c)(3), regarding a client’s vaccination history, the required documentation was submitted by the client's parent. The Administrator presented the document to LPA, and it was confirmed to be accurate. For the deficiency cited under Title 22, Section 80069(c)(1), regarding a client not having a completed TB test, the test remains incomplete. The facility attempted to have the test administered on 5/2/2025 at 3:00 PM, but the clinic did not proceed due to the absence of a doctor’s order. As a result, a civil penalty of $1,000 was assessed for failure to correct the deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with the Appeal Rights, was provided to Administrator Carolyn Williams.

On 04/30/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Carolyn Williams and informed her of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. During the visit, LPA verified that all staff listed on the staff schedule have background clearances as reflected in Guardian. At approximately 1:00 PM, LPA began the Client Records Checklist section of the CARE Tool. The facility maintains all client documents in an online system called Kipu EMR. LPA Medina used the LIC858 checklist to document observations. Upon review, some client records were missing Needs and Services Plans, and one client was missing both a TB test and immunization records. Please refer to the LIC809-D for further information. At approximately 3:00 PM, LPA began reviewing the Staffing section of the CARE Tool. The facility maintains staff records across multiple platforms, including the internal Dayforce website, Navex One training program, and Dayforce training program. Additional missing documents were emailed by HR during the visit. LPA recommended that, for future licensing visits, all training and personnel documents be organized into a centralized folder for each staff member to facilitate future audits. Please refer to LIC9102 for further details. Continues on LIC809-C

At approximately 5:00 PM although there was not sufficient time to conduct a thorough physical plant inspection, LPA conducted a general walk through of the home and found it to be clean and in good repair. A continuation visit will be required to complete the annual inspection. During today's visit, LPA completed the review of client and staff records. The LIC311B was provided to the licensee for future reference to assist in organizing documentation. It is recommended that the licensee consider methods to ensure that required forms, although maintained, are accessible and readily available during licensing visits. As a result of this inspection, three deficiencies are being cited in accordance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 84070(c)(3), 80069(c)(1), and 84068.2(a). Please refer to the LIC809-D pages for additional information. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Carolyn Williams, Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On May 14, 2025, at approximately 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced annual/random inspection (continuation) at the above-mentioned facility. Upon arrival, LPA met with Program Administrator Carolyn Williams. The facility is licensed to serve up to six (6) clients. At the time of the inspection, there were four (4) clients and five (5) staff members present. At approximately 2:00 PM, LPA Medina began the physical plant inspection using the CARES Inspection Tool. The facility was observed to be clean, organized, and free of obstructions or hazards. No bodies of water were present. The kitchen was adequately stocked with a variety of food items, all within expiration dates. Bathrooms were found to be sanitary. There are a total of six (6) beds, arranged in three (3) double-occupancy bedrooms. All bedrooms had clean linens and sufficient storage space. The hot water temperature measured within the required range: 118.9°F at the shower faucet and 102.3°F at the bathroom sink. No deficiencies were observed in this section. At approximately 3:00 PM, LPA began reviewing the operational requirements of the CARES Inspection Tool. During the review, the program statement was initially misplaced but was located toward the end of the visit. Upon review, it was noted that the board of directors listed in the document was not recognized by the Administrator. Additionally, no records of board of directors meetings were available for review at the time of the visit (refer to LIC 809-D). Records of prior Licensing visits from the past three (3) years were also not immediately available but were located later during the inspection. LPA advised the Administrator to store all essential documents in a centralized location to ensure accessibility during future Licensing inspections. Continues on LIC809-C.

The annual inspection is not yet complete. LPA Medina will return to complete the remaining components of the inspection, including staff and client interviews, at a later date. As a result of this inspection, one deficiency is being cited in accordance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84063(a) – Accountability. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the Appeal Rights was provided to Administrator Carolyn Williams.

deficiencies.title:
Accountability

(a) The board of directors shall be active in ensuring accountability, and shall perform, at a minimum, the following duties

narrative:
On May 15, 2025, at approximately 3:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced annual/random inspection (continuation) at the above-mentioned facility. Upon arrival, LPA met with Program Administrator Carolyn Williams. The facility is licensed to serve up to six (6) clients. At the time of the inspection, there were four (4) clients and five (5) staff members present. At approximately 3:30 PM, LPA began reviewing the Disaster Preparedness section of the CARE Inspection Tool with the Administrator. The facility maintains a backpack stocked and ready at all times in case of an emergency, which contains essential documents for each client, including medication lists, Needs and Services Plans, contact information, and insurance information. No deficiencies were observed in this section of the CARE Inspection Tool. At approximately 3:40 PM, LPA began reviewing the Emergency Intervention Plan section of the CARE Inspection Tool. Staff at the facility are trained in CPI (Crisis Prevention Institute) intervention techniques. LPA verified staff training by randomly reviewing staff files, which confirmed completion of the required training. At 4:00 PM, LPA reviewed the Special Health Care Needs section of the CARE Inspection Tool. There are currently no clients with special health care needs residing at the facility. Continues on LIC809-C

At 4:15 PM, LPA began conducting interviews. Two (2) staff members and two (2) clients were interviewed, in accordance with regulations. During the course of the interviews, LPA discovered that the facility has been operating outside of its approved Plan of Operation regarding the number of therapy sessions provided to clients. Currently, the facility conducts only one (1) individual therapy session and one (1) family therapy session per week. However, the approved Plan of Operation states that the facility will provide 2–3 individual therapy sessions and two (2) family therapy sessions per week. Please refer to LIC-809D for details. As a result of this inspection, one deficiency is being cited in accordance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80022(k) – Plan of Operation. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with the Appeal Rights, was provided to Administrator Carolyn Williams.

However, the facility is being cited for the second allegation in regards to clients cleaning hazardous material as a violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Section 84072(d)(1) – Personal Rights. Please refer to LIC9909-D for details. At this time, one deficiency has been issued. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Lewis Farias, Milieu Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/29/24 at 12:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint inspection at Center for Discovery and spoke with Lewis Farias, Milieu Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Based on LPA’s interviews with staff and clients, as well as a review of records, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegations—that staff did not ensure the minor received therapy sessions and that staff forced minors to clean hazardous material—are SUBSTANTIATED. Regarding the first allegation about therapy sessions, the facility was recently cited for not providing the number of therapy sessions agreed upon in the Plan of Operation. The facility still needs time to correct deficiency therfore no deficiciency is being cited. Continues on LIC9909-C.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(1) Personal Rights (d)The licensee shall ensure... as applicable: (1)To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home... and political ties. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and observation the facility did not ensure clients lived in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home by having them clean an area with rat feces, which poses a potential risk to Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative:
On 7/24/25, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jonathan Medina and Omar Sawyer conducted a quarterly case management inspection in accordance with the terms agreed upon during the January 2023 Noncompliance Conference (NCC). LPAs met with Administrator Carolyn Williams and explained the purpose of the visit. The NCC visits were extended for an additional two quarters due to continued non-compliance observed between April and June. As outlined in the NCC terms and during previous inspections, several requirements were reviewed. Documents observed on this visit indicated compliance, with all staff receiving the required training at the time of hire and additional training on a quarterly basis. LPAs reviewed an updated LIC 500 and supporting documentation for three staff—including LIC 501 forms, First Aid and CPI certifications, and current training records for the past 12 months. All other staff were already reviewed in a recent annual facility inspection completed on 5/15/2025 meeting this quarters requirements. Overnight staffing requirements have been consistently met, with two staff members present during each overnight shift, including one facility manager. During review of the June schedule, LPAs observed the use of nurses to cover staff ratio requirements. Further investigation is needed to determine whether the use of the nurse registry is being correctly implemented at the facility. Bed check logs were reviewed and found to be complete and organized. Although there were some discrepancies in the physical folder, proof that bed check rounds were conducted was found in the digital bed check log. Regarding administrative oversight, Carolyn Williams passed the Administrator examination on 11/27/24 and is now a certified Administrator. Administrator was confirmed to be only working at one home and meet the 20hr requirement of being at the home as reviewed on staff schedules. Continues on LIC809-C

LPAs reviewed the facility’s overall compliance over the past quarter. In recent months, the facility has experienced multiple compliance issues, particularly related to reporting requirements, staff conduct, adherence to the facility’s Plan of Operation, and one instance of lack of supervision. On 1/13/2025, during a prior NCC visit, the facility was cited for failing to report unusual incidents. This deficiency was discovered during LPA’s review of facility records. During the initial annual inspection conducted on 4/30/2025, the facility was cited for failing to develop Needs and Services Plans for the clients reviewed, and one client was found to be missing a TB test. On 5/5/2025, a complaint was received alleging that staff made inappropriate comments to a minor. This allegation was substantiated. On 5/12/2025, another complaint was filed alleging that staff spoke inappropriately to a minor in care. This allegation was also substantiated. Both complaints involved the same staff member, who has since been terminated. The related deficiencies were promptly addressed and cleared. On 5/14/2025, during the investigation of another complaint, LPAs discovered through confidential interviews that significant incidents had not been reported. As a result, a civil penalty was issued for a repeat deficiency related to reporting requirements. The home was referred to TSP services with Selena Hood and completed a training on reporting requirements and mandated reporting. LPA Medina observed that incident reporting had significantly improved following the TSP training. On 5/29/2025, the facility received two substantiated complaint allegations. The first stated that staff did not ensure a minor received therapy sessions. The second stated that staff forced minors to clean hazardous materials. Additionally, during the continuation of the annual inspection on 5/15/2025, LPA identified deficiencies related to the frequency of therapy sessions being provided. Staff interviews and client statements confirmed that only one individual and one family therapy session per week were being conducted. However, per the facility’s Plan of Operation, each client is to receive two to three individual therapy sessions and two family therapy sessions per week. The facility is currently working on submitting an updated Plan of Operation to reflect the revised therapy schedule. Lastly, on 6/02/2025, the facility received a complaint alleging that the facility failed to provide supervision sufficient to meet clients' needs. This allegation was substantiated. The staff member involved in the incident has since been terminated and deficiency cleared immediately. All Plans of Corrections (POCs) for the above deficiencies have been cleared, with the exception of the updated Plan of Operation, which is still under review by LPA. Three confidential client interviews were conducted, and staff interview data has already been collected during the recent annual inspection. No deficiencies were observed on todays visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Carolyn Williams.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/11/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a visit to the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator Carolyn Williams and explained the purpose of the visit. Based on a review of confidential records and interviews, although the allegations may have occurred or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to support that the allegation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is deemed unsubstantiated. The incident reportedly occurred three years ago, and several pertinent documents—such as shift notes, internal incident reports, staff interviews, staff schedules, and staff files (including documentation of supervision training)—were not available for review due to the amount of time that has passed. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Carolyn Williams. Her signature on this form acknowledges receipt.

narrative: Control Number - 0001979-FN On August 8th, 2025 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Will Ea conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility to follow up on an Incident Report. LPA met with the facility administrator, Carolyn Williams. At time of arrival, four staff members and four clients were present. The incident report in review was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on July 15th, 2025. According to the report, a client had refused to relinquish a butter knife and held the knife in a threatening manner towards staff. Staff intervened and the client tossed away the knife and attempted to self-regulate in their room. Staff maintained Line of Sight watch on client while giving space to self-regulate. Client expressed ideation to physically harm staff and thus law enforcement was contacted, placing the client on a psychiatric hold. A few days after returning from hold, the client was discharged from the facility. LPA conducted two staff interviews, including an interview with the staff member directly involved in the incident, and one client interview. LPA took pictures of the drawer where utensils are stored. Based off interviews, it was determined staff reacted appropriately to protect the health and safety of clients in care, staff, and the dysregulated client. No deficiencies were observed or cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the facility.

Based on LPA’s interviews with staff and clients, as well as a review of records, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Since the staff member in the allegation was terminated the Plan of Correction (POC) was cleared immediately. At this time, one deficiency has been issued. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Carolyn Williams, Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 6/20/25 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint investigation visit to deliver the investigation findings. LPA met with Carolyn Williams, Administrator, and informed her of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, although the above allegation may have occurred or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the allegation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. While interviews confirmed that the staff member was ill, there is no evidence to support that the staff member was under the influence or that alcohol was visibly present at any time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Carolyn Williams, Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

13On 7/2/25 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint inspection at Center for Discovery and spoke with Carolyn Williams, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Based on LPA’s interviews with staff and clients, as well as a review of records, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegation—Facility does not provide supervision to meet clients' needs—is SUBSTANTIATED. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and file review the facility did not ensure clients were being supervised, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On 09/03/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a case management to discuss the facility's current Administrator. The prior administrator left the facility and paperwork has not been received for a new administrator as of this date. Discussed with Program Manager Sarah Weins and she advised that she will inform the corporate office that information has still not been received by Community Care Licensing. Due to COVID-19 restrictions, the information was discussed via telephone and this document was scanned to Ms. Weins on this date with a request for signature and scan back.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/04/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a follow up complaint inspection and met with Administrator Britney Gay. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, the inspections was conducted by tele-inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Residents were interviewed and were consistent in stating that they were meeting in the hallway to kiss each other or entering rooms prior to bedtime without staff knowledge. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there was a lack of supervision that resulted in inappropriate behaviors between residents. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with the Administrator. A copy of this report was scanned to the Administrator with a request for signature and a scan back on this date. Deficiency on the attached page.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on the interviews conducted with the residents, the interviews were consistent that the residents would meet in the hallway and kiss before bedtime or go to each other's rooms without staff knowledge which poses an immediate risk to the Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Daiquiri Boyd and Charles Kinney conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual Continuation inspection. LPAs met with Katee Wheaton Milieu Manager and Program Director Roshonda Cureton The Group Home (GH) currently has 6 clients in placement. LPAs asked for updated copies of LIC308 Designation of Administrative Responsibility, LIC309 Adminstrative Organization, and a copy of the new lease to be presented to Licensing by email. Interviews of all clients were completed at this visit. A Technical Violation was issued at this visit for one staff due to a CPR expired date of 09/13/21. A copy of the report was provided to the GH at conclusion of inspection.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Daiquiri Boyd and Charles Kinney conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs met with Katee Wheaton Milieu Manager and Program Director Roshonda Cureton A tour of the facility was conducted. The Group Home (GH) currently has 5 clients in placement. A file review was conducted, no prior deficiencies were found within the past 12 months. LPAs asked for updated copies of LIC308 Designation of Administrative Responsibility, LIC309 Adminstrative Organization, and a copy of the new lease to be presented to Licensing by October 1, 2021. A review of Licensing Information System on September 16, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the GH have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. No citations issued on today's visit. A copy of the report was provided to the GH at conclusion of inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection 7/13/22 at 10:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection,10 out of 12 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, July 13, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the safety plans and Needs and Services Plan the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Katee Wheaton.

investigation_findings: 13Complaint Specialist C.K. Kinney(CS) traveled to Center for Discovery, Fresno and met with Ciara Armstead. CS conducted confidential interviews and delivered findings of investigation. Based on review of documentation and confidential interviews CS was able to find a preponderance of the evidence that the allegation occurred. This facility is being cited for violation of Title XXII Division 6 Article 06 Chapter 1 section 80075(b)(5)(B) Health Related Services. Copy of this report, citation, and appeal rights provided to facility at conclusion of inspection

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Health related Services:The licensee shall ensure...(B) Once ordered by the physician the medication is given according to the physician's directions. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Confidential interviews and review of documentation demonstrated Patient was out of prescribed medication, and staff was unable to obtain refill in timely manner.

narrative:
On 3/1/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted an unannounced annual inspection. Met at the facility by Facility Manager Ciera Armstead. Additionally present are two mental health techs and a Therapist. A facility physical plant was conducted upon arrival to the facility. 1. Facility Grounds were inspected. 2. Outdoor space observed. No bodies of water observed. 3. Chemicals are generally stored in locked garage cabinets. A few cleaning chemicals were observed under kitchen counter- a technical advisory was issued on this date. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications were observed on this date 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual was present upon inspection. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The house has 4 bedrooms, single or double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. At this time, because there are only 3 clients, each client has their own bedroom. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of non-perishable foods observed 10. Weekly menu observed 11. Dining room observed. Table and seating provided for all clients.. 12.Facility has two full restrooms, both for client use. Water temperature was within the regulatory range. 13. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility. insurance and registration are both current. Resident (Client) files reviewed from 1:30-2:30. 3 resident files reviewed. Files were substantially complete.

The current Program Director (Administrator) has recently left employment. The facility has a plan in place for a new certified administrator. A Technical Advisory note is provided to the facility on this date to note required documents for a change of Administrator. Facility is directed to work with their assigned Analyst, Charles Kinney (Charles.Kinney@dss.ca.gov). LPA Reviewed 6 (six) personnel records with assistance from HR personnel Accessing online files. As well as reviewed fingerprint/association records for all personnel. Review conducted between 2:30 pm and 3:30 pm. LPA will return at a later time to discuss and issue report regarding personnel records. Information regarding CPI Certifications Requested.

On the above date, LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) continued the Annual Inspection started on 3/1/23. Met with Facility Manager Ciera Armstead upon arrival at the facility. Robert Thomas, Regional Director was present for the inspection as well. During this inspection, LPA continued the review of personnel records, and completed reports, including technical violation and Technical Advisory. On this date, Citations are noted in the following areas, pursuant to CCR, Title 22, division 6, General Licensing or Group Home Regulations: Emergency Intervention Staff Training 84365(d)(1)(C) Personnel Records (84065(d)) Health Related Services 80076(f) On this date, advisory notes are provided in the following areas: Buildings and Grounds 80087(g) Administrator Qualifications 84065(d) Criminal Record Clearance 80019(e) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property and Belongings 80026(k) Licensee is requested to update and submit the following forms: LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility), LIC 309 (Administrative Organization) by 3/16/23

narrative: On March 25, 2022, at 2:30 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Smith conducted an Annual Inspection and met with Licensee, Tim Chapman. LPA disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility by the Licensee. The facility currently has no staff or clients. The facility is a 3-bedroom, 2-bathroom house. Licensee accompanied LPA inside and out of the facility during this inspection. At 2:40 pm LPA Smith toured the kitchen. There is one refrigerator, microwave, a stove with 4 gas burners and one pantry. Refrigerator is large enough to store enough perishable foods for at least 2 days. Pantry is large enough to store a food supply of at least 7 days. No deficiencies were noted in the kitchen area. At 2:50 p.m. the remainder of the inside of the facility was toured. Living room: Furniture has no visible damage. There is one sectional sofa. Dining room: Has one table, six chairs, and a bench. Garage: The garage is unattached and used for storage. It is always locked and not accessible to clients. The facility uses a stackable washer and dryer. No deficiencies were noted on the outside grounds at this time. There are no deficiencies according to the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Licensee, Tim Chapman, whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents.

On March 10, 2023 at 8:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a pre-licensing inspection for a Group Home license. Children’s Critical support Homes was previously licensed and is relocating to the above address for a new license. LPA met with Leilani Whitfield, Orange county regional director who led a tour of the group home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the director. The group home will have four clients; two of the clients will reside the 49 Mark lane and the other two clients at the 50 Mark lane with a total capacity of four. The group home is a story building sharing the address 49-50 Mark lane with two bedrooms, one bath and three bedrooms, one bath respectively which is set up as follow: 49 Mark lane · Bedroom #1 has a twin sized bed; it was vacant, it will sleep one client. · Bedroom #2 had a twin sized bed; it was vacant. It will sleep one client A living room, a kitchen, dining area, two storage, one bathroom, and the patio/backyard and a shared laundry room outside at the backyard. 50 Mark lane · Bedroom #3 had a full sized bed; it was vacant. It will sleep one client. · Bedroom #4 had a full sized bed. It was vacant. It will sleep one client. · Bedroom #5 it was furnished with office furniture. It is currently used as an office A living room, a kitchen, dining area, storage, one bathroom, and the patio/backyard and a shared laundry room outside at the backyard.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there was one client per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for client’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Inside the facility there was no fireplace. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet under the kitchen sink. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 107.5 degrees. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items and it was in the kitchen pantry. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by the facility, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pool or other body of water. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for relocation will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Leilani Whitfield

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi on 08/22/2023 at 09:29 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the visit, LPA Choi met with, Leilani Whitfied, Administrator and conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. No immediate health or safety risks were observed. narrative:
On September 4, 2024 at 10:00 AM Community Care Licensing (CCL) Licensing Program Analyst(LPA), Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced required annual inspection. LPA was met at the facility by Administrator Nolette Untalan. The facility is a licensed group home with the capacity of four clients ages 0 -17 years old and currently has a current census of four clients. The group home is a single story building sharing the address 49-50 Mark lane which is set up as follow: 49 Mark lane · Bedroom #1 has a full sized bed; It sleeps one client. · Bedroom #2 had a full sized bed; It sleeps one client A living room, a kitchen, dining area, two storage, one bathroom, and the patio/backyard and a shared laundry room outside at the backyard. 50 Mark lane · Bedroom #3 had a twin sized bed; It sleeps one client. · Bedroom #4 had a twin sized bed. It sleeps one client. · Bedroom #5 it was furnished with office furniture. It is currently used as an office A living room, a kitchen, dining area, storage, one bathroom, and the patio/backyard and a shared laundry room outside at the backyard. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There were dressers for each client and additional cabinet space for storage. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. Both kitchens had functioning appliances and secured cabinets for knives and cleaning supplies.

A physical plant inspection was completed using the Care Tools and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children’s recreation time. As stated by the facility, there are no weapons/firearms and there were no pool or other body of water. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Water temperature was within required range of 105-120 degrees and tested at 107.4 degrees. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. CCL reviewed four clients files during the time of inspection. Client files contained all required documents. Two facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. No clients were interviewed because they were at school. Facility reports that all clients due are nonverbal and not able to participate in an interview CCL reviewed six staff files. LPA observed deficiencies in staff files, All staff have not met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. Facility is being cited for Type A deficiency for not meeting Title 22 Continuing Care Requirements Section 1522(c)(1) Health and Safety Code. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811 dated 9/4/24, and Appeal Rights were provided to facility administrator, Nolette Untalan.

During the visit, LPA's met with Administrator Nolette Untalan.and conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. No immediate health or safety risks were observed. LPA reviewed 1 of child’s records and 3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 1 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records. On 03/26/2025 at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez attempted to conducted an unannounced annual visit to the facility listed above. LPA met with Nolette Untalan, Administrator. Due to technical difficulties, the Annual was unable to be conducted. LPA provided a copy of this report by email to Administrator Untalan due to printer malfunction.

On 04/30/25 at 9:50 AM Licensing Program Analyst(LPA), Gilbert Marquez conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPA was met at the facility by Veronica R, House Lead and Administrator Nolette Untalan. The facility is a licensed group home with the capacity of four clients ages 0 -17 years old and currently has a current census of four clients. The group home is a single-story building sharing the address 49-50 Mark Lane which is set up as follows: 49 Mark Lane has two bedrooms (#1 and #2), there is only one client per bedroom. One bedroom has a queen bed, and the other has a twin bed, and storage space. There is a living room, a kitchen, dining area, two storages, one bathroom, a patio/backyard and a shared laundry room located in the backyard. 50 Mark Lane has two bedrooms (#3 and #4), there is only one client per room and each room has a queen bed and storage room. There is an employee office, a living room, a kitchen, dining area, storage, one bathroom, and the patio/backyard with the shared laundry. Physical Plant inspect was completed with Veronica(S2). All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in locked cabinets. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. **Continued on LIC809-C**

Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. The water temperature was tested in bathroom one which measured 110.3F degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was observed to have all required supplies. All client files are stored and maintained on a secure internet database. LPA reviewed four of four client files to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed four client medication records. LPA reviewed five staff files out of 16 to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Staff records are stored via a secured records portal. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. LPA conducted three staff interviews (S1 – S3). Client interviews were not conducted as they have limited speech. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 02 Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status 80010(a) A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and client file review, one of four clients (C1) was 18 years of age. The current license for this facility only allows for children from 0 – 17 years of age. Therefore, a Type B violation is being given for C1 being placed beyond the license limitations. An exit interview was conducted, a plan of correction was created, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report, plan of correction, confidential names list, and appeal rights were provided to Nolette Untalan. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On November 20, 2020, at 11:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jesus Cervantes, conducted an unannounced case management visit at the facility and met with Facility Administrator, Alvin Mallillin. The purpose of this visit was to follow up on a letter from the Department of Social Services Caregiver Background Check Bureau dated November 06, 2020, Confirmation of Removal regarding Thomas Munoz.. Alvin Mallillin was advised LPA Mr. Munoz was hired in 2015. Mr. Munoz resigned from the facility on November 19, 2019. In response to the Caregiver Background Check Bureau letter dated November 06, 2020, a CBCB-3.1 form certifying that Mr. Munoz had been removed from the facility/home as of November 19, 2019 was completed and submitted to LPA. Based on evidence obtained during today’s visit, the LPA has verified the individual is not present or residing at the facility. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Facility Administrator, Alvin Mallillin. Due to COVID-19, a signed copy of this report will be in the facility file. Verification of removal is complete.

On September 29, 2022 at 9:46 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Anne Visaya arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced annual/required inspection. LPA A. Visaya disclosed the purpose of the visit and met with Administrator Alvin Mallillin was granted access to the facility. The home is consist of 2 single story home, home # 48 and home # 47 Upon entry to the facility, a living room with a locked closet that contains activities for the children, dining area with dining table and 4 chairs, a computer in a computer cart, and a small cabinet with counter top, and a kitchen area. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes. Used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate shelf and closet space. Home # 48 Bedroom #1, furnished with 1 full size bed, a closet and plenty storage and sleeps a 19 year old male client. Bedroom #2, furnished with 1 full size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space and sleeps a 17 year old male client. Bedroom #3, serves as office for the administrator and files are locked in this office. Bathroom number one hot water temperature measured to be 110.6 degrees Fahrenheit, Home # 47 Bedroom #1, furnished with 1 full size bed, a closet and plenty of storage and sleeps a 19 year old male client Bedroom #2, furnished with 1 twin size bed, a closet and plenty of storage and sleeps a 16 year old male client Bedroom #3, is empty at this time and serves as storage. Bathroom number one hot water temperature measured to be 109.6 degrees Fahrenheit, Continue....

The Facility has a sufficient food supply which includes a sufficient supply of fresh fruits, vegetables, can goods, meat and staples. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Medications are locked. Sharp knives, cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the bedroom hallway area. The first aid kit contains all required items. Telephone service and appliances are all in working order. There are no guns or weapons as stated by the administrator. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. A review of the homes operation show that the facility is licensed to serve four developmentally disabled clients. Current census of clients in care is four at this time. The License, facility sketch, emergency disaster plan, personal rights poster, activity schedule, meal menu are posted at this time. A review of five of eleven staff records indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and CPR and first aid is up to date except for the administrator expired on 03/06/2022. Administrator confirmed and will immediately undergo training and will provide the department of proof of correction. 80075 (f) (f) Staff is responsible for providing direct care and supervision shall receive training in first aid from persons qualified by agencies including but not limited to the American Red Cross. A review of four of tour clients files are noted to have documents required per regulations in file. Children's records contained all medical history, immunization records, medical consent forms signed by their authorized representative and children’s signed needs and services plans are up to date. LPA observed and reviewed medication records, a separate log for pyschotropic medications were not implemented. 84070(b)(13) (13) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the child documenting all the following: A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the children…. LPA provided the correct LIC 622B to the administrator, stated that he was not aware of the form. Licensee updated the medication record to reflect the correct form (LIC 622B for Psychotropic Medication). Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there is a deficiency found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to facility Administrator Alvin Mallillin. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and confidential names List (LIC 811) were given and explained to the administrator.

In regard to the complaint, it was specifically stated that “client came to school with a large bruise, about a size of a fist, under C1’s left eye”. During the investigation, a confidential interview denied C1 was hit causing bruising while in care. Confidential interview disclosed that C1 had self-injurious behaviors and known to make false statements. Another confidential interview denied hitting C1 and causing bruising in care. Another Confidential interview disclosed that C1 robbed C1’s hand on C1’s face until it was red. Confidential interview could not remember being hit in the face. Confidential interview added that the home was safe for C1. LPA received conflicting information regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, the Department determined there was not sufficient information to determine that C1 was hit while in care, causing bruising. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with LIC 811 to Children’s Critical Support Homes’ Facility Administrator.

narrative:
On Friday 7/9/21 at 10:57AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Co-Administrator / Facility Manager Patti Ioni for a required annual inspection. COVID-19 safety precautions were taken, including wearing masks, hand sanitizer, and pre-visit screening call. During inspection, LPA toured the facility site and grounds. There were no obstructions, hazards, or bodies of water on the grounds. Co-Administrator stated that there were no firearms on the premises, and LPA did not observe any. Room temperature was kept at a comfortable temperature within the permitted range. The kitchen was stocked with utensils and dishware to meet the needs to residents. Food storage was sanitary and organized, and the pantry was stocked with food to meet the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate. Medications were locked away and separated by resident. Sharps and knives were stored in a locked kitchen drawer, and chemicals were stored in locked cabinets in the locked laundry room. There is one male resident who has their own bedroom. Bedrooms were tidy, and linens were clean. All residents have their own bed and ample drawer space. Hygiene products are provided for the residents. During visit, LPA observed that staff engage with the residents and maintain appropriate staff-client ratios. LPA interviewed all present staff (3) and no residents, as residents were nonverbal and/or absent. The following issues were observed: The water temperature at the resident bathroom sink reached only to 100.4 F, which is below the minimum temperature allowed, 105 F. An advisory was issued, per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80088. Foster youth rights were not posted in the facility. An advisory was issued, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84072. The resident roster was not up to date. An advisory was issued, per CCR, Title 22, Section 80071. Complaint procedures were not posted in the facility in a location visible to residents and authorized representatives. An advisory was issued, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84072.2.

The following issues were observed (continued): Documentation of compatibility of residents sharing a room was not kept in the client files. An advisory was issued, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84087. The facility has not been submitting incident reports for every injury or manual restraint. An advisory was issued, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84061. The facility has not been logging instances of manual restraints in monthly logs. A citation was issued, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84361. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Co-Administrator / Facility Manager Patti Ioni, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: LPA advised that the facility continue to carefully document all marks observed on R1's body, including any incident that could have caused marks, and to submit incident reports for all unusual incidents, especially if they cause an injury or bruising to a resident. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. There are no citations. An exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager Patti Ioni, whose signature on this from confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On Thursday 8/19/21, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings regarding the above allegation. LPA met with Facility Manager Patti Ioni and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on the confidential complaint report, the allegation is regarding red marks on resident R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) neck and upper chest. Based on confidential interviews and record review, R1 does have aggressive and self-injurious behaviors and frequently causes minor injuries to self. R1's behaviors include biting self and throwing self on the ground. R1 also reportedly appeared upset, indicated pain at the site of the injury on the face, and did not want to go home. However, other witness reports indicate that R1 is content at the facility and gets along well with staff. LPA observed R1 at the facility to be happy, playful, and joyfully engaging with one-on-one staff. Staff reported not witnessing an incident that could have caused the injury to R1. The facility maintains a log of R1's incidents, self-injurious behaviors, and marks on body.

narrative: On Thursday 07/07/2022 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela made an unannounced visit to the facility to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA Valenzuela met with met with Co-Administrator/Facility Manager Patti Inouye and informed of the purpose of the visit. The facility is licensed to have a capacity of 6, and currently has 6 youth in placement. During inspection, LPA Valenzuela toured the facility site and grounds. There were no obstructions, hazards, or bodies of water on the grounds inside the house or in the backyard. LPA Valenzuela observed, the license, Emergency Disaster Plan, Weekly Menus, Personnel Report, and Group Planned Activities and appropriate posters were posted in an accessible location. LPA Valenzuela checked both the room temperature and the water temperature and observed it was kept at a comfortable temperature within the permitted range. The kitchen was stocked the adequate essentials to meet the residents needs. Sharps and knives were stored in a locked kitchen drawer, and chemicals were stored in locked cabinets in the locked laundry room. Food storage was sanitary and organized, and the pantry was stocked with food to meet the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate. Medications were locked away and separated by resident. Bedrooms were clean,linens were clean, and each resident has their own bed and closet/drawer space. In the resident bathroom, hygiene products are provided and separated by resident name for the residents. During visit, LPA Valenzuela observed that staff interact with the residents and maintain appropriate staff-client ratios. LPA Valenzuela interviewed one staff member (1) and no residents, as residents were in summer school. LPA Valenzuela reviewed 6 resident files and 6 staff files. All files were complete and contained all the correct documentation for both resident and staff files. At this time, per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Co-Administrator/ Facility Manager Patti Inouye, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 3/14/23, at 10:45 AM, LPA Alyssa Ng, made an unannounced inspection and met with Ren Baylon, direct care staff. Upon arrival, LPA Ng discovered that there was one client home but there was no Facility Manager nor House Manager present. At 11:10 AM, Maria P Lira Reyes, Managing Administrator arrived. Maria stated that the Administrator for the listed facility is not here. There is a current census of five clients. LPA Ng asked if there was a designated Facility Manager in their place. Maria said that there was none. LPA Ng stated that a Facility Manager needs to be present when a client is home. LPA Ng is issuing a citation of Chapter 5 Group Home Section 84065.2(3) Personnel Duties. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Managing Administrator Maria P Lira Reyes, whose signature confirms this receipt.

On 6/23/23 at 1:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a case management inspection at listed facility and spoke with Patti Inouye, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss reporting requirements and two clients in care who are over the age of 18. When reviewing the client roster, LPA Ng found that two clients are over the age of 18. Their current license is for clients who are between the ages of 6-17. LPA Ng completed a file review on 6/16/23 and found that there were no age exception requests for both clients in care. In addition, certain unusual incidents, such as epidemic outbreaks are to be reported by telephone within 24 hours. The facility failed to make the telephone report to CCL. Facility cited per CCR regulation, 80010(a), Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status and 80061(b)(1)(H) Reporting Requirements. Please see 809D. At this time, two deficiencies were cited, an exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Patti Inouye, Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80010(a): A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, licensee did not operate according to conditions and limitations of license due to two residents being 20 and 21. The facility not licensed for clients over 18, which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.

80061(b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day…a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event…(H) Epidemic outbreaks. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on IB interview and record review, Facility failed to report epidemic outbreak by telephone within 24 hours. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.

investigation_findings: 13On 6/23/23 at 1:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Cicada- Almond and spoke with Patti Inouye, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Part of this complaint was taken as an assignment by Community Care Licensing (CCL's) Investigations Branch (IB) on 03/08/2023. Two out of four allegations were upgraded to a full investigation on 03/08/2023 and assigned to Inv. Jorge Martinez. During investigation, interviews were conducted, photos obtained, and incident reports were reviewed, and it was determined that minor sustained multiple injuries while in care and staff does not ensure that minor is dressed in clean clothing. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, Minor sustained multiple injuries while in care and Staff does not ensure that minor is dressed in clean clothing, is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and 80072(a)(2) Personal Rights. Please refer to attached 9099D. At this time, two deficiencies were cited, an exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Patti Inouye, Administrator.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (a)The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on pictures and interviews, client in care sustained multiple unexplained injuries which poses an immediate safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.

Personal Rights (a): Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: (2) To be accorded safe, healthful and comfortable accommodations, furnishings and equipment to meet his/her needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews, client wore inappropriately sized clothing and torn up shoes to school. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.

narrative:
On 7-24-23 9:47AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Patti Inouye, Administrator and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Group Home is licensed to serve six clients. Present during the inspection were three staff and six clients. At 10:05AM LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. All client files were complete and in good order. Staff files: Staff 5 did not have criminal record clearance associated to the listed facility, but is associated to other facilities in the Children's Residential Program and employed at other Cicada facilities. Administrator Inouye was able to provide a completed Criminal Background Clearance Transfer Request Form (LIC 9182) during the inspection, and proof of submission to CDSS. At 12:23PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed four bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 105 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 69 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a kitchen cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff and no clients. Three clients were nonverbal and three clients refused to be interviewed. continued on LIC 809-C

continued from LIC 809 At 1:30PM, LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time the facility is being issued a Technical Violation, California Code of Regulations, Criminal Record Transfer, Criminal Record Clearance Transfer 80019(e)(3). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Pattie Inouye, Administrator

investigation_findings: 13On 3/20/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to the facility to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Patti Inouye and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observation, and record review, evidence could not be obtained proving that the involved resident was left in soiled clothing for an extended period of time nor that abuse or neglect resulted in scratches on the involved resident's skin. Obtained evidence reflects regular pull-up changes and that the involved resident often has hard, dry stools, for which LPA advised consulting the physician. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager, whose siganture on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 07/29/24 10:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn Flynn conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPA Pierotti met with Lira Reyes and toured the facility inside and out. The Group Home is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 4 staff and 4 clients. LPA Pierotti reviewed client and staff files. All client and staff files were available and contained all necessary forms. LPA Pierotti toured the facility. LPA Pierotti observed 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Pierotti tested the water temperature and found it to be 106.5 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 77 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a kitchen cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Pierotti toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. LPA Pierotti interviewed 1 staff and no clients. Clients left for school and outings during the inspection. The clients that were remaining in the home were nonverbal. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Lira Reyes.

On 7/29/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Will Ea made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting the facility’s annual inspection. LPA met with Direct Care Staff/House Lead, Rowena Gabe(S01), and informed them on the purpose of this inspection. No clients were present and were all at school and one staff was present. The CARE Tool was used to conduct this inspection. LPA reviewed the facility's plan of operations, client files, staff files, and conducted a walk through of the facility inside and out. During the facility walk through LPA observed the facility to be maintained at a comfortable temperature, water from the client restroom faucet was measured at 114.5F, and an outdoor activity space was observed free from hazards. LPA observed waste bins, all with lids. The facility did not have any bodies of water. LPA toured each of the clients' bedrooms and observed functional lighting, adequate storage space, clean linens, clean bedding, and age appropriate decor. Food supply was adequate with a sufficient supply of fresh and durable grocery items. Allowance balance was maintained for all clients and balance amount was correct. MAR, PMAR, and medication were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Logs were complete and accurate. Sharps were kept in a secure drawer in the kitchen. All chemicals and cleaning agents were kept in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. The safety drill logs were maintained and conducted on at least a quarterly basis. Overall the facility appeared to be clean, safe, and in good repair. LPA conducted a review of all four client files and four randomly selected staff files. Client and staff files were found to be in order and up-to-date with no issues observed. (continued on 809C)

One staff interview was conducted. LPA took pictures of their current staffing schedule, LIC500 and LIC610. LPA requested an updated copy of the admin organization LIC 309, which S01 agreed to provide by e-mail. Overall, LPA found no issues or defects while conducting the inspection. A copy of this report was provided to House Lead Rowena Gabe along with a copy of the appeal rights. Rowena's signature confirms their receipt and acknowledgement of the summary.

(continued from 9099) Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility did not have the responsible party's consent for non-emergency medical treatment. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. The administrator has agreed to sign and return the LIC9099. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility and the LPA issued an Advisory Note on Title 22 Section 84070 Children's Records. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conversed via phone with Administrator Noel Camatog regarding a complaint investigation at the facility. The purpose of the conversation was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Due to current COVID-19 protocols, this visit was conducted over the phone and the appropriate signatures will be acquired subsequently. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli inspected the Group Home facility (virtually), interviewed staff, teachers, Regional Center staff, and Parent, and reviewed documentation. LPA confirmed through records and interview with Administrator Camatog that although the facility had a signed Consent for Emergency Medical Treatment (LIC627B), they did not have an authorization on file for non-emergency medical care. Regulations require consent forms for both circumstances, but facility was utilizing the "RECORDS TO BE MAINTAINED BY THE FACILITY – GROUP HOMES" (LIC311B), which is currently available on the CCL website, and only lists the LIC627B as being required. (continued on 9099-C)

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to the Facility and met with Administrator Noel Camatog. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating this allegation LPA McCambridge interviewed staff, observed clients, and reviewed files. LPA was unable to interview clients due to the fact that the clients are non-verbal. LPA observed clients to be safe and accorded dignity during the inspection. During interviews staff stated that that staff have never harmed or spoked inappropriately to clients. Without being able to speak to the clients to corroborate the allegatons LPA determined the allegations to be unsubatantiated. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection of the facility. Due to Covid19, the inspection occurred using the video conferencing platform, Facetime. LPA met with Administrator Ludeking and inspected the facility inside and out. The facility is licensed to serve 4 clients. There is currently 1 female resident. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. The walkways were free of obstruction throughout the house and backyard. There is a locked shed in the backyard. The outside area consists of the following: A garden area with raised beds, patio table and a trampoline with safety netting. Documentation was posted which included, personal rights emergency exit plan, disaster plan and Covid19 protocol. Employee and clients files are kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the staff office. The client had a hygiene kit. The window screens were in good repair. Medication disbursement is logged using a MAR and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs the medications are kept in and the medications are also kept locked. The fire extinguisher is fully charged, with current tags. The facility vehicle is a mini van with current tags that expire in May of 2021 and the insurance is current through July 2021. The tire tread was in a safe range. The kitchen knives were kept in a locked cabinet. The kitchen was stocked with enough perishable/non-perishable food for 5/14 days for 1 client. The March menu was posted. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. Each client's bedroom has a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. There were additional linen in the laundry room, along with additional bath towels and face cloths. Laundry supplies were stored in a locked cabinet. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were in working order. The garage had an additional freezer of meats and vegetables and a cabinet of extra cleaning supplies. The client's bedroom had personal affects, clothing and dresser. The house phone is operational. No deficiencies noted at today's evaluation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to the Administrator at ludekingfe@gmail.com.
