LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. The walkways were free of obstruction throughout the house and backyard. There is a locked shed in the backyard. The outside area consists of the following: 2 raised garden beds, patio table with chairs and a trampoline with safety netting. Documentation was posted which included, personal rights emergency exit plan, disaster plan and license. Employee and clients files are kept in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in a locked entry closet. The clients have hygiene kits. The window screens were in good repair. Medication disbursement is logged using a MAR and is cross reconciled with the bubble packs/bottles the medications are kept in and the medications are also kept locked. The facility vehicle is a minivan with current tags that expire in May of 2023 and the insurance is current through July 2023. The tire tread was in a safe range and seat belts are in working order. Kitchen knives are kept in a locked box. The kitchen is stocked with enough perishable/non-perishable food for 5/14 days for 3 clients. The meal menu was posted. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 4 clients. Each client's bedroom has a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. There is additional linen in the laundry room, along with additional bath towels and face cloths. Laundry supplies were stored in a locked cabinet. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector are in working order. The fire extinguisher is fully charged, with current tags. The garage had an additional freezer of meats, vegetables and prepped foods; and a cabinet of extra cleaning supplies. The client's bedrooms have personal affects, clothing and dresser. The house phone is operational. Deficiencies noted at today's evaluation were cited on the 809 D page. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report and appeals process were provided to the Administrator.

On January 31, 2024 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez attempted an unannounced inspection at the above location. During arrival LPA and LPM met with direct staff at the front door who informed LPA and LPM that there was illness in the home. Staff called Cleofe Ludeking, Facility Administrator, who was ill at home, to verify whether staff and children have been tested. FA stated that they will be going to be tested on Friday, LPA stated that all staff and children need to be tested within the next week and LPA is to be notified when this is completed via telephone call. Another inspection attempt will be made at a later date, once the home is cleared. Exit interview was conducted. No report was left at the facility during todays visit.

On February 21, 2024 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez, Tatyana Shulz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez arrived at the above facility to conduct an Annual Inspection. During the inspection LPAs and LPM met with CEO/Administrator Cleofe Ludeking who assisted with the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. The facility was equipped with 4 bedrooms, three full bathrooms. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection were met, only one client present with three staff members. LPA Luman-Gonzalez interviewed 3 staff members and was able to interview 1 client because the rest were at school. LPA will interview other 2 client at a later date. Facilities Annual Fees are up to date and there are 3 private placement. CARE tool was unavailable during this inspection. Physical Plan LPAs and LPM observed License, Personal Rights and all required forms were posted in the living room area. Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions were inaccessible to clients.Plenty of nonperishable foods were observed in cabinets and extra stock in the garage. Food menu was posted in the kitchen area. Working telephone was observed in the living area. Carbon monoxide detector was observed and it was in working condition. Smoke Detector observed in working condition. First Aid Kit fully stocked in the locked closet by the front door. Common Room available in the living area and play area. Dining area was observed to have plenty of seating with furniture in good condition. Medication centrally stored, locked and made inaccessible to clients. Client records and staff records are locked in file drawers. Hot Water was tested and was at 118 degrees F. (Page 1 of 3)

Fire Extinguisher was observed by the kitchen area and the inspection was up to date. Toilets, bath and shower fixtures were in good repair. Bedrooms-required linen and furnishings were observed to be adequate. Vehicle use to transport the clients was properly maintained, lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts were observed to working properly. Shed in the back yard was observed to be used as a storage and was locked. Required bedding/furniture, light fixtures in the bedrooms were in good repair) The areas observed out of compliances were: Bedroom #1 wall was observed to have holes on the wall. Bedroom #1 and #3 were missing screens on their windows. No citations issued but a Technical Violation was given. Operations Complaint Procedures For Youth Reviewed with the Facility Administrator. Residents normally speak to their families if there are complaints, and the families bring it to the Facility Administrator's attention. Board Minutes were conducted on June 17, 2023 and December 4, 2023. Current issues were discussed as well as issues with the facility or residents were addressed. The areas were all observed to be in compliance. Disaster Preparedness Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available at the facility upon request. Quarterly Drills conducted and documented monthly. Disaster preparedness supplies verified by LPAs and LPM during todays inspection. Emergency Intervention Facility is ProAct trained/certified. No restraints are conducted unless there is an emergency or danger to self and others. Staff training is only on ProAct. (Page 2 of 3)

Staffing/Volunteers LPAs and LPM reviewed 3 client files and observed that all clearances were current. Staff has paid their fees and is waiting for their updated certificate. All staff trainings were verified to be current. Client Records LPAs and LPM reviewed 3 client files and verified the records to be up to date. LPAs notified Staff regarding the updated Psychotropic Medication forms. Client's behavioral plans properly addressed the behavioral concerns. Due to Private Placement, JV220 does not apply to the current residents. Centrally Stored Medication and log reviewed. Cash Resources log was reviewed and observed to be up to date. Special Health Care Needs (SHCN) This facility does not qualify as a Special Health Care Needs Home. An exit interview was conducted with Cleofe Ludeking and a copy of this report was left at the Facility. (Page 3 of 3)

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia on 01/14/2025 at 9:00 AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Valencia met with Cleofe (Fe) Ludeking-Facility Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 0/3 of child’s records and 0/0 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. While LPA was conducting records, LPA observed all children in care were placed by their biological parents and do not qualify. LPA reviewed 3/3 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records and signed documents from biological parents. LPA interviewed 0/0 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed 0/3 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication, as all children are privately placed. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Cleofe (Fe) Ludeking-Facility Administrator No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Cleofe (Fe) Ludeking-Facility Administrator

On 04/04/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon started an unannounced Annual Inspection of this Group Home. LPA was met by Administrator Cleofe Ludeking who gave a tour of the interior and exterior areas of the facility's physical plant. No Building & Grounds deficiencies were observed; the pathways were unobstructed and no potentially hazardous items or areas were accessible to clients. The records review was started with clients' files. Personnel records will be reviewed during the continuation of this inspection. More time is needed to complete this inspection. No citations are being issued at this time. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On 04/08/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon continued the required Annual Inspection of this Group Home. LPA was met by Administrator Cleofe Ludeking who facilitated client and staff interviews and the review of facility records. The inspection findings are as follows: The facility has a capacity of four; its current census is three. The physical plant has no bodies of water. The Home's interior was found to be clean and in good repair. At least two communal spaces were available for clients' relaxation and visits as needed. The facility has two full bathrooms for clients' use as needed, both of which were found to be in good working condition with bath/shower and vanity fixtures providing hot water that read at 111.8 and 105.8 degrees F, respectively. The Home's phone landline was tested and found to be live. A first aid kit was on hand, inspected, and found to contain all required items. Each client has their own private room--no clients share rooms. Multi-drawer dressers were observed to be in good condition in each client room. The facility's backyard was well-maintained, with no hazardous or potentially dangerous items or areas accessible to clients--some yard maintenance equipment were stored securely (with a lock) in a shed. LPA found no evidence of any kind of pest infestation; no flies or other insects were observed indoors throughout the inspection. Per client interviews, Personal Rights are being accorded and none reported any violations perpetrated by facility staff. Staff interviews were consistent in describing the facility's plan of operation. Client and staff files contained all required elements. The facility’s board of directors’ meetings minutes were made available and reviewed. This facility is in substantial compliance with Title 22 Regulations. No citations are being issued as a result of this inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On June 1, 2021 at 8:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez made telephone contact with Administrator Cherie Mills to conduct a Pre-Licensing inspection of the facility. Due to Covid-19 a tele-inspection was conducted this date via Microsoft Teams. The facility was inspected inside and out with Administrator Cherie Mills and Human Resources Executive Assistant Aerie De La Cruz. The home is a two story residence with one group therapy office, one recreational room, and two and a half bathrooms. This home provides awake night staff. The facility will be operating with the capacity of 6. The bedrooms are set up as follows: Bedroom #1 will be occupied by two residents; two twin beds, all required linen, mattresses in good condition. Bedroom #2 will be occupied by two residents; two twin beds, all required linen, mattresses in good condition. Bedroom #3 will be occupied by two residents; two twin beds, all required linen, mattresses in good condition. Bedroom #4 will be occupied by one resident, as needed; one twin bed, all required linen, mattresses in good condition. All bedrooms contained adequate shelf and closet space for resident’s belongings. The staff offices contained office supplies, staff schedule and emergency and disaster plan that was posted. Administrator stated that resident, and Staff files will be stored electronically in the facility's database system. Medications and the first aid kit were locked in the medication room/pantry located in the kitchen. Medication room has a locking door and a locking medication cabinet. The facility also has a refrigerator that locks to store medications that require refrigeration. Cont. on 809-C

Medication logs will be kept electronically. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Water temperature of the kitchen sink of the property was measured at 109.8 degrees. The property contains a pool in the backyard which is covered. All hazardous items were made inaccessible to areas where residents do not have access. Cleansers/chemicals were stored in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked drawer in the kitchen. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation Policy, Disaster Plan, Employee Schedule and current menu. LPA observed a sufficient supply of 7-day non-perishable food for six residents and a sufficient supply of 2-day perishable food. There was a variety of snacks available for residents as well. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. During the tele-inspection, Components II and III were conducted. There were no deficiencies cited based on the inspection this date. Facility Provisional License to be issued pending the approval of addendums and revisions to the program statement to be submitted to the Department. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and emailed to Administrator Cherie Mills for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

On November 10, 2021 at 10:01am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Post-Licensing Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Administrator Cherie Mills. The home is a two story residence with one group therapy office, one staff office, one recreational room, and three and a half bathrooms. There are currently no children placed at the facility. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in one of the client bathrooms was measured at 115.8 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. The medications will be stored and locked in a cabinet in the storage closet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a cabinet in the laundry room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the laundry room and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operations, Emergency Intervention, and Emergency Disaster Preparedness. All the staff files are stored and secured on an online database. LPA reviewed one of one staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Cont. on 809-C

Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. Based on the facility inspection, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Administrator Cherie Mills.

On September 1, 2022 at 10:29am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an Annual/Random inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Administrator Cherie Mills. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in one of the client bathrooms was measured at 119.3 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the medication room in the hallway. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked supply closet. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked pantry cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the medication room and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator Cherie Mills. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There is a swimming pool located in the backyard of the facility which is made inaccessible with a pool cover. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Due to time constraints and the need to complete staff interviews, and staff file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at a later date. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operational Requirements. Interviews were conducted with seven facility staff. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained to Administrator Cherie Mills. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Administrator Cherie Mills.

On 04/17/25 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Cherie Mills, Administrator, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six ambulatory children ages 13-17 years old. The current census is six youth. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a double story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with Yasmin Ruben, Program Administration Assistant and included the following checks: four bedrooms, kitchen, four bathrooms (three client, one staff), medication room, dining room, living room, and two staff offices There is a gym detached from the main building and an outdoor living space with a discontinued pool that had a pool cover. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. LPA observed a security system camera on the front porch at the facility. There are no cameras in the interior of the house. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. **Continued LIC809C**

**Continued from LIC809** On the second floor, Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. Two bedrooms contain two twin beds, and the other two bedrooms only have one twin bed. The water temperature was tested in bathroom one which measured 117.9 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to everyone and had all required supplies. All client files are stored and maintained on a secure internet database. LPA reviewed five client files (C1 – C5, see LIC811 and LIC811C Confidential Names List) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed five client medication records. LPA reviewed five staff files (S1 – S5) to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Staff records are stored via a secured records portal. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. LPA conducted two staff interviews(S2 and S3) and two client interviews(C2 and C5). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies cited during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the LIC811 and LIC811C was provided to Cherie Mills. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On 9/28/2023 @ 10:05AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donna Edwards made an unannounced annual visit at the facility. LPA met with Veronica Villa, Administrator who assisted with the inspection. LPA Edwards and Administrator conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. The Facility staff-client ratio at the time of the inspection is Staff 15 and Client 3. LPA observed 9 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The bedrooms were clean and consisted of beds, bedding, desk and storage and the bathrooms were clean well-lit and well stocked with supplies. The Recreation Rooms had two televisions, a pool table, basketball court and gaming unit with games. The sitting area had a large sofa with seating for 8 and 2 gaming chairs. LPA inspected a training room with housed the clients’ records. LPA observed 6 locked filing cabinets with client records and 3 cabinets with emergency supplies, clothes, and games. The kitchen area was clean, and LPA observed Nonperishable foods for one week and fresh perishable foods for two days. The water temperature was at 109 F. The dining area had three large tables and benches. The currently monthly meal menu was posted. Off the dining area was a seating are with a large couch, TV, Entertainment Center, gaming system games and puzzles. The outdoor area was clean and well maintained. The recreational area had a volleyball and soccer set. The back yard also had three locked sheds. The sheds contained recreational equipment, clothes, and extra emergency equipment. The school in the back of property had two classrooms which contained tables, chairs, books, and whiteboards. Medication Room was locked and contained four locked cabinets marked for over-the-counter medications and prescribed medications. The office also had a locked drawer for the MAR to be stored. LPA did 5 staff interviews and 3 client interviews. Fire Extinguisher and Carbon Monoxide detectors were tested. No deficiencies were noted at todays visit. A copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

On August 18, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu met with Administrator Sergio Castaneda for the purposes of conducting a final walkthrough before facility closure. facility_name: CRITTENTON SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
narrative:
On June 27, 2022, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias arrived at Crittenton Services for Children and Families Group Home (GH). LPA and LPM, were met and granted access by Program Director Ericka Vasquez and Assistant Program Director, Michael Saavedra. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 10:00 AM, Program Director, Ericka Vasquez and Assistant Program Director, Michael Saavedra, led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Covarrubias and LPM Davis. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility’s, kitchen, living room, two bathroom/showers and five bedrooms (two clients per bedroom), and outdoor activity space located in the garage. The facility is set up as follows: two bedrooms, and two bathrooms (one staff bathroom and one client bathroom) located downstairs, and three bedrooms and one-half bathroom located upstairs. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detector was in appropriate working order and fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. At 12:00 PM LPA and LPM observed there was no carbon monoxide detector located in the facility. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted including the, Personal Rights form and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked in a medical cart which is locked in the staff office. First Aid Kit is stored in the staff office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. At 12:30 PM the hot water in the client’s bathrooms was measured to be 129.1-degrees Fahrenheit in bathroom #1- and 122-degrees Fahrenheit in bathroom #2. Per the Assistant Program Director, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. (Continued of LIC 809C...)

LPA and LPM reviewed eight out of eight client files which were completed with updated Needs and Services Plans, valid TB test, and client medical assessments. The facility is required to have at minimum one carbon monoxide installed; therefore, the facility is being cited for California Code of Regulation (CCR) 84087(d). The facility was also observed to have a water temperature higher than 120 degrees Fahrenheit, therefore the facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80088(e)(1). All corrections were made at the time of visit. Due to only the physical plant, and client records being reviewed this inspection will be continued at a later date.

facility_name: CRITTENTON SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
narrative: On July 5, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias, Joon Choi, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis, arrived at Crittenton Services for Children and Families Group Home (GH). LPAs and LPM, were met and granted access by Program Director Ericka Vasquez and Assistant Program Director, Michael Saavedra. The purpose of the visit is to continue an annual inspection of the facility that was initiated on June 27, 2022. LPA’s and LPM already completed the physical inspection of the facility and reviewed facility client files. LPAs and LPM reviewed ten out of ten personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are maintained in the corporate office in the building adjacent to the facility. LPA Choi conducted four out of eight client interviews. Three clients refused to be interviewed and one client was not present during the time of inspection. Clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services are being provided. LPA Covarrubias requested the Board of Directors meeting minutes, based on review of meeting minutes, the facility was found to comply with all applicable regulations. LPA Choi conducted five staff interviews that were present during the time of inspection. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's GH Program Statement, Emergency Intervention Plan, clients’ Needs and Services plan, and Reporting Requirements. Based on interviews with staff, the facility appears to be meeting Core Services/Supports requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, was provided to Assistant Program Director, Michael Saavedra.

narrative:

LPA reviewed five staff files(S1 – S5) to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Staff records are stored via a secured records portal. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. LPA conducted two staff interviews(S1 and S2) and one client (C1) interview. facility_name: CRITTENTON SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
narrative: Confidential interviews denied allegations of a lack of supervision. According to confidential interviews, it was Staff # 1 (S1) who had observed Child # 3(C3) hit or “smack” C2 in the face, after C2 was refusing to eat, and immediately reported the incident to their supervisors, who then notified Children’s County Social Worker. Confidential interviews also denied that C1 had received a fracture on their leg due to a lack of supervision. According to confidential information, fracture was observed in C1’s leg after C1 was taken to be seen by a physician after the facility had reported C3 abusing C2. According to confidential interviews, C1 and C2’s County Social Worker requested to have both children medically evaluated after C3 had been observed by staff and security footage, physically abusing C1 and C2 during a feeding session. Regarding allegation of C2 not being properly fed while in care, confidential interviews stated that although C2 had arrived underweight to their facility, C2 had managed to gain some weight during the approximate 2 months that they had lived at this facility. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. IB investigator and LPA Mena were unable to interview C1 and C2 due to their young age and limited verbal ability. There were no other known witnesses to these allegations. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that that Child #2 (C2) is not being properly fed and sustained a fracture while in care, and of a lack of supervision resulting in Child # 1 (C1) being slapped while in care, as well as staff not seeking timely medical attention for C1 and C2, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Assistant Program Director, Michael Saavedra to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegations. Special Investigator (SI), Lyyjoki and LPA Mena interviewed Facility Director (FD), Facility Administrator (FA), County Social Worker (CSW), Youth Care Worker (S1), as well as reviewed medical, client and facility records. Community Care Licensing received information on February 11, 2022 alleging that Child #2 (C2) is not being properly fed and sustained a fracture while in care, and of a lack of supervision resulting in Child # 1 (C1) being slapped while in care, as well as staff not seeking timely medical attention for C1 and C2. Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. IB investigator and LPA Mena obtained conflicting information during interviews.

Pine Cottage has ten bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room in seven rooms, and three clients are in single bedrooms. The cottage has one client bathroom that is equipped with four standing showers and four stalls. The water temperature was measured to be 112 degrees Fahrenheit. Willow Cottage has seven bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is also one client per bed. The cottage has one client bathroom that is equipped with five standing showers and four stalls. The water temperature was measured to be 115 degrees Fahrenheit. Continued on LIC 809 C

Aspen Cottage has seven bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than three clients share a room in three rooms, no more than two clients share a room in four rooms, and there is also one client per bed. Each room is equipped with its own bathroom and there is two standing showers and one singular shower. The water temperature was measured to be 110 degrees Fahrenheit. All sharp and hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible where clients will not have access to them. Each cottage is equipped with a staff office, where there is a locking cabinet for medications. The facility's smoke detectors throughout the facility are hard wired with direct communication to the fire department. The facility was observed to have various mattress beds in each cottage that were not equipped with good springs, therefore the facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 Section 84088 Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies. facility_name: CRITTENTON SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
narrative: However, if a client indicates they are not sexually active no other reproductive services are provided. Confidential interviews and documents reviewed indicate that sexual education is not being provided to clients. Based on confidential interviews the allegation that the facility is not informing clients of their personal rights regarding reproductive and sexual health care services is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Continuing Requirements 84072(d)(31) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights was provided to Erika Vasquez-Program Director.
investigation_findings: 13On October 31, 2024, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacquline Garcia arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Erika Vasquez-Program Director to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA Garcia conducted an inspection of the facility on September 25, 2024, at 8:30 AM. No deficiencies were observed. LPA Garcia interviewed eight Staff (S1-S8) and eleven Clients (C1-C11). The following documents were reviewed during the investigation: Program Statement, Intake Procedures, Incident Reports, Parenting Classes Curriculum, and Nursing Assessment. On September 20, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the facility is not informing clients of their personal rights regarding reproductive and sexual health care services. Confidential interviews revealed that during the intake process the clients are asked if they are sexually active, depending on the clients’ responses, services and referrals are made and the clients are linked to reproductive care. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE 9099-C.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(31) Personal Rights: The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9…To have access to age-appropriate, medically accurate information about reproductive health care, the prevention of unplanned pregnancy, and the prevention and treatment of sexually transmitted infections. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the facility was not providing reproductive health care education to all clients in care, which posed potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative:

The facility is separated into five housing units and identified as follows: Willow Cottage has seven bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, or three clients if they are one family. They hold a waiver granting this from 2021. There is also one client per bed. The cottage has one shared client bathroom that is equipped with five standing showers and four stalls. Each bedroom has their own restroom with a toilet and sink. The water temperature was measured to be 118 degrees Fahrenheit in bedroom #5. Aspen Cottage has seven bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than three clients share a room in three rooms, no more than two clients share a room in four rooms, and there is also one client per bed. Each room is equipped with its own bathroom and there is a shared client bathroom with three showers. The water temperature was measured to be 112 degrees Fahrenheit. Juniper Cottage is currently not in use due to lack of clients. It has seven bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than three clients share a room in three rooms, no more than two clients share a room in four rooms, and there is also one client per bed. The cottage has a shared client bathroom with showers, and one restroom in every room. **Continued on LIC809C**

**Continued from LIC809** Pine Cottage is currently not in use due to lack of clients. It has ten bedrooms and are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room in seven rooms, and three clients are in single bedrooms. The cottage has a client shared bathroom that is equipped with four standing showers and four stalls. The Valley View building holds a downstairs recreation room, and two staff offices, and supply closet space. Downstairs is where the clients personal belongings are kept when they come in to the program. Federal government regulations require that all cell phones and personal belongings are confiscated at entry into the program. The building has an upper level that has play areas for infants and toddlers, and a medical examination room that Crittenton uses for in house pediatric care by a doctor who comes on site on a frequent basis. The main floor of this building holds the lobby, and the office of the Program Director. “The Café” is another building and can hold up to 40 people at a time for meals. The cooks prepare all meals here, but clients are not forced to eat in the cafeteria. Each home has its own kitchen and refrigerators. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. LPA observed cameras at the cottages outside and in the common areas of the cottages. No cameras were observed in the bedrooms. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All sharp and hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible where clients will not have access to them. Each cottage is equipped with a staff office, where there is a locking cabinet for medications. The facility's smoke detectors throughout the facility are hard wired with direct communication to the fire department. The alarm was set off and all alarms were functioning. The fire department was notified before the test occurred. Each cottage had fire extinguishers which were current with maintenance. The following required posted items were observed for clients in the cottages: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and current food menu. There was a playground area equipped with an anchored swing and slide set and rubber chips for safety. **Continued on LIC809-C PAGE 3**

**Continued from LIC809C PAGE 2** All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. All toiletries were locked and there were an adequate supplies of extra toiletries in the basement. The first aid kit was accessible to all staff and had all required supplies. All client files are stored and maintained in paper copy at another location. LPA reviewed five client files(C1 – C5) out of 24 clients at Valley View Building to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed five client medication records. Staff records are stored via a secured records portal and accessed through the head of HR. LPA reviewed five staff files to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. LPA conducted three staff interviews(S1 – S3) and three client interviews(C1, C2, and C6). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies cited during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Erika Vasquez. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file

narrative:
On November 12, 2024 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jacqueline Garcia arrived at Crittenton Services for Children and Families Amerige House to conduct an unannounced annual inspection. LPA met with Program Director, Michael Saavedra, Program Director, Erika Vasquez and Unit Supervisor, Belinda Robinson. LPA toured the facility inside and out with Michael, Erika, and Belinda. The facility is a two-story residence with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. Four bedrooms are being utilized as bedrooms and one bedroom is used as a storage room. Two bedrooms are arranged so that there are two clients sharing a room, and one client per bed. Two bedrooms are arranged so there is one client per room. There is adequate closet space for client’s belongings. There are eight cameras located on the property (five cameras on the outside, and three cameras in the inside of the facility). The three client bathrooms were observed to be clean and in good repair. The hot water was measured at 119 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a hallway closet. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked toolbox in a locked closet. The facility's smoke detectors are hard wired into the facility and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector was operable, and three fire extinguishers were observed to be fully charged and in working condition. There are no guns or weapons on facility grounds as stated by Program Director, Mike Saavedra. LPA observed facility posted items in the dining area that included: Child’s Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and Menu. Client's medication was observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked medication cart in the staff's office. LPA observed a variety of food stored in the refrigerator and kitchen cabinets. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and a two-day perishable supply of food. All meals are prepared off-site at the main kitchen, located at the Valley View Campus and brought to the facility. There are no pools or other bodies of water on the property. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space; all exits, and walkways were free from obstruction. LPA observed age-appropriate toys, games, and books for client’s recreation time. ****CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

LPA reviewed one client file. All documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. LPA reviewed five staff records. All documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. LPA interviewed two staff. Based on the facility inspection, confidential interviews, and file reviews there are no deficiencies found at this time. narrative: On June 3, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint with multiple allegations alleging staff inappropriately touched minor while in care and staff spoke inappropriately to minor while in care. Specifically, it was reported that a staff touched C1 and made sexual comments to C1 in the back corner of the facility where there were no cameras. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements to whether C1 was inappropriately touched by S1 and C1 was spoken to inappropriately by a staff. Confidential interviews revealed there was not a preponderance of evidence to prove any of the allegations based on the information gathered during the investigation. In addition, there were no witnesses to support the allegations of staff inappropriately touching C1 while in care, and staff speaking inappropriately to C1, therefore the allegation is deemed to be unsubstantiated at this time. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegation alleging staff inappropriately touched C1 while in care and staff spoke inappropriately to C1 while in care, may or may not have occurred, however they are not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided along with appeal rights, Crittenton SVCS For Children and Families, Program Director, Erika Vasquez.

Documents reviewed included Facility Documentation, Photographs, Text Messages, C1’s Client File, S1’s Employee File, and Police Reports. *****CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE.

narrative: However, if a client indicates they are not sexually active no other reproductive services are provided. Confidential interviews and documents reviewed indicate that sexual education is not being provided to clients. Based on confidential interviews the allegation that the facility is not informing clients of their personal rights regarding reproductive and sexual health care services is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Continuing Requirements 84072(d)(31) Personal Rights. Confidential interviews revealed that during the intake process the clients are asked if they are sexually active, depending on the clients’ responses, services and referrals are made and the clients are linked to reproductive care. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE 9099-C.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84072(d)(31) Personal Rights: The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9…To have access to age-appropriate, medically accurate information about reproductive health care, the prevention of unplanned pregnancy, and the prevention and treatment of sexually transmitted infections. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the facility was not providing reproductive health care education to all clients in care, which posed potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative:
On 03/26/2025 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez and arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Administrator Corazon Pasion and Administrator Marie Noel. The home is a one-story residence with a total of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in one of the client bathrooms was measured at 117.0 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. The medications were stored and locked in a medication cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked cabinet in the garage. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked drawer in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is in the medication cabinet and contained all required supplies. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways and bedrooms were checked and were operable. The fire extinguishers were updated and showed proof of adequate maintenance. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator, Corazon Pasion. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. **Continued on LIC809-C**

**Continued from LIC809** The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is an in-ground swimming pool located in the backyard of the facility which is made inaccessible with a fence and two pool gates that swing away from the pool, self-close and have a self-latching device located no more than six inches from the top of the gate. The fence is constructed so that the fence does not obscure the pool from view. LPA noted that there is one vehicle in use to transport the clients in care. LPA reviewed the vehicle log, and the vehicle itself. The vehicle is brand new and only had 1,600 miles. LPA conducted two staff interviews (S1 and S2), and one client interview (C1). During the inspection, LPA reviewed two client files. All client files had the required documents per Title 22 Regulations. LPA reviewed 5 staff files. All staff have training requirement. Per a review of Guardian System, all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. Currently the facility is overdue on their licensing fees. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed, and interviews, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and this report was explained. A copy of this report and Confidential Names List LIC 811 were emailed to Administrator Corazon Pasion due to printer malfunction.

On 07/11/25, at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez and Licensing Program Manager Ann Valenzuela met with Licensee Corazon Pasion for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection of the facility regarding criminal record clearances. The facility is licensed to serve four developmentally disabled clients ages 10-17 years old. The current census is two clients. LPA obtained the current LIC500 and that triggered a criminal record clearances check on Guardian. LPA found that four out of ten individuals (S2, S3, S4, S5– See Confidential Names List LIC811) did not have a completed background clearance listed on Guardian. LPA obtained the work schedule for the previous 30 days and found that all four individuals worked more than five shifts in the last month. LPA conducted two staff interviews (S1 and S6). Based on LPA observations, file reviews and interviews, the following type A deficiency is given today regarding the four staff who were not have clearance eligibility on Guardian (S2, S3, S4, S5) who were listed on the LIC500 as employees of this facility, and worked five shifts in the last month. This is not in compliance with Title 22 Section 80019(e)(1): Criminal Record Clearance. Civil Penalties of $2,000 is being assessed today. Please see LIC809D and LIC421BG for full text of citation, how the civil penalty was calculated, and to review the plan of correction. **Continued LIC809C**

**Continued from LIC809** An exit interview was conducted with the Licensee to explain this report, the LIC809D page, and a plan of correction. The appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, along with the LIC809D, LIC421BG, LIC811, and the appeal rights were given to Administrator, and additionally will be kept in the facility file.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced tele Pre-Licensing visit to the home on 1/13/21 at 9:00 AM and met with Licensees, Desiree Clifton and Christine Quiruz and administrator John Tarawali. This visit is being conducted virtually via Microsoft Teams due to COVID-19 restrictions currently in place at this time. LPA toured the facility inside and out and observed the following items: LPA observed that none of the necessary COVID-19 are currently posted and LPA offered to provide the necessary postings at the conclusion of the Pre-Licensing visit. Licensee showed LPA a mass COVID disaster binder that the facility has prepared for COVID procedures for staff and visitors. Licensee states that prior to entering the facility, all visitors and staff will be required to take their temperatures and document their daily temperatures in their binder upon entry. Near the front door, LPA observed a single occupancy bedroom that had a single bed, bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, dresser, night stand, lamp, chair and closet area. Carbon Monoxide detector is on the first floor near the client bedroom and a gaming area is near the front entrance of the facility and has a couple of small gaming chairs and television. First level bathroom was observed and is equipped with a shower and tub with glass sliding doors and a shower curtain for privacy. LPA observed that the bathroom had hand sanitizer, soap and paper towels for client use. LPA did suggest that the facility mount the paper towels in the bathroom to avoid them getting into the toilet and causing issues. LPA did have the licensee turn the water on in the bathroom and flush the toilet to verify that there is running water.

LPA observed the thermostat in the hallway and did observe that the current temperature of the home was 70 degrees Fahrenheit in the home. LPA observed an activity area in the main seating and kitchen area of the facility and this activity area was equipped with a giant Jenga game, computer, books and magazines, remote control cars, coloring pages with crayons, colored pencils, markers and sketch pads, microphone for karaoke activities, card games and charades for kids game, puzzles and an extra table in the middle of the room that can be removed for other activities not requiring a table. LPA observed that the dining area is off of the kitchen and the table is set up for placement of four clients. Licensee states that the dining table has a plate where snacks for the clients are going to be kept for access to clients when they desire. LPA observed that there is a fire extinguisher in the dining area but that there is no inspection tab on the fire extinguisher. Licensee states that they got an email from the inspector that it is fine the way it is since it was just purchased. LPA did advise that they were informed that they are to look for the inspection tab on the extinguishers and that they should follow up about this. LPA observed a gas fire place in the living room area of the facility and Licensee reports that this is a gas fireplace and that the gas has been disabled so it will never be used in the facility. LPA observed that the kitchen area is located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had the stove, microwave built in, refrigerator, double oven and pantry with no lock on the door. Inside the pantry, LPA observed plenty of non-perishable food items at this time. LPA also observed some food items in the refrigerator but food items are very limited at this time as Licensees were advised that perishables were not required during the pre-licensing visit. LPA observed that sharps are to be kept in a drawer in the kitchen and this drawer is secured by a magnetic locking system. LPA did advise the facility that storage of the magnet to release the lock cannot be kept on the refrigerator or anywhere that clients would have access. Chemicals are to be stored under the kitchen sink and this lock is also the magnetic locking system. Licensee reports that the facility will have a land line telephone service at the facility as well as a house cell phone in an effort to protect client medical information when taking clients to medical appointments. Licensee states that she does not want the staff to have any personal information related to the clients on their personal cell phones so when taking clients to appointments, they will be required to take the house cell phone.

LPA observed that the medications are to be stored in the closet by the front door, under the stair case leading to the second story of the facility. This closet has the first aid kit and other first aid supplies as well as cubbies to hold client medications. LPA also observed a small refrigerator in this closet that will also house medications that need refrigeration for clients in care. LPA observed that this closet has a locking door and will not be accessible to clients in care. LPA did advise the Licensee to remove all over the counter medications that come with the first aid kit to ensure that no clients can obtain or have access to these medications. Licensee took LPA to the second story of the facility and LPA did observe that there is a laundry room in the landing area of the upstairs. The laundry room is located next to the bathroom for the clients and bedrooms for the clients. LPA observed that the three client bedrooms located on the second floor that are all single occupancy rooms equipped with the single beds in each room, bedding including mattress covers, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, dresser in each room, night stand in each room, lamp in each room, chair in each room and closet areas in each room as required. LPA observed that the bathroom is equipped with a dual sink vanity and that the bathroom on the second level has a tub and shower area, no glass doors and a shower curtain. Licensee did turn the water on in the bathroom to verify running water and toilet was flushed to verify it is working. LPA did advise that the Licensee place a paper towel dispenser in the bathroom on the second floor as well. Bathroom was observed to have hand soap and hand sanitizer in the bathroom as well. LPA questioned the storage of towels in the facility and LPA did observe a storage area in the landing area where towels are to be kept to be accessible to clients when showering or bathing. LPA also observed an area on the second floor where Licensee intends to keep all required postings for client use like the Personal Rights and employee postings as well. LPA is advising that a copy of the personal rights poster also be posted in the main area of the facility as this is required for the Personal Rights and Ombudsman postings. On the second floor, LPA did observe an other closet where staff are to store extra hygiene items and bedding and LPA did advise that the closet be locked since it will house razors and extra hygiene items. Licensee did advise that any items in this closet not needing to be locked and stored inaccessible will be placed in the other storage area of the second floor that is not locked or secure. LPA toured the master bedroom on the second floor that is equipped with a bathroom for staff use. Licensee did advise that this room will be utilized for staff only and that no clients will be given access to this area. LPA did

observe that the staff room has a locking door, is currently housing computer and other office supply equipment. Licensee advised that all client files will also be housed in this room. Licensee states that the only file not to be kept in this area is related to medication and medication administration records and that binder will be in the medication area for the purposes of documenting medication when administered to clients. Licensee states that the ongoing notes for the clients will also not be housed in this area as this also needs to be in the area where staff are at with clients to document items as they happen. LPA advised that that would be fine. Licensee took LPA to the outdoor area of the facility to tour the outdoor area. LPA observed that there is a covered area outside but that there is currently no seating in this area. LPA informed Licensee that there needs to be an outdoor seating area for clients to sit outside when they would like to. Licensee showed LPA that the hot water heater access is through a door outside. LPA observed two utility sheds on the outside part of the facility and requested that both of these be opened but neither Licensee had the key to these sheds. LPA informed Licensees that the LPA would need a picture of the inside area of these sheds prior to the end of the day to verify its contents. Licensee did report that these sheds only housed a lawn mower and other yard equipment but LPA informed that we still have to verify this information prior to issuing license. LPA observed that the yard appears to be large enough to perform some activities should clients choose to use this area for outdoor activities. LPA did discuss with Licensees and administrator the fingerprinting requirement. LPA did advise Christine Quiruz that she is not fingerprint cleared for the Child Abuse Clearance Index and must be fingerprinted again in order to capture that requirement. LPA also informed Licensees that three of the four other staff that were to be hired and were ready to start work soon are not fingerprint cleared for Child Abuse Clearance either and they too would need to obtain additional fingerprint clearance to capture that requirement as well. LPA discussed with Licensees that the program design and application review documents will be sent to Licensees by Friday, 1/15/21 and that they would have 30 days to provide the required feedback to Licensing. LPA advised Licensees that the license would be effective on 1/13/21 with the license shall be printed 1/14/21. Once printed, the license would be sent via email to Licensees and Regional Center representative. Exit interview conducted with Licensees and document provided via email for signature and return.

Licensing Program Analyst, Ignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived at the above Group Home to conduct an announced Pre Licensing inspection of the facility on February 10, 2022 at 11:35 AM. LPA met with Administrator, Desiree Clifton to conduct the inspection LPA and Administrator conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passage ways and egress were unobstructed. No potentially hazardous items or areas were observed. The group home is requesting to be licensed for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients, ages 7 and 17 years old. The clients are developmentally disabled. The home is a two story home. LPA observed near the front door, a single occupancy bedroom that had a single bed, bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, dresser, night stand, lamp, chair and closet area. LPA observed Carbon Monoxide detectors and a gaming area is near the front entrance of the facility and has a couple of small gaming chairs and television. First level bathroom was observed and is equipped with a shower and tub with glass sliding doors and a shower curtain for privacy. LPA observed an activity area in the main seating and kitchen area of the facility and this activity area was equipped with computer, books, remote control cars, coloring pages with crayons, colored pencils, markers and sketch pads, card games and charades for kids game, puzzles and an extra table in the middle of the room that can be removed for other activities not requiring a table. LPA observed that the dining area is off of the kitchen and the table is set up for placement of four clients, however, the kitchen counter has four chairs for clients. LPA observed that there is a fire extinguisher in the dining area and upstairs. LPA observed that the kitchen area is located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had the stove, microwave built in, refrigerator, double oven and pantry with no lock on the door. Inside the pantry, LPA observed plenty of non-perishable food items and snacks.

LPA also observed perishable food items in the refrigerator. LPA observed that sharps are to be kept in a drawer in the kitchen and this drawer is secured by a magnetic locking system. Chemicals are to be stored under the kitchen sink and this lock is also the magnetic locking system. The facility has a working land line and cell phone. Menus and activity schedules are posted. LPA observed that the medications are stored in the closet by the front door, under the stair case leading to the second story of the facility. This closet has the first aid kit and other first aid supplies as well as cubbies to hold client medications. LPA also observed a small refrigerator in this closet that will also house medications that need refrigeration for clients in care. LPA observed that this closet has a locking door and will not be accessible to clients in care. Second story of the facility ,LPA observed that there is a laundry room in the landing area of the upstairs that is locked. The laundry room is located next to the bathroom for the clients and bedrooms for the clients. LPA observed that the three client bedrooms located on the second floor that are all single occupancy rooms equipped with the single beds in each room, bedding including mattress covers, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, dresser in each room, night stand in each room, lamp in each room, chair in each room and closet areas in each room as required. The bedrooms have fire detectors in each room and the Carbon Monoxide is placed in the hallway wall. LPA observed that the bathroom is equipped with a dual sink vanity and that the bathroom on the second level has a tub and shower area, no glass doors and a shower curtain. LPA toured the master bedroom on the second floor that is equipped with a bathroom for staff use; it also has extra hygiene items and beddings and the confidential staff files are locked in a cabinet. Administrator did advise that this room will be utilized for staff only and that no clients will be given access to this area. The home has a Disaster plan, Facility Sketch and Personal Rights. The facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility is prepared for licensure pending a final review of the file and Licensing Program Manager's Approval. Exit interview was conducted with Administrator.

LPA observed the Administrator has applied to renew their administrator's certificated that expired in April 2023. LPA observed one out four client records were missing the medical assessment, two out four client records were missing Ambulatory status, examination for tuberculosis and immunization records. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulations 80088(e)(1) Fixtures, Furniture Equipment and Supplies, 80069 Client Medical Assessment and 80022(k) Plan of Operation. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80088(e)(1) Fixtures, Furniture Equipment and Supplies. Hot water delivered to fixtures used by clients shall attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based upon LPA's observation LPA observed the hot water temperature was 130 degrees Fahrenheit.

Client Medical Assessment. 80069(a) Client Medical Assessment. The licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client and 80069(c)(1) Client medical assessments shall include results of...tuberculosis..... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based upon four clients records reviewed one out four client records (C2) were missing the medical assessment, two out four client records (C1 & C3) were missing Ambulatory status, two out of four client files (C2 & C4) were missing examination for tuberculosis and immunization records.

80022(k) Plan of Operation The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based upon LPA observation at the time of arrival there was two staff, one client and one infant, age 10 months, onsite. The facility is not licensed to provide care for infants. Staff interviewed stated this was staff S1's child and is usually not here, but the infant's caregiver was not available so staff brought the infant with them.

LPA requested the following documents for review: Annual required training logs, placement agreements/admission agreement, agency signed policies and procedures, and Client Information/Face Sheet, Needs and Services Plans/IPP, agency case notes regarding youth 1 (Y1), police reports, and LIC 500, employee staff schedule, and Staff 1 contact information. LPAs conducted an inspection of the agency. Confidential interviews were conducted with ten individuals, and attempted with 1 individual, during the period of October 23, 2024, to November 13, 2024. During the investigation of facility staff hit a minor and Facility staff scratched a minor, LPA Martinez and LPA Green toured the facility with William Riddle (house manager). On this inspection, LPA inspected the physical plant including but not limited to the kitchen, dining room, children bedrooms, children bathrooms, laundry room, activity room, and outside courtyards of the facility. LPA Martinez reviewed client 1’s (C1) file, on October 23, 2024, and obtained documentation for the complaint investigation. Annual required training logs, placement agreements/admission agreement, agency signed policies and procedures, and Client Information/Face Sheet, Needs and Services Plans/IPP, agency case notes regarding youth 1 (Y1), police reports, and LIC 500, employee staff schedule, and Staff 1 contact information. LPA conducted interviews from October 23, 2024, to November 13, 2024. Five out of ten confidential interviewees reported they never witnessed staff 1 (S1) being aggressive towards the children or hitting them. The six out ten interviewees reported they had no concerns about S1 or the facility. One out of ten Interviewees reported an altercation did occur, and they were aggressive towards a staff and hit them. One out of ten interviewees reported they never fought with C1 and C1 did not hit them. One out of ten interviewees reported they were not able to corroborate C1’s physical fight with a staff. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with William Riddle/house manager.
