narrative: On July 23, 2024, at 9:00 AM, Component II of the application process for Daylee Joy Residential Group Home located 7225 Hobart Blvd. Los Angeles, Ca. 90047 was held at the El Segundo Children’s Residential Regional Office in El Segundo. Attending Component II were the following individuals: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Charmetha White, and Administrator, Leah Hawkins. The purposes of this Component II meeting were to review the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. The following incomplete application forms were discussed at the meeting: Financial Information Release and Verification (LIC 404), Personnel Report (LIC 500), Group Home Orientation Certificate, CPR certificates, staff facility association and Group Home 40 Hour Administrator certificate. Program Statement: Sections 1-29 was reviewed and discussed. Pre-Licensing Inspection will be conducted on July 26, 2024, at 9:30 AM. A copy of this report was issued to the Administrator, Leah Hawkins.

On July 26, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White made an announced visit to the above location, for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection for the pending licensure of Daylee Joy Residential Group Home. LPA met with Administrator, Leah Hawkins, who granted access to the home, and provided a tour of the interior and exterior physical plant. This home is seeking a license to provide care and supervision for five (5) developmentally disable children ages, 12-17 years old, ambulatory only, and non-minor dependents. Currently the census is zero (0). There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The Administrator confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons on the premises. LPA observed the following during the inspection: The facility is a three (3) bedroom, two (2) bathroom single family dwelling located in a residential neighborhood. The front porch is completely enclosed with a black iron gate and the home is set up as follows: Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Office area, Laundry area, Backyard, detached garage, and detached office. Living room: has two (2) couches, a chair, a mounted TV, and a glass enclosed non-operational fireplace. Dining room: has table and four (4) chairs. Kitchen: has double door refrigerator/freezer, five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at time of this inspection), a microwave, dishwasher, ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. There is also a kitchen nook containing a small table with two (2) chairs, and a locked filed cabinet, which will be used to store medication. Laundry area: is located off the kitchen and has a stackable washer and dryer, there is also an exit door leading to the side of the home. Backyard: has ample space. LPA observed lose stones and a hole in walkway. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 1 of 3)

Detached garage: Administrator informed LPA the garage is used for storage by property owner. LPA will return to view garage as administrator did not have access at the time of this inspection. Detached Office: LPA observed office is under construction; the outer exterior has unfinished walls, interior will be used as an office, and at the time of this inspection it is being used for storage. Bedrooms: Bedroom #1 and #3: have two (2) twin beds; Bedroom #2 has one (1) twin bed. Each room has closet space. There were no dressers in the bedrooms. All bedrooms have a mounted TV, a ceiling fan/working light, and security bars. The security bar emergency latches were not operational at the time of this inspection. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located along the hallway, adjacent to bedroom #1 and has a toilet, tub, shower, and sink. Bathroom #2 is located off the kitchen near the laundry area and has a toilet and sink. Hot water was tested and measured within 105 – 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed the home to have a three (3) fully charged fire extinguisher. The smoke detectors were tested and found to be in working order. All posting requirements were met. The temperature of the facility is regulated by window mounted air conditioners throughout and electric floor heaters. LPA observe the facility to have a camera system that monitors the exterior of the home (front yard, both sides of the home, porch, and driveway) only. LPA reminded Administrator to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights. Children are to be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports, Law Enforcement contacts, and to report all changes within the home to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Administrator acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3).

Vehicle: Currently the facility does not have a vehicle to transport the clients. The administrator will provide information about the company vehicle later to be inspected. The following items need to be in the home prior to licensure: Perishable and Nonperishable food supply in the quantity per the regulations Drawers for clients’ rooms Operational Security bar releases Carbon monoxide deter Extra linens Hygiene products for clients Cleaning/laundry supplies Locked storage for poisons/cleaning supplies First Aid kit complete with scissors, thermometer, tweezers Working facility telephone Locked storage cabinet for client & staff files An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator. Application review will continue when the above items and all items discussed during the Component II (face-to-face office meeting) have been completed. (Page 3 of 3).

On September 19, 2024, at 9:10 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) C. White and J. Armstrong made an announced visit to the above location, for the purpose of conducting a second Pre-Licensing Inspection for the pending licensure of Daylee Joy Residential Group Home. LPA’s met with Administrator, Leah Hawkins, who granted access to the home, and provided a tour of the interior and exterior physical plant. This home is seeking a license to provide care and supervision for five (5) developmentally disable children ages, 12-17 years old, ambulatory only, and non-minor dependents. Currently the census is zero (0). LPA’s observed the following during the inspection: The facility is a three (3) bedroom, two (2) bathroom single family dwelling located in a residential neighborhood. The front porch is enclosed with a black iron gate and the home is set up as follows: Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Office area, Laundry area, Backyard, detached garage, and detached office. Living room: has two (2) couches, a chair, a mounted TV, a glass enclosed non-operational fireplace. LPA’s observe the facility to have a camera system that monitors the exterior of the home (front yard, both sides of the home, porch, and driveway) only. Dining room: has a wooden table and six (6) chairs. Kitchen: has double door refrigerator/freezer, five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at time of this inspection), two (2) microwaves, a dishwasher, ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. There is also a kitchen nook containing a small table with two (2) chairs, and a locked filed cabinet, which will be used to store medication. Laundry area: located off the kitchen, has a stackable washer and dryer, an exit door leading to the side of the home, and a staff bathroom. Backyard: has ample space, with turf grass. Report continued on LIC 809C (page 1 of 3)

Detached garage: LPA’s observed the garage being used to store clothing, it also contains a small sink and a non-operational stove. Administrator informed LPA’s items in the garage belong to the property owner. Detached Office: LPA’s observed to office being used as storage. Bedrooms: Bedroom #1 and #3: have two (2) twin beds; Bedroom #2 has one (1) twin bed. Each room has ample closet space, two (2) drawers for each client, and working combination light/ceiling fans. All bedrooms have a mounted TV. LPA’s observed partial security bars on bedroom windows which allow for emergency exiting. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located along the hallway, adjacent to bedroom #1 and has a toilet, tub, and separate shower, and sink. Bathroom #2 is located off the kitchen near the laundry area and has a toilet and sink. Hot water was tested and measured within 105 – 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA’s observed the home to have a three (3) fully charged fire extinguisher, one (1) in the kitchen, one (1) in the living room, and one (1) along the hallway. The smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. All posting requirements were met. Temperature in the facility is regulated by window mounted air conditioners throughout and electric floor heaters. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The Administrator confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons on the premises. LPA’s observed the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Vehicle: Facility will use a 2020 Dodge Caravan to transport the clients. LPA’s inspected the interior and exterior of the vehicle. LPA’s observed all seatbelts, the front lights, brake lights, back up lights, blinkers, and horn to be in working order. Vehicle registration is current through June 2025. Report continued on LIC 809 C (page 2 of 3).

LPA’s reminded Administrator to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and to ensure the corresponding form are placed in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Administrator acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the inspection, LPA’s reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports, Law Enforcement contacts, and to report all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. LPA’s informed Administrator that a Component III Tele-orientation will be scheduled per Community Care Licensing procedures. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator. (Page 3 of 3).

On March 28, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts J. Armstrong and License Program Manager E. Hernandez made an announced visit to the above location, for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Administrator, Leah Hawkins, who granted access to the home, and provided a tour of the interior and exterior physical plant. This home is licensed to provide care and supervision for five (5) developmentally disable children ages, 12-17 years old, ambulatory only, and non-minor dependents. Currently the census is zero (0). LPA and LPM observed the following during the inspection: The facility is a three (3) bedroom, two (2) bathroom single family home located in a residential neighborhood. The front porch is enclosed with a black iron gate and the home is set up as follows: Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Office area, Laundry area, Backyard, detached garage, and detached office. Living room: has two (2) couches, a chair, a mounted TV, a glass enclosed non-operational fireplace. LPA and LPM observe the facility to have a camera system that monitors the front yard. Dining room: has a wooden table and six (6) chairs. With the posting of Personal Rights, Facility Map, Emergency Contact list, and House Values/Expectations. Kitchen: has double door refrigerator/freezer, five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at time of this inspection), two (2) microwaves, a dishwasher, ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. There is also small office space in the kitchen containing a small table with two (2) chairs, and a locked filed cabinet, which will be used to store medication. Laundry area: located off the kitchen, has a stackable washer and dryer, an exit door leading to the side of the home, locked cabinets for storage and a staff bathroom. Report continued on LIC 809C (page 1 of 3)

Backyard: has ample space, with turf grass. Detached garage: LPA and LPM was not able to see the garage due to Licensee not having the key, Licensee will get a copy of the key from the property owner. Licensee stated the garage is used for storage for the property owner. Detached Office: LPA’s observed to office being used as storage. Bedrooms: Bedroom #1 and #3: have two (2) twin beds; Bedroom #2 has one (1) twin bed. Each room has ample closet space, two (2) drawers for each client, and working combination light/ceiling fans. All bedrooms have a mounted TV. LPA and LPM observed partial security bars on bedroom windows which allow for emergency exiting. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located along the hallway, adjacent to bedroom #1 and has a toilet, tub, and separate shower, and sink. Bathroom #2 is located off the kitchen near the laundry area and has a toilet and sink. Hot water was tested and measured within 105 – 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA’s observed the home to have a three (3) fully charged fire extinguisher, one (1) in the kitchen, one (1) in the living room, and one (1) along the hallway. The smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working. All posting requirements were met. Temperature in the facility is regulated by window mounted air conditioners throughout and electric floor heaters. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The Administrator confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons on the premises. LPA’s observed the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Vehicle: Facility will use a 2020 Dodge Caravan to transport the clients. LPA inspected the interior and exterior of the vehicle. LPA observed all seatbelts, the front lights, brake lights, back up lights, blinkers, and horn to be in working order. Vehicle registration is current through June 2025. Report continued on LIC 809 C (page 2 of 3).

LPA’s reminded Administrator to ensure the following when children are in Place: To make sure to have non- perishable and perishable foods that is not expired, to clean the backyard to be free of debris, to retrieve a copy of the garage key from the property owner. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports, Law Enforcement contacts, and to report all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator. (Page 3 of 3).

inappropriate sexual incidents among residents, particularly during times when residents are still awake. While residents were upstairs to fall asleep, supervision should not lapse during night time, particularly at a time where it could be reasonably believed that not all residents are yet asleep, as was the case with this incident. Night staff should be present in the facility at a location where supervision can be provided to all residents and all activity can be clearly seen and heard to ensure appropriate intervention can be provided as needed. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84065.5 Staff/Child Ratios. LPA also recommends that moving forward, the facility consider the history of and/or tendency for, within the served population, inappropriate sexual incidents and ensure that all residents have appropriate supervision when at the facility together, including those who do not have a specific requirement in their program plan for 24/7 supervision. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Facility Manager Liza Tagpis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Additionally, reports indicate that youth also would have preferred greater supervision and felt that staff believed one youth over the other, which could have been prevented if staff were present to witness the incident themselves. Based on interviews, enhanced supervision was needed in order to prevent additional...

met_with: Supervisor Edwin Isip, Administrator Ryan Busalacchi
narrative: On 4/7/22 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility regarding the group home facility closure. LPA met with Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing, entry screening, and pre-visit screening call. The facility has received an Adult Residential Facility (ARF) license on 12/14/21 and will be closing the group home facility. Closure letter, closure plan, and forfeited license have not yet been sent to Licensing. LPA requested these items when notified of the transition to ARF and surrender of group home license on 3/2/22. Today, LPA received the formal closure notice and closure plan from Administrator Ryan Busalacchi, as well as the ARF license, and LPA collected the forfeited group home license at visit. LPA issued a citation of Health and Safety Code, Section 1524. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 11/03/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility, which has transitioned to an adult facility, to deliver a deficiency citation regarding an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Facility Manager Liza Tagpis and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, it was learned that an incident occurred involving a facility staff member sending inappropriate online messages to a former resident shortly after their move to a new placement. While the resident was no longer in care, their online information and/or identifying information to locate them online was secured due to the resident having been in care while the staff member was employed at the facility. The staff member did not ensure the resident was accorded dignity and respect. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84072(d)(1). See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/03/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility, which has transitioned to an adult facility, to deliver findings for the invesitgation of the above allegation. LPA met with Facility Manager Liza Tagpis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation pertains to an incident in which a staff member sent inappropriate messages to a then former resident. Based on interviews, it is not clear that any inappropriate messages or interactions occurred or were sent while the resident was in care at this facility. The staff member was immediately removed from the schedule and no longer works for the licensee, and based on interviews, no repeat or similar incident has occurred. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager Liza Tagpis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng on 3/14/22 at 10:45AM. During the inspection, LPA Ng met with Maria Tan (Facility Manager) and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 2 of child’s records on site at the facility at 11:00 PM. At 12:30, LPA asked facility manager for staff files regarding training. The facility was given two technical violations during an annual inspection on 3/11/2022 for: CCR 84068.3(a): The needs and services plan specified in Section 84068.2 shall be updated at least every six months to determine the following. CCR 84066(b)(6): The licensee shall maintain the following personnel records: (6) A record of each work performance evaluation and any correspondence with the employee. Both plan of correction dates are on April 4th 2022. LPA reviewed 2 of child’s psychotropic medications and records at 1:30 PM. Due to not having staff files ready for review and needs and service plans available, LPA was unable to review staff files but reviewed C1 and C2's 2020-2021 ISP. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site at 2:00 PM. ------ CONT. ON LIC809-C------

LPA interviewed 0 clients currently taking psychotropic medication at 2:00 PM. C1 said waved Hi but was unable to answer questions. C1 seemed to be in good spirits. When counting one of the medications for C1, there was 18 pills extra. Facility Manager advised that C1 went to the hospital for those days and did not know if the hospital gave the medication to C1. LPA Ng advised to put it on a destruction log and properly dispose of the extra medication. LPA conducted exit interview with Maria Tan, Facility Manager at 3:00 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Maria Tan, Facility Manager upon completion. No deficiencies were cited today. LPA conducted exit interview with Maria Tan, Facility Manager at 3:15 PM.

met_with: Supervisor Edwin Isip, House Manager Maria Tan, Administrator Ryan Busalacchi
narrative:
On 3/18/22 at 9:48AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a case management - annual continuation. LPA met with Supervisor Edwin Isip, Facility Manager Maria Tan, and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing, entry screening, and pre-visit screening call. During the initial inspection on 3/07/22, LPA inspected the facility and grounds and facility and personnel files using the CARES Inspection Tool. LPA continued with the tool to complete the inspection of resident records on 3/11/22. Today's visit is to complete and the deliver the report. At visit, LPA re-toured the facility and updated observations of deficiencies listed below. The following was observed: The facility living and meal prep spaces are clean and sanitary; the facility's first aid kit was observed to be complete; personal rights were posted; facility license was posted; smoke detectors are in working condition; water and room temperature measured within permitted ranges. The following deficiencies were observed on 3/7/22 and/or 3/11/22 (See attached LIC 809-D pages): 1) Two (2) unsecured jugs of laundry detergent were observed on the floor in the corner of resident R2's (See attached LIC 811) bedroom. LPA issued a citation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) Section 80087(g). Laundry detergent jugs were immediately removed from the room and placed with locked chemicals. 2) Laundry detergent was stored among food items all accessible to resident R2 as they were stored unsecured in R2's bedroom. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80087(i). The laundry detergent jugs were removed, and R2 was moved out of this room by 3/18/22. 3) The storage loft in resident R2's bedroom has no full wall separating the spaces, so R2's bedroom is joint with staff "room" in the loft, meaning staff and resident shared a bedroom. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84087(b)(6). R2 was moved out of this room by 3/18/22. 4) More than 10 bottles of empty, expired, or discontinued medications were observed in a locked cabinet in the kitchen, including psychotropic medications, and at least one psychotropic that expired in November...

... 2021 and was filled in 2020. Supervisor and Facility Manager confirmed these should have been destroyed. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80075(I). 5) In the kitchen was a bulk stack of peanut butter each with an inch of separated oil and dated "Best before Oct 17 2020" as well as a large jug of chicken flavoring with real chicken in ingredients dated "Jan 29 22." LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80076(a)(1). Peanut butter and chicken flavoring were removed immediately. 6) The facility uses only a rotation of planned menus and has no saved menus to reflect what was served in case it differed from the planned menu. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80076(a)(5). 7) The attached storage loft with low ceiling and accessed by narrow, ladder-like staircase in resident R2's bedroom was observed to be used as a staff bedroom for live-in staff member. The facility was previously cited and advised of the requirement to not use the storage space as a bedroom on 4/19/19. LPA issed a citation of CCR Section 84087(b)(4). R2 was moved out of this room by 3/18/22, and the storage space is no longer being used as a staff bedroom. 8) Facility Manager stated disaster drills are conducted twice a year and that two drills were conducted in 2020, one in 2021, and none so far in 2022. Logs were located for only 3/31/20, 12/17/20, and 9/3/21. LPA issued a citation of Health and Safety Code (HSC) Section 1565(c), which requires quarterly drills. 9) Supervisor and Facility Manager confirmed that restraints have been performed at the facility in the past 6 months but there was no log of manual restraints. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84361(f). 10) Staff files for S1, S3, S4, S5 (see LIC 811-C) were observed to have incomplete or missing initial training logs. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84065(i). 11) Staff files indicate that less than 20hrs of annual training was received in 2021 and no training record or training certificate for training in 2021 for staff S1, S2, S3, S4, S5 were observed in the files. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84065(j)(1). 12) The files for residents R2, R3, R5 were observed to be missing admission agreements, and Supervisor and Facility Manager were not able to locate all missing admission agreements. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80070(b)(6). 13) The files for residents R1, R3, R4, R5 were observed to be either missing needs and services and/or behaviorist/Regional Center treatment plans or having plans 2+ years old. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84070(b)(11). 14) The files for residents R1, R4, R5 were observed to be missing psychotropic medication consent documentation. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84070(b)(12). 15) The medication administration records (MARs) for residents R1, R4, R5 were observed to log...

... psychotropic and non-psychotropic medications jointly rather than psychotropic medications being logged separately on the (or version of) LIC 622B Psychotropic MAR (PMAR). LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84070(b)(13). 16) Facility Manager stated that the facility keeps old medication bottles, removes the labels, and uses them to transfer medications to that container for residents' home visits. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80075(k)(6). 17) The files for residents R1, R5 were missing property/valuables inventory, and the inventories were not updated for 2021/2022 for R2, R3, R4. Facility Manager confirmed that items had since been removed or added, such as shoes or holiday gifts. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80026(h). 18) LPA observed that the licensee did not ensure that no bedroom was used as a general passageway to another room due to resident R2's bedroom being the only way to access a ladder-like staircase to the storage loft being used as a staff room for live-in staff member. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 84087(b)(5). R2 was moved out of the room by 3/18/22, and the storage loft is no longer being used as a staff bedroom. 19) LPA observed that the licensee did not ensure the facility was clean and in good repair due to: smoke detector hanging by wires in the living room; hallway bathroom missing shower curtain and rod; resident R1's bedroom dirty with unsanitary floor, two dirty food containers and spoon on desk, crumbs on all furniture and in crevices, crumbs and wet and dried unknown substances on the floor from the doorway to the closet to the bed, candy wrapper, bowl of dried applesauce, plate with left over crust and residual oil/liquid on plate in the closet, 18 eaten yogurt cups in dresser drawer, two plates, spoon, and 2 hot dog buns in another drawer, cheese wrappers, empty Ensure drink bottle, empty jar of parmesan cheese in another drawer. Facility Manager stated the rooms are cleaned daily and that R1 makes this mess in one day. LPA issued a citation of CCR Section 80087(a). Shower curtain and rod replaced and R1's room cleaned by 3/11/22, and smoke detector secured by 3/18/22. LPA advised of the following deficiencies (See attached LIC9102 pages): 1) LPA observed that complaint procedures were not posted in the facility. LPA advised of this requirement, per CCR Section 84072.2(a)(3). Complaint procedures posted by 3/18/22. 2) LPA observed that emergency drills were not conducted quarterly as required and that documentation of drills was not available in the facility records. Facility Manager had to locate the logs from their computer and had difficulty locating them all. LPA advised, per CCR Section 80023(d)(2), that all logs be maintained at the facility site in either an electronic file accessible to licensing personnel during all visits or in the physical...

... facility files. 3) LPA observed that all staff files were missing work performance evaluations. Supervisor stated that performance evaluations are maintained in the confidential files at the administrative office. LPA advised, per CCR Section 84066(b)(6), that the facility maintain a record of work performance evaluations and also that per Section 80066(e)(1), the facility ensure all personnel records are accessible at/from the facility site. 4) During visit on 3/7/22, LPA observed that there were confidential client documents scattered and disorganized on a table in the garage. During visit on 3/11/22, LPA observed that staff left the laundry room open as well as the garage door while two residents were present and walking around the facility. Residents could have entered the garage and grabbed the documents, which LPA discussed with Facility Manager. Having the documents disorganized and outside of the proper secured file storage area does not encourage maintenance of confidentiality of documentation. LPA advises, per CCR Section 80070(c), that the facility ensure the garage door is kept closed and locked while residents are at the facility and that the facility remove and properly store the client documents currently in the garage. Garage was cleaned by 3/18/22. 5) LPA observed that residents R1 and R3 files were missing signed medical care consent forms. LPA advises, per CCR Section 84070(b)(10), that the facility ensure consent forms are signed by the authorized representative at admission. 6) LPA observed that needs and services and treatment plans were missing from the files and the plans that were in some of the residents' files were more than a year old, which was discussed with Facility Manager and Supervisor. LPA advises, per 84068.3(a), that needs and services should be maintained and should be updated at least every six months. 7) LPA observed that the facility did not maintain documentation of bedroom sharing arrangements. LPA advised, per CCR Section 84087(e), that the facility begin documenting bedroom sharing and that residents are compatible and maintain this documentation in the file of each child sharing a bedroom. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Ryan , whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi
narrative: ... at the facility at between 6-6:30AM, the Facility Manager checked on the resident and then called 911. The resident was assessed by a doctor on the same day of the seizure, and a follow-up evaluation by a neurologist was scheduled. Due to the fact that the resident did not have seizures in their care plan, there was no seizure plan in place, so when the signs of a seizure were recognized, 911 should have been called immediately. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80075 Health Related Services. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/22/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility was unaware that a resident in care had a history of seizure activity. The resident last had a seizure at 9 years old, approximately 7 years ago. This is not documented in the resident's care plan and was only learned after a staff member witnessed the seizure and the facility notified a family member, who informed the facility of the previous seizure. The staff who witnessed the incident, which occurred around 5AM, responded to the sound of the resident falling off the bed and upon observing the resident shaking, turned the resident's head, and observed the resident until they stopped shaking after about 2 minutes, at which point the resident was able to get up and lie down on their bed. Due to believing it to not be critical, the staff member did not call 911. The staff shortly after called facility management, and when Facility Manager arrived... [CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE]

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Health Related Services (a) The licensee shall ensure that each client receives necessary first aid and other needed medical...services, including arrangement for...transportation to the nearest available services. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview, licensee did not ensure necessary medical attention due to resident having seizure and staff not immediately calling 911 despite no known seizure history, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield on 3/1/2023 at 10:40AM. During the inspection, LPA Belfield met with Edwin Isip, Supervisor and Ryan Busalacchi Licensee. The facility is licensed to serve 6 clients. Currently there are 5 clients residing in the facility. No clients were present at the start of this inspection. The facility has three verball clients and two verbal cleints who were at school during the inspection. LPA reviewed 3 of child’s records, 2 staff files, interviewed one staff and observed facility files. A walk-through of the facility was conducted with supervisor Isip and Licensee Ryan B. Observed during this inspection, the facility was clean and free of obstructions, proper signs were posted such as personal rights poster, menus were observed, bedrooms were observed with proper storage. During a staff file review the training conducted for psychotropic medications did not include the information used for sufficient training. staff files were observed to have this training conducted in 2022 and not as apart of the initial and ongoing training in the California Code of regulations section 84065(k)(7). Facility issued Technical Assistance advisory for section 84065(k)(7) Personnel Requirements. LPA reviewed three clients ISP ( needs and service plans) and they were not signed by the clients social worker. It was discussed with licensee that that the request should be made to obtain signatures from the social workers. Licensee agrees to this as stipulated by signing this report. LPA also observed in one client file, the JV223 was expired. communication was observed with facility and social worker and the JV223 is currently still in process. Communication was observed buy this LPA that the reason for not having updated form on file is due to county social worker not completing the process at this time. Advisories issued. No citation for violation of California Code of Regulations, title 22, Division Six, were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report will be sent to licensee Ryan Busalacchi.

met_with: Administrator Ryan Busalacchi, Supervisor Edwin Isip; Facility Manager Frances Nelson
narrative:
On 2/21/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Ryan Busalacchi, Supervisor Edwin Isip, and Facility Manager Frances Nelson and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. During visit, LPA conducted two staff interviews and two resident observations. Residents returned from school around 4PM. At the end of visit, LPA encountered a system error that resulted in LPA's computer freezing and prevented the report from being completed and provided to licensee at visit. LPA completed report and provided to licensee on 2/22/23. During inspection, LPA observed the facility to have made significant improvements in compliance from the previous year's annual, including better file organization and implementation of staff training and resident activities. Food was within date, fresh, and stored correctly. One tub of expired sour cream that did not have visible mold was disposed of during visit. Hot water measured within permitted range, and the fridge was maintained at a temperature within permitted range. Planned menus and as served menus were maintained. Restraint log was maintained. Staff interviewed were knowledgeable of facility procedures and mandated reporting duties. Residents observed appeared dressed in clean, appropriate clothing and to be comfortable with staff present at the facility, evidenced by approaching and engaging with staff upon return from school. However, the following concerns require addressing. Two cigarette butts were observed with staff on the back patio near the rear sliding door. Construction items/supplies of a large nail on the ground and planks of wood with nails sticking out were observed in the side yard accessible to residents in care, with more planks in the other, gated-off side yard. The large nail was immediately removed by staff. Multiple areas of unknown brown substances were observed...

...on the wall of the kitchen by the table, on the wall and back door of the rear bedroom, and on the ceiling of the middle hallway bedroom. The word "crime" was graffitied on the dresser in the middle hallway bedroom, and curse words were graffitied on the door of the rear bedroom and on two walls in the dining room, the latter of which staff statements indicate were not in the last two weeks. Residents R2 and R3 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List) are prescribed levetiracetam and trazadone, respectively, and neither medication was logged on a separate log. Staff files contained missing or incomplete initial training logs for staff S1, S2, and S3 (See LIC 811), and all staff files reviewed were missing at least some certificates for trainings licensee confirmed staff attended. Activity supplies could not be located in the facility. LPA is issuing 2 citations of 80087 Buildings and Grounds, 2 citations of 84088 Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies, 1 citation of 84070 Children's Records, and 1 citation of 84065 Personnel Requirements. LPA is assessing two civil penalties of $250 each, $500 combined, for repeat violation of the same subsections of Sections 80087 and 84070, which were previously cited on 3/18/22. See LIC 809-Ds and LIC 421s. Additional advisories were provided, which are not citations. See LIC 9102s. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Supervisor Edwin Isip and Administrator Ryan Busalacchi, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 2/29/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Supervisor Edwin Isip and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. LPA toured the facility site and grounds and reviewed facility, personnel, and resident records. LPA observed the facility to be free of hazards. Chemicals, medications, and sharp or potentially dangerous household items are stored where inaccessible to residents in care. Bedrooms are clean and organized and maintained in safe condition. During inspection, LPA observed the following which require follow-up: 1) Staff S5 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names List dated 2/29/24) does not have a background clearance. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. See attached LIC 809-D. In addition, pursuant to Section 80019(g), LPA is assessing an immediate civil penalty of $100 per five days in violation for a total of $500. See LIC 421BG dated 2/29/24. 2) LPA observed food splattered on the kitchen walls as well as sticky substances on the interior and exterior of kitchen cabinets with dust stuck to the substances. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80087 Buildings and Grounds and 80076 Food Service. See attached LIC 809-D. LPA observed additional areas in which technical assistance can be beneficial. See LIC 9102s dated 2/29/24. A continuation visit will be required to complete this inspection. Licensee also agrees to submit a current LIC 500 to LPA by 3/1/24. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Supervisor Edwin Isip, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 5/6/2024 at 10:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and LPA Mona Lam conducted a visit to the licensed facility. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9(a)(2). LPAs met with Frances Nelson, Manager, at 10:50am. LPAs reviewed two of child’s records and two of staff personnel files on site at the facility. Two children met SB484 Psychotropic Medications inspection criteria. . LPAs did not interview staff present because they were not involved in psychotropic medication administration. LPAs did not interview children currently prescribed psychotropic medication during this visit. One child was present, this child did not meet inspection criteria. During the inspection the LPAs observed that the facility did not have documentation that one child had engaged in the planning of their services, LPAs delivered a Technical Violation for California Code of Regulations 84068.2(d)(1) (see attached LIC9102). LPAs observed that one staff member that was administering medications had not received Psychotropic Medications training. This poses a potential risk to the health, safety, and/or personal rights of clients in care. LPAs delivered a Type B citation for California Code of Regulations 84065(i)(3)(M) Personnel Requirements (see LIC809D). LPAs observed Edwin Isip, Supervisor conducted a medication count at 1:30pm. This inspection was not finished during this visit. LPA(s) will return to interview one child and two staff members. LPAs conducted an exit interview and delivered appeal rights at 2:12pm and provided a copy of this licensing report to Edwin Isip, Supervisor.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84065(i)(3)(M) Personnel Requirements - Medication procedures, assistance with medication, universal precautions... including oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, one staff member that has been administering medications has not received medication training. This poses a potential risk to the health, safety, and/or personal rights of clients in care.

narrative: On 07/24/24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Kristin Pierotti and Celeste Aparicio conducted a visit to the facility for a case management inspection. LPAs discussed the process of requesting age exceptions with the Facility Administrator and the Facility Supervisor, who stated they will be submitting a request to the Department. investigation_findings: 13On 10/21/24 at 10:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted a complaint investigation visit at the facility in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Edwin Isip, Facility Supervisor and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, it was found that the client in care had bruising on different parts of their body, which staff observed and thought to be caused by the client’s medical condition. Through medical record review it was found that the client has a condition in which easy bruising occurs. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations, record review, and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no citations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Edwin Isip, Facility Supervisor.

narrative: On 02/10/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Edwin Isip, Facility Manager and toured the facility inside and out. The Group Home is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 1 staff and 0 clients. At 11:00am, LPA Pierotti reviewed client and staff files. Client files were complete and contained all necessary documents. Client Needs and Services Plans were reviewed and were current. Staff files were complete and contained all necessary documents. Staff training logs were reviewed and all staff have completed the necessary training. At 12:45pm, LPA Pierotti toured the facility. LPA Pierotti observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Pierotti tested the water temperature and found it to be 115.2 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked in the staff room and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored safely and in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. LPA reviewed client's medication logs and found them to be complete and up to date. The facility is in good repair and clean. At 1:00pm, LPA Pierotti toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. LPA Pierotti interviewed 1 staff and 0 clients. All clients were at school during the time of the inspection. The majority of the clients who reside in the home are non-verbal. LPA will attempt to conduct client interviews with the verbal clients at a later date. At this time there were no deficiencies found. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Facility Manager whose signature confirms receipt.

met_with: Director Ron Dhillon, Administrator Nick Moriana, Board Member Mandave Sandhu
narrative: On 2/6/25 at 12PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Executive Director Ron Dhillon, Administrator Nick Moriana, and Board Member Mandave Sandhu for a schedule prelicensing inspection. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA toured the facility site and grounds and discussed the facility's application. The facility is a single-story house in a residential neighborhood. The house is set up with three double-occupancy bedrooms, one and a half bathrooms, and a master suite bedroom currently set up as a staff office with locked storage for medications and emergency supplies. There are three living areas, one dining area, a laundry room, and a two-car garage. There are multiple closets and cabinets throughout the facility for storage of linens and other facility supplies. Hot water initially measured above the permitted range, but the water heater setting was lowered, and hot water measured within range by the end of the visit. The facility has a thermometer and the Applicant plans to monitor hot water temperatures. The facility has a video camera set up beside the garage that is not in use. However, Appilcant expressed interest in putting up cameras, and LPA suggested Applicant refer to PIN 24-09-CRP. Additionally, there are unsecured paint cans in the garage that Applicant agreed to remove upon completion of planned painting touch-ups and notify LPA once that is complete. LPA discussed the forms still needed for the application and the pending program statement updates. Most forms were obtained at visit. LPA informed Applicant to expect a summary of all pending items by 2/11/25. Based on this inspection, upon completion of the items discussed above, the facility will be ready for licensure. A copy of this report was provided to Executive Director Ron Dhillon.

On 06/17/25 at 10:50am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti and LPA Simran Nayar conducted a post-licensing inspection. LPAs met with Nick Moriana, Facility Administrator and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPAs used the CARE Inspection Tool and conducted a tour of the facility site, review of 5 personnel records and 2 resident records, and confidential interviews with 1 staff member and 1 resident. LPAs observed the facility to be in good condition, clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The facility currently has 2 residents and each resident has their own bedroom with individual beds and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. LPAs observed personnel and resident records to be complete and had all necessary documents. Staff have full background clearances, and first aid training certifications. All staff are actively completing the initial training requirements. Residents' records contain current emergency contact information, complete care plans, accurate medication records and cash records. Based on interviews, LPAs observed staff to be knowledgeable of facility policies, mandated reporting, and intervention procedures. LPAs observed residents to each be provided 1:1 supervision, to be dressed in well-fitting, appropriate, and clean clothes, and to appear comfortable in care, showing no hesitation around staff or in responding to staff guidance. Continue on LIC812C

No deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, was left with Facility Administrator whose signature confirms receipt.

narrative: The Department has determined that the allegation of a Physical Plant violation is deemed to be unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited per California Code Regulation An interview was conducted in person and the report was provided to the Program Director on 06/03/2022
investigation_findings: 13On June 3,2022 at 10:15AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the finding. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information regarding the reported pest at the facility. Information and records obtained revealed that there were no statements or documented evidence to support that the allegation that the facility "Staff are not ensuring facility is free from pests”, occurred. The internal Investigation revealed that no evidence to support the allegation of a physical plan violation. There was no statement obtain from clients due to phasing out of the program. LPA obtained statements from staff and records that the facility implemented a safety plan by contacting Pest Control vender to inspect the facility to ensure that the facility was infested wtih pest. LPA gathered information to confirm that the Pest Control vender placed manual Glue Traps for mice in specific areas of the facility to ensure the safe of the clients.

facility_name: DIAMONDS IN THE ROUGH GROUP HOME
narrative:
On 08/23/21 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPAs), Pamela Silva and Juliet Robles, conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at the facility and met with Dr Dwon Phillips, Administrator. This is a 24-hour facility which offers services and supervision to ambulatory clients with developmental disabilities. The facility is licensed for a capacity of four (4) clients, male or female ages 8 to 17 years old. There are currently three (3) clients in placement. The LPAs requested the following items and information: Personnel Report LIC 500, client roster, Plan of Operation/Program Statement (POO/PS), Board of Directors Meeting Minutes, and client and staff files. At 9:45 AM, LPAs and the Administrator did a walkthrough of the entire facility. The facility is clean, safe and in good repair. All exits and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. There are no bodies of water in the premises. There are no weapons or firearms in the facility. Facility has all required posters throughout the facility. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms were tested and are operable at the time of the inspection. Hot water temperatures are maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F). Temperature in clients’ rooms are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). All sinks, showers and toilets were clean and in working order. First aid kit was readily available and complete. Medications were observed to be centrally locked and are accessible only to staff responsible for stored medications. Medication Administration Records (MAR) versus medication logs were checked. The facility has perishable food supplies for at least 2 days and non-perishable food supplies for two weeks. The facility provides nutritious snacks between meals. Food Menu is posted. Knives and other sharps were observed to be locked in the kitchen cabinet. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and toxins are locked and inaccessible to clients.

Children live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Individual beds are in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. All children attend school when school is in session. The facility's Emergency Disaster Plan needs to be updated per Provider Information Notice (PIN) 21-03-CRP 2020. At 10:30 AM, LPAs reviewed three (3) client and five (5) staff files. All facility staff or other individuals who require caregiver background checks have received DOJ/FBI criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPAs discussed the findings with the facility administrator. LPAs issued five (5) Technical Advisories on the following: CCR 84365(d)(1)(A) and 84365((d)(1)(C) Emergency Intervention Plan, CCR 84065(i)(3) Staffing Records, CCR 84070(b)(12) and CCR 84070(b)(13) Client Records. LPAs agreed to work with facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with CCR Regulations. The administrator was provided information on where to locate Provider Information Notices (PINs), guidance of the new CARE Tools Inspection Process and Guardian. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC9102TAs and the confidential names list were provided to the Administrator.

facility_name: DIAMONDS IN THE ROUGH GROUP HOME
narrative: On 09/24/21, at 1:30 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer made an unannounced case management visit to the above facility. The purpose of the visit was to verify information Community Care Licensing received regarding the facility staff contacting the client's placement agency requesting the removal of the children because they were closing in fourteen (14) days. When LPA arrived at the home no one answered the door, the ring doorbell wasn't working, but the home doorbell worked. LPA rang the doorbell, knocked on the security door, walked around the home with no answer, and left a business card on the door. LPA Gilmer knocked on the neighbors at 15313 doors a young lady answered said she hadn't seen anyone at 15312 and that her mother has the telephone number of the licensee. LPA left a card and asked if she would have her mother call LPA with the telephone number. LPA also knocked on 15318 and 15319 doors no one answered. LPA later learned that the Licensee/Owner of the group home Dwon Phillip Hill passed away on 09/23/21. No further information has been provided.

met_with: Milieu Manager - Blaise Eversole & Maribel Eck - On Call Program Director
narrative:
On August 24, 2022 at 9:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Required 2-Year Inspection. LPA met with Blaise Eversole, Milieu Manager who granted access to the location. LPA met with Maribel Eck, On Call Program Director and together a tour of the entire facility was conducted both inside and out. The facility is a private pay substance abuse & mental health facility licensed to provide care and supervision services for six (6) children ages 11-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census at the time of the inspection was six (6). The facility is a two story 3-bedroom, 2 ½ bathroom house which includes a Living room, Dining room, Kitchen, Laundry area, a Classroom area, Staffing offices, a Den/Group room, a Wrap-around Patio, a Gurage, and a Backyard. The home is set up as follows: Living room: Is equipped with two sofas. Dining room: Is equipped with a table with seating for 8 people. Kitchen: Is equipped with is 5 burner gas operated stove/oven (4 out of 5 were operational), a double door refrigerator/freezer, a dishwasher, and a microwave. The home was observed to have one-week supply of non-perishable and two days of perishable foods, including nutritious snacks, and the weekly menu is posted. The trash can is equipped with tight fitting lid. Laundry area: Is located in the locked staffing area. It is equipped with a washer/dryer, found to be in working order, and a locked storage cabinet containing all disinfectants, and cleaning solutions. Den: Is located on the second floor at the top of the stairs is used for group therapy sessions. It is furnished with equipped 3 sofas, a table with 8 chairs, and a mounted TV. This room has two separate doors leading to the outside wrap-around patio. Wrap-Around Patio: is covered, it has two (2) small locked storage bins, observed to store tools, two (2) seating areas, and a grill. Classroom: is equipped with tables, chairs, two (2) computers, school supplies, storage area for each client, and a sink for hand washing. Report continued on LIC 809C

Gurage: is equipped with a pool table, a ping pong table, a locked deep freezer and refrigerator which stores extra food, and two locked storage cabinets which store the facilities emergency disaster equipment. Staffing Offices: are located on the first floor and remain locked. Backyard: has a basketball court. Bedroom #1- upstairs- two twin Beds, closet Space, dresser, window, working light, and an attached bathroom. Bedroom #2 - upstairs - two twin Beds, closet Space, dresser, window, and working light. Bedroom #3 - upstairs - two twin Beds, closet Space, dresser, window, and working light. Each room is occupied by two clients. Bathrooms: All bathrooms were checked and found to be in good repair and working order. The hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The home was inspected, and the following was observed: The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. The home has 3 regulation fire extinguishers. There is a working telephone readily accessible. Medications are locked in staffing office and made inaccessible to clients in care. Temperatures in client’s room are maintained between 68-85 degrees (F). Sharp knives are locked in a toolbox stored in a locked pantry located at the front of the house. Overall LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water located at the facility. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The Program has a total of fourteen Staff. LPA received copy of the LIC 500. LPA will return on a later date to review staff and client records and complete staff and client interviews. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

met_with: Evan Sahn- Program Director & Elizabeth Smith - Milieu Manager
narrative:
On September 21, 2022 at 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Discovery Adolescent Program IV, for the purpose of conducting a Required 2-Year inspection. LPA met with Evan Sahn, Program Director and Elizabeth Smith, Milieu Manager, and was granted access into the facility. The facility was toured at 11:30 AM both inside and out. The facility is a private pay mental health facility licensed to provide care and supervision services for sixteen (16) children, ages 11-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census at the time of the inspection was nine (9). The facility is two story, 8 bedroom, 7 bathroom house and it is set up as follows: Bedrooms: there are four bedrooms each, on opposite wings of the second floor, and separated by the staff station and classroom area. Each bedroom has two twin beds, which include two attached storage drawers; two separate closets; working lights; and non-operating windows. Bathrooms: there are three bathrooms on the first floor, and four bathrooms, two in each wing, on the second floor. Laundry rooms: there are a total of two laundry rooms, one in each wing on the second floor, and both remained locked. Dining Area: equipped with multiple tables and chairs. Kitchen: equipped with an electric stove, two ovens, 3 microwaves, a double door refrigerator, a double door freezer, a pantry, and a dishwasher. Classroom area: equipped with computers, chairs, TV, and bookshelves. Outdoor recreation area: there are two outdoor areas, one on each side of the dining room area. The areas are equipped with basketball court, ping pong table, and multiple sitting areas. Medication room: located on the first floor and remains locked. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Staffing offices/Therapist rooms: there two staffing offices and five therapy offices. The carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Facility fire alarm is hard wired and was not tested during inspection. Medications are locked medication room and made inaccessible to clients in care. Additionally, medications that require refrigeration is stored in a double locked refrigerator located in the medication room. First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. Sharp knives are stored in a locked box locked in the kitchen pantry. The facility has 7 regulation fire extinguishers. The facility has a working telephone readily accessible. Menu is posted in kitchen area. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week, perishable foods for two days, and clients are provided nutritious between meals. Temperatures in client rooms and common areas were found to be between 68 - 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperature was tested and found to be between 105 - 120 degrees (F). Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons inaccessible to clients. Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The front yard and outdoor recreation area were clean and free of debris. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches were unobstructed. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. There was no swimming pool or bodies of water located at the facility. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency or the Foster Care Ombudsperson, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Group Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. Program Director provided LPA with a copy of the Personnel Report (LIC 500). LPA will return to facility at a later time to review client and staff records. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this site visit. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

There was no evidence to support C1’s limitations on phone calls and family visits due to their non-participation in the program. Documentary evidence revealed C1’s attendance and participation in some program group activities. There is no evidence or witnesses to support that “Facility staff did not seek minor appropriate medical attention”. Based on the interviews conducted, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Edison was unable to determine if the above said allegation occurred, therefore the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended, and the finding can be changed. Based on the observations made during today’s visit, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Program Director.

narrative:
On February 25, 2021 at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Stephanie Hudak conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with Facility Manager/ Group Home Administrator, Adrian Rivera. The home is a one-story home residence with a total of twelve bedrooms and six bathrooms (ten client bedrooms and two staff offices) (four client’s bathrooms and two staff bathrooms). Eighteen clients were present during the inspection and they were in group therapy or online school. Staff present were four direct care staff, one nurse and five therapists. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf, dresser and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. At 11:00 AM, the hot water in client bathroom #1 was measured to be 115 degrees Fahrenheit. At 11:10 AM, the hot water in the client bathroom #2 was measured to be 114 degrees Fahrenheit, there is a bathroom across from client bathroom #2 that is wheelchair accessible, hot water is measured at 112 degrees Fahrenheit. At 11:15 AM, the hot water in the client bathroom #3 was measured at 112 degrees Fahrenheit. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to clients. In the nurse’s office there is a locking cabinet for medications. LPA Williams checked Client #1 through #5 medications. Cleansers/chemicals, cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners/chemicals are locked in the front closet near the front door. Sharps are locked in a locked box in the group room. Cooking knives are locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors located in each wing where the client rooms are located were operable, are all hardwired into the entire facility with a main control box. LPA observed the main control box and the fire alarm system are in working condition. (Continued on page 2)

There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Facility Manager/ Group Home Administrator, Adrian Rivera. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, and current menu. LPA did not observe the facility license to be posted in a common area. LPA did not observe the visitation policy to be posted in an common area. LPA did not observe page 2 of Personal Rights to be posted in common area. Technical advisory notes will be issued for missing items. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA observed the facility pool to be inaccessible and over five feet tall. Half of the fence was rod iron and the other half of the fence was a vinyl fencing material. At 12:00 PM, LPA and LPM reviewed 5 client files and all files contained a majority of the necessary documents required for inspection as required for Title 22 regulations. It was discussed with the facility manager/Administrator that a few of the required forms were missing therefore a Technical Advisory will be issued. At 12:30 PM, LPA and LPM reviewed 5 staff files. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigation and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA was unable to verify staff training hours during time of inspection. Facility Manger/ Administrator, Adrian Rivera was advised to email current training records to LPA. A review of administrative records indicates the facility currently has a licensing fee of $908.00 due by March 1, 2021. Based on observations and inspection, there are no citations being issued at this time. However Technical advisory notes are being issued for client and staff records missing documents. Technical Advisory notes are also being issued for documents not posted in common areas. It is being noted that Community Care Licensing is requesting copies of the following for new Group Home Administrator: LIC 308 Designation Facility Responsibility, application and or resume, Group Home Administrator Certificate and Board Resolution confirming Mr. Rivera’s appointment as administrator to be submitted by March 25, 2021. A copy of Client and staff records review forms (LIC 858 and 859) and technical advisory notices (LIC 9102) will be emailed to Adrian Rivera by close of business day tomorrow. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Adrian Rivera.

On 11/04/2022, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jessica Peete and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Cheraki Davis, conducted an unannounced Annual Continuation visit at Discovery Mood and Anxiety Program Group Home. LPA Peete was met by the facility by Program Director Sylvia Parron at 9:40am. LPA Peete and LPM Davis visited the facility on 11/03/2022 to complete inspection of the Physical Plant, Operational Requirements and Disaster Preparedness. At 10:00 AM LPA began the review of the Emergency Interventions assisted by Milieu Manager Stephanie Rosales. All the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 10:45 AM LPA began the review of the Client Records assisted by Milieu Manager Stephanie Rosales. Five client records were reviewed (C1-C5) . At 12:00 LPA observed licensee did not comply with California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80069(c)(1). The regulation is stated as follows: (c) The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. The licensee did not have the results of a tuberculosis examination for #C1, C3, and C4. As part of the Plan of Correction the licensee will provide tuberculosis results for the clients noted above. At 12:56 PM LPA observed the licensee did not comply with CCR 84069.1(a). The regulation is stated as follows: (a) A child for whom vaccination against the following diseases cannot be verified shall receive the first doses of the appropriate vaccines within 30 calendar days of placement in the facility and shall receive follow-up doses as recommended by the physician who administered the first doses. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

The licensee did not have the immunization record #C2, #C3, and an incomplete immunization record for #C4. As part of the plan of correction the licensee will provide the immunization records to include proof of immunization for the following: Poliomyelitis, Diphtheria., Pertussis,i.e.,whooping cough, Tetanus, Measles. Rubella, i.e., German measles, and Mumps for the clients noted above. At 1:30 PM LPA began the review of the Staff Records assisted by Milieu Manager Stephanie Rosales and Human Resource Compliance Specialist Sima Fotoohi. Five staff records were reviewed (S1-S5). All the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. Due to time constraints, LPA’s will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Milieu Manager Stephanie Rosales

On 11/09/2022, at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced annual continuation visit at Discovery Mood and Anxiety Program Group Home. LPA visited the facility on 11/03/2022 and 11/04/2022 to complete inspection of the physical plant, operational requirements, disaster preparedness, client records and staff records.
