At 11:00 AM LPA conducted five staff interviews (S1,S3,S6,S7,S8). During today’s inspection S2 and S5 were not on site. At 12:10 PM LPA continued with staff file reviews assisted by the by Milieu Manager. All required documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided and no deficiencies were sited. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies were observed during today’s visit an exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were given to Milieu Manager Stephanie Rosales.

On November 03, 2022 at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jessica Peete, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Cheraki Davis, conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Discovery Mood and Anxiety Program Group Home. LPA and LPM were met at the facility by Program Director Sylvia Parron at 9:20 AM. LPA and LPM began a physical plant inspection at 9:45 AM assisted by the Program Director and Milieu Manager Stephanie Rosales. The physical plant inspection included the following checks: A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facilities formal entry, kitchen area, dining room, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, two group rooms, two staff bathrooms, and two staff offices. There are three client wings (Green Wing, Blue Wing and Yellow Wing) All wings, except for the Yellow Wing, have three client bedrooms, one therapy office and one client bathroom. The Yellow wing had three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms and one therapy office. The facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Per Program Director there are no guns or weapons on facility grounds. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in the front closet near the front door. Sharps are in a lock box located in the milieu (common area) and the cooking knives are locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the food menus are posted. LPA observed the following postings: the facility license, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies and Personal Rights form. Age appropriate toys, games and books were observed for client’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, and all exits were free from obstruction. LPA observed the facility pool in the backyard to be inaccessible clients. The fence around the pool has a self-latching gate that swings outward and measured over five feet tall. The pool is clean and well maintained. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order and located throughout the facility. Fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced and located throughout the facility. Medications are centrally stored inside the nurses’ office and locked in a portable medication cart. The washer and dryer are located inside the facility near the Green Wing. All detergents are kept locked in a cabinet and are inaccessible to clients. All bedrooms have individual beds, the facility ensures that there are two client per bedroom, with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There is adequate drawer space for each client’s belongings. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured in each wing and were within 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. At 9:48 AM LPA observed that the licensee did not comply with California Code of Regulations (CCR) 84072(a) Each facility licensed to provide foster care for six or more children shall post a listing of a foster child's rights. The licensee did not have the foster child’s rights posted. At 10:08 AM LPA observed that licensee did not comply with (CCR) 80088(f)(1). (f) Solid waste shall be stored, located, and disposed of in a manner that will not transmit communicable diseases or odors…. (1) All containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes shall have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers; shall be in good repair, shall be leakproof and rodent-proof. LPA observed the trash can in the kitchen and bathrooms did not have lids. The facility has a total of three vehicles, labeled V#1, V#2 and V#3. All are used to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. At 11:07 AM LPA observed that V#2 had a crack in on the passenger side windshield violating CCR 80074(c) Motor vehicles used to transport clients shall be maintained in a safe operating condition. At 11:50 AM LPA began the review Disaster Preparedness with the Program Director and Milieu Manager. All the documentation pertaining to this area of the inspection was provided, and no deficiencies were noted. At 12:15 PM LPA began the review of the Operational Requirements assisted by the Program Director and Milieu Manager. At 1:03 PM LPA observed the licensee was not in compliance with CCR 80020(a). All facilities shall secure and maintain a fire clearance approved by the city or county fire department, the district providing fire protection services, or the State Fire Marshal. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

The licensee could not provide proof of fire clearance for the garage that was converted into a group room. Due to time constraints, LPA's will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Program Director Sylvia Parron. This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 11/03/2022.

On November 30th, 2022, at 9:35 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete met with Discovery Mood and Anxiety Program Group Home Program Administrator Sylvia Parron to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL), Administrator #1 (A1) was employed on 10/03/2022, and Administrator #2 (A2) was employed on 10/09/2019. A2 meets the education and has a Group Home Administrator Certificate but does not meet the experience qualification. The facility is being cited for violation of California Code Regulations 84064(b). Administrator Qualifications and Duties (b) Effective January 1, 2000, all group homes shall have a qualified and currently certified administrator. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights and LIC 811 to Discovery Mood and Anxiety Program Administrator Sylvia Parron.

met_with: Facility Chief Executive Officer (FCEO) John Smith
narrative: Confidential witness statements indicated that facility staff (S1 and S2) were conducting bedroom checks throughout the night every 15 minutes. Confidential witness statements revealed that C1 hid C2 under C1’s blankets as facility staff conducted their routine bedroom checks. Confidential interviews stated that C1 and C2 did not remember the names of the facility staff on shift that night. Confidential witness statements disclosed that the allegation could not have happened on S1 and S2’s night shift. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 and S2 are alert during their shifts. Confidential witness statements indicated that S1 and S2 conducted body and breath checks every 15 minutes and that all clients were asleep. Confidential witness statements indicated that S1 and S2 did not observe clients outside their bedrooms. Confidential witness statements disclosed that C2 would need to walk across the main common area where S1 or S2 were positioned to get to C1’s bedroom on the opposite side of the facility. It is unknown which staff was on shift during the incident. Although confidential interviews stated that S1 and S2 did not observe clients outside their bedrooms, C1 and C2 engaged in consensual inappropriate sexual interactions during the staff night shift. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that the minors (C1 and C2) engaged in inappropriate sexual interactions and staff are not providing adequate supervision is substantiated. The facility is cited for violation of Children’s Residential Group Home Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 6 Continuing Requirements 84065.2 Personnel Duties (b) Child care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times. Confidential witness statements disclosed that C1 and C2 engaged in inappropriate sexual interactions, and staff are not providing adequate supervision, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Facility Chief Executive Officer (FCEO) John Smith.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 84065.2(b)(1): Personnel Duties (b) Child care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) Supervision, protection and care of children individually and in groups at all times. This requirement is not met by: Based on confidential interviews, C1 and C2 engaged in inappropriate sexual interactions, and staff (S1 and S2) are not providing adequate supervision did not provide care and supervision that met the client’s needs and ensured the health, safety, and well-being of C1 and C2, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.

met_with: Facility Chief Executive Officer (FCEO) John Smith
narrative: Confidential witness statements indicated that the facility staff nurse (FN) and facility staff (FS) instructed C1 to remove their clothes from their underwear and put on the hospital gown provided by the facility staff. Confidential witness statements revealed that the FN and FS conducted a “body check” of C1. Confidential witness statements revealed that the body check consisted of C1 undressing down to their underwear and putting on the hospital gown provided. Confidential interviews stated that FN and FS instructed C1 to remove their clothes and underwear and for C1 to put on a hospital gown. Confidential interviews stated that FS and FN never instructed C1 to remove their underwear. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 was not provided with a safe and comfortable environment. Confidential witness statements disclosed that C1 did not feel comfortable and safe during the “body check.” Confidential interviews stated that C1 felt vulnerable and violated during the “body check” procedure. Confidential witness statements indicated that C1 was not treated with dignity and respect. Confidential interviews stated that C1 did not want to complete a “body check.” Confidential witness statements disclosed that C1 needed to complete a “body check” and was part of the admission intake process. Confidential interviews indicated that they were aware of the “body check” procedure as part of the intake process but unaware of the details of clients having to remove all their clothes and put on a gown. Confidential interviews stated that it was not indicated on the intake form that C1 was to undress down to their underwear and that C1 would be provided with a hospital gown to wear as FN and FS checked C1 for bruises, injuries, and marks. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegations that the staff violated the minor's (C1) personal rights, staff did not treat the minor (C1) with dignity and respect, and the staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment are substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is being cited for violation of the California Code Regulations Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 6 Continuing Requirements, section 84072 Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9…Confidential witness statements disclosed that staff violated C1's personal rights and did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for C1, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Facility Chief Executive Officer (FCEO) John Smith.
investigation_findings: 13On April 29, 2024, at 11:48 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced visit and met with Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Facility Chief Executive Officer (FCEO) John Smith to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. narrative:
On June 19, 2024 at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jose Gonzales, Jessica Peete and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis arrived unannounced to Discovery Mood and Anxiety Group Home (GH). At 9:40 AM, assisted by facility staff Diedre Barriger, LPA’s and LPM completed a health and safety inspection of the facility which included the facilities formal entry, kitchen area, dining room, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, two group rooms, two staff bathrooms, and two staff offices. There are three client wings (Green Wing, Blue Wing and Yellow Wing) All wings, except for the Yellow Wing, have three client bedrooms, one therapy office and one client bathroom. The Yellow wing had three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms and one therapy office. The facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order and located throughout the facility. Medications are centrally stored inside the nurses’ office and locked in a portable medication cart. All detergents and other cleaning products are securely locked and inaccessible to clients. All bedrooms have individual beds, the facility ensures that there are two client per bedroom, with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There is adequate drawer space for each client’s belongings. At 10:22 AM LPA’s toured the yellow wing and observed one dead insect in bedroom 3. Per staff statement the facility receives bi-monthly pest control services to manage and prevent insects. At 10:28 AM LPA’s inspected the observation room, located off the milieu. LPA’s observed two dead flies in the windowsill and observed the bedroom wall had paint damage. At 10:32 AM LPA’s toured the Blue wing and observed the bottom left bathroom cabinet needed repair. At 10:37 LPA’s toured the Green wing and observed bedroom had writing on the wall and paint damage. Based on observations the licensee is not incompliance with Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80087(a) (1) deficiencies are being cited; see LIC809 D. ***CONTINUED on LIC 809 C***

An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Vice President of Western Region of Operations (VP) Robert Thomas.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: 80087(a)(1) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. (1) The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects. This requirement is not met by: Based on LPA observations during the health and safety inspection facility did not ensure that facility grounds were in good repair. This poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative:
Confidential interviews indicated that the maintenance workers repaired all broken fixtures, furniture, and tiles. Other confidential interviews indicated that the facility has a housekeeper who cleans the facility's common area, nurses’ station, staff offices, and staff restrooms. Confidential interviews revealed that the housekeeper cleans the clients’ bedrooms, restrooms, and dining areas. Confidential interviews stated that all broken furniture and fixtures are reported to administrative staff to submit a request for maintenance repairs. The Department also received a second allegation that the facility staff does not provide staff/client ratio care and supervision to minors. Confidential interviews indicated that the facility maintained one staff per eight clients ratio. Other confidential interviews indicated that the staff-to-client ratio is one staff per six clients. Confidential interviews stated that the nurse will assist with supervision when staff leave on break. Confidential interviews revealed that administrative staff and nurses are utilized to ensure the facility maintains one staff per six-client ratio. During the inspection, LPAs and LPM observed one staff per four clients at the facility. The Department also received a third allegation that the facility does not have trained staff to meet the minor's medical needs. Confidential interviews indicated that the staff does not know how to check the client’s vitals or properly distribute medication to clients. Confidential interviews indicated that the facility nurse manager (NM) trains particular staff to check the client’s vitals and dispense medication. Confidential interviews stated that NM would monitor the staff to check the client’s vitals and dispense medications to ensure the staff followed the procedure. Confidential interviews indicated that there is a nurse on duty every shift: morning, afternoon, and overnight. Confidential interviews stated that not all the clients need their vitals checked before and after medication passing. The Department also received a fourth allegation that the facility staff does not ensure minors are provided adequate food service. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff do not have a food handlers’ card. In addition, confidential interviews also stated that leftover meals are left on the counter for hours. During the inspection, LPA observed the food handler cards in the staff facility file and did not observe food being left on the kitchen counters. Confidential interviews stated that the facility has a lead chef (LC) and a weekend chef (WC). Confidential interviews indicated that LC prepares and cooks lunch and dinner during the week. Confidential interviews stated WC prepares and cooks lunch and dinner on the weekends. ******CONTINUED on LIC 9099C******

Confidential interviews indicated that meal leftovers are stored in plastic Ziplock bags and containers after the food has cooled down, labeled with the date the meals were cooked, and stored inside the refrigerator by LC and WC. Confidential interviews indicated that the leftover meal is discarded three days after the date the meals were cooked. Confidential interviews stated the facility staff served the clients prepackaged food for breakfast, such as cereal, bagels, milk, and juice. Confidential interviews indicated the facility staff cooks and prepares the meals. The Department also received a fifth allegation that the facility staff does not ensure the facility is free of insects. Confidential interviews revealed that they had observed flies and roaches inside the facility. Confidential interviews indicated that they had not seen an infestation of insects inside the facility. However, other confidential interviews stated that they have occasionally observed a fly and spider inside the facility. Confidential interviews stated that pest control sprays the inside and outside of the facility every three months. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and facility record review, the facility staff does not ensure the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, the facility staff does not provide staff/client ratio care and supervision to minors, the facility does not have trained staff to meet minor's medical needs, the facility staff does not ensure minors are provided adequate food service, the facility staff does not ensure minors are provided sufficient food service, and the facility staff does not ensure facility is free of insects are unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside and met with Program Director (PD) Olevia Labeeb.
investigation_findings: 13On September 17, 2024, at 11:07 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced visit and met with Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Program Director (PD) Olevia Labeeb to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA inspected Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Group Home at 9:00 am on June 19, 2024; no health and safety hazards were observed. LPA reviewed six client’s records (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6). During the investigation, interviews were conducted with six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6), the Lead Chef (LC), the Nurse Manager (NM), the Mental Health Technician (MT), the Education Liaison (EL), and the Interim Program Administrator/ Milieu Manager (MM). The Department received a complaint on June 11, 2024, that the facility staff does not ensure the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients. Confidential interviews indicated they observed mold in the bathrooms, and some floor tiles were lifting. *****CONTINUED on LIC 9099C****

narrative:
Confidential interviews indicated that the administrator informed S1 not to be alone with C1 to prevent an allegation. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was not inappropriately touched at the facility and that the alleged incident occurred at C1’s previous placement. Confidential interviews stated that it was never witnessed that S1 or any other staff member attempted to touch C1 or any other clients residing at the facility. The Department also received a second allegation that the staff spoke inappropriately to the minor (C1). Confidential interviews indicated that facility staff did not speak to the clients inappropriately and spoke to them with respect. Confidential interviews stated that C2, C3, and C4 never heard staff speaking inappropriately to C1. The Department also received a third allegation that a staff allowed a minor (C1) to leave the facility. Confidential interviews indicated that the facility staff would encourage C1 to leave the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that a C1 was unhappy at the facility and wanted to be transferred to a different program. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was directed to call their parents and inform them of C1’s disappointment with the facility. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 walked out of the facility. Confidential interviews disclosed that the program director (PD) and milieu coordinator (MC) followed C1. Other confidential interviews indicated that the program director allowed C1 to leave the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that PD and MC encouraged C1 to make a better choice and return back to the facility. The Department also received a fourth allegation that the staff did not properly report incidents involving minor (C1) to an authorized representative. Confidential interviews stated that the facility staff did not properly report incidents to C1’s authorized representative. Confidential interviews revealed that the administrative staff, management, and therapist report all incidents to C1’s authorized representative. Confidential interviews stated that the administrative staff, management, and therapist instruct the facility staff to report an incident to the client's parents if they are off-site or after hours. In addition, confidential interviews also stated that the milieu coordinator (MC) reports all incidents to the client's authorized representative after hours. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and facility record review, the allegations that staff (S1) inappropriately touched the minor (C1), staff spoke inappropriately to the minor (C1), staff allowed minor (C1) to leave the facility, and staff did not properly report incidents involving the minor (C1) to an authorized representative are unsubstantiated.****CONTINUED on LIC 9099C****

The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside and met with Milieu Manager (MM) Marcus Gitchuway.
investigation_findings: 13On October 18, 2024, at 11:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced visit and met with Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Milieu Manager (MM) Marcus Gitchuway to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA Jessica Peete inspected Discovery Mood & Anxiety Program Riverside Group Home at 10:55 am on May 14, 2024; no health and safety hazards were observed. LPA reviewed four client’s records (C1, C2, C3, and C4). During the investigation, interviews were conducted with three clients (C1, C2, and C3), the Educational Liaison (EL), the Milieu Coordinator (MC), and the Interim Program Administrator/ Milieu Manager (MM). Due to C1’s continual behavioral issues, it was determined that in C1’s best interest, an interview with C1 would not be conducted during the investigation. On May 10, 2024, the Department received an allegation that the staff (S1) inappropriately touched a minor (C1). Confidential interviews indicated that staff (S1) never touched C1 inappropriately. *****CONTINUED on LIC 9099 C*****

narrative:
On December 30, 2020 at 3:00 p.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cameo Banks conducted a virtual telephone visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Annual/Required Inspection. LPA met with Licensee, Leah Hawkins, via video conference and a tour was conducted both inside and out. The facility is licensed as a Group Home with a capacity of five children ages 9-13 years, ambulatory only. The census today is one. The home is set up as follows: This home is located in a residential neighborhood. The home has with three (3) bedrooms, one (1) bathroom, living room, dining area, kitchen, front/ backyard detached back house that remains locked. Living Room: There is one sectional sofa which appears to be in new condition. Fireplace in living room has screen cover. Dining Area: One table with four (4) chairs. Kitchen: There is a new stove/oven with four (4) gas burners. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The was at least a two day supply of perishable food supplies. There is a fire extinguisher located in the kitchen. The knives, cleaning supplies and medications will be locked in the closet that is located to the right once entering the family room and made accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All cleaning supplies, knives and medications are locked and will be stored in locked cabinet. Trash can has a tight lid Bedroom #1: This room is equipped with one twin size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Report continued on LIC 809C

Bedroom #2: The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #3 The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. This room has a backdoor entrance/exit that is locked. Bathroom: Toilet, sink and tub/showers are in safe, clean, and operating condition in all bathrooms. Backyard: Backyard is clean and free of debris. There is also a locked shed for storage. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons inaccessible to clients. Children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Facility has non-perishable foods for two days. Facility provides nutritious between meal snacks. Medications locked/accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Facility personnel instructed to report violations of personal rights. Facility posts child’s rights if licensed to provide foster care for six or more children. Children not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Children accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. Facility records client cash resources, personal property and valuables. Children’s records were not reviewed during this inspection due to inspection being conducted virtually. Facility staff acknowledge abuse reporting requirements. Adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances. Facility staff recirds were not reviewed during this inspection. Facility reports changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Facility reports client injuries requiring medical treatment. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Current and available for review.Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Designation/staff assignments current. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations

On 11/17/2021 Licensing Program Analyst, Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the said facility to conduct an annual inspection. LPA Karnsrithong met with Administrator, Leah Hawkins and Direct Care Staff, Shantal Manabat, who provided a tour of the facility. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to five (5) children, ages 13-17 years old, ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. This home is located in a residential neighborhood. The home has with three (3) bedrooms, one (1) bathroom, living room, dining area, kitchen, two (2) detached units in the backyard. LPA Karnsrithong conducted one (1) client and two (2) staff interviews. LPA Karnsrithong reviewed three (3) client and three (3) staff files. LPA Karnsrithong has observed the following during the time of inspection: Living Room/Common Area: There is broom closet next to the door which has the broom, vacuum, and mops for the facility. There is a locked cabinet which stores cleaning supplies and knives. There is a fireplace in the living room but is covered and non-operable. There is a sectional sofa, ottoman, television and two (2) small tables in the living room. The reward chart, children’s personal rights, and facility sketch plan and emergency disaster plan are also posted in the living room area. Dining Area: One table with two (2) chairs and a one (1) bench. This is currently being used as the COVID-19 sign in area and not being used during meal time. Clients are eating in the common room or in their respective bedrooms. Laundry Area: This area is next to the kitchen. There is a operable washer and dryer. There is a shelf and counter top as well. Emergency Supply bins are stored in the laundry area. (Page 1 of 3)

Kitchen: There is a stove/oven with four (4) gas burners. There is a microwave, refrigerator, toaster, blender and Instapot. There is enough supply of perishable and non-perishable food supplies. There are cups, plates, utensils, pots, and pans accessible to use. There is a dish drying rack as well to use. Sample menus for breakfast, lunch, snack, and dinner are posted in the refrigerator. Kitchen cleaning schedule is also posted in the kitchen area. Office Area: This area is located next to the kitchen. It has two (2) desks, two (2) chairs, a filing cabinet, computer, printer, facility documentation and records for the (Medication Records, Consumer Notes, Clients Records, Staff Records). Labor law and licensing postings, client and staff schedules are also in the office area. First Aid kit is also located in the office area. Bedroom #A: This room is equipped with one twin size bed. The room has a closet, drawers, laundry basket, and television. There is currently one (1) client staying in this room. There is adequate lighting in this room as well. Bedroom #B: The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. There is a television in this room. There is only one (1) client staying in this room. Bedroom #C: The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are two (2) closets. There is adequate lightning, an entertainment table, television, and video game console. This room has a door that leads to the side of the house but is kept locked at all times. There are currently two (2) clients staying in this room. Bathroom: There is one (1) bathroom in the facility. It has a toilet, sink, bathtub, and shower. There is also closet space for toiletries. Backyard: The backyard is fenced in and is clean and free of any debris. There are two detached units in the backyard that is locked and not being used by the facility. (Page 2 of 3)

Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Clients medications are locked and stored. Medication log is updated regularly client’s photo is also posted on the binder for easier identification. Clients records are stored in binders and can be accessed for audit or inspection. Staff document client reports on separate individual binders. The electric, water and gas utility shut off valves are located outside the home. Hallways and pathways inside and outside the facility are unobstructed and free of debris. There is a fire and carbon monoxide alarm in the hallway. There is a controlled thermostat to maintain safe and appropriate temperature throughout the facility. The facility provides extra-curricular activities to clients such as yoga, visiting the park, and shopping at the store. Clients are provided with clothing allowance and staff take them to the store to purchase supplies as needed. Each bedroom has a nightly check log for each client to be monitored and conducted by staff. The facility also has a certified Behavior Intervention Analyst that provides services of a minimum of 16 hours a month per client. (Page 3 of 3)

Evidence obtained revealed that RP & Staff denied that Staff hit youth in care. Also, confidential interviews with Child 1 stated Staff did not hit him and he felt safe. Child 2 denied that Staff hit child in care. Child 3 was not able to answer questions due to to disability. Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence obtained the information did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. Due to inconsistent statements LPA Phillips was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be Unsubstantiated meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged incidents occurred. No deficiencies cited at the time of this investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and copy of this report was left with facility administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On October 27, 2021 at 3:30PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Zena Phillips conducted a follow-up complaint investigation visit to Dream Home Residential and met with Leah Hawkins, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations: Facility staff hit youth. Facility staff handled youth in a rough manner. LPA Phillips conducted confidential interviews with related parties, reviewed facility records and Incident Reports. Based on the interviews conducted and statements obtained during the investigation the above allegations cannot be substantiated because LPA Phillips obtained inconsistent statements from RP, staff and residents in care.

13On March 18, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility to conduct a follow-up complaint inspection. LPA met with Leah Hawkins, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation of the allegation that minor was hit by another minor while in care, LPA Karnsrithong conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. Confidential interviews indicated that although an incident occurred between clients while in care resulting to minor injuries, staff provided appropriate emergency intervention and first aid. The facility provides one-on-one direct care staff that supervises clients who have special needs while they are in the facility to support when such incidents occur. Authorized parties were notified in a timely manner regarding the incident and appropriate behavior intervention plans were administered at the time of the incident. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with administrator and copy of the report will be provided.

narrative:
On 12/19/2022, Licensing Program Analyst, C. White arrived made an unannounced visit to Dream Home Residential for the purpose of conducting a Required Inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager, Tammy Eldridge who granted access to the facility. LPA met with Administrator, Leah Hawkins and together toured the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to five (5) children, ages 13-17 years old, ambulatory only. The current census is four (4). There are no bodies of water on the premises. This is a three (3) bedroom, one (1) bathroom single story home located in a residential area and is set up as follows: living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, office area, and a backyard which includes two (2) detached units. Living room: is furnished with a sectional sofa, a chair, a mounted TV, and two (2) tables. The area has a covered non-operable fireplace, a locked cabinet, and a locked broom closet. Dining room: Currently this area is not furnished as it is used to COVID check in. Client’s eat in the living room or their respective bedrooms. Kitchen: is equipped with refrigerator/freezer, microwave, air fryer, and a four (4) burner gas stove/oven. All burners were tested and found to be working at the time of this inspection. The facility was found to have the required amount of perishable and non-perishable food supplies. LPA observed the facility to have ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. Laundry area: is located inside the kitchen. The area contains a washer and dryer, shelf, and a locked cabinet. The area also stores the facility’s emergency supplies bins. There is an exit door off the laundry area which leads to the backyard. Report continued on LIC 809C (page 1 of 3)

Office area: is set up in the breakfast nook of the kitchen. The area is equipped with two (2) desks, three (3) chairs, a locked filing cabinet, a built-in cabinet with a security latch lock, computer, and a printer. Client records, Staff records, Facility logs, Medication logs, Consumer Notes, and First Aid Kit are stored in this area. Medication requiring no refrigeration is stored in the locked file cabinet in this area. The facility does not contain any medication which required refrigeration. Backyard: The backyard is fenced in and is clean and free of any debris. There are two detached units in the backyard that is locked and not being used by the facility. Bedroom #1: is equipped with one (1) twin size bed. The room has a closet, drawers, a working light, and a window. The room is occupied by one (1) client. Bedroom #2: is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. The room has a closet, drawers, a working light and a window. The room is occupied by two (2) clients. Bedroom #3: is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. The room has closets, drawers, a working light, a window, and a door leading to the side of the house; this door is kept locked at all times. The room is occupied by one (1) client. Bathroom: There is one (1) bathroom in the facility. It has a toilet, sink, bathtub, and shower. There is also closet space for toiletries. Clients medications are locked and stored. Medication log is updated regularly. Clients records are stored in binders and can be accessed for audit or inspection. Staff document client reports on separate individual binders. The electric, water and gas utility shut off valves are located outside the home. Hallways and pathways inside and outside the facility are unobstructed and free of debris. Smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector was tested and found to be in working order. The facility has a regulation fire extinguisher located in the kitchen. Hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The facility temperature is controlled by a thermostat and the temperature is maintained between 68-85 degrees (F). Report continued on LIC 809C (page 2 of 3)

Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are stored in a locked in living room cabinet and made inaccessible to clients. The facility does not maintain any sharps on the premises. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Personal Rights, menus, and activities were posted in the facility. (page 3 of 3)

On 01/25/2023, Licensing Program Analyst, C. White made an unannounced visit to Dream Home Residential for the purpose of discussing overdue fees. LPA met with Administrator, Leah Hawkins, who granted access to the facility. When LPA arrived the facility was being inspected by two (2) Regional Center Representatives. LPA discussed the overdue annual fess to the Administrator. The Administrator reported that the fees will be paid by Friday, 01/27/2023. PER California Code Regulations, TITLE 22, the facility is within regulation standards at this time. A copy of this report was left with Facility Administrator.

Backyard: The backyard is fenced in and is clean and free of any debris. There are two detached units in the backyard which are not used by the facility. Bedroom #1: is equipped with one (1) twin size bed. The room is occupied by one (1) client. Bedroom #2: is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. The room is occupied by two (2) clients. Bedroom #3: is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. The room has a door leading to the side of the house which is kept locked at all times. The room is occupied by one (1) client. All bedrooms have a closet, drawers, a working light, and windows. Bathroom: is equipped with a toilet, sink, bathtub/shower combination and a closet. LPA observed client records, staff records, facility logs, medication logs, and First Aid Kit are stored in the office area. Medication requiring no refrigeration is stored in a locked file cabinet. The water shut off valve is located outside of the home near street curb. The gas shut off valve is located outside in the back of the home. The electricity shut off valve is located inside the home in the laundry area. The facility does not maintain any sharps on the premises. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions. and detergents are kept locked in the living room storage cabinet and made inaccessible to clients. Smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector was tested and found to be in working order. The facility has a regulation fire extinguisher located in the kitchen. Hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees (F). The facility temperature is controlled by a thermostat and the temperature is maintained between 68-85 degrees (F). Overall LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA discussed and advised the Licensee to ensure the following: Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Personal Rights, menus, and activities were posted in the facility. PER California Code Regulations, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 5 no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On April 27, 2023 at 11:49 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegations. LPA met with Facility Manager, Tammy Eldridge and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Staff denied the allegations. Staff stated clients bathe each morning prior to getting dressed for school. Staff stated Client #1 attended school in short pants once and that the client is sent to school in uniform pants regularly. Staff stated appropriate clothing is provided for the clients in care. Staff stated Client #1 has a history of self injurious behavior and that the client’s mother is aware of this. Staff stated clients in care are not neglected or abused by any staff. Client interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. LPA was unable to obtain a statement from Client #1 as the client is non-verbal. Based on information obtained, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No deficiencies cited. Exit interview completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On 10/31/2024 Licensing Program Analyst, Justine Armstrong and Regional Manager arrived at Dream Home Residential facility to continue the annual inspection. LPA Armstrong met with Facility Director Leah Hawkins who granted access and tour of the facility. LPA Armstrong reviewed 3 client files and two staff files. Living Room/Common Area: Upon entering the facility, there is common area that is used by clients for relaxation and meetings. The living room has couches, television and rug. There is utility closet next to the door which has the broom, vacuum, and mops for the facility. There is a locked cabinet next to it which stores cleaning supplies. There is a fireplace in the living room but is covered and non-operable. There is another locked cabinet close to the fireplace which stores extra hygiene products, diapers, and bed pads. The grievance chart, children’s personal rights, and facility sketch plan are also posted in the living room. Backyard: The backyard is fenced in and is clean and free of any debris. There are two detached units in the backyard that is locked and not being used by the facility. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Client’s medications are locked and stored. Medication log is updated regularly client’s photo is also posted on the binder for identification. Clients’ records are stored in binders and can be accessed for audit or inspection. Staff document client reports on separate individual binders. The electric, water and gas utility shut off valves are located outside the home. Staff are aware of the location of utility shut off valves. Hallways and pathways inside and outside the facility free of debris. There is a controlled thermostat to maintain safe and appropriate temperature throughout the facility. The facility provides extra-curricular activities to clients such as trying new food restaurants, visiting the park, and shopping at store. Clients are provided with clothing allowance and staff take them to the store to purchase supplies as needed. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

narrative:
On 10/30/2024 Licensing Program Analyst, Justine Armstrong and Regional Manager Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at Dream Home Residential facility to conduct an annual inspection. LPA Armstrong met with Facility Manager, Tammy Eldridge and Direct Care Staff, Gregory Lilly, who granted access and tour of the facility. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision up to five (5) children, ages 13-17 years old, ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. This home is located in a residential neighborhood in Los Angeles, California. The home has three (3) bedrooms, one (1) bathroom, living room, dining area, kitchen. LPA Armstrong conducted 2 client and two staff interviews. LPA Armstrong has observed the following during the time of inspection: Dining Area: One table with two (2) chairs. Clients are eating in the common room or in their respective bedrooms. Laundry Area: This area is next to the kitchen. There is an operable washer and dryer. There is a shelf and countertop as well. Kitchen: There is a stove/oven with four (4) gas burners. There is a microwave, refrigerator, toaster, blender and Air Fryer. There is enough supply of perishable and non-perishable food supplies. There are cups, plates, utensils, pots, and pans accessible to use. There is a dish drying rack as well to use. Sample menus for breakfast, lunch, snack, and dinner are posted in the refrigerator. Kitchen cleaning schedule is also posted in the kitchen area. (PAGE 1 OF 2)

Office Area: This area is located next to the kitchen. It has two (1) desk, two (2) chairs, a filing cabinet, computer, printer, facility documentation and records for the facility (Medication Records, Consumer Notes, Clients Records). Labor Law and licensing postings, client and staff schedules are also in the office area. First Aid kit is located in the office area. This area is being used by staff only. Bedroom #A: This room is equipped with one twin size bed. The room has a closet, drawers, laundry basket, and television. There is currently one (1) client staying in this room. There is adequate lighting in this room as well. Bedroom #B: The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. There is a television in this room. There is only one (1) client staying in this room. Bedroom #C: The room is equipped with one twin size bed. There are two (2) closets. There is adequate lightning. This room has a door that leads to the side of the house but is kept locked at all times. There are currently two (1) client staying in this room. Bathroom: There is one (1) bathroom in the facility. It has a toilet, sink, bathtub, and shower. There is also closet space for toiletries. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility. (PG 2 of 2)

investigation_findings: 13On 11/22/2024, at 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kim Dear and Licensing Program Manager, (LPM), Enrique Hernandez, arrived at the facility to deliver findings for complaint investigation 34-CR-20240808123404. LPA met with Licensee, Leah Hawkins. and a health and safety assessment was conducted. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidence. Statements that were inconsistent and did not produce corroborating evidence to support staff physically abused minor in care. narrative:
On June 27, 2025 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong, License Program Anaylst (LPA) Aimee Moratalla and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Enrique Hernandez conducted an Informal Meeting with the Licensee Leah Hawkins from Dream Home Residential. The meeting was conducted at El Segundo Local Unit Children Residential Regional Office located at 300 Continental Blvd El Segundo, CA 90245. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the facility concerns. El Segundo Children Residential has concerns on the following things: Complaint allegations 7 within 10 months License responsibilities and required presence Supervision and Training Mandated Reporting Responsibilities Document incident with Staff Protection of Child Personal Rights Facility Manager Concerns Staff Policy and Procedure (LIC Continued on 809C)

Recommendations: The department recommends that the Licensee document instances when staff do not adhere to policies and procedures. It is important to update staff policies and procedures regularly. Additionally, staff should receive further training on supervision techniques, personal rights, and crisis management. Continuing to ensure the safety and well-being of all minors in the facility is essential. The Facility Manager or Licensee should arrive at the facility during unannounced visits from Community Care Licensing. The Licensee must comply with Title 22 regulations and Community Care Licensing (CCL) requirements. A copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

The investigation further included review of client file, incident reports and review of facility file history as well as, review of medical forensic exam report, and Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) investigative report. In addition, confidential interviews were conducted with two youth, two staff members, Administrator, and contacts with, assigned Quality Assurance Specialist-South Central Los Angeles Regional Center, LAPD, and Department of Children and Family Services (DCFS) assigned Emergency Response Social Worker. Record review revealed C1 resided at Dream Home Residential from December 2024 through 2/25/2025. The investigation uncovered several inconsistencies with the allegations. Documentary evidence from medical records and confidential interviews revealed inconsistencies as interviews found conflicting answers to questions asked by medical staff concerning specific accounts and dates of alleged sexual abuse. Confidential interviews by Investigator Santana also revealed inconsistencies. Statements obtained denied seeing any form of abuse or any opportunities for staff to engage in abuse. Confidential statement further revealed recantation of abuse to assigned social worker on 3/03/2025 but reaffirmed alleged abuse to others since leaving placement. Records reviewed found no indication of any trauma during C1's forensic examination. Confidential interviews with staffs and resident further denied the allegation, denied witnessing or other residents being subjected to sexual abuse. Information obtained found that C1 maintains that S1 threatened C1 with a gun to instill fear to sodomize C1. Interviews found that staff members denied there are firearms on the property, and witnesses also denied observing S1 handling a firearm at the facility. Information from interviews found that C1 maintains that S1 gave C1 marijuana on several occasions. Facility staff members reported that C1 sometimes asked for marijuana, but witness statements maintain denial of giving C1 any marijuana or that C1 smoked at the facility. Statements determined denial and no witness observations of S1 smoking at the facility. Based on gathered information, the allegations that S1 sexually abused C1; S1 threatened C1 with a gun and S1 provided marijuana to C1 is therefore determined unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, at this time. A copy of this report is provided to Administrator by email.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/25/2025 at 10:20 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at Dream Home Residential, met with Facility Representative and further spoke with Facility Administrator, Lea Hawkins, via telephone to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegations. On 2/25/2025, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging conduct inimical and sexual abuse by a Staff member towards Youth (C1) as staff reportedly sexually abused C1, threatened C1 with a gun, and provided marijuana to C1. The allegations were referred to CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Jose Santana. On 03/03/2025, LPA Regina Martin conducted the initial complaint inspection to inform licensee receipt of the allegation and subsequent investigation. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)

facility_name: EDGEWOOD CENTER FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
narrative:
On December 22, 2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA met and toured the facility with America Grajeda and Augustine Arballo Jr. This facility is transitioning from a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program to a Group Home. There are several buildings on the property. The Stow Cottage is utilized as the residential cottage, with a capacity of 12. The Stow Cottage consists of 6 client bedrooms and several client bathrooms, living and dining areas, kitchen, laundry, recreation room and many other rooms for client use. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed and all doors open freely. There is no pool on the facility premises. Fire arms are not allowed on the facility premises. At the time of visit, the following was observed: Fire extinguishers are throughout the house. Smoke detectors are throughout the house and operational. Carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway. Each bedroom has a bed, clean linens, and adequate drawer/cabinet space. Facility has a fire clearance. First aid kit was observed. Hot water temperature measured at 118 degrees Fahrenheit.

Staff records are kept in the Administration building, on the property. Client files are locked in the chart room, in Dimond Cottage. Medications are centrally stored and locked. Disinfectants and other toxic materials are locked. Hygiene products are locked in the hallway closet. Extra bedding and towels are in the hallway closet. Knives and sharps are kept locked in the kitchen. This facility has been approved for licensure as a Group Home with a capacity of 12, as of today, December 22, 2022. LPA Pavia will email a copy of your license.

facility_name: EDGEWOOD CENTER FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
narrative: On 3/22/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Administrator Alyssa Kianidehkian and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. LPA conducted a tour of two cottages, the main residential cottage, Stow, and a secondary cottage, Halleck. Administrator informed LPA yesterday that a tree fell on Stow that afternoon and the residents were moved to Halleck. No residents were in Stow when the tree fell, and the licensee is working on making repairs to the roof. Both cottages were clean, and food and the residents' belongings have been brought over to Halleck. Kitchen and bathrooms were sanitary, and activity space was organized and free of obstructions. LPA conducted interviews with 3 residents and 3 staff and reviewed 5 resident files and 5 personnel files. Files were observed to be complete, and no concerns were identified in interviews. The following deficiency was found: Hot water in the resident bathrooms measured above the permitted range (above 120 F). LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80088(e)(2). See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Alyssa Kianidehkian, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Staff #1 is office located inside the facility next to bedroom #3. All fire extinguishers were fully charged. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box inside a locked kitchen cabinet. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. Children in care will be supported, encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care will be able to contact the licensing agency. Children will not be restricted in telephone use except by program choice. All posting requirements were met. The home will operate within capacity and limitations of license. there is camera waiver on file but is under review A REVIEW OF THE FACILITY'S PERSONNEL SUMMARY ON 11/10/2020 REVEALS THAT STAFF HAVE DOJ/FBI CRIMINAL RECORD CLEARANCES AND A CHILD ABUSE BACKGROUND CLEARANCE. (See LIC809-D) Due to time constraints, LPA shall return to complete the Annual Required Inspection. Exit interview was conducted and Plans of Corrections were reviewed and developed with the Facility Manager. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and left with the Lead Staff CeCi Perez due to that the Facility Manager had to leave the facility. Page 3 of 3

Minors are not allowed hygiene items Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements regarding whether clients are not allowed hygiene items. Interview information revealed that clients are given hygiene boxes that contain toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, lotion, and other products which are available when the clients request them. Confidential interviews stated that clients are provided razors to shave but under the supervision of staff. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff can withhold hygiene items from clients and provide them upon the request of the client depending on the client’s level. Staff open minors’ personal mail Confidential interviews indicated that the therapist keep all mail, unopened until the clients’ next one-on-one therapy sessions. It was also disclosed that clients are required to open their letters in front of staff to make sure there is no contraband and confirmed that staff do not open clients’ mails. Other confidential witnesses were unaware of the mail process and could not speak to this allegation. Some confidential witnesses stated that the clients open their personal mail in front of staff, and others stated the clients’ primary therapists open their mail for them to screen letters and packages for contraband or triggering content. Minors not receiving an allowance Confidential interviews revealed that none of the minors received allowance during their residency at this Group Home. Per Facility Representative(s), the purpose of not providing clients allowance was to reduce the ability of incoming contraband. Facility Representative(s) also indicated that clients did not have a need for allowance as the Program provide the necessities for clients. Confidential interviews revealed that although allowance is not given, the facility provide for clients’ needs which includes items while on outings. Minors are denied access to personal property Confidential interviews revealed that clients are denied personal property based on scheduled activities and for their safety. Some personal items are stored locked in a cabinet and made available to clients upon request. Per Facility Representative(s) some items such as razors require direct supervision, while other personal items (such as books, clothing and etc.) are not allowed to be possessed by clients because the item could trigger client’s behaviors or jeopardize their safety while in treatment Continue on LIC9099-C

Based on the confidential interviews, observation, and record review, it has been determined that although the allegations that minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors’ personal mail, minors not receiving an allowance, and minors being denied access to personal belongings may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. The program statement has been updated to ensure that the clients’ needs will be met based on their individual assessments per Title 22 Group Home Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility manager.
investigation_findings: 13On November 29, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation. LPA Hernandez met with Danielle Castro and discussed the investigative findings. On June 7, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging minors are not treated with dignity; minors are not allowed hygiene items; staff open minors' personal mail; minors are not receiving an allowance; minors are being denied access to personal property. Confidential interviews were conducted with 6 staff and 2 of 2 clients. Facility’s Program Statement, Plan of Operation, Parent Handbook and Training Manual were reviewed. The following information was obtained during the course of the investigation: Minors are not treated with dignity Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. Some confidential interviews reported that the clients did not have to leave the door open while using the restroom and other interviews stated that clients must leave the bathroom door ajar while using the restroom. It was noted in the facility’s program statement that staff are to ensure that the clients keep the bathroom door ajar when using the restroom. Continue on LIC9099-C

There is a vehicle available to transport consumers/clients 2023 Honda Odyssey and the current auto insurance is with ACE American Insurance Company. Vehicle is in very good condition. Therapy Rooms: One of the three therapy rooms is located next to the kitchen. The second therapy room is located outside in a converted shed. Group room#2 (Former therapy room)is located out in the backyard across from the nurse's office, and is unused. Bathrooms: The facility has a total of four and a half bathrooms. School Room: Is located to the right once entering the facility. There is ample seating space with chairs, desks, computers, and a covered fire place. Dining Room: Is located next to the School Room. There is one table with nine (9) chairs. Group Room #1: Is located next to the kitchen. There are ample seating space and a covered fire place. There is also a door that exits out into the yard. Kitchen: There is a stove with (6) burners.. There is a detached oven currently working at this time. There is a microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The food service in the home is adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. The cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the clients and stored/locked under the kitchen sink and in hallway closet. All trash cans have a tight lid on. There is also a gathering area located to the side of the kitchen. There is a first aid kit in the pantry. Medication Closet: Is located next to the Laundry Room. Page 3 Outdoors: The entrance and backyard are all free of debris and hazardous materials. There is a barbecue area with operating burners. LPA Wilson. also observed two outdoor seating areas available with enough seating for 14 for persons to use. There is also a swimming pool on the premises with a five foot fence with a self-latching lock. Overall, the home appears to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. LPA Wilson. observed non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. The home has a first aid kit stored inside a cabinet in the laundry room. The facility has a total of seven (7) fire extinguishers, six (6) smoke alarms and six (6) carbon monoxide detectors, all in working condition. All fire extinguishers were fully charged. There is also an AED Defibrillator in the home and emergency lights. There is no available additional power source for emergencies. Disinfectants and poisons are inaccessible to the clients in care they are kept locked at all times. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box inside a locked kitchen cabinet. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. The following was discussed with the facility Compliance Officer: Program holds accreditation by the Joint Commision as of 11/19/2022, and valid for thirty six (36) months. LPA Wilson was able to complete (2) staff and (2) client interviews (FN, RC, C1 and C3) LPA Wilson was not able to complete staff file, and client file review and will need to return to facility to complete the staff and client file reviews. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with FN. A copy of this report needed to be emailed on 11/21/2023, to (FN and CO) due to technical difficulties. Signature will be on file.

narrative:
On December 11, 2020 @ 1:10PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Tele-Inspection Annual for the facility listed above. A Tele-Inspection was conducted due to Covid 19 conditions and restrictions. LPA Landry met with Administrator, Clinical Program Director & Interim Manager. Facility was toured inside and out. There were 3 clients currently enrolled in this program and residing in this Group Home. Facility is a treatment facility and accepts private placement's. Facility is two story, 4 bedrooms upstairs, 3 inside attached offices and 2 detached offices on premises. There are a total of 4 bathrooms (2 upstairs and 2 downstairs). Offices are locked when not in use by staff. LPA Landry reviewed all clients records and requested four staff records be sent via email for review. Facility maintains: 1. Working smoking detectors. 2. Required size/type fire extinguisher. 3. Working telephone. 4. Sufficient food supply both two day perishable and seven days non-perishable. 5. Sufficient utensils, pots, pans, plates, bowls & etc. 6. Sufficient closet & drawer space. 7. Sufficient living space both indoor & outdoor. 8. Locked boxes for medications. 9. Sufficient towels & linen supply. 10. Required first aid kit was complete. Medications, toxins, sharp objects, cleaning supplies and all other hazardous items are inaccessible. Medication logs were observed. Facility maintains electronic records for staff and clients. ------>

Personal Rights & Food Menus, Emergency Plan, Facility Sketch and License were posted. LPA Landry requested an updated Personnel Roster/Time Schedule. All exits are free of hazards and all doors open freely. Covid 19 entrance and exit rules were discussed. There is an in ground swimming pool on premises which has wrought iron fencing and a self latching gate at the top of the gate. Facility has Living-room area, dining-room and kitchen areas. There are also two detached office areas on the premises. Unfortunately due to an on site emergency and time constraints tour was shortened. However, the overall, the home was toured and LPA was able to observe the home was clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. LPA Landry did observe all Covid 19 postings. There are no deficiencies observed and cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to facility Administrator..
