narrative: On May 30, 2023 at 9:55 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson arrived at the above mentioned facility for a case management visit, regarding an incident report received by CCL. S1 provided LPA Will with entry into the facility. A copy of client list and LIC 500 was emailed to LPA. LPA Wilson spoke with staff (S2) regarding the incident report dated 05/18/2023 involving foster youth (C1). LPA also spoke with (S3, S4) by phone, separately (See LIC811 for list of names dated 05/30/2023). LPA interviewed (S3, S4),and clients (C1, C2, C3) who stated the the client was transported to the hospital for drug use on 05/18/2023 and staff immediately came to the aid of (C1). Staff S3, S4) agreed the client's actions to bring drugs into the facility was a safety concern, and provided copies of the shift notes from 05/17/2023 through 05/19/2023 via email. At 10:37am (S2) provided LPA with a walk-through tour of facility. Facility is a two-story residence, with (4) bedrooms and (2) bathrooms for clients, offices, kitchen, dining, community room, laundry, medication station, therapy rooms, outdoor area with seating and an art room. Facility has a small stream, gated pool and a deck. Based on records review and interviews conducted, the licensee did ensure the care and supervision of the client. The client (C1) possessed illegal and or harmful substances, that were obtained outside of the facility. Staff had probable cause for a search; as the client was being placed at the facility on 05/17/2023 from another facility Muirwood, located in San Francisco. Upon placement, staff conducted a body check, however, the client (C1) hid the substance inside his clothing, upon entering the home. Client interviews reveal that staff did check on client the night before the incident and before client fell asleep. Client (C1) took the substance in the morning with no witnesses. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On December 22, 2023, at 9:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an announced visit to EGI Treatment Agoura Group Home, for the purpose of concluding an Annual inspection. LPA Wilson met with Operations Manager (OM) who granted access to the facility. Individuals mentioned in this report are identified on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 12/22/2023. This facility has a Group Home license to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 12-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is a pool or bodies of water on the premises, which meet the regulatory reference. The facility has current Accreditation with CARF International. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA met with Staff (S1), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has a Group Home license to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 12-17 years old, Ambulatory only. There is a pool or bodies of water on the premises, which meet the regulatory reference. The facility has current Accreditation with CARF International. This is a one (1) story Group Home, Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood at 6425 Chesebro Drive Agoura Hills, CA. 91301.. This is a three (3) three-bedroom, two (2) bathrooms, one (1) staff office in two story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, backyard, and an attached garage used for storage and exercise.There are two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. LPA Wilson inspected the following: Entry Hallway - has a smoke alarm in working condition Clinical Director's Office - for staff and client meetings, and has a telephone Staff Restroom - is a full bathroom IT Closet - locked (continued on 809c page 2 of 3)

Page 2 Staff Office - has one camera, posted policies and procedures, facility sketch, license (no camera waiver on file), waiver for medicare services, Lab license, emergency numbers and two (2) desks for nurse and Operations Manager. School Room - (4) desks and tables with computers (1) round table and (8) chairs total. This room has a smoke alarm. Kitchen - Pantry hold non perishable food enough for one week. Refrigerator contains food enough for (3) days. There is a 5 burner stove in working condition, there is an oven, dishwasher, toaster, Instapot, Airfryer, refrigerated bread drawer, a small refrigerator for client snacks, fresh fruit, camera, smoke alarm, carbon monoxide detector and emergency lights. Water was within good temperature range. Dining Area - Table with (8) chairs. Menu posted and TV Living Room - Seating for (7)TV and fireplace not used, and client cubbies Gym - located in the garage, there is an empty refrigerator, phone water heater closet, fire extinguisher and extra freezer 10:40am LPA Wilson inspected the following: Nursing Station - Room is kept locked and contains the laundry station with washer and dryer in good condition. First Aid kit and PPE kept in cabinets. Emergency lights Medication Room - MAR found in KIPU LMS. Room is locked and contains PRN and medications prepped daily. No bubble packs used. Bathroom 1 - This is a full bathroom used by clients. Shower not used and water temperature within normal range. Second Floor - Cubbies for Each Client at top of stairs. Smoke alarm and fire extinguisher Bedroom 4 - Occupied by (C1) there is one (1) bed with clean linens and one dresser Bedroom 1 - Occupied by (C2) there are two (2) beds with clean linens and two (2) dressers Bathroom 2 - is a full bathroom with (2) sinks which has water temperature of 110 degrees. Water temperature is below 90 degrees. Licensee provided recent invoice for plumbing. which states a grohe cartridge is needed to address the water temperature Continued on 809C page 3 of 3

Bathroom 3 - This is a full bathroom used by clients. Bathtub not used and water temperature within normal range Emergency Supplies Closet - found in bathroom 3 and locked. Contains clients luggage, emergency supplies and cleaning supplies Bedroom 3 - is unoccupied there are two (2) beds with clean linens and two (2) dressers Bedroom 2 - Occupied by (C3) there is one (1) bed with clean linens and one dresser Hallway - contains locked hygiene products Outdoor Area - large area with perimeter fencing above 5 ft. Swimming pool has fencing around the perimeter. There is plenty of seating in various areas. There is a bridge which leads to a therapists office. Office - has a fire extinguisher, separate heating and cooling system, telephone and camera Vehicle - 2018 Toyota Sienna with current vehicle insurance and registration in very good working condition. Overall, the home appears to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. LPA Wilson inspected the following: Staff Records with (CO) LPA ensured Administrator Certificate was current. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for the three (3) clients in placement. LPA confirmed that all staff have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response, which meet qualification. LPA Wilson was able to complete staff file review, for staff (S1 and PT)) Livescan, Health Screening, CPR/FIrst Aid, Mandated Reporter Training, Narcan Training, Water Safety Certificate, Job Duties and proof of education were reviewed and staff meet requirements. LPA Wilson inspected the following: Client Records with (CO) LPA reviewed client (C1) files, Needs and Services Plan, Emergency contact information, Health Screening, Immunization records, education records and medical coverage. LPA Wilson conducted confidential interview with client (C1) There is a Type B deficiency observed or cited at this time. [See LIC809D]. Exit interview was conducted with (CO) and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On November 18, 2024 at 10:45 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson and Program Administartor (S1) left the Evolve Calabasas home and arrived to the above listed facility at 11:06am in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 11/06/24. During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 11/06/24; due to the Malibu fires, SoCal power pre-emptively turned off all power in this region. The decision was made to move all clients; six (6) from the Calabasas facility and six (6) from the Agoura facility to the Evolve Aura location in Tarzana, which had three (3) clients in care. The number of clients (12) total; did not return to their homes until 11/08/24 which resulted in the licensee not operating in accordance with the Emergency Disaster Plan terms specified in the Plan of Operation. Further, due to the number of clients (15) total; there was not sufficient accommodations, furnishings and equipment to meet clients needs. A (2) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiencies have been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (S1) whose signature on this report confirms receipt.

On June 9, 2021 at 10:36 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Hamilton conducted an SB484 Psychotropic Medication tele-Inspection and met with the Assistant Administrator Maxine Kniazeff. The tele-inspection was conducted via Facetime due to COVID-19. The facility was inspected inside and out with the Assistant Administrator. During the inspection, LPA interviewed two staff and was advised that at this time the facility does not have any dependent clients in care. LPA conducted file reviews prior to the inspection. LPA reviewed zero client records and reviewed two staff records. At 10:43 AM, LPA began the two staff interviews via Facetime. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Assistant Administrator Maxine Kniazeff. LPA scanned and emailed this LIC 809 to Assistant Administrator Maxine Kniazeff.with a request for signature. Signed copies will be placed in the facility file

On February 3, 2022, at 10:15 AM. LPA Babatunde Aborchie conducted an unannounced facility visit to Elizabeth Homes/Stanton Avenue and met with Facility Assistant Administrator Maxine Kniazeff. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual required inspection. The home was licensed to provide care for six ambulatory clients. During this inspection, LPA toured the facility with the Assistant Administrator inside and out. Currently, there were no clients in placement due to major renovation. The home had six bedrooms and two bathrooms. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Rooms were free of smell and odor. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Assistant Administrator at this time. Water temperature was within limit of regulatory requirements. Smoke detectors & carbon monoxide detector in hallways are all tested and operable. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids.

The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. All cleaning supplies and sharp objects (knives) were locked in the kitchen cabinets. The emergency supplies contained all required items in case of emergency. The back yard is safe and free of hazards. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. In accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4 there were no deficiencies being cited at this time. Based on this annual inspection, the home was operating within the limitations of the license. An exit interview was conducted, copies of this report was provided to the Facility Assistant Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced case management telephonically due to Covid 19 to review the incident report dated 4/15/2021. LPA conducted interviews with the Alta California Regional Center Service Coordinator and the client's parent. Due to the client's intellectual disability, an interview was not able to occur for the purpose of gathering information related to the incident report. No citations were issued. A copy of this report was emailed to the administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an unannounced case management inspection related to an incident report dated 1/21/2022. A client had set fire to a paper towel and 3 birthday candles using the stove. LPA interviewed the Administrator and caregiver staff member. No citations were given. A plan was developed regarding the incident.

An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 3/15/2022 with Facility Administrator and House Manager. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit at the agency. The licensing fees are current. The Facility has a capacity of 6 and currently has 6 residents. There are 11 staff members associated to the license and 4 currently working at the Facility. LPA reviewed 4 staff files, all which were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 4 child files were reviewed. The child’s needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan were current in 1 of 4 files. Behavioral Plan (IBST) and quarterly reviews were complete and up to date. Immunization records were current. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. Additionally, the child’s file had a record of personal property. Personal rights, menu, license and emergency exit plan were posted. The facility was inspected jointly with the Facility Administrator and House Manager. LPA attempted to interview 5 clients, but due to their diagnosis of intellectual disability and Autism, the clients were not able to communicate verbally. There are 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. Two of the bedrooms have 2 beds and are shared by 2 clients. 2 of the bedrooms are single occupancy bedrooms. Each bedroom had a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. The common area has couches and chairs to sit in, and a TV. The facility is in good repair. There are locked cabinets in the laundry room with cleansers and detergents. Additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms are kept in a hall closet. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. LPA observed in the backyard and saw a patio table with chairs and a bicycle for the clients. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 6 client for 4 days/3 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 1 fully charged fire extinguisher. Sharps were kept locked in the kitchen. The kitchen was stocked with plates, utensils and drinking cups sufficient for 6 clients. The water temperature from the bathroom faucet was 111.1 degrees. The client's hygiene kit was stocked and stored in a locked laundry room. A fully stocked first aid kit is kept in the kitchen. Continued...

An exit interview was conducted and discussed with the Facility Director. One citation was issued on a D page and a copy of the annual inspection report and appeal process was provided.

On 3/21/24 at approximately 09:08 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Carmona made an unannounced annual inspection using the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tool and met with Cleofe Ludeking, Administrator. LPA Carmona conducted a walk through of the interior and exterior of the facility during the inspection today. The facility is a one story home that consists of 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. One of the bedrooms has 2 beds and is shared by 2 clients. 2 other bedrooms are single occupancy bedrooms. Each bedroom has a firm mattress, with a bed cover, sheets, blanket and pillows. The common area has couches and chairs to sit on, and a TV.There are locked cabinets in the laundry room with cleansers and detergents. Additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathrooms are kept in hall cabinets. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets. The passageways from the front to the back of the facility are unobstructed. The front and back yard are clear and free of debris. LPA observed all clients provided adequate amounts of clothing and size of clothing. The kitchen has a pantry and a refrigerator which were fully stocked with two days of perishable food and seven day’s worth of non-perishable food. All clients have a medication log and LPA observed all the medications locked and stored away in cabinet. The bathrooms are clean, sanitary and functioning with warm water temperature of 106 degrees. LPA checked all fire alarms and carbon monoxide alarms and they are fully functioning. The first aid kit was fully stocked, and readily available. The fire extinguisher is fully charged. There is adequate lighting throughout the facility. At the time of the inspection there are 4 clients placed in the group home and 9 staff. LPA Carmona reviewed the client roster and LIC 500. LPA Carmona also reviewed 5 staff files and all files had required documents, including CPR/ First Aid certificates, criminal record clearance, and training documents. The clients currently placed have limited communication skills therefore LPA was unable to interview them. The clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable home and are treated with respect. Overall, the home was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. All clients attend school. The facility is up to date with their fees. Exit interview was conducted. No deficiencies cited during this inspection. A copy of this report provided to Cleofe Ludeking, Administrator.

On March 19, 2025 at approximately 8:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Zaria Turner, made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above Group Home. LPA Turner met with Administrator, Cleofe Ludaking, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. LPA conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility was clean, safe and kept free of obstruction. LPA observed the posting of License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of four bedrooms, two bathrooms, a visitation room, kitchen, activity room, dining room, staff/office room, laundry room, storage room, and two car garage. Bedroom one and two are equipped with one bed, bedding, two dressers, a TV and TV stand, a closet, and space for clothing and personal belongings. Bedroom three is equipped with two beds, bedding, four dressers, a closet, and space for clothing and personal belongings. Bedroom four is equipped with two beds, bedding, four dressers, a closet, a TV, a chair, an electric fireplace, and space for clothing and personal belongings. The two bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets and running water. The visitation room is equipped with two sofas, a chair, a coffee table, two side tables, a desk and two chairs, a dual fireplace, and a filing cabinet with extra toiletries. The activity room is equipped with two sofas, a rocking chair, a TV, art supplies, and a dual fireplace. The dining room is equipped with a table, three chairs, and a bench.There is one hall closet with multiple cabinets equipped with extra linens, clothing, and incontinence supplies. There is a laundry room with a washer and dryer and cabinets above and racks where extra linen, toiletries, hygiene products, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away. There is a garage equipped with two fridges, three filling cabinets, and racks where extra linen, toiletries, hygiene products, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to clients in care and locked away, under the kitchen sink, in the laundry room, and in the garage. Refrigerator temperature is at or below 45 degrees F. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. Sharp objects are locked in the cabinet in kitchen. There are containers to place leftover food. A working land line and a working cell phone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets, bathtubs, and shower fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a table and four chairs, a patio awning, and a garden. There is no pool on the premises. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection, Physical Plant, Operation, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention, Staff and Client Records, and Clients With Special Health Care Needs. A total of five staff files and five client files were reviewed. LPA conducted three staff interviews. LPA conducted an observation of two nonverbal clients in care. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility annual fees. An exit interview was conducted with Cleofe Ludaking, Administrator, and a copy of this report was provided during today's inspection.

Based upon the interviews and documentation, no citations have been issued.

The facility consists of four bedrooms, two client bathrooms, one staff bathroom, kitchen, living room, dining room, staff room, staff office, and three car garage. Two client rooms are equipped with two beds, bedding, closet, two dressers and space for clothing and personal belongings. Two client rooms are equipped one bed, bedding, closet, a dresser and space for clothing and personal belongings. The two client bathrooms at the facility are equipped with working toilets and running water. The living room is equipped with two sofas, a rocking chair, two desks and two chairs, a hutch desk, two bar stools, a dining table and six chairs, a chair and coffee table, a TV, and a gated fireplace. There are two closets with extra linens, towels, and clothing. There is a laundry room with a washer and dryer and cabinets above and below where extra linen, toiletries, and cleaning supplies are kept and locked away.Disinfectants/cleaning solutions are inaccessible to clients in care and locked in the laundry room and garage. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

The garage contains three refrigerators, a cabinet for nonperishable food, and extra toiletries and cleaning supplies. Refrigerator temperatures are at or below 45 degrees F. There is nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable food for three days minimum. There are containers to place leftover food. A working telephone is available at the facility. Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are in working order. First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. Soap and paper towels are available to clients in care. The facility is free of vermin. The backyard contains a table and four chairs, a clothesline, a gardening area, and a bike. There is no pool on the premises. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection, Physical Plant, Operation, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency Intervention Plan, Staff and Client Records. A total of six staff files and six client files were reviewed. LPA conducted three staff interviews and observed four clients in care. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility annual fees. A Technical Violation (TV) was assessed during today's inspection. (See LIC 9102 TV) An exit interview was conducted with Cleofe Ludaking, Administrator, and a copy of this report was provided during today's inspection.

An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 6/28/2021. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. Community Care Licensing file, incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit to the facility. The licensing fees are current. The Group Home has a capacity of 6 and currently has 4 youth. There are 10 staff members associated to the license and 2 currently working at the Group Home today. LPA Kinder reviewed 5 staff files; all those reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 4 child files were reviewed. C2 needs a copy of their needs and services plan/Individual Program Plan in their file. C1 needs a current physical as the last one occurred over a year ago. Immunization records were current for all youth. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representatives. Medication Sheets were accurate for each client. Additionally, the children's files had a record of personal property. The facility was inspected jointly with Priscilla Castellanes, Administrator of the Group Home. LPA attempted to interview 4 clients, but due to their diagnoses of intellectual disabilities and Autism, the clients were not able to communicate verbally. There are 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The facilities are in good repair, but the client bathroom and 1 client bedroom (next to the client bathroom) need to be painted and 1 mattress needs to be replaced as it is concaved in the middle and has 5, finger sized holes all the way through. There is a hall closet with additional linen if needed for the bedrooms and the bathroom. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets. The passageways from the front to the back of the home are unobstructed. LPA observed 2 locked sheds in the backyard with yard supplies and client belongings. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 4 clients for 4 days/5 weeks. Smoke detectors are in working order. There is a carbon monoxide monitor and 1 fully charged fire extinguisher. An exit interview conducted and discussed with Priscilla Castellanes, Administrator, deficiencies were cited on an 809D page and a copy of the annual inspection report was emailed to the Group Home.

An annual required inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tana Kinder on 7/19/2022. Criminal record clearances were reviewed, and the facility is in compliance. Community Care Licensing file, unusual incident reports, facility roster, facility profile and complaint history were reviewed prior to visit to the group home. The licensing fees are current, paid for 2022. The Group Home has a capacity of 6 and currently has 4 clients. There are over 17 staff members associated to the license and 2 in process. LPA Kinder reviewed 5 staff files and all which were reviewed were complete and up to date. Staff files reviewed have required training hours, education, and fingerprint clearances. 4 child files were reviewed. Children's needs and services plans/Individual Program Plans were completed and up to date. Medical consent forms were signed by authorized representative and current. Additionally, each child’s file had a record of personal property and P&I documentation. The facility was inspected jointly with Priscilla Salvador, Administrator and the group home is in compliance. Copy of the license, personal rights and emergency exit plan are prominently posted. Client and staff files are in locked cabinets. The passageways from the front to the back of the home are unobstructed. LPA observed enough perishable/non-perishable food for 4 clients for 4 days/3 weeks. Carbon Monoxide detector is in working order, as well as a wired smoke alarm system. There is 1 fully charged fire extinguisher. The water temperature was 106.7 degrees. LPA interviewed 2 clients at the Group Home and 2 staff. There are no title 22 deficiencies cited today during inspection. Exit interview conducted and discussed with Priscilla Salvador, Administrator and a copy of the annual inspection report was left at the group home.

Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Tana Kinder conducted an inspection related to the incident report submitted on 7/12/22 about the incident that occurred on 7/12/22. LPA interviewed staff, observed non-verbal client and reviewed medical records related to the incident. No citations were given. An exit interview was conducted and A copy of this report was provided.

On February 23, 2023, at 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Shalisa Stiger and LPA Stephanie Lor conducted an annual continuance. The purpose of this visit is to conduct client and staff interviews. LPA Stiger interviewed two (2) clients and one (1) staff during this inspection. LPA Stiger tested the water temperature and it showed 104.9. LPA Stiger conducted an exit interview and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

This is an amendment and supercedes the original report on 2/21/23 issued by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger who conducted an annual inspection. This amendment was created due to missing signatures on the original C and D reports. On February 21, 2023, at 9:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger and LPA Stephanie Lor made an unannounced required inspection to the above facility. LPA Stiger met with the Administrator. LPA observed all required postings posted. LPA observed and tested smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector. There is 1 staff office with locked files, desks, lockers, and extra belongings. There was a Technical Violation (TV) for missing door frame to staff room. LPA observed 2 bedrooms with appropriate bedding and furniture. All bathrooms were tested and working. The hallway cabinet contained extra linens, towels, blankets and hygiene products. All cleaning chemicals were locked and inaccessible to clients. LPA observed medications and sharps to be locked. There is 1 fire extinguisher on site. LPA reviewed 5 staff and 4 youth files. There was a Technical Assistant (TA) given for missing visitation documents in 2 client files. Additionally, there was a Type B for client files stored in family room accessible to staff and clients. First aid kits had all required items. LPA Interview 1 staff. No clients were available to interview during this inspection. (see next page)

LPA observed the kitchen refrigerator, freezer, and pantry to be filled with perishable and non-perishable food items. LPA observed an adequate supply of utensils, dishes and a menu. A trash bin with a lid is located in the kitchen. The living room was observed to have adequate furniture and lamps. Washer and dryer is located in the garage and accessible to clients. LPA observed the outdoor area to be clear of clutter and debris. Then facility vehicle contained fist aid kit and vehicle logs. The locked garage contained holiday decorations, tools, canned goods and client's inventories. A Type B was issued for medication being accessible to clients. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator at the facility.

narrative: On March 1, 2024, at 9:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced required Annual Inspection to the above facility. LPA Stiger met with the Administrator who assisted with this inspection. This facility is licensed for six (6) clients and currently has four (4) clients in care. LPA Stiger observed all required postings posted. LPA Stiger observed and tested smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector. LPA Stiger observed one (1) staff office with locked files, desks, lockers, and extra belongings. LPA Stiger observed two (2) client bedrooms with appropriate bedding and furniture. All bathrooms were tested and working. The hallway cabinet contained extra linens, towels, blankets and hygiene products. All cleaning chemicals were locked and inaccessible to clients. LPA Stiger observed medications and sharps to be locked. There is one (1) fire extinguisher on site tested and working. LPA Stiger reviewed four (4) staff files and four (4) youth files. LPA Stiger issued a Technical Assistant (TA) given for missing an Individualized Program Plan (IPP) for one (1) youth file. LPA Stiger interviewed one (1) staff. No clients were available to interview during this inspection. LPA Stiger observed the kitchen refrigerator, freezer, and pantry to be filled with perishable and non-perishable food items for four (4) clients. LPA Stiger observed an adequate supply of utensils, dishes and a menu. A trash bin with a lid is located in the kitchen. LPA Stiger observed the living room to have adequate furniture and lamps. Washer and dryer is located in the garage and accessible to clients. LPA Stiger observed the outdoor area to be clear of clutter and debris. The locked garage contained holiday decorations, tools, canned goods and client's inventories. LPA Stiger conducted an exit interview with Administrator and provided a copy of the report to facility.

On November 7, 2024 at 11:57 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to the above Group Home for the purpose of addressing the age range not being followed at the facility. LPA was greeted by Priscilla Salvador, Licensee, who granted LPA access. The census at the facility is 3. On September 5, 2024 LPA Buchannan was notified that the census of the facility was 4 clients between the ages of 17 to 22. LPA was informed that the 22 year old client would be leaving the facility by October 18, 2024. LPA Buchannan was also informed that an age exception request was going to be submitted to the department for a 19 year old client in care who exceeded the age range on the License. Currently the facility is Licensed to provide care and supervision to 6 clients ages 12-17 years old, 4 Ambulatory and 2 non-Ambulatory. File review showed that as of 10/15/2024 the 22 year old client left the facility, LPA also confirmed this upon inspection. As of today, LPA Buchannan has not received the required documentation from the facility to review the age exception request for approval or denial. LPA is issuing a Technical Advisory for the following: One 19 year old client in care is living in the facility and has not been granted an age exception (See LIC 9102 TV) LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of facility and no deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Licensee, Priscilla Salvador.

On 04/02/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced Annual inspection of this Group Home and met with Administrator Priscilla Salvador. A tour of the interior and exterior areas of the Home's physical plant was done and no Building & Grounds deficiencies were observed. Facility staff were interviewed; client and staff records were reviewed. No citations are being issued as of this time. A subsequent onsite inspection is needed to complete this Annual inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to the facility.

On 04/04/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon continued and completed the Annual Inspection of this Group Home; LPA was met by Administrator Priscilla Salvador with whom the findings were discussed and are as follows: The facility has three client bedrooms each of which furnished with the necessary beddings and personal storage space that sufficiently meet the requirements. The clients' bathroom was found to be in good working condition and provided hot water metered within the acceptable temperature range (105.0 degrees F out of the vanity sink; 106.3 degrees F out of the shower/bathtub fixture). Waste bins had covers and there was no indication of any pest infestations. The facility had on hand at least a week's worth of perishable and dried goods for its current census; no inspected food items were beyond expiration dates. An inspection of the physical plant's backyard was also done: the Home has no bodies of water on premises; no potentially hazardous items or areas were left accessible to clients. Passageways were unobstructed and the facility's building and grounds were found to be in good repair. A review of the facility's records was conducted: four client files and five personnel files were reviewed and found to contain required documentation. Interviews were conducted with three direct-care facility staffers; no interviews with clients were possible due to the population's developmental levels. This Group Home was found to be in substantial compliance with Regulations; no deficiencies are being cited. Exit interview was done, and a copy of this report is being provided to Elk Grove Ranch-Valley Oak.

The purpose of the visit is conducted an annual required inspection. LPA Meza – Gonzalez met with Program Administrator (PA) Tracie Arellano. The facility is licensed for four developmentally delayed ambulatory clients. There are four clients in care. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms, two bathrooms, staff office, kitchen, dining room, living room, garage, laundry room, backyard and front yard. Bedroom #1 contains one twin size bed; all required linen, is present and mattresses are in good condition. Bedroom #2 contains one full size bed; all required linen is present and mattresses in good condition. The facility has two bathrooms. The bathrooms is clean, sanitary and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 110 degrees F. The dining room has a dining table with four chairs and a bench. The dining room and kitchen are clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez two-day perishable supply of food in the refrigerator. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. The pantry closet is next to the dining. LPA Meza – Gonzalez observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable in the pantry There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The sharp knives are locked in a cabinet in the pantry. There is an additional freezer and refrigerator in the garage for additional food. See LIC 809C page 2

Cleansers/chemicals are locked a cabinet in the garage. The garage is set up as a workout room with four stations, punching bag, treadmill, bike and workout trampoline. The clients are able use the workout room under staff supervision. The garage also storage for seasonal decors, emergency disaster supplies, over follow first aid kit and over follow paper items. There is a washer and dryer for clients use with staff supervision. The overall clients’ hygiene products are located in a locked cabinet in the laundry area. There is a first a kit and contains all required supplies in the laundry area. The staff office has first aid supplies in the medication cabinet. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked in a cabinet behind the staff desk in the staff office. The living room a space for art, a table for puzzles, two couches, a TV and an indoor basketball game. There are a variety of recreational activities such as board games for clients’ use. There is an additional closet with additional recreational activity items. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean, well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The facility has ten smoke detector and two carbon monoxide detector. The fire alarm and carbon monoxide were check and was operable. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, visitation policies, emergency disaster,(LIC 610C) and license is posted. There are no clients or staff were present at time of inspection. Due to time constraints, the annual inspection is being extended for staff files reviews, clients file review, staff and clients interviews. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies observed during today’s visit. An exit interview was conducted, and this report was reviewed with PA Arellano and a copy of this report was provided.

LPA reviewed two of two child’s records on site at the facility at 1:15PM. LPA reviewed two of two staff personnel files on site at the facility at 3:30PM. LPA reviewed two of two child’s psychotropic medications and medication records at 2:00PM. LPA interviewed two of two staff on site at 2:30PM. LPA interviewed two of two children currently taking psychotropic medication at 3:00PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Tracie Arellano, Administrator, upon completion. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Tracie Arellano, Administrator, at 4:30PM.

Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The facility has ten smoke detector and two carbon monoxide detector. The fire alarm and carbon monoxide were check and was operable. The last emergency disaster drill was held on October 20, 2022. LPA Meza-Gonzalez reviewed four clients' files (see confidential list, dated: October 26,2022) and seven staff files. Based on interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that S1 pushed C1. Therefore, the allegation is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violating California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, regulation 84072(c)(15) Personal Rights (see 9099-D page). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with the Administrator Vice President Residential Services Fred J. Lindahl III
investigation_findings: 13On July 12,2024, at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with of Assistant Vice President of Residential Services Fred Lindahl III and Vice President of Residential Services Laurie J. Purcell at Home of Guiding Hands, Incorporation, to deliver finding of the above allegation. On 9/28/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui initiated the complaint allegation and interviewed one staff. Furthermore, LPA Anderson interviewed two of three clients, two of three staff and reviewed Individual Program Plan (IPP), San Diego County Health and Human Services Report, San Diego County Sheriff’s Department report as well as Special Incident Report. The Department received a complaint on September 21, 2023, alleging staff pushed child. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 wanted to go to the store, C1 got upset bite and kicked S1. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 admitted C1 came towards S1 and in self-defense S1 pushed C1 away and C1 fell and hit C1’s back.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (c)(15) Section D: Personal Rights. Personal rights include the right to be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed that S1 pushed C1 while in care which posed an immediate health and safety or personal rights risks for the client in care.

narrative:
On Wednesday 9/1/21 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Dioneil Noriega and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call and mask-wearing. LPA used the Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. There are five children in care, and four children were at school. There are three staff. LPA toured the facility site and observed: -- The facility site and grounds are clean, free of debris and hazards, and is well-maintained. -- Food is properly stored, is fresh and within date, and meets the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate to meet the needs of residents in care. The kitchen is stocked with utensils and dishware. -- Medications, sharps, and chemicals are all locked and inaccessible to residents in care. -- The smoke detectors were tested and are functioning. -- The first aid kit is missing tweezers and scissors. LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80075, that the facility ensure the first aid kit is stocked with all required items. LPA inspected the facility files and observed: -- The client files are complete and contain all required documentation. Medication records are complete and indicate consistent and proper administration of medications. LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84070, that the facility begin logging all psychotropic medications on a separate log, using the LIC 622B Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) or variation of this form. -- The staff files are complete and contain all required documentation. All staff are cleared and associated to the facility. LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84065, that the facility update the training records, as it does not currently reflect that the 20 hour annual requirement was met. The records do reflect that 13 hours have been completed for 2021 so far, and LPA advises that the facility ensure they meet the 20 hours by the end of the year.

LPA conducted resident observation and staff interviews: -- Resident present during visit appeared happy and comfortable and was being engaged by attentive staff. -- Staff are knowledgeable about the needs of residents in care and program procedures. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Dioneil Noriega, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/2/22 at 11:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 5 clients. During this inspection, 2 clients and 1 staff were present in the home. The staff present was a direct care staff. At 12:30 PM, another direct care staff and client arrived at the facility. There were no facility manager or Administrator present. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. Two clients are non-verbal and one client is was verbal at the time of the inspection. LPA Ng observed the clients and staff interacting during play time. Staff were responsive to the clients needs and able to provide care and supervision to the clients in care. Clients were smiling and clapping when staff played to music. LPA conducted one client interview and two staff interviews. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied, and has two double occupancy bedroom and 1 single occupancy bedroom. There are two staff bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings, desks and chairs, and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 115 degrees F. The thermostat measured 71 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was in the kitchen. LPA observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. -----------CONT. ON 809C-----

At 11:30 AM LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. There is a basketball hoop and a sitting area in the backyard. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR), as well as individual Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Records (CSMDR). All medications were consistent with these records. Facility is in compliance, with only the following exceptions: Due to Facility Manager and Administrator not being present at the time of the inspection, staff files were not reviewed. Facility cited for California Code of Regulations 80044(a) Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency. Please see 809D. LPA Ng will come back at a later time to review staff files/training. There was no Facility Manager and Administrator present. Facility cited for California Code of Regulation 84065(a) Personnel Requirements. Please see attached 809D. After reviewing client files, records reveal that all clients are over the age of 18. Clients ages are 23, 22, 22, 21, and 20. Facility had one age exception for a client until the age of 22. That clients' current age is 23. During the last annual dated 9/1/2021, it was discussed that the clients who were turning over 18, were going to be moved to an Adult Residential Facility. However since that visit, no application was submitted and clients are still in care. Facility cited per CCR regulation, 80010(a), Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. Please see 809D. At this time, three deficiencies were cited today. Appeal Rights were provided, an exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at listed facility.

narrative: On 2/24/2023 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a cas management inspection at Ella’s Home and spoke with Dioneil Noriega, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss the conversion to Adult Residential Facility (ARF). On 9/2/2022, LPA Ng went to listed facility to conduct an Annual Inspection. During the file review, it was revealed that clients residing in the home are over the age of 18. LPA Ng cited per CCR regulation, 80010(a), Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. LPA wrote age exceptions for two clients. Currently, there are 5 clients in the home. They are ages 22, 20, 22, 24, and 22. Facility Manager Dioneil stated that their Program Design is done. The Application for the Adult Residential Facility is almost completed. The listed facility already has an ARF so they have been in contact with their LPA at Adult and Senior in the Oakland Office. Regional Center is aware of their application. Their estimated time for completion/submission is a month. LPA will contact Facility Manager Dioneil monthly for updates. At this time, no citations were given. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was left with Dioneil Noriega, Facility Manager.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/24/2023 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at Ella’s Home and spoke with Dioneil Noriega, Facility Manager. During investigation, LPA Ng did a search of the active/pending Administrator certification list, and it was determined that the listed Administrator on file did not have an active certificate. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1: 80066(a)(12)(B)(1) Personnel Records. Please refer to attached 9099D. deficiencies.plan_of_correction: (a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. narrative:
On 07/19/23 at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 5 clients. During this inspection, 3 clients and 3 staff were present in the home. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. Three clients are non-verbal and one client is was verbal at the time of the inspection. LPA Ng observed the clients and staff interacting during play time. Staff were responsive to the clients needs and able to provide care and supervision to the clients in care. Clients were smiling and clapping when staff played to music. LPA conducted 3 client interview and 2 staff interviews. At 11:00 AM, LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied, and has two double occupancy bedroom and 1 single occupancy bedroom. There are two staff bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings, desks and chairs, and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 115 degrees F. The thermostat measured 68.5 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps and chemicals were located in the garage in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was in the kitchen. LPA observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. At 11:30 AM LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. There is a basketball hoop and a sitting area in the backyard. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard along with two storage sheds. All staff and client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each staff and client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR), as well as individual Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Records (CSMDR). All medications were consistent with these records. -------------cont. on 809C-------------------------

Resident and staff records were observed to be complete and the facility in compliance, with only the following exceptions: During inspection, LPA requested a updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of the facility's Guardian roster on July 19th, 2023 indicates that all but one staff to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Facility is being cited 80019(e) Criminal Background Clearance. During a review of the staff files, the listed Administrator did not have a current/active Group Home Administrator certificate. The Administrator has a current Adult Residential Facility certificate. LPA Ng stated that the Administrator would still need a Group Home Administrator certificate since the facility is still under a Children's Residential license. Complaint procedures were not posted in the facility and was not accessible for staff and clients and their authorized representatives. LPA advises per CCR regulation, 84072.2(a)(3), complaint procedures must be posted in the facility within clear view of clients and their authorized representatives. At this time, 3 deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Facility Manager, Rosalinda Maria, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 09/11/2024 at 11:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection and met with Dioneil Noriega, Administrator. LPA Rodriguez disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility. LPA Rodriguez and LPA Medina used the CARE Inspection Tool. There were three (3) staff members, and four (4) clients were present at the time of inspection. One client present was verbal, and the rest of the clients present were non-verbal. The facility currently has a census of five clients. All clients are non-minor dependents ages twenty-one and up. LPA Rodriguez and LPA Medina reviewed four (4) staff files and five (5) client files. LPA Rodriguez and LPA Medina also reviewed the personnel binder and the emergency disaster plan. LPA Medina conducted two confidential staff interviews and one confidential client interview. During the physical plant inspection, no deficiencies were found. The facility was clean, sanitary, free of obstructions, and an adequate amount of food for all clients in care was present. Client bedrooms were clean and had space for belongings and client necessities. LPA Rodriguez and LPA Medina observed the locked cabinet where all facility files and medication is stored and kept. Administrator informed LPA’s that the Group Home is currently in the process of turning into an Adult Residential Facility. The required Annual Inspection is complete. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted at 3:20 p.m., and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Dioneil Noriega, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 08/05/2025 at 10:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced annual inspection and met with Dioneil Noriega, Administrator. LPA Medina disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to guide the inspection. At the time of the visit, there were three staff members and two clients present. One of the clients is verbal and the others are non-verbal. Administrator Noriega stated that the Group Home is currently in the process of converting to an Adult Residential Facility. Due to personal family matters, there have been delays in submitting the required documentation for the conversion process. At approximately 10:30 a.m., LPA Medina reviewed five client files under the client records section of the CARE tool. All clients were confirmed to be non-minors. Clients are enrolled in day programs and regularly participate in weekend outings. An area of improvement was noted in this section: several clients' Needs and Services Plans were overdue for updates. Per regulation, Needs and Services Plans must be reviewed and updated at least every six months. Please refer to LIC9102 for more information. At 12:00 p.m., LPA Medina reviewed four staff files belonging to staff who actively work in the day-to-day operation of the facility. Each file contained current CPR certifications, health screenings, criminal record statements, personnel records, and documentation of completed training. No deficiencies were observed in the staff records section. Continues on LIC809-C

At 1:15 p.m., LPA Medina began the physical plant inspection. The facility was observed to be clean, sanitary, and free of hazards or obstructions. Client bedrooms were well-maintained, with appropriate furnishings, clean linens, and adequate storage space. Medications and facility records were stored in a locked cabinet. All bedrooms are double-occupancy. Food observed on-site was of good quality, properly stored, within expiration dates, and sufficient to meet regulatory requirements. The water temperature measured 108°F, and the thermostat reading was 69°F—both within regulatory limits. No deficiencies were observed in the physical plant section. At 2:00 p.m., LPA Medina reviewed the operational requirements section of the CARE tool. Upon review of the facility’s license, it was determined that the home is operating outside the conditions authorized by its license. The facility is licensed to serve clients ages 6 to 17; however, all current clients are over the age of 18. Please refer to LIC809-D for details regarding this deficiency. At 2:15 p.m., LPA Medina reviewed the disaster preparedness section. The most recent emergency drill was conducted on July 21, 2024. As required by regulation, emergency drills must be conducted quarterly. However, the facility maintains an up-to-date client roster, medication log, and current Needs and Services Plans for all clients to ensure preparedness in the event of an emergency. Please refer to LIC809-D for additional information on the deficiency. At 2:30 p.m., LPA Medina reviewed the emergency intervention plan. The Administrator reported that staff are trained in Pro-Act, and the home operates as a hands-off facility. No restraints are used. No deficiencies were observed in this section. During the inspection, LPA Medina conducted two confidential staff interviews and one confidential client interview. The required annual inspection has been completed. Two deficiencies were cited during today’s visit: one under California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80010(a), and one under Health and Safety Code, Section 1565(c). An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Dioneil Noriega at 3:30 p.m. During the meeting, the findings, including appeal rights, were reviewed and a copy of the report was provided via email. Administrator’s signature on this form acknowledges receipt of the report and understanding of the information discussed.

On 08/20/2025 at 12:30p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Dioneil Noriega, Administrator, to follow up on outstanding Plans of Correction (POCs). LPA Medina disclosed the purpose of the visit and was granted entry. At the time of the inspection, there were two staff members and three clients present. On 08/05/2025, LPA Medina conducted the facility’s annual inspection. As a result of that inspection, the facility was cited for two deficiencies: California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80010(a) – Operating beyond the limitations of the license. Health and Safety Code, Section 1565(c) – Failure to conduct required emergency drills. During today’s visit, LPA Medina reviewed the POCs with the Administrator. It was determined that both deficiencies were not corrected by the agreed due date. Consequently, the facility was assessed two civil penalties totaling $200 for failure to correct, and will continue to accrue $100 per day until the deficiencies are cleared. Additionally LPA conducted a quick walk through of the home and observed the home was clean and in good repair. An exit interview was conducted, and the report along with appeal rights was reviewed with and provided to Dioneil Noriega, Administrator.

On December 21, 2021, at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection. Embark at San Martin has submitted an application for a Group Home license, for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12-17. This inspection was conducted with Jessica Longoria and Genia Towner-Diaz and included observation of the following: The main living facility is a two story home. The first floor includes three client bedrooms; one and one half client bathrooms; kitchen and living room; area set up for school; and, a private space to meet with clients. The second floor is the staff area which includes an office and bathroom, and is locked and inaccessible to clients. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the closet; locked and centrally stored medication room/cabinet observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; food storage space observed; emergency foods observed; perishable foods and nonperishable foods will be bought as soon as licensed; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; all smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order; carbon monoxide detector observed; fire extinguishers are properly charged; appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients; facility has a swimming pool/hot tub with fencing (facility meets the regulation requirements for inaccessibility for their population); and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility or on premises. The main living facility also has an isolation room which includes two beds and a bathroom, which is kept locked, and will only be used for COVID positive clients.

Additional structures and buildings on the property: an outdoor BBQ area which includes one bathroom; locked and inaccessible barn which stores all maintenance tools; second home on the property is a staff only structure that consists of staff offices and where the staff files will be locked; and, grapevines on the extended property. All client files are electronic and available to Community Care Licensing (CCL). CCL is waiting for the fire clearance and a bank statement in lieu of financial verification. Once these items have been received and reviewed, Embark at San Martin will be ready for licensure on January 18, 2022.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia, LPA Paul Simien and LPA Lisette Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection on today's date at 9:00am, and met with Administrator, Noel Beaulieu. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12 -17. There are currently 5 clients residing in the facility. During this inspection, the entire facility was toured. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions. There is adequate indoor activity space and materials. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Adequate storage space observed. Individual beds are in good repair, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. Weekly menu is posted in the kitchen. Facility has a personal chef that buys and cooks all meals, daily. Several fire extinguishers were observed throughout the facility. LPA Pavia, LPA Simien and LPA Valenzuela reviewed 9 staff records. All current residents were placed within the last 2 weeks. All files are current and complete. Fingerprint clearances were reviewed using Guardian, on 4/28/22. All facility staff or other individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index clearances and/or exemptions. There were no Title 22 deficiencies observed during this visit.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a office visit. LPA discussed this with Brandy Spindel, Clinical Director (CD) at 11:50 PM on 12/15/22. LPA Simien conducted a office visit to establish who was currently running the facility and met with CD and discussed the following: CCL's requirement that the facility must communicate a change of Administrator within 10 days, Embark's contingency plan to replace the previous Administrator, Administrator requirements, Employees needing fingerprint clearance, payment of licensing fee, and Incident reporting requirements. The facility informed LPA Simien that the previous administrator left on 12/5/22. The facility stated that they would email LPA Simien a contingency plan to replace the Administrator, which includes resumes for individuals who they plan to fill the Administrator role. LPA Simien conducted a walk through of the facility. There were six clients and seven staff members at the facility. LPA Simien emailed LIC 624 PDF form (incident report) and the email address to send incident reports to facility. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Brandy Spindel, CD whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

On 1/30/22 at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met withBrandy Spindel, Clinical Director (CD) at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA reviewed four staff files. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Brandy Spindel, CD at 3:30 PM.

On 2/1/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Brandy Spindel, Clinical Director (CD) at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA conducted plaint, operations, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention sections and interviewed three staff members. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Brandy Spindel, CD at 3:30 PM.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility to inform them that a new complaint had been filed with Licensing and that LPA Simien was opening an investigation for the above listed allegations. LPA discussed this with Dawn Halliburton-Rudy, Administrator (ADM) at 10:30 AM on 7/1/22. Based on confidential interviews conducted on 7/1/22. There was evidence of above allegations occurring. The complaint allegations, facility did not provide supervision resulting inappropriate interaction between clients, is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation is substantiated. As a result of this visit, there is one title 22 Regulation and General Licensing Standards 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) violation observed. The facility will be cited (see LIC 9099-D for details). Appeal rights were discussed and provided. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Jael Debora, Residential Dirctor whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews conducted by LPA Simien. Clients engaged in inappropriate sexual activity due to a lack of staff supervision. This poses a health and safety risk to the clients in the facility.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegation. LPA met with Daniel Padron Garcia, Site superviser (SS) at 1:45 PM on 6/7/23. LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documents during this investigation. During interviews with individuals invovled it was determined that the facility at times was operating out of ratio due to a staff shortage. There were times where there was only one staff member watching six clients. This lead to some of the individuals' needs not being met.Things individuals could do were limited due to not having enough staff to provide supervision for everyone. Based on interviews and documents review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above listed allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there is one General Licensing Standards 80065 Personnel Requirements violation (80065(a)) an one General Licensing Standards 80022 Plan of Operation (80022(k)).The facility will be cited. Appeal rights were discussed and provided to ED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Daniel Padron Garcia, SS whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents (POC will be made on a different day due to Admin being ill).
