narrative:
An informal meeting is held on January 4, 2023 at 12:30 PM. The following are topics to be discussed are regarding the concerns the department has. Present in the meeting: Licensing Program Managers, (LPM) Carolyn Flynn, LPM Helga Wong, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield, LPA Paul Simien, Brian Rogers, Princess Garcia, Christy Beaudin, Brian Beutin, Amir Rafiei, and Heather Schaffer. . The following topics are discussed due to concerns on recent non-compliance of the regulation and citations: - Reporting requirements: Facility had administrative changes to their board of directors and administrative organization; these changes were not reported to the Department. - Plan of Operation: Practices regarding food and snack supplies are not available to youths, staff training not meeting the requirements, staff are not trained on the regulations, the facility is not in compliance with applicable laws and regulations on personal rights of clients in care, criminal record clearance, and using restraint that was not part of their plan of operation. - Recent complaints and citations: Facility was cited for substantiated allegations for failing to report incidents to the Department. Facility was cited for not complying regarding pool safety, records not available for review by the Department, staffing being out of ratio, not providing notification to parents of crucial information (complaint regarding youth’s health and not eating opened 4/12/2023), crisis response, and concerns with lack of supervision (complaint closed on 7/1/2023).

Criminal Record Clearance: Concerns regarding lack of fingerprint clearance and having individuals working in the facilities. Concerns with restraint policies and procedures: Facility staff using restraint when not necessary, blocking clients, placing clients on 5150. (Complaint opened 11/8/2023). Crisis Response / protocol: Based on an investigated complaint opened on 10/24/2023, the facility did not have supervisor / manager / administrator or a person in charge to respond to police during a crisis. The response was handled by a staff member and the report of this incident was not reported to the Department. - Food service: Each facility must have the required amount of food per the regulations. The facility has been observed and cited for not having the proper amount of food in each home. Although the chef cooks at one home, each home must have proper food supply for the clients in care. Plan for compliance: · Reporting requirements: § Facility will submit a written plan to ensure changes to their board of directors and administrative organization will be reported to the Department within 7 days and designate multiple staff that are responsible to reporting requirements. · Plan of Operation: Facility will submit and update on their Plan of Operation to ensure snack are available for the youths in care; staff training on applicable laws and regulations on personal rights of clients in care, criminal record clearance, and using restraint, emergency intervention plan, and trauma informal; and update emergency intervention plan on restraint. All discussed the possibility of transitioning the group homes from co-ed to single sex. This was discussed but no decision was made regarding this.

Recent complaints / citations: Facility will submit an update plan §Regarding pool safety and supervision when youths using the pool § Records available for review during the Department Inspection § New LIC 500 form to ensure staffing being in of ratio. § Contact with youth’s responsible authority representative/parent when an incident happened to them. · Criminal Record Clearance: Facility will submit an update plan to ensure all individuals working at the facility have Criminal Record Clearance before starting work at the facility and management oversight on this hiring process. · Concerns with restraint policies and procedures: Facility will submit a new plan on restraint policies and procedures and ensuring staff received training · Crisis Response / protocol: Facility will submit a new plan to have additional managers on Crisis Response. LPA discussed the submission of the updated application with Christy Beautin and they stated they would submit during the week of January 8, 2024. The meeting was concluded.

On 1/31/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield attempted to conduct an annual inspection at the above facility. At this time the inspection was not able to be completed due to positive covid cases. LPA will conduct this inspection on a later date. A copy of this form will be sent to Administrator Garcia.

On March 6, 2024 an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Shikya Belfield and Jasmine Cardeno at the above facility at 10:00 Am. LPA’s arrived at the facility and met with the House Manager, Alyssa Avila and HR director, Vicky Groom, Regional Executive Director Amir Rafiei. LPA’s informed Embark representatives of the purpose of this visit to conduct an continuation of the annual inspection of the facility. The facility has a capacity of six clients, ages twelve through seventeen and is currently holding a census of six. The home has three client bedrooms, each bedroom has two beds and the home has two client bathrooms for all the youth. There is a dining room, a living room, and a kitchen. All smoke detectors were tested and were in working order. The fire extinguisher was prominent and is up to date based on observations at the previous inspection. During this inspection LPA reviewed five staff files and six client files. During a file review it was observed that the facility staff have not received annual training. Facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84065(j)(1) Annual Training. Also observed during a medication log review, the facility did not have the PMAR properly completed, facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84070(b)(13)(C) Children's Records. Technical Violations were issued for sections 84070(b)(13)(D), 84070(b)(13)(E), 84070(c)(1) Children's Records, as there were no signed copies of the needs and service plans by clients or their authorized person. Deficiencies described on the following page 809D. Board meeting minutes will be sent to the department by 3/11/2024 as well as staff training record for medication. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Alyssa Avila and Vicki Groom.

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Notwithstanding Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), all child care staff shall complete a minimum of 20 hours of annual training, except as specified in (2) below. This requirement was not met as evidenced by, Based on a file review conducted by LPA, it was observed that the facility staff have not received annual training. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the clients in care.

The quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed. This requirement was not met as evidenced by, Based on a file review conducted by LPA, it was observed that the PMAR's in the client record do not have the quantity listed for each medication for 6 out of 6 clients. This poses potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.

narrative: Based on a review of facility training records, staff did not receive training in the required training topics as outlined in the regulations and were not trained to handle or in preparations for situations in the facility. Therefore, these allegations are Substantiated. Facility cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80022(k) Plan of Operation, 80022(k) Plan of Operation, 84065(i) Personnel Requirements, and an advisory is being issued for section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds as described on the following page LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report along with appeal rights was left with Alyssa Avila.
investigation_findings: 13On 3/19/2024 at 9:38 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Mona Lam, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to inform the facility representative of the findings for the allegations above. LPA met with Alyssa Avila who assisted with the inspection. Based on confidential interviews conducted and supportive documentation to include but not limit repair receipts. The facility grounds has a septic tank that became backed up and the plumbing in the facility was not able to be used. Clients needed to use the restrooms in the main office next door. Facility also has a broken dryer and the dryer used to dry clients clothing is in the office next door. Facility maintenance person responded and the septic tank was worked on for at least two days. Technical advisory issued. Based on confidential interviews and a review of supportive documentation to include but not limit staff schedule and program plan of operation, the facility was operating outside of the required operating ratio according to plan of operation. Based on confidential interviews administrator and supervisors did not respond to crisis situations when called on for support as outlined in the plan of operation emergency intervention plan.

narrative:
On January 27, 2025 at 10:13 AM, an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Mona Lam and Hanako Primer at the above licensed facility. LPAs met with Michelle Hankes, William Han, Christopher VanNuLand and Zuzana Houbova. The facility has a capacity of six clients, ages twelve through seventeen and is currently holding a census of four. The home has three client bedrooms, each bedroom has two beds and the home has two client bathrooms for all the youth. There is a dining room, a living room, and a kitchen. LPAs inspected refrigerator and observed some foods without labeled dates. LPAs advised in labeling foods with dates for best practice. LPAs observed menu on fridge with listed lunch and dinner. LPA Lam asked if breakfast was served to youth in care. Michelle stated breakfast is served to youth. LPA Lam issued technical advisory 80076(a)(2) Food Services in listing breakfast on weekly menu. LPAs observed house phone was unplugged and located in closet. Facility removed house phone from closet and plugged house phone in the living room. A Type A citation was issued under 80073(a) Telephones. LPAs inspected a first aid kit. LPAs observed no thermometer in a first aid kit in a backpack brought for outings, but a thermometer within nurse's office. LPA Lam issued a technical advisory under 80075(g)(1)(G). All smoke detectors were were identified and are in working condition. The fire extinguisher were prominent and looked in good condition. LPA Primer measured bathroom hot water up to 94.6 degrees Fahrenheit. A Type A citation was issued under 80088(e)(1) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies. LPAs inspected the backyard of the facility. LPAs observed a pool without a pool cover. A Type B citation was issued under 80087(e)(1) Buildings and Grounds. (Continued on LIC809-C)

LPAs inspected four client files. During the inspection, LPAs observed two files that did not list prescribing physician for current medications of clients. A technical violation was issued under 80070(b)(10) Client's Records. LPAs did not observe dental history within all of the client files. A Type B citation was issued under 84070(b)(7) Children's Records. LPAs observed all treatment plans, which did not contain child's or authorized representative's signatures. A Type A citation was issued under 84070(c)(1) Children's Records. LPA Lam asked any youth uses a Telecommunications Device. William Han identified one youth to use a telecommunications device. LPAs did not observe LIC9158 for youth. A Type B citation was issued under 80068(b) Admission Agreements. LPA Lam asked if youth sharing bedrooms have a documented compatibility agreement. No documentation was identified in the files for youth sharing bedrooms. A Type B citation was issued under 84087(e) Buildings and Grounds. LPA Lam inspected signed documentation of child's personal rights per client file. LPA Lam observed signatures for client's and authorized representative's. LPA Lam observed Alyssa Avila's name listed under licensee/designee in each of the client's personal rights, without their signature. LPA Lam asked who is delivering personal rights for clients due to being informed Alyssa Avila have been on leave with Embark for almost a year. Michelle informed that the enrollment director/therapist or direct care staff would deliver child's personal rights. A technical advisory was issued under 84070(b)(17) Children's Records. LPAs inspected photos of valve shut offs, fire clearance, board of directors' meeting minutes, and past licensing reports. LPA Primer conducted four confidential client interviews. At this time the inspection is not complete and it will be concluded at a later date. Seven (7) deficiencies were cited at the inspection (refer to LIC809-D). An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report and appeals rights page were discussed, printed, and delivered to Michelle Hankes prior to leaving the facility.

On February 5, 2025 at 10:30 AM, an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Mona Lam and Hanako Primer at the above licensed facility. LPAs met with Michelle Hankes, who assisted with the inspection. The facility has a capacity of six clients, ages twelve through seventeen and is currently holding a census of five. During the inspection, LPAs reviewed five client files. LPAs issued three Type B citations: 84070(b)(15) Children’s Records, 84070(b)(16)(G) Children’s Records, and 84070(c)(2) Children’s Records. LPAs issued a technical violation under 84068.3(b)(1) Modifications to Needs and Services Plan. LPA Primer conducted five confidential staff interviews. LPA Primer attempted one client interview. Youth denied interview. At this time the inspection is not complete and it will be concluded at a later date. Three (3) deficiencies were cited at the inspection (refer to LIC809-D) and one (1) technical violation was issued. Facility appealed 80087(e)(1) Building and Grounds, and the deficiency has been dismissed. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report and appeals rights page were discussed, printed, and delivered to Michelle Hankes prior to leaving the facility.

On February 24th, 2025 at 10:07AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mona Lam and Hanako Primer conducted an unannounced annual continuation inspection to the above licensed facility. LPAs met with Administrator Michelle Hankes and Human Resources Director Zuzana Houbova. LPAs inspected facility vehicle, which was in working condition. LPAs inspected facility's emergency keys. During the inspection, LPAs continued inspecting five staff files. At this time of the inspection, LPAs were not able to observe documentation on job shadowing, administrator or administrator designee's assessment on each child care staff within 7 calendar days of completion of the 8 hour training, and documentation of on-the-job training. At this time, the following training were not observed within the staff files, but are not limited to: prudent parent standards, medication procedures, assistance with medication, universal precautions, recognition of early signs of illness and the need for professional assistance, child's right to receive sexual and reproductive health care and information, guidance about how to engage and talk with children about healthy sexual development and reproductive and sexual health, and information on current contraception methods. LPAs issued two Type B citations under: 80066(a) Personnel Records and 84065(i)(3) Personnel Requirements. Two (2) deficiencies were cited at the inspection (refer to LIC809-D) and one (1) technical violation and one (1) technical advisory were issued. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report and appeals rights page were discussed, printed, and delivered to Michelle Hankes prior to leaving the facility.

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
narrative:
On June 1, 2022, at 8:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection. Embark at San Martin - New Avenue Campus has submitted an application for a Group Home license, for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12-17. This inspection was conducted with Noel Beaulieu and included observation of the following: The facility is a one story home. The home includes three client bedrooms; three and a half client bathrooms; kitchen and living room; area set up for school; mindfulness nook; a private space to meet with clients; a staff office; an admissions office; and, an isolation room/extra office, with a Murphy bed, which will only be used for COVID positive clients or additional staff space. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the closet; locked and centrally stored medication room/cabinet observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; food storage space observed; emergency foods observed; perishable foods and nonperishable foods will be bought as soon as licensed and have a placement; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; all smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order; carbon monoxide detector observed; fire extinguishers are properly charged; appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility or on premises.

The backyard includes a swimming pool/hot tub with fencing (facility meets the regulation requirements for inaccessibility for their population); outdoor BBQ area; solar paneling in the far rear of the property; garden area; dog kennel (will not be utilized unless for storage); and, grapevines on the extended property. All staff and client files are electronic and available to Community Care Licensing (CCL). (There will also be hard copy files for clients.) Embark at San Martin - New Avenue Campus is ready for licensure today, 6/1/22. Your license will be mailed.

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegation. LPA met with Daniel Padron Garcia, Site superviser (SS) at 1:45 PM on 6/7/23. LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documents during this investigation. During interviews with individuals invovled it was determined that the facility at times was operating out of ratio due to a staff shortage. There were times where there was only one staff member watching six clients. This lead to some of the individuals' needs not being met.Things individuals could do were limited due to not having enough staff to provide supervision for everyone. Based on interviews and documents review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above listed allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there is one General Licensing Standards 80065 Personnel Requirements violation (80065(a)) an one General Licensing Standards 80022 Plan of Operation (80022(k)).The facility will be cited. Appeal rights were discussed and provided to ED. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Daniel Padron Garcia, SS whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents (POC will be made on a different day due to Admin being ill).

deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Personnel Requirements (a): Facility personnel shall be competent to provide the services necessary to meet individual client needs and shall, at all times, be employed in numbers necessary to meet such needs. This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews conducted by LPA Simien. Some individuals stated that clients' needs were not being met due to a lack of staffing.

(k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement is not met evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and documents review conducted by LPA Simien. Individuals stated there were times when the facility did not have the proper staff to client ratio based on the ratio estabilished by the facility's program statement.

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Celest Aparicio, conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct case management regarding information received by the department on the facilities operations. Based on a review of the guardian system the facility has more than two staff who are not associated to the facility. LPA discussed the staff associations with administrator Princess Garcia who assisted with the inspection. LPA requested the following documents from administrator Garcia; training records for all staff, needs and services plan for all clients and a copy of the grocery order that was placed for the facility. During a walk-through of the facility with administrator Garcia, LPA's observed the facility to not have enough snacks and food items available for the clients in care to obtain regularly without assistance. LPA's also observed during this inspection were missing forms on the facility walls such as personal rights and activity schedule. Also observed were locked food cabinets. LPA's discussed these issues with administrator Garcia. Due to time restrictions and technical issues with LPA equipment, this inspection must be completed at a later date. At that time all issues and citations will be addressed. LPA's left the facility with facility documents ( incident report binder) that will be returned to the facility within the required time frame. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report will be sent to administrator Princess Garcia.

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Celest Aparicio, conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility. The purpose of this inspection is to complete the case management inspection conducted on 10/24/2023. LPA’s met with Brittany Haug who informed these LPA’s that administrator Garcia would be arriving in one hour. LPA Belfield returned incident report binder to Staff Haug that was taken from facility during the previous inspection. Based on LPA observations, conducted confidential interviews, and supportive documents to include but not limit, incident reports and staff schedules. It was confirmed that during the day, clients do not have regular access to snacks between meals as required by the regulations. It was observed by LPA’s that cabinets containing snacks are locked. During the inspection on 10/24/2023, LPA Belfield requested the needs and service plans for all clients in care, although three clients plans were submitted, seven were not. As of today’s date, LPA has not been given the plans for the clients. During the inspection on 10/24/2023, LPA’s observed the pool in the back of the facility does not have a secured fence surround the pool, that is required to be inaccessible to clients in care. It was confirmed that the facility performs restraints on the clients in care which is not a part of the program design. Based on observations of provided staff schedules and a review of the guardian system, the facility has Seven staff (see LIC 811 dated 10/27/23) who are not criminally record cleared to work in the facility and seven staff who are not associated to the facility. Facility is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations. Title 22. Division, Six, Section 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance. Facility is being assessed a civil penalty.

Facility is being cited for the following violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Sections 80022(k) Plan of Operation, 84044(b) Inspection Authority, 80087(e) Buildings and Grounds, and 80076(a)(4) Food Services as described on the following page 809 D. LPA Belfield and Administrator Princess Garcia discussed the concerns of the facilities operations and an informal meeting will be scheduled with administrator and program vice president. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to administrator Princess Garcia.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/15/2024 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and LPA Celest Aparicio, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to inform the facility representative of the findings for the allegations above. House Manager Alyssa Avila assisted with the inspection. narrative:

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
narrative:
On June 27, 2025, at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted a required annual inspection at Embark at San Martin - New Avenue Campus. The facility is a Group Home, for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12-17. This inspection was conducted with Executive Director, Micki Hankes, of the following: The facility is a one story home. The home includes three client bedrooms; three and a half client bathrooms; kitchen and living room; area set up for school; a private space to meet with clients; and a staff office. LPA Lam observed rugs in each of the bathrooms that are able to slip. LPA Lam issued a technical violation under 80087(b)(1) Buildings and Grounds. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the closet; locked and centrally stored medication room/cabinet observed; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; food storage space observed; emergency foods observed; perishable foods and nonperishable foods were observed; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients. LPA Lam observed a flour bag and marshmallow bag opened in pantry. In addition, LPA Lam observed some items in the pantry freezer that are not dated. LPA Lam advised in labelling dates consistently in addition to properly sealing food items to prevent contamination under 80076(a)(18) Food Service. (Continued on LIC 809-C).

Freezer temperature was observed as -5 degrees F; refrigerator temperature was observed as 35 degrees F. Room temperature was observed as 71 degrees F. Tap water temperature was observed as 127.4 degrees F. LPA did not observe warning signs for the high water temperature. LPA Lam issued a Type A deficiency under 8088(e)(2) Fixtures, Furniture, and Supplies (see LIC 809-D). The following documents were inspected: registrar of clients, bedroom compatibility assessment, board of directors' meetings minutes, clients' complaint procedures, disaster/mass casualty plan, photos of valve shut offs, fire clearance, past licensing reports, quarterly emergency disaster drills, and other information being readily available within an emergency. LPA Lam did not observe procedures of storage and preservation of medications that require refrigeration, although information of storage and preservation of medication is provided. LPA Lam issued a technical advisory under 1565(a)(7)(E) Other Provisions. Facility is trained in holds, although facility does not actively use hold techniques. LPA Lam did not observe a monthly log of each use of manual restraints. LPA Lam issued a technical violation under 84361(f) Documentation and Reporting Requirements. LPA Lam inspected a portion of the client files, but has not finished. At this time the inspection, it is not complete and it will be concluded at a later date. One (1) deficiency was cited and two (2) technical violations and two (2) technical advisories were issued at the inspection. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report and appeals rights page were discussed, printed, and delivered to Micki Hankes prior to leaving the facility.

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
narrative: On July 1, 2025, 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted a continuation required annual inspection at Embark at San Martin - New Avenue Campus. The facility is a Group Home, for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12-17. This inspection was conducted with Christine Ziemba, Clinical Director, of the following: LPA Lam inspected client medication. One medication for a client was found in a Ziploc bag. LPA asked nurse if medication has been distributed to youth. Nurse stated that medication provided was by parent during intake. Nurse stated that they needed to destroy medication, but had ordered youth the replacement medication. LPA conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews. LPA inspected client files and found multiple clients' treatment plans did not contain clients' signatures. LPA issued a Type B deficiency under 84070(c)(1) Children's Records. LPA inspected staff files. LPA was unable to observe multiple staff members' competency tests regarding emergency intervention. LPA issued a technical violation under 84365(d)(1)(C) Emergency Intervention Plan. At this time the inspection, it is not complete and it will be concluded at a later date. One (1) deficiency was cited and one (1) technical violation was issued at the inspection. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report and appeals rights page were discussed, printed, and delivered to Christine Ziemba, Clinical Director prior to leaving the facility.

facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN-NEW AVENUE CAMPUS
narrative:
An informal meeting is being held on April 2, 2025, at 10:00 AM. The reasons for the meeting are for prior concerns in 2024, at the aforementioned facility. In addition, components two and three will be completed for the new facility currently under application review, pending a provisional license, with Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam. Present in the meeting: Licensing Program Manager, (LPM) Joel Segura, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood, and Mona Lam, Administrator, Amir Rafiei, and Executive Director, Micki Hankes . Between the dates of November 2023 through April 2024, the following citations were given to the aforementioned facility: client medication are not properly documented, clients were not given medications as prescribed, facility is operating out of ratio, clients are not able to receive phone calls, client files are incomplete, facility failed to report incidents to the department (multiple times), staff working without having Criminal Record clearance, staff did not seek medical attention to minor in a timely manner, staff are not qualified, facility failed to provide an environment free from emotional abuse, Clients are not accorded dignity in their relationship with staff, clients are unjustifiably placed on a psychiatric hold, Clients do not feel safe, healthy, or comfortable in the facility and clients do not feel they are treated with respect.

The following deficiencies and concerns were discussed with Mr. Rafiei and Ms. Hankes. It was also indicated that additional inspections at the facility may occur at the discretion of Community Care Licensing (CCL) to ensure compliance, as well as the safety of clients in care are being met. It is noted there have not been any deficiencies at the facility since April 2024. During the meeting Ms. Hankes, and Mr. Rafiei informed the department that the facility has made several changes to improve how the facility operates. A few examples shared were new staff on floor first while shadowing, supervisor has a new hire check list, more than the minimum ratio 1:6 more daily staff, upgraded program narrative, client files periodically updated, and going to an electronic version, an increase of administrative staff, more competitive raised salary to retain employees, on going training provided weekly, a therapist on site attending a Master's program, and a change in culture, with an improvement in the overall program including continuous improvement in strategies. The meeting was concluded at 12:00 PM, and a copy of this report was provided via email to Ms. Hankes. Due to the meeting being conducted via Microsoft Teams, the original signatures will be kept in the facility file.

This inspection was conducted with Amy Bravo and included observation of the following: The facility is a two story home. The home includes 3 client bedrooms; 2 client bathrooms; kitchen and parlor room; dining room, butler's pantry area set up for school; mindfulness nook; two private spaces to meet with clients; a staff office; an admissions office; and, an isolation room/extra office, with a Murphy bed, which will only be used for COVID positive clients or additional staff space. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the closet; locked and centrally stored medication room/cabinet observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; food storage space observed; emergency foods observed; perishable foods and nonperishable foods will be bought as soon as licensed and have a placement; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; all smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order; carbon monoxide detector observed; fire extinguishers are properly charged; appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility or on premises.

The backyard includes three patio areas, and two separate lawns; two seating areas, fireplace area, an outdoor BBQ area; and a garden area. facility_name: EMBARK AT SAN MARTIN - SAN MARTIN AVE
narrative: On August 27, 2025 at 11:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam made an unannounced inspection to the above listed facility. The purpose of this inspection is inspect the physical plant. At the time of the inspection, there were two clients in care. LPA met with Micki Hankes, Administrator. LPA inspected refrigerator and observed perishables within refrigerator. LPA advised for facility to maintaining fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days on the premises. LPA observed a posted menu of the previous week and not an updated menu of the current week. LPA issued a technical violation under 84076(b) Food Service. LPA observed telephone to be located in a public area near the entrance. LPA advised phone to be located in an area for youth to conduct confidential calls. LPA asked administrator where grievance forms can be submitted to the facility. Administrator indicated it is next to the locked box for youth to submit near to the entrance of the facility. LPA did not observe any indication of the purpose of the locked box. LPA advised posting a sign next to the locked box for complaint purposes. LPA inspected exterior of the property. LPA observed grill with an open drawer of a connected gas tank. LPA advised administrator to close drawer to prevent youth from accessing potential hazardous items. No deficiencies were cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Micki Hankes, Administrator and a copy of this report was printed and left with Micki Hankes, Administrator.

On January 21, 2022 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced annual inspection of the Emmanuel Family Home and met with Facility Administrator Jonathan Sparhawk. The home is a one story residence with 5 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. The facility currently serves six clients. LPA inspected the facility interior and exterior. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The living room consists of a television with a spacious living room and three couches. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility maintains at least one week supply of nonperishable, snacks, and a 2 day supply of perishable foods. Bedrooms are furnished and have adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, mattress covers and mattresses are in good repair. LPA observed clean bath towels, and washcloths available for clients. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The facility has air conditioner throughout the house and maintained at a comfortable temperature. Hot water temperature measures 116.0 degrees. There are no weapons or firearms at facility. Medications and First Aid kit are locked and centrally stored dining room/ office cabinet. The cleaning solutions and toxic chemicals are locked in the cabinet in the locked laundry room. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored under the sink. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the dining/ staff area. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, and current menu. (see continuation form LIC-809C dated 01/21/22)

LPA reviewed Physical Plant, Operations, Disaster Preparedness, and Emergency Intervention. LPA conducted staff and client file reviews and interviews. LPA conducted 3 of 3 staff interviews, 4 of 4 staff file reviews, 0 of 6 client interviews due to clients (C1-C6) not being able to answer questions and 6 of 6 client file reviews. Based on client record review, 6 of 6 client files, the licensee did not have a current court order, or a written authorization of the clients (C1-C6) parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication and 6 out of 6 client medication logs did not have a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the client(C1-C6), which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Title 22, Section 83070(b) (11) & Section 84070(b)(13). See LIC809-D dated 01/21/22 for the cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was reviewed with Program Administrator Jonathan Sparhawk.
